The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p: A Preparatiue to Contentation: Conteining a diſplay of the wonderfull diſtractions of men in opinions and ſtraunge Conceits: And of the ſeuerall Diſcontentations which are incident to euerie particular vocation and condition of men in this life, with the cauſes and inconueniences of the ſame: Alſo how they may be either ſalued or qualified, pacified or eaſed.
Confected Applicatorie, eſpecially to this people and time, as an Argument moſt neceſſary and profitable to be vrged.
By Iohn Carpenter.
LONDON Printed by Thomas Creede. 1597.

div.head: ❧TO THE MOST Noble Theophilos, the friend, and welbeloued of God: I. C. wiſheth the right happie increaſe and continuance of the Grace, loue, and peace of God, and the higheſt felicitie in Ieſu Chriſt.
div.p:
AS he which regardeth the wind, ſhall not ſow: and he that reſpecteth the cloudes, ſhall not reape, (as ſaith Salomon) ſo,Eccle: 11.4 if euery wel-willing mind that would gladly benefit the Church and common wealth, ſhould bee diſcouraged by the partiall cenſures of ſtraunge conceited heades, and the ſtinging obloquie of vncharmed tongs (wherewith the ingratefull worlde is repleniſhed) many things which bee both profitable and neceſſarie for either ſtate, would bee couched in thriftleſſe obſcuritie: and, as a thouſand learned wits haue bin thereby the ſooner occaſioned to fling from their fingers, both the pen and the paper, enterring moſt vnhappily their Lords Talent: there would preſently be ſeene too to many of thoſe negligent fooles, which perceiuing that all trauaile, and the perfection of workes do purchaſe emulation and enuie of one man towards an other, doo folde their handes with this ſorie reſolution: Yet one morſell with quietneſſe, is better, Eccles. 4.5.6 then both the hands-full with labour and vexation of ſpirit. And as for mine owne parte (most Noble Theophilos) although
I ſpeake of peace, and prepare for Contentation: yet haue I no leſſe cauſe of care and diſcouragement proffered me therein, when I aſſure my ſelfe to meete with them which are Enemies to peace, and (in their Diſcontented hearts) prepare themſelues to warre: for as the moſt vnnaturall maladies and venemous humours do moſt ſtrongly wraſtle and ſtriue againſt the ſoueraigne ſalues, and wholſome medicines which are diſcreetly prepared and applied to expel and purge them, & to reſtore health vnto the patient: ſo is it the nature of the vaine men of this world (eſpecially of ſuch as are Moriones Diaboli, I meane the diriders of religion) to ſtriue and ſtruggle againſt thē which prepare to purge and heale ſuch paſſionate perſons: Neither will they like well of any medicine, how good and ſoueraigne ſoeuer it bee, that ſhall be applied vnto their maladies. Howbeit, becauſe The Truth is ſtrong and preuaileth, and the Author of Truth hath taught, that whoſoeuer he bee which hath receiued either one Talent, or two Talents, or fiue Talents, after his abilitie, hee is to imploy and occupie the ſame accordingly: and hath alſo willed all them who minde to bee worthie partakers of the Supper of the great King, to eſchewe all excuſes and delaies: I haue thereon preſumed and aduentured in this ſort to caſt fourth my bread as on the face of the waters: Eccles. 11.1 yet in this good hope, that in the length of dayes it ſhall bee recouered, and that my labours in the Lorde ſhall not bee in vaine. Next, for aſmuch as it is the bounden dutie of euery leige Subiect,1 Cor. 15.58 ſo to tender and regard the ſafetie of his Prince, and the welfare of his Countrey, that when he perceiueth either the forreigne enemie to prepare his forces and endeuour to inuade: or the vnnaturall Subiectes to withdrawe their obedience and incline to rebellion: hee withſtande the one and ſuppreſſe the other to his power: defending
and preſeruing both his Prince and Countrey, I thought it no leſſe my dutie to do the like. Therefore, when I conſidered how Nimrod that mightie Hunter before the Lorde, on the one ſide had called togither and muſtred his forces and aſſiſtants towardes the reedifying of the confuſed Tower of Babel; Pſal. 137 and that the diſſembling Edomites on the other ſide, had aſſayed to raiſe and pull downe the repayred walles of Hieruſalem: and had taken vnto them in that Action, the Iſmalites, the Moabites, the Hagarenes, Gebal and Ammon, and Amalek, the Philiſtines, and them that dwell at Tyre, with Aſſur, who haue caſt their heads togither, and are confederate againſt the Lord and his holy Annointed: yea, and that ſome other, pretending to new build with Zorobabel and the principall fathers of Iſrael, 1 Iſra. 4.23. haue rather hindred, then any way furthered the Lords worke, and haue practized without ceaſing to reduce our State, and ſo well ordered Common-wealth into an heedeleſſe Anarchie, and lawleſſe libertie,VVant of gouernment. which ingender nought elſe, but a monſtrous Ataxie and wofull infelicitie (from the which,A confuſion or diſorder. I beſeeche God in his mercie to keepe and defend vs): I was thereuppon vehemently prouoked and ſtirred vp to ſtand foorth and to acquite my ſelfe (though as the meaneſt of others yet) Zorobabel, Nehemiah, and other the principall Builders vnder our moſt redoubted Lord Ieſus, to ſet hand to the Lords worke, the which being begun, he would ſhould be vrged: beeing in hande, hee willeth to bee furthered: and beeing accompliſhed, he commaundeth the ſame to be maintained accordingly. To, and for the which purpoſe, I haue taken in the one hand an Inſtrument to build for and with, Iſrael: & in the other hand a Sworde to fight againſt the foes of Iſrael: beeing right well aſſured, that the wiſedome of God (the which Ireuerence and highly eſteeme) is better then the weapons
of warre: and that the valour of his Grace is preferred far aboue al the power, prudence, and pollicie of man. And ſeeing that it is that naughtie humor of Diſcontentation. (engendred in Ambitious heads, and in diſtracted mindes) that ſo much enflameth & agonizeth the ſtate of our church and Common-wealth, the which it laboureth to loade with ſuch inconueniences, as are not onely dreadfull and daungerous, but moſt miſerable and remedileſſe. I thought it good in this time, and vpon this occaſion, to diſplay on the one ſide, the horribleneſſe of that humour, and to diſſwade men from the ſame: on the other ſide, to ſhewe the vnſpeakable good of Contentation) the which ſpringeth vp of the feare of God, and combineth with true obedience to the Prince and brotherly loue) and to perſwade all men to imbrace it, as that which is not onely commaunded and commended in the word of God, but alſo eſteemed, honoured and obſerued of them that be the Lords. For this cauſe I haue both framed and intituled this diſcourſe, A Preparatiue to Contentation. This hauing finiſhed, and perpending to whome I might chiefely dedicate the ſame, I happily thought on thee (Moſt Noble Theophilos) to whoſe Nobilitie before all others, I both preſent and commend it, mooued to this choiſe by no meane cauſes. For firſt I conſider of thy worthineſſe beeing (indeede) the friende and welbeloued of God, and therein preferred to all others, as is the ſoule to the body and things caeleſtiall, to the things terreſtriall.

2 Next, I am not ignorant that theſe and ſuch like things which concerne the kingdome of God, doo properly appertaine vnto ſuch as being of God beloued, doo alſo loue and feare him; the which Saint Luke well conſidered, and therefore hauing compoſed two learned Volumes of the Euangelicall Hiſtory, he dedicated them both vnto his deare Theophilos. Luke 1.3. Acts 1.1. Thirdly, it is certaine
that the moſt reuerend Name and note of thy Nobilitie, doth adde ſuch an Admirable Grace to the things, which to the ſame commended thy worthineſſe, vouchſaueth to accept, that in regard thereof, they are the ſooner admitted and imbraced, as thoſe, which were ſometimes offred in the Temples, and conſecrated to holy vſes, haue beene eſteemed for pretious Iewelles, as Plynie ſaid, writing to Veſpaſian the Emperour.

4 Thy right willing and gratefull heart, in the ready acceptation and right eſtimation of thoſe things (though ſlender and by meane perſons) of good will dedicated to thy Nobilitie, is apparant and commended: the which (beeing well weighed (coulde not but mooue me at this time, to caſt into thy Treaſure-houſe this my good-wil offring, though ſo ſlender, as the two mytes of the pore wydow mentioned in the Goſpell.

5 Being the faithfull of the Lord, and of him ſo wel-beloued, thou wilt not admit, that either thoſe which ſlide of ignorance, infirmitie or feare, ſhould bee made publique examples of diſgrace: or that whatſoeuer is eyther ſayd, written, or wrought (eſpecially by them that thereby endeuour to benefit the church and common-wealth) ſhoulde bee wreſted and vrged with hard cenſures and like conſtructions: but rather, that the multitude of ſinnes ſhould be charitably couered, and all things taken in the better ſence, and fauourably conſtrued. Therefore I haue beene moſt willing to ſubmit my ſelfe and my labours in this parte vnto thy godly Iudgment, and right charitable conſtructions.

6 As it hath pleaſed god in his loue & mercie, both to grace and protect thee, ſo hath he alſo giuen thee a will & abilitie to fauour and defend both his ineſtimable truth, & the true profeſſours thereof: that ſo, howſoeuer the worldlings rage and raue againſt the one and the other, VViſedome may bee
yet iuſtified of her Children: the Truth and her louers approoued and defended of them that loue and feare the Lord.

7 Finally: I haue been moſt willing (moſt worthie Theophilos) in this ſort to ſignifie my heartie affection and good will towards thee: for whoſe happie increaſe and perſeueraunce in the loue and grace of God, with all proſperitie I pray daylit vnto his Diuine Maieſtie, and that by thine happie Miniſterie he would vouchſafe yet to helpe, ſuſtaine and edifie his Church, and promote and further that true, auncient, liuelie and Catholique faith and holy Religion within this realm and Church of England: the which hath theſe many yeares of our peace bin worthily defended in the ſame, by our right Christian and moſt Soueraigne Princeſſe Queene Elizabeth, whoſe moſt excellent Maieſtie, the moſt mightie God long proſper and preſerue to reigne ouer, vs, for the comfort of his Church, and his high Glorie. And thus I commend this Preparatiue vnto thee (moſt Noble Theopilos) and thy ſelf vnto him who hath both loued, graced, and bleſſed thee in his Sonne Ieſu Chriſt: to whome be praiſed and glory for euer more, Amen.

Against Polypragmoſyne.

Chap. 11 VVe may not dreame of better euents of our
ſtudies, then others haue had before vs: against Innouaſiōs.
Chap. 12 The ambitious perſons, wanting preferment, begin to ſlaunder, condemne and contemne the Magistracy and the lawes: the Prince is to be honoured, and the lawes to be abeyed of good ſubiects
Chap. 13 Sedition is a vile and noyſomething: euery good man knowing the daunger thereof, doth wiſely fly and eſchue it.

Chap. 15. Happy bee they that protest well, and walke accordingly. Three kindes of Protestants
Chap. 16 The examination of ſome particular parts of title Protestants

Chap. 22 The beſt medicines for the cure of mans maladies, muſt be made of the word of God.
An eſpeciall Comfortatiue for the Magistrate
Chap. 23 Conſolations and inſtructions for the Paſtor
Ca. 24 Comforts to content the Houſholder, the Scribe, and other perſons, in their ſeuerall places
Chap. 25 Euery man is to take the benefit of Time, to keepe himſelfe within the boundes of his owne vocation: to depend on the diuine Prouidence: the vnlike endes of pietie, and impietie.

div.head: To the true Chriſtian and indifferent Readers, Peace, Contentation, and Saluation in Chriſt Ieſu, the Author and worker of the ſame.
div.p:
THere is no man liuing vnder the Sun, which feeleth not the painfull effect of Adams ſinne, in the bitter ſence of wofull miſeries. But the godly and beſt diſpoſed perſons, in whatſoeuer time, place, or calling they liue, are conſtrained with Simon of Cirene to beare the Croſſe after their Maiſter Chriſt. For why, there be not only miniſtred vnto them many mightie cauſes of Diſcontentation, through thoſe greeuous oppreſsiōs vrged on them by the vngodly, whom the Lord maketh his roddes to correct and puniſh his owne when they offende him: wherby the very heart of Mary is pearced with the ſword, as Simeon propheſied: but alſo the holie ſpirit in them is moued, through the horrible ſinnes and greeuous offences of the ingratefull againſt God, to driue the meſtiue mill of lamentation, with flouds of weeping teares. All rhe which (neuertheleſſe) the Lord of mercie, and God of conſolation, mittigateth and moderateth in them that feare and loue him, both by the inward comforts of his ſpirit, and by the externall miniſterie of his word. But as for the vngodly (which are meere ſtraungers from the wombe, and naturally deuoyd of peace, like the raging waues of the ſea that caſt out their own filth) the Lord ſuffreth Satan to rule them at his pleaſure: he giueth them ouer, to be deſtroyed in their owne luſts, as ſuch of whom he hath no regard, and ſuffereth them to ſpeake lyes, to prophane his holy religion, and to ſway in their abhominable ſinnes, vntil
their wickedneſſe be full, when he is willing to require them with his iuſt iudgements in diſpleaſure. In the meane time, waxing proud, and climbing on high through hautie preſumptiō of the Lords long ſuffring (which ſhould rather drawe ſinners to repentance) they take no meane pleaſure and glory to oppreſſe and offend the Lords little ones, and daily deuiſe and endeuour to diſturbe & trouble the profitable tranquilitie and peace of the Chriſtian Common-weale: wheras placing the Lord Ieſus on the high Pinacle of the Temple, they aſſaie how they might caſt him downe headlong, to the great griefe of the godly thereby offended, the diſhonour of Chriſt, therby contemned: and the prouocation of the God of heauen, thereby diſpleaſed and vrged to powre downe his terrible vengeance and vnhappie woe vppon them by whome thoſe offences come. The ſtate & condition not only of other times and nations, but alſo of this our owne, yeeld vs too many pittifull examples of this Argument. Wherein, we ſee how the rough raging waues of humane deuiſes, ſuggeſted and prouoked by the high bluſtring winds of diuelliſh Ambition, haue not a litle moleſted and perplexed (I ſay not thoſe Marriners that embarqued Ionas towardes Tharſus only, but alſo) Noah and his familie in the Arke: the Apoſtles of Chriſt in the ſhip, and ſuch as are paſſengers euen in the ſame veſſell with Chriſt towardes the Hauen of happineſſe. Beſides that, we may ſee, how that on the very maine land, litle Dauid hath very much ado to reſcue the ſeely ſheepe from the hungrie Lyons teeth. An houſe is much ſooner throwne downe, then reedified: a Citie is not ſo eaſily reduced into
vnitie and concorde, as it is diuided. And ſurely there, where the diſtracted mindes and wandering opinions of ambitious heads, haue not only contriued and commenced, but alſo drawne foorth and twiſted the odious threede of Diſcontentation, wee may expect none other thing therof, but vtter ſubuertions of Townes, Cities, Countries, Churches, Kingdomes, without ſpeedie preuention. Therefore, this is that, which in the account of all wiſe men is vnhappie, and after the iudgement of all the godly, moſt vngodly, and the occaſion of greater courage and boldneſſe to the forraign enemy, then the feebleſt reſiſtances of them that be combined in true concord and peace.

But what is that to vs? I would (indeede) that theſe things did neither touch vs, nor were found rowſting in our houſes! but, when the vizard of hautie conceit and proper integritie, is remooued from our bleared eyes, we cannot but plainly perceiue, that the Church (notwithſtanding the ſincere preaching of the word of God in the ſame) is intollerably burthened with Sectes opinions, and dangerous Sciſmes: and that the whole Common-wealth is no leſſe vnhappily peſtred with diſcords, diſſentions, ſeditions, and many other huge enormities and euilles of this laſt age and wane of the worlde, wherein the bande of Chriſtian Charitie is broken, he Truth (though ſo ſtrong and aboue all) is entertained but as a wandering Pilgrime on the earth, euen with them that fawne on her preſence: the right faith is ſorely cōtemned by them that haue taken vp weapons vnder pretence to defende her: and the Prince of darkneſſe groweth ſtronger and
ſtronger without reſiſtance, towards the end of his raigne in the world, who hath vehemently enflamed and ſtrongly prouoked the enemies of the Church againſt the Church: to the which they threaten fire and ſword, and daily endeuor deſtruction. And this to compaſſe & effect, they haue ioyned hands with mightie Potentates, they haue armed wel waged ſouldiers, they haue prepared their ſtrong barbed Horſes, their ſwift Chariots, and a thouſand warlike engins, to the terror of the weake in ſpirit, to the affliction of poore Ioſeph, and to the diſhonor of the name of God: who laugheth them to ſcorne, and knoweth wel how to confound them in their owne deuiſes, when it ſhall pleaſe him to expreſſe his diſpleaſure towards them, and his loue to his children. But what inconueniences may enſue the preſent miſchiefes, who knoweth not, that hath wiſedome to diſcerne thereof? and what good Chriſtian would not endeuour to ſtop and preuent the ſame? Therfore (though after many others, yet with and among ſome others) to meete with thoſe deſperate maladies, and to aſſay to preuent whatſoeuer greater euils may thereof enſue (according to that meane wiſedome and abilitie the Lord hath giuen me) I haue confected A Preparatiue to Contentation: and made the ſame Applicatory to this our time, Nation, and the preſent occaſion. An Argument moſt neceſſary to be vrged, and a thing in earneſt expectation of all good mindes, within whom the holy ſpirit of diſcipline is made ſad and ſorrowfull, through the conſiderarion of the manifold diſorders and huge inconueniences of noyſome Diſcontentation, and to whoſe good natures, the true
Contentation, is euery way both profitable and acceptable, in the feare of God, and honour of the Prince, (howſoeuer harriſh and vnpleaſant it ſeemeth to the taſte of him that is oppreſſed with the humor of ſingular conceit) as thoſe potions which are in taſte bitter and ſowre, may be more wholſom for the diſtreſſed patient, then ſuch as are ſweet and wallowiſh. And (indeed) although I could not be ſo briefe as Phocian was in the Citie of Athenes: nor (if I could) would I be either ſo copious as Demoſthenes with the Graecians, or ſo eloquent as Cicero with the Romains, to whoſe learned immitatours I referre both the lapping vp of plaine things in obſcuritie, and the handling of publique controuerſies in ample diſcourſes: yet haue I wiſhed and indeuoured to be rather modeſt with Paule, and charitable with Iohn, then impudent with Tartullus, and curious with Peter: hazarding al my credit & eaſe, in regard of your profit and peace. Moreouer, albeit I know wel, that to many of you, this my preſent Preparatiue ſhalbe but like the glimmering light of a Candle ſet in the bright Sun ſhining, hauing (indeed) litle need of this meane helpe: yet I perſwade, that ye which loue brotherly fellowſhip, feare God, and honour the Prince, will not diſdaine it, but rather, that ye will be the more readie vpon this, and ſuch like occaſiōs, to ſtand vp in the defence of the truth againſt all erronious opinions, vaine deuiſes, and ſyniſter practiſes of man, as it beſt becommeth you with all ſuch as be of the houſhold of faith. Neither doubt I, but that alſo the ſooner by the force of this Preparatiue, the rage and rygour of the Diſcontented wil be aſſwaged, the domeſticall enemy in part, terrified,
the ſeditious Aduerſary of our ſtate quailed, or at the leaſt made aſhamed, and the forreine foe the better obſerued and reſiſted: that ſo, both in the one and the other, the Lord of heauen may be worthely glorified. For theſe cauſes haue I the rather publiſhed this Preparatiue, the which alſo I pray and beſeech you (Chriſtian Readers) before the Lord Ieſus, and his holy Angels, to take in good part, and to conſtrue therof indifferently, to apply it diſcreetly, and to vſe it in all points charitably, for the better quiet of conſcience, the peace of the Church, and ſafetie of the Common-wealth, in the feare of God: vnto whoſe goodneſſe, let vs daily pray for the true Contentation.

closer.signed: More yours then his owne, in the Lord Ieſu. I. C.

div.head: An Admonition to the gentle Readers.
div.p: WHereas it is ſaid in the 6. Chapter, that the Number of the Beaſt is conteined in certaine Hebrew and Greeke words and voices &c. ye ſhall vnderſtand, that the ſaide Number, is to be gathered and made of the letters and characters of the ſame wordes after the manner of the Hebrewes and Greekes, which vſe their Alphabeticall letters and characters for Arithmeticall figures.

div.head: Faults eſcaped.
div.p: Moreouer, becauſe it was not my good lot to be preſent at the printing of this Booke, there bee therein too many faults eſcaped, for the which I am ſory, and do beſeeche you gentle Readers either to conſtre all in the beſt ſence, or elſe to reade or correct them thus.
In pag. 6. lin. 2. reade thus Clh. mlc. ail. or thus, Calah. Melech. ael.

In pag. 64. lin. 1. ſupply theſe words omitted H Aitalih. cſchr. chuh. which ye may thus reade ha Italy ceſchar: chehunah. 1. lo: Italy is like a Prince of the prieſthood. Lin. 7. read ha. anoſch cijhovah. Lin. 23. read Royh quohel ha Romah.
In pag. 59. lin. 3.4.5. read it thus, yeares 666. expired: but chiefly from the time that the Diuel was let at libertie after the thouſand yeeres: that is ſithence the yeare of our Lord 1000.
In pag. 113. lin. 1. ſupply (No, thus haue I ſaid) &c.
rible confuſions and wofull Diſcontentations.

The miſeries of this laſt age of the world, vnder the raigne of Antichriſt.2. And as all men of all ages before vs haue ſeene, and might the ſame confeſſe: ſo we alſo that liue in theſe deſperate and daungerous dayes, do now ſee, and may alſo the ſame confeſſe, that not onely Heuah by her fall hath her conceptions multiplied, and her ſorrows encreaſed: but alſo the ſonnes of Adam haue conceiued opinions, trauailed with miſchiefes, and brought foorth iniquities, whereof (as ſuch which haue ploughed wickednes) they haue reaped wretchednes, drawing not only from Adam, by diſcent naturally, but alſo from the Angell apoſtate, by immitation wickedly, the cankered humour of Diſcontentation, to the prouocation of the God of heauen, to the diſquiet of the Church, and to the ſhame of their owne faces. Whereupon, the godly are moued to ruminate Salomons concluſion, Eccle. 1.2. & 12.8. Vanitie of vanities: yea, and enforced they are to confeſſe, that againſt the inhabitours of the Earth, and of the Sea, there is a roll of a Booke written without and within, Eze. 2.10. Apo. 12.12. full of Lamentations, Mourning, and VVoe: for that the Authour of all Diſcontentation, the Diuell, is come downe vnto them, and hath great wrath, (yea more then euer hee had) for that his time is but ſhort.

3. For although this diſcōtented diuel, euer enuying the ſtate of the Saints, hath ben long time (euen from the fall of Adam, vnto this day) buſied, tripping on the heele of the promiſed Seede: yet is he nothing wearie, he giueth not ouer: but he continueth as nimble, as ſubtile, as ſtrong, as diligent, and as terrible, as hee was in the beginning of the world: and this waning age too well prooueth the deepeneſſe
and extremities of his moſte peſtilent practiſes: wherewith (poaſting from coaſt to coaſt, Iob. 1.7. and compaſsing the earth rounde about) hee ſtrugleth with tooth and nayle moſt eagerly, and that often vnder the faire face of a bright Angell, to ſeduce, drawe away, and keepe captiue (as for his owne) the Soules, which Ieſus Chriſt the king of righteouſneſſe by his conqueſt hath redeemed. Such is his mightie force! ſuch is his madde furie! ſuch is his eager bent! and to this purpoſe, he vſeth ſuch bottomleſſe deuiſes, as thereby (if poſsible it were) hee woulde deceiue the holie choſen people of God.

So it pleaſeth the Lorde of heauen to permit and ſuffer (for a time) this inſtrument of his wrath to rage in the worlde:Why God ſuffreth the Diuell to rage in the world. partly for the exerciſe of the Church in this her pilgrimage through the huge wilderneſſe of this worlde: that the godly being tryed, may runne vnto his mercie for comforte,2. Tim. 3. Apo. 2.10.11.17.27. Auguſtine. and by the ſame reſiſt the enemie, and reſiſting, may get the victorie, and hauing the victorie, they may bee crowned: for were there not an enemy, there could bee no battaile: Were there not a battaile, there ſhoulde bee no victorie: and were there not a victorie, there would bee no Crowne: Eccle. 1.13. & 2.26. Rom. 1.21. partly, hath the Lorde thus ſuffered this Enemie to raigne ouer the children of diſobedience, and to rage in the worlde for the puniſhment of tranſgreſsions and ſinnes, for a ſcourge to beate and to humble the children of men, chiefely them which knowing God, doo neither glorifie God, as God; nor bee thankfull in their hearts for the benefite of his Sonne; but waxing full of Vanitie in
their carnall imaginations, doo walke their owne wayes in the lewdneſſe of their mindes. But aboue all, that the higheſt God might be glorified, as well in the horrible confuſion & deſtruction of his proud enemies; as in the wonderfull deliuery and ſaluation of his elected Saints.

4. To let paſſe the recitall of a thouſand ſubtile ſeductions and mightie encounters of that grand enemy, which heere to tell would be tedious and irkeſome: what is hee in all the world, that hath not in one time or other of his life, either felt or perceiued his practiſes, his deuiſes, his bent againſt Chriſt, and his rage in the world? Beyond all other, his wayes and means to aſſault & annoy the Church of Chriſt, his Satanical ſhifts and diuelliſh conueyances, practiſed by thoſe his two miſchieuous miſcreants, Couered. Gog and Diſcouered. The two mighty enemies of Chriſt and his Church in the world Reu. 12.1. Magog: that is to ſay, the Pope, and the Turke, are plainly diſcouered. Theſe two, though they be enemies the one to the other of them, haue yet conſented, the former couertly, the latter openly, to perſecute and purſue with all bloudie crueltie, the myſticall Woman and her ſonne, now little leſſe then a thouſand years, according as the Prophets, the Apoſtles, and Chriſt himſelfe haue moſt truly foretold of them to come in this latter age & wane of the world. Lo! ſuch two outcaſt hands hath that direfull diuel, to contend and ſtriue for him in his deadly quarrell! Theſe, and ſuch like Antichriſtiā perſons (ſaith Chryſoſtome) are the very weapons of the damned diuel: for as a man cannot do any thing againſt his enemy without weapons or inſtruments, ſo neither can the diuell without the miniſtery and ſeruice of ſuch vngodly & wicked perſons, vexe, perſecute, and trouble
the Saints of God in the world.Lodolf. de vita Chriſti, Cap. 5.2. Theſe vngodly and wicked miſcreants be indeed the powers of the diuell, without whom hee cannot ſowe his wicked ſeedes in the world: for in the Saints hee findeth no place. Neither hath this ſubtile Serpent inuented any fitter way to combine Gog and Magog in league, and to reconcile Herod with Pilate, then by the perſecuting, the crucifying, the blaſpheming, the tormenting, and vexing of Ieſus Chriſt in his members. Pſal. 2.1. & 83.56. And therefore he hath vehemently ſuggeſted, and furiouſly prouoked the Heathen to rage, the People to imagine vaine things, the kings of the earth to ſtand vp, and the Princes to aſſemble togither againſt the Lord, and againſt his annointed.

5. But, to the great terror of all the vngodly, that thus oppoſe themſelues againſt the Lorde and his Saintes; and to the endleſſe comfort of all his holy Elect, we heare what he ſaith: He that dwelleth in heauen ſhall laugh them to ſcorne: the Lord ſhall haue them in deriſion: he ſhall ſpeake to them in his wrath, and vexe them in his ſore diſpleaſure: yet haue I ſet my king vppon my holy hill of Sion. Thus, Gen. 11.1. though Nimrod that mightie hunter before the Lord, with his folowers, do incite and ſtirre vp one another in this ſort: Let vs make brick, Laterificemus. aedificemus. and therewith let vs build vs a Citie and a Towre, whoſe toppe may reach vnto heauen: and let vs make vs a name: and wil not be reſtrained from that, which they haue imagined to doo: yet will the Lorde God himſelfe come downe to viſit and confound them, with this meete alluſion to their incitation:
Deſcendamus.
Confundamus.
Let vs go down & confound their language: and hee will ſcatter them from that place vpon all the earth. Thus hath the Lorde God derided Sennacherib, Pharao, Herod, the high Prieſtes,
the Romane Potentates, and all others, that haue exalted themſelues & raged in the world againſt his Church. The whiles, as the ſhip in the Sea, which after many tempeſtuous ſtormes arriueth into the hauen of peace: and as the trauailing woman, after many wofull throwes, is deliuered of a ſonne, to her exceeding conſolation, ſo the Church of God, ſtandeth; flouriſheth, and obtaineth at length that eternall peace which the Sonne of God hath purchaſed for his Saintes, mawgre the tyrannie, the hypocriſie, and the Sophiſtrie of the wicked world: and the horrible rage and furie of that damned and diſcontented diuell.

div.head: CHAP. II.
The practiſe of the enemie troubling the Church and the Common-wealth of England. The ingratitude and diſcontentation of Engliſh-men.
div.p: WHy ſhould we note only the generall griefes, and point at that which ſeemeth ſo farre hence? Let vs rather (as we be iuſtly moued) draw homeward, and we ſhal diſcry many miſerable Vanities,Vanities in England. (I ſay▪ not vnder the Sunne, but) euen heere in this particular part of Europe. I doubt not, but that the wiſe Chriſtian will (as the wiſe Patient) permit me with the Phiſitian,The enemy 〈◊〉 entred on our 〈◊〉 Church, & Commonwealth, and therin ſowen the ſeeds of diſcontentation and trouble. firſt to diſplay, and then to preſcribe medicines for mans maladies.

Mans mortall foe, hath too boldly intruded himſelfe both into our Church and into our Commonwealth,
and by an vſurped tyrannie, daily diſturbeth and troubleth the tranquilitie and peace of the ſame. And therein men being enflamed, are become in ſteed of reaſonable and Chriſtian, brutiſh and prophane: they are growne contentious, haultie, vainglorious, ambitious, wrathfull, enuious, contumelious, gluttonous, couetous, faithleſſe, and as ſaith the Poet, An vnprofitable Charge of the earth, Telluris invtile pondus. Homer. whom neither one ſimple and right Religion can content or pleaſe: but, as among the Philoſophers, ſome Stoikes, ſome Epicures, ſome Academikes, ſome Peripatikes: and, as of the Lawiers, ſome Caſsianes, ſome Sabianes, ſome Proculianes: and as among the Iewes, ſome Iuſtitiarij. Saduces, ſome Legis expoſitores. Phariſes, ſome Operarii. Eſſees: and as in their Vniuerſities, ſome Libertines, ſome Cyrenians, ſome Alexandrians, ſome Cilicians, ſome Aſians, &c: ſo now they excogitate and inuent diuers hereſies or Sectes, in their choyſe, of ſtraunge conceited opinions of ſome certaine perſons, into the which, they lyke well to diuide themſelues, Luke 15.28. and trauayle therein (as in moſt intricate Labyrinthes) without any ende or perfection at all. In the meane time, they doo (with that glorious Clergie of the Iewes) chower againſt the Church of Chriſt, and lyke vnto that diſcontented and moſt diſdainefull Elder Brother, they will not vouchſafe to enter into the houſe of ioy and gladneſſe with the yoonger Brother, there to reioyce in right concord and contentation: though the Good Father himſelfe come foorth and verie gently and friendly entreat them to come in.

Eccle. 13.19. Hyena, is a ſubtile wild beaſt, that by counterfeiting mās voyce beguileth him. Luke 2.35. Lytta is the worme in a dogs toong, that makes him madde. Prou. 30.15.For this purpoſe, Hyena trieth euery mans nature to the vttermoſt, Sathan ſifteth Peter as wheate, and the very ſoule of Mary is ſo deeply pearced with the ſword, that except this miſchief be timely obſerued, and the inconuenience thereof wiſely preuented, lewd Lytta will breede madde melancholy, and the Horſe-leaches two daughters that know not to crie ho, will deuour and conſume altogither. For Lucifer being caſt out of heauen, and hauing no power left him to aſcend thither againe, lieth like an vnprofitable braunch in the depth of the earth, where hee hath enkindled ſuch a fire, as cannot bee quenched with mightie ſtreames of water.

2 In truth, we Engliſh-men (far beyond all other nations vnder the Sun) are worthily occaſioned with glad harts and appeaſed minds to praiſe the name of our moſt mercifull God, for this ſo good a ſtate of our Church & Common wealth, as we haue had, and yet do enioy, vnder the moſt happie gouernment of our moſt Chriſtian Princeſſe Queene Elizabeth, whome the preſeruer of Princes long proſper & protect: And we may pray, Iſay. 39.8. with King Hezekiah, that this Trueth, that is to ſay, this quiet and peaceable State wherein the light of Iſrael ſhineth, may be continued accordingly. And it cannot be denied, but that many good men in many ages (whoſe blood hath confirmed their witneſſe of Chriſt) haue groned for, and yet could not ſee ſuch bleſſed dayes: and that, when by the goodneſſe of God, the godly in their times did happily ſee theſe & ſuch like heauenly commodities and bleſsings granted to men, they were moſt glad, and congratulated in the ſame, with right heauenly praiſes vnto the Lord.

Alas, why is it then, that now men waxe wearie of prayer? wearie of Gods ſeruice? wearie of the word of God? wearie of true obedience? wearie of peace and quietneſſe? wearie of goodneſſe? wearie of God? and how commeth it to paſſe,Engliſh men be not cōtent with their great bleſsings. that Engliſh men in lieu of forraine pleaſures, doo diſdaine their home commodities? How is it, that ſo many of them haue ſuch vnquiet cōſciences, ſuch ſtrange conceits, and are neuer cōtented with whatſoeuer good thing the Lord God in his mercie enricheth them? May they be accounted a choſen generatiō, an holy prieſthood, and the children of the moſt high, that ſo yern and murmure againſt him in their hearts euerie day? But vnto them (me thinketh) I heare one applying this fable: The Aſſe and the Ape do both complain: the one, for that he hath not hornes: the other, becauſe hee wanteth a tayle: to whome, the Moule or want thus anſwereth: But if, that ye did well conſider of my miſerable blindneſſe, ye wold not ſo complaine of ſuch your want. Such as neuer felt the bitterneſſe of thraldome and bondage, do not acknowledge the rare benefit of freedome and libertie. But if theſe perſons did well thinke on the miſerie of the Nations and Countries neare about vs, and of the infelicitie of our forefathers, wanting indeede thoſe bleſsings which we haue, or might in this our time enioy, and they with vs; they would gladly content themſelues in peace, & expreſſe their grateful minds to God our heauenly father; for all the great goodneſſe that he hath graunted vnto vs, and to them, in the abundance of his mercies: yea, they would heartily praiſe the liuing Lord for his benefits, Pſal. 107.8. and preach of the wonders that hee hath wrought for the children
of men.
Men be forgetfull of benefits, and alſo of old afflictions.
Gen. 3.1. Luke. 16. 2. Pet. 2.4. Iude. 6. But they remember not the wife of Loth, which was turned into a pillar of Salte, nor Adam and Heuah, which were both thruſt our of Paradize, when they beganne to bee diſcontented with thoſe pleaſures which the Lorde had allotted them there: nor the rich-man in hell, who at length wiſhed to bee eaſed when it was too late: nor the Angels, which forſaking their firſt eſtate (in the rage of their diſcontentation) were caſt downe headlong and reſerued to the iudgement of the great day, in euerlaſting Chaines of darkeneſſe: All theſe examples are blotted out of their memories. They haue alſo quite forgotten all the afflictions of Ioſeph, and all the euer hee did for them in Egipt: as the men of the third and fourth generation after, knowe not their former friendes and benefactors, nor make any enquirie of their auncient good deedes ſhewed to them and their Fathers. And they haue cleane baniſhed from their mindes, all thoſe great good workes and notable wonders, that the Lorde hath declared on their fathers, and on many of them alſo, in leading them ſafely through the Marian flouds with the preſeruation of theyr heauenly foode and ſpirituall prouiſion, to ſee and enioy theſe calme Halcyon dayes of peace and Chriſtian proſperitie. But,Iuuenal. being pearked vp with the preſent lōg leagues, tranquilitie, peace and proſperitie (which as we ſee hath alſo inconueniences) they be grown therwith ſo wanton,Omnes cum valemus bonum conſilium aegrotis damus. Ter. that, as they which be in health do giue good counſell to them that be ſicke, which counſell themſelues in any theyr extremities can ſcarce follow: they can eaſily promiſe now beeing in health (as they thinke) not only to themſelues continuall
reſt, quietneſſe, and a defence againſt all daungers: but alſo to others that bee in trouble, they proffer the like ſecuritie without God: as if themſelues were Lordes of Hell and Death, and had all proſperitie, and all troubles in theyr owne propper power to diſpoſe: then the which, nothing can be more fooliſh, nor more repugnant to the wiſedome of God.

3. Now, in equall cenſure,Afflictions be ſometimes meeter for men, thē proſperitie. Scipio. what may be thought meeter for ſuch perſons, then bitter warres, hard afflictions, miſeries at home, enemies abroade, (as once Scipio iudged of the caſe of the Romanes, for whoſe better proweſſe & diligence, he thought it right neceſſary, that Carthage remained an enemie vnto them.) Neither hath the Lord God himſelfe permitted his people ſo to ſtincke on the dregs of proſperitie, but hath rolled them with many afflictions vppon ſuch occaſions, as thereof he hath ſaid, by the Prophet Hoſeah: Hoſ. 6.14. I will be vnto Ephraim, as a Lion, and as a Lions whelpe to the houſe of Iudah: I, euen I will ſpoyle, and goe away: I will take away, and none ſhall reſcue it; I will goe and returne to my place, till they acknowledge their fault and ſeeke me: In their affliction, they will ſeeke me diligently.

Of theſe things, if they once taſted but one dram of the bitterneſſe,They bee fooles that acknowledge not preſent benefits, but negligently let them paſſe away. (with thoſe other Nations) they would ſoone chaunge their mindes and opinions, as in a caſe ſodainly altered, & acknowledge of what great bleſsinges they haue depriued themſelues, through ſuche their monſtrous ingratitude. Till then, they ſhall bee numbred vppe among thoſe fooles, that confeſſe not a good thing whiles they haue it in their handes, but, being thereof depriued,
they do moſt earneſtly (but all in vaine) craue and deſire it. Ier. 8.14. The Lord God graunt this, that we be not put to ſilence, and that we haue not water mixt with gall to drinke, becauſe we haue offended him in theſe our diſcontentations: then may we ſeeke for comfort againſt ſorrow: but ſorrow ſhall come vpon vs, and heauineſſe ſhall vexe our harts, that the health of the people ſhall not be recouered with the helpe of all the Phiſitians or triakle in Gilead (as the Prophet ſaith) The wiſe will ponder theſe things, Pſal. 107.43. and they only ſhal vnderſtand the louing kindneſſe of the Lord towardes them and their children: Gen. 49.14. but Iſachar, though a great boned Aſſe, ſhall couch downe betweene two burthens: and being depriued worthily of that good thing which they ſometime vnwoorthily poſſeſſed, they ſhall be moued to confeſſe, that God was among them, and they knew it not.
Gen. 28.16.

div.head: CHAP. III.
The mal-contented Papiſt, his practiſe, purpoſe, and daily expectation, how he muſt be pacified.
div.p:
THe maleuolent diſpoſition of the trayterous limbes of Gog; lurking heere in ſecret (as the curſed Cham, betweene Shem and Iaphet) is ſuch, Gen. 9 25. Iud. 14.15. and 16.5. that with the Philiſtines, they doo not only plough with Samſons Cowe, to finde out Samſons riddle, but alſo do labour to perſwade Dalila, to ſearch out the ſtrength of Samſon, to ſhaue off his hairy lockes, and to betray him into the hands of his mortall enemies. Vnder a cloake of ciuill obedience, Mat. 22.21. Ioh. 19.12. they pretende
Caeſars wealth; but yet, Brutus and Caſſius were the chiefe conſpirators and murderers of Iuli-Caeſar, but Octauius reuenged it on them. Plutarch. Sueton. Luk. 19.14. Gen. 29.41. reteining in heart their inueterated malice againſt the Religion, gouernment, and the ſtate of Caeſar, they do with Brutus and Caſsius contriue ſhrewd matters, not conſidering, that God (when it ſhall pleaſe him) will raiſe vp an Octauius, to reward them in the ende. But this thing being leaſt thought on (whatſoeuer they ſhew) they like & loue Caeſar, as they did their lawful Lord, who ſent a meſſage after him, ſaying: VVee will not haue this man to raigne ouer vs. And their loue and affection towards their brethrē, wel reſēbleth that of Eſau towards his brother Iaacob, who wiſhed for his fathers funeralls, that he might be reuenged on Iaacob his natural brother. To effect and haſten all theſe matters,2. Sam. 15. Abſolon with his faire flattering tongue, beginneth to ſteale away the hearts of the people from Dauid their lawfull King. Achitophel with his craft & ſubtiltie, is ready to counſel vnthriftily, the high Prieſts offer largely, and finally, Iudas Iſcarioth is the man (or rather the diuell) which is appointed the executioner of this tragedie, and he (for his owne filthie lucre) intendeth to betray his liege Lorde (yet with a kiſſe, vnder a ſhewe of loue and friendſhippe) into the high prieſts handes, to bee crucified. This is that they gape for, this is their expected Iubelie and golden day, wherein they determine as bloud-thirſtie butchers, to embrew their ſeruile handes in ſoueraigne and innocent bloud: and thereupon to become prickes in out eyes, whippes to our ſides, ſcourges to their owne Nation, and deſtructions to themſelues, and their own mothers children. Theſe bee (indeede) the fruites of their holie vowes and religious profeſsion! With theſe and ſuche high
pointes of diuellſh ſeruice, they adulate their moſt holie father, and thinke that therein they pleaſe the moſt high God, and merite to themſelues eternall life.

Zopirus. Zopirus the Perſian (as Herodote reporteth it) though an Heathen man, was contented to ſuſtaine the cutting off, of his noſe, his eares, and his lips, to further the enterpriſe of his liege Lorde Darius, againſt proude Babilon: the like (in a manner) is ſaid of that famous Vliſſes, Vliſſes apud Homer. for the behoofe of his Countrey men againſt the Troyans: But theſe perſons, being enemies to God, rebelles againſt their Prince, and falſe Traytours to their owne Nation, are preſt and readie,Dolon Verg. li. 12. Aeneid. Pſal. 137. rather with Dolon the Troyan, to betray all, and with the diſſembling Edomites to prouoke the enemies of Iſrael againſt Iſrael, (when an opportunitie ſhall bee offered them) then to ſuſtaine anie loſſe, or to do any good for any of them all.

The Papiſt his obedience.2. Albeit theſe craftie Foxes ſo long as they be tyed in Chaines, ſeeme familiar and tame: yet let them once catch an opportunitie of eſcape, and they runne with all haſte to the wood againe. And although theſe rauening Wolues being faſt haltered to the tree, can counterfayt the little ſchollers in the Schoole,Obedientia vulpina, & lupina, non columbina. and learne to ſpell P.a.pā.t.e.r, tēr: yet when they ſhall ſee the harmeleſſe Lambes leaping within their reache, they will quite forget to ioyne ſillables, and to ſay pater: but they will crie out, Agni, Agni, Lambes, Lambes, and catch them for their praie.

Iſa. 29.15.But woe vnto them (ſaith the Prophet) that ſeek deepe to hide their counſelles from the Lord: for their workes are in darkeneſſe, and they ſay, who
ſeeth vs? and who knoweth vs? your turning (in your deuiſes) ſhall it not bee eſteemed, but as the Potters claye, and that within a verie ſhort time? Yea, I doubt not, but that the Lord wil ſo work, that they ſhall be, (as they haue bin heretofore) preuented of their bloudy purpoſe, by this, that the Lord our God will perſwade Samſon to take theſe Foxes, Iudg. 15.4. and to tye fier-brandes to their tayles, and to ſende them home to the ſpoyle of theſe vncircumciſed Philiſtines: that thereby they may feele the force of that fierie lawe. Deut. 33.2. Iudg. 15.16. For one Samſon (one true Nazarite, hauing the aſsiſtance of Gods ſpirite) ſhall do more with the ſeelie Iawe-bone of an Aſſe, then a thouſande of thoſe vncircumciſed Philiſtines, with all their worldly power, fleſhly deuiſes, and diuelliſh practiſes. Neither ſhall their deuiſes proſper, ſo long as God is with vs, as to whome the Prophet ſaieth in the name of the Lorde: Iſa. 8.10. Breake downe (O ye people) and yee ſhall be broken downe: hearken to, all ye of farre Countries: Muſter ye, and ye ſhall be broken downe: Prepare ye, and ye ſhall be torne in peeces. Take your counſell togither, yet ſhall your counſell come to nought: determine the mattter, yet ſhall it not proſper: for God is with vs.

And if that the horribleneſſe of our owne ſinnes, and a generall Apoſtaſie from the Lorde,We are to beware that our owne ſins occaſiō not our enemies to triumph ouer vs. prouoke not his iuſtice to a deadly hatred of vs and our liues (as the tranſgreſsions of Ephraim and Iuda, before the Babilonicall captiuitie prouoked him, (which the good Lorde in his mercie forbid) the Ruſticus expectat d ••• defluit 〈◊〉
Ruſtick may gape long inough for the ſtaie of the ſtreame, which yet will runne without
fainting. Iſa. 29.9. Rom. 10.19. So let them wayte (beeing prouoked to enuie by them that feare God, and that liue in true obedience to his Annointed) vntil their ſpightfull eyes fall out, theyr yearning bowelles breake, and their faynt ſoules be ſwallowed vp with vaine dreames and friuolous expectations. In the meane time, let them not imagine, that their cloſe iuglings in hucker-mucker, Iſa. 29.16. can couer their treacherous deuiſes and conſpiracies from the Lord, when hee ſeeth all: nor can bleare the eyes of his Annoynted, when Eliſha deciphereth all: nor may couch that in ſecrecie from the ſight of all men, when they themſelues (much lyke vnto them which daunce in nets) demonſtrate all.

It is more hard to root them out, then it is to finde them out.3 Though Caeſar ſayde of the Scythians, that it was an harder thing to finde them out, then to vanquiſh them: yet of theſe may we ſay, it is nothing ſo difficile to finde them out (notwithſtanding their great diſsimulation and monſtruous hypocriſie,) as it is to roote them out, or to expel them. For as the Iebuſites preſumed to dwell with the children of Iuda in Hieruſalem,
Ioſua 15.63. and the inhabitants of Hieruſalem could not caſt them out from among them: ſo preſume theſe Gogites to inhabit amōg the true ſubiects, and are ſo friended and fauoured, ſo rooted and eſtabliſhed, as they cannot eaſily be expelled and caſt out. Howbeit, whether they be in preferment before many others, as Hamā was in the Court of Ahaſueroſh, or bee put vnder tribute, as the Canaanites were vnder the children of Manaſſes and the Ephramites, How to know them. they may eaſily be diſcerned (as I ſaid) and that partly by their faces, and partly by their languages, beſides their common practiſes, in like ſort as the
trees are knowne by their leaues and fruits. For firſt their cankred hearts cannot but yeelde forth at time and times ſuch a countenance as Cayn ſometime expreſſed towards Abel his brother,Gen. 4. when the Lorde ſaid to him: VVhy art thou angry? and why is thy countenance abated? If thou doeſt well, ſhalt thou not receiue? and if thou doſt euil, lieth not thy ſinne at the doore (to be ſeene?) The Samaritanes knewe that Chriſt was a Iewe by his face, which was full bent towardes Ieruſalem. Luk. 9.53. But on the other ſide, we know theſe Gogites to be not Iewes, not true Chriſtians, but bond men to Pharao, and captiues to Nabucadnezar, by that that their faces are not bent towardes the land of Canaan, nor towards Ieruſalem, but they looke backeward towards Egypt, and towardes Babilon, as ſuch as rather loue bondage before freedome, & captiuitie before redemption. And that ſome which haue beene happily drawen from thence againſt their wils (as thoſe Iewes who hauing libertie granted them to returne home with Zorobabel, did ſet the land of the liuing at naught) they doo yet looke with ſterne faces and eager countenances againſt their brethren, and waite but for paſports to be ſent packing. And ſurely an happie thing were it for the right Iſraelites, if they were once gathered and caſt out, being as noyſome to the true ſubiects as ſtones, brambles, and buſhes, in the Lordes vineyard,Iſay 5. and as tares that grow in the field among the corne.

4. Beſides this, they decipher themſelues by their tongues: for when they ſhould ſay Schibboleth, they ſay Sibboleth, & their languages be mixt with Aſdod,
Iudg. 12.6. 2. Eſr. 13.24. Ammon, and Moab, neither are they able pronounce in the right Iewiſh language. Whereas the
talking of the right Chriſtian is wiſedome, Eccle. 27.11.13. their talk is abhomination, for thereby they endeuour to prophane the glorie of the Goſpel, to blemiſh the credit of the Lords annointed, and to corrupt the manners of the true ſubiects. By the which our moſt noble ſoueraigne Princeſſe is iuſtly mooued to complaine of them, as Moſes did of thoſe old Iſraelites, ſaying: I know thy rebellion, and thy ſtiffe necke, while I am yet aliue with you this day, ye haue beene diſobedient to the Lord, and how much more will ye be diſobedient after my death? Such (indeede) are they founde to be, and knowne well to be, howſoeuer they change their ſuits to dazle mens eyes, of whom we may beware, for whiles they be not expelled, by their vnhappie example and leauen of vngodlineſſe, many ſimple ſoules laden with ſin, ſtand ſuſpenſiue in the matters of religion: & others make queſtion, whether it were better for them, either to lurke at home in hope of longer life,Verg. or elſe with Achilles to batter the walles of proude Troy in the ieopardie of life. Others think, that though Nabucadnezzar which captiued them, is cruell and greeuous to be ſerued, yet hee which commeth after him (namely Baltſazar) may be a bon companion for their purpoſe.2. Cor. 39.22 And all the whiles they conſider not that God will ſtirre vp Cyrus the Perſian to inuade proude Babilon, and to deſtroy Baltſazar with al his laſciuious concubines, and carnall companions. Neither is there any wiſedome, ſtrength,The deſire of the true Proteſtant, for the pacification of thoſe papiſts. counſell or policie againſt the Lord God. To ſtriue againſt God is to labor againſt the ſtreame.

5. Oh that the Lord would yet perſwade them as he did Iaphet, to dwell and ſerue gladly with good contentation within the happie Tabernacle of
Shem. Oh that he would either in his iuſtice extirpate and roote out all cankered Cananites from his vineyard, Gen. 9.27. Mark. 7.26 or that he would grant them grace in time to reuert and repent with the Syropheniſſan, and quiet their giddie heades, if not for any loue to the Lord and his annointed, yet (at the leaſt) for feare of that fearefull lot which he caſteth forth for their choyſe and heauie portion which will not repent. Oh that the learned and wiſe magiſtrates in the commonwealth, and the faithful paſtors in the church, wold both ioyne together, duly to obſerue, rightly to detect, and timely to expel theſe blaſphemous Gogites, that the glory of the ſon of God be not derogated, & the ſafetie of his annointed bee not endangered through the peſtilent practiſes of ſuch troubleſome tares, neither that the ſounde ſheepe bee infected through the contagion of ſcabbed Goates.

This is Solomons counſaile, or rather the aduiſe of the holy ghoſt in ſuch a caſe.Cant. 2.5.
Get vs the foxes (and to teach that this muſt be done betimes, yer much hurt be done, he ſaith againe) yea the little foxes that hurt the vines. Alſo Paul perceiuing that certain falſe Apoſtles were crept in among the Galathians whom hee had now long time taught in the truth of the Goſpel, and that they had corrupted the pured doctrine to the offence of the church, Gal. 5.12. Mar. 9.43. hee preſcribed them this medicine. VVould to God (ſaid he) they were cut off which diſquiet you. And our ſauiour teacheth. If thy right hand hinder thee, cut it off and caſt it from thee. Such a thing reſpecteth the Poet.

q.l: VVith knife cut off (diſpairing cure) the foiſtred ſore:Immedicabile vulnus Eaſe recidendum, ne pars ſyncera trahatur.
That it thoſe partes which yet are ſound, may hurt no more.

div.p: In this buſines, if both the magiſtrate and the miniſter ſhall be negligent, yet will the higheſt of all come downe to viſit his Church, and ſend deliuerance to the ſame by ſome other meanes (as Mardochai ſaid to Heſter) when they and their families ſhall no be holden guiltleſſe. Heſt. 4.14.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
The Papiſt hath taken a bad cauſe in hand.
div.p: ALbeit that my purpoſe bee not to handle controuerſies, yet would I with all mine heart, that the folly of them that hang on the traine of Antichriſt ſhould bee decyphered, that thereby the ſooner (if it pleaſe God) ſome of thoſe ſeduced ſoules may change their opinions, repent and pray to the Lord to grant them now at the length to know the truth,1. Tim. 2.25 26. & that they may eſcape the ſnare of the deuill, and be turned from the power of darkenes vnto the father of lights: that they may no longer truſt to the hypocriſie of him that muſtreth himſelfe as an Angell of light, Act. 26.18. and by that art (which Cyprian calleth deuiliſh) ſeeketh to deceiue the heedeleſſe: I haue therefore thought it good to ſay ſomewhat elſe, firſt of the cauſe, and next of the puniſhment and ſufferings of theſe mal-content miſcreants.

The cauſe of the mal-content papiſt is wicked.2 As for their cauſe (as it ſhal be both proued and plainely ſeene (God willing) it hath in it neither any authoritie of the word of God, nor probabilitie of truth: for their ſtriuing and ſtrugling is to extoll the
Biſhop of Rome, and to defend the Supremacie of his vſurped authoritie, againſt Chriſt, his Apoſtles, Martyres, and truth. Indeede the Apoſtle ſaith: Let euery ſoule be ſubiect vnto the higher power.
Rom. 13.1, 2. But what power meaneth he? the power of the Pope, or of any other Biſhop? No, but ſuch a power as of right hath a ſword to take vengeance, and to the which tribute is of dutie payable, (as by the wordes of the ſame Apoſtle following in the ſame chapter may be proued.) But the right of the ſword and tribute belong onely to Emperors, Kings, Princes, and ciuill Magiſtrates in their places, and not vnto the Biſhops, Prieſts, & miniſters of the word, as both by the doctrine and example of Chriſt, Ioh. 18.11. Mat. 22.21. and the doctrine and teſtimonie of his Apoſtles Peter and Paul may be eaſily learned. Therfore it followeth, that euery Soule, that is to ſay, euery perſon, whether of the Laitie, or of the Clergie, and ſo euery Pope, and euery Biſhop of Rome, ought to be ſubiect to the Emperour, to the King, to the Prince, and to that ciuill magiſtrate eſpecially aduanced and authoriſed to raigne in and ouer that prouince or place where he dwelleth. This is that power (ſaith Chriſoſtome) to the which the Apoſtles, In Rom. 13. hom. 23.
Prophets, and Euangeliſts are ſubiect on earth. Who are they then, that would exempt the Biſhop of Rome from his ſubiection to this authoritie.The ſword of the miniſter. The miniſter of the word of God (who in the Primatiue Church was called a Biſhop or a Deacon) hath a ſword alſo to fight with: howbeit, the ſword of the ſpirit only,Chryſ. in ep. ad philip. hom. 2. that is, the word of God, a meete weapon for the miniſters of Chriſt thereby to ſtrike their enemies, and to defend themſelues.The miniſters weapō Ephſ. 6.17. And to take away all colour of that vſurped power which the Lorde did foreſee
they would in time affixe to Peters authoritie, hee ſharpely rebuked Peter, becauſe hee had drawen a ſword, Mat 26.52. and commaunded him to put it vp into the ſheath.Bern. de conſideration. ad Eugenium. Com. ſuper decr. Car. d. 10. c. Quoniam. This thing Bernard the Abbot well noted, and therefore when Pope Eugenius, whom the Romanes had expelled, would for that iniurie in all haſt be reuenged with the temporal ſword, calling them ſerpents, dragons, & beaſts, he aduiſed his holineſſe to vſe more moderation, writing vnto him (among other things) thus: Aggredere verbo, ſed non ferro: that is: Set on them with the word, but not with the ſword. Againe he ſaid: If thou wilt haue both the ſwordes, thou ſhalt haue neither of them, declaring thereby that his right weapō was the word of god, & not the Emperours ſword, and that it was all vnmeete for him to vſe thē both. Howbeit, theſe mal-contented perſons, taking on them the guide of others, as the very miniſters of Antichriſt,
Antonin. par. 3. tit. 22. ca. 5. de max. pont. papa.
Aug. Selenchus de primatu. do endeuour to ſeduce & leade away the ignorant ſoules from God to the deuill. And this that they may the ſooner contriue & compaſſe, they be incited & prouoked by the father of lies, not only to extol and aduance the Biſhop of Rome aboue al other Biſhops, patriarks, & miniſters of the word, and intitle him the vniuerſal Pope, In the twelfth yeare of King Iohn, the 2. legates of the Pope did aſſoile all Engliſh men of their homages to their king. So Pius quintus the Pope entending the ſame ſent his Romiſh Bull the vicar of Chriſt, the ſucceſſor of Peter, but alſo to prefer the ſame biſhop to all kings and Emperors, yea, to al the angels of God. To his holineſſe they labor to draw away the minds and harts of al ſubiects frō their lawful princes, and to take away al obedience of the members of Chriſt from their true head, who in regard of the popes honor, are promiſed by him to be aſſoiled, not only of al homages, ſeruices and fealties that they owe, and by the word of God and their owne oaths, are bound to yeeld, & to do vnto their lawful kings, princes, and gouernors, but alſo from their obedience to the Goſpel,
in ſuch ſort as they do,into England by Iohn Feltō, the which he placed on the Biſhop of Lō dons gate, importing the excommunicating & depoſing of the Queenes maieſtie, and other trayterous conſpiracies againſt her highneſſe perſon. Deut. 17. Mal. 2.7. which labor to pul away ſoules from God to the deuil. And they wold, if they could, draw down thoſe Saints that be placed with the Lord in heauen, and ſet them not only thrals on earth to ſerue to their madneſſe, but alſo with the deuill in the depth of hell.

3 It is true, that the prieſts mouth ſhal keep wiſdome: that the people are to enquire the law at his mouth: that the apoſtles be ſēt forth into al the world to preach the goſpel to euery creature, that they be the miniſters of Chriſt & diſpoſers of the ſecrets of God, & that they are in their places to be heard, reuerenced & double honored of al them to whō the benefit of their functions and labors do appertaine: howbeit, that the prieſt haue bin preferred in authority to their kings, & that biſhops haue gouerned, Act. 1.26. Rom. 10.15. 1. Tim. 5.17. or may lawfully gouerne & beare rule in al things aboue emperors and princes, it cānot be proued in holy ſcriptures, but the contrary is found. Aaron the prieſt was his time moſt beautiful, hauing that right Vrim & Thummim, Prieſts are not preferred to princes in the word of God. he ſhined in knowledge, perfectiō, & glory, wherin therfore hee might be preferred to al the prieſts that ſucceeded him, vnto the time of Chriſt, yet did he not exalt himſelfe in gouernment before Moſes, Moſes was preferred to Aaron. who in that reſpect, was glorious before Aaron. Moſes was not only the prince and Lord of the people, but the prince & lord of Aaron too, notwithſtāding that only in ye prieſthood, being his peculiar office, Aaron did excel. Moſes apointed & ſubſtituted vnder him iudges & officers in their places: he alſo anointed Aarō ye
prieſt & filled his hād with the book of the law, Exod. 28.41. & ful ſacrifices to be offred to the lord. And, as touching the authority and office of either of thē in their places, the lord ſaid to Moſes, Thou ſhalt ſpeake vnto him, that is, Exo. 4.15 16. to Aarō. & put the words in his mouth. Again, he ſhalbe vnto
the people, as thy mouth or ſpokſman, and thou ſhalt be vnto him Lelohim, for God: that is to ſay, thou ſhalt be his prince or captain, or a wiſe coūſeller & ful of the ſpirit of God,1. Sam. 10.6.9. (for indeed the Lord furniſheth and beautifieth the right godly Princes and Magiſtrates with many rare ornaments and diuine gifts, far before other perſons.) So likewiſe in another place God ſaide to Moſes: Lo, I haue made thee Pharaos God, and Aaron thy brother ſhall be thy Prophet. Which Rabbi Abraham thus expoundeth.Act. 7.1. Thou ſhalt appeare before Pharao like an Angell in dignitie, and Aaron ſhall be thine interpreter: then not his head, nor his king. Beſides this,
Aaron ſubmitted himſelf to Moſes.
Exo. 32.24 when Aaron had offended about the Calfe that was made, and perceiued that Moſes was very angry for the ſame, he hūbly ſubmitted himſelf, & ſaid: Let not Adoni, my Lord, or my Maiſter, be angrie. This was in thoſe dayes when the Prieſt was moſt glorious in his place, & to whom al the reſt in ſucceſsion ſhould be conformed. Deut. 17.15 2. Cro. 29.20.23. Moreouer, that the Prieſts haue bin placed by their Kings, and that they haue beene ſubiect vnto them in all things next vnto God, and that they haue not beene preferred before their Kings and Princes at any time, in rule, power, and dignitie, in the dayes of Ioſophat, Hezekiah, Ioſiah, Dauid, Solomon, and ſuch other, the Hiſtories of thoſe times do ſufficiently witneſſe. According to the which, and after the writings and examples of Peter, Paul, & the ancient fathers, as well in the prime as in the chiefe ſway of the church, the lawful prince enioied his authoritie, he was chiefly heard & obeyed in al things next vnder God: and that, whenſoeuer the Biſhops, prieſts, and miniſters of the word neglected their offices, and offended againſt God and the lawes, it apperteined
to their Prince to reproue them, to correct them: to whoſe Cenſure, they haue bene likewiſe contented to ſubmit themſelues, after that example of Aaron, who yeelded himſelfe to Moſes.
Fabian. Cornelius. Biſhops of Rome. Greg. B. of Rome, ſubmitteth him ſelfe to the Emperour. L • . 3. ep. 61. ad Maurie lib. 3. ep. 64. Thus Fabian and Cornelius, both Biſhops of Rome, ſubmitted their liues to Decius the Emperour: So Gregorie the firſt of that name, was contented to ſubmit himſelfe vnto the Emperour Mauritius, whoſe humble ſeruant he called himſelfe, and granted himſelfe obedient to his commandement. And further he ſaid in a certaine Epiſtle, that Chriſt had giuen power to the Emperour to beare rule, not onely ouer ſouldiers, but ouer Prieſtes alſo. This was a litle before the time that Boniface the third aſpired to the Popedome. And long after this, Pope Leo 2. yeelded himſelf vnto Lewes the Emperor,Leo. 2. q. 7. Nos ſi. and ſaid, that alſo al others vnder his iuriſdiction, ſhould be iudged by his Maieſtie, for the correction and redreſſe of all faults and diſorders, knowing well, that the Emperour was in authoritie the next vnto God, and leſſe then God only:Tert. ad Scapul. For ſo (ſaith Tertullian) is the Emperour greater then all men, while he is leſſe then the only true God.

4. This is that chiefe Power (indeed) to whom the charge of all the people is principally committed. The obedience to this power, the Apoſtle calleth a good-worke: but they that obey not, do cōtemne this good-worke, and are contrary to the will of God. 1. Tim. 3.
Peter the Apoſtle ſaith: Submit your ſelues to all manner Ordinances of man, for the Lords ſake: he ſpeaketh this,1. Pet. 2.13.17. as well to Biſhops and Miniſters, as to others: and he ſheweth the preheminence of the Prince before all others, when he addeth: Eite Baſileî, ôs Hupereconti. VVhether it bee vnto the King, as hauing the preheminence:
either vnto Rulers, as vnto them that are ſent of him. And this he ſhutteth vp with this reaſon. For ſo is the will of God. 2. Chro. 24.20.23.24. He ſaith againe, Feare God, honour the King. And this is according to that example of the prieſts, Leuites, and the people of the olde time, being obedient to the cōmandement of their kings.There is none example in the ſcripture for the popes ſupremacie. If in all the holy Bible, there were any ſuch pregnant example, teſtimonie, or argument, for the defence of the Supremacie of the Pope aboue the emperour, and of other clergie men aboue their lawfull Princes, oh God, how they would triumph then! But we finde not any ſuch matter, and therefore their courage might ſoone bee allayed, if they were not too impudent. Moreouer, it cannot be denied, but that many wiſe and godly Kings and Princes haue gladly preferred and aduaunced beyond ſome others, many learned, wiſe, graue, and diuine Prophets, Biſhops, and miniſters of the worde, for their owne better inſtruction, counſaile, and comfort.Grat. ca. 24. quaeſt. 1. offic. Howbeit, that therefore the Biſhop of Rome onely ſhould bee preferred to all Kings and Princes in the world, aduanced aboue all other Biſhops in the Church, yea, and exalted indignitie beyonde the Angelles of GOD, (as if hee were very God.
Anton. in parte 3. Sum. maior. ti. 22. c. 2. de poteſt. papae.
E • . ca. 3. de Iur. & 4. de poteſta. clauium, & ca. 5. de. maxima poteſtate papae. ) Surely all the reaſons that Antonine and others whatſoeuer, haue yet produced for the confirmation thereof, are weake and friuolous. There hath beene no little adoo to contriue and bring this to paſſe, that the Biſhop of Rome ſhould be the onely head of all other Biſhoppes and Prieſtes, and that the Church of Rome ſhould be the mother of al other Churches.

Great contention aroſe and continued betweene the Biſhoppes of Conſtantinople and Rome, about
theſe matters, for an hundred and twelue yeeres at the leaſt, vntill that in the ende, Boniface the third of that name, a man too ambicious and craftie,Phocas made the biſhop of Rome ſupreme head aboue all other Biſhops. obtayned the preheminence vnder that bloudie Phocas, (which had a little before killed his Lorde and Maiſter Mauritius the Emperour, with his wife and children, and ſo gotten poſſeſsion of the empire) about the yeere of our Lorde 605. A very meete authour for ſo godly a practiſe, which hath alſo in none other wiſe beene continued, then it firſt commenced and tooke his originall, that is to ſay,Vrſpergenſis in Phoca. Sabellicus. li 6. M. Palmerius. by cruelty, murther, and hypocriſie, to the finall ruin and decay of the Emperours honour and eſtate.

5. If this authoritie bee fathered on Saint Peter, who ſeeth not how farre they go aſtray from all truth, and that they would alſo dazle the eies of them which ſee full cleerely?The authoritie of the Pope cannot be fathered on S. Peter If Peter had beene the cheefe among the Apoſtles in order, yet who can prooue that hee was ſo in office? And if hee had beene preferred to all the other Apoſtles both in order and office, (as wee finde it not, but rather that he was onely equall with them) yet, who can iuſtly ſay, that Peter was ordained of Chriſt to bee the vniuerſall head of the Church, that Peter hadde authoritie giuen him to make the Biſhoppes of Rome cheefe Biſhops ouer all others by continuall ſucceſsion: that Peter himſelfe was at Rome, and was the Biſhoppe of that Cittie, and that hee dyed at Rome. Surely all theſe things they ſhall neuer bee able to prooue. But if they coulde prooue all, yet with what face preſume they to extoll theyr Pope aboue Kings, Princes, Emperours? It is certaine, that Chriſt Ieſus commaunded his Apoſtle Peter to
paie tribute to the Emperour, and commaunded that Caeſar ſhould haue his due: Saint Paul in many places exhorteth men to be obedient to the Emperour, and Ordinances:1. Pet. 5.2.2. and S. Peter hath not only taught ſubmiſsiō to the ſame as before is ſaid: but alſo ſharply reproued them, that, being placed in the Church, would ſeek to gouerne and rule ouer their brethren, as Lords of the Heathen.Lact. de diui. praemio, li. 7. cap. 25. But the Pope, notwithſtanding this, being aduaunced by craftie, indirect, and diuelliſh meanes, far aboue his worthineſſe, as that Tyrant, which of all others is to be deteſted and abhorred, (as it ſhall be further plainly prooued) doth vſurpe dominion ouer all Biſhops & Churches, and aboue all Princes & people, in ſuch tyrannical ſort, as yet neuer any Tytan or Heatheniſh Tirant hath don, ſit hence the creatiō of the world. And ſurely, ſo both Paul, and alſo Peter, would boldly tel him to his face, if they were now liuing on the earth.Phocas. Boniface 3. When Phocas for his owne ſafetie, profite, and glorie, yeelded to this, that Boniface the Biſhop of Rome, ſhould be the chiefe Biſhop of the world, hee litle thought of the inconuenience that would grow thereof: or, if hee had thought thereon, yet regarded hee rather his owne preſent honour and gaine, then the good of them that ſucceeded him. And albeit, that the Germane Emperor Otho. 1. had giuen his oath,Otho. 1. Platina. Pope Ioh. 13. and made faire promiſes to Pope Ioh. 13. to bee dutifull and beneficiall to him and his Church, vppon this condition, that he would be a meanes that hee might be receiued into Rome, and there crowned Emperor, with the title of Auguſtus: yet, when afterward he ſaw the pride of the Pope, and conſidered into what thraldome he had caſt himſelfe, hee could hardly beare it
in the time of Pope Iohn: but afterward, perceiuing that Benedict the 5. which ſucceeded Iohn, Benedict 5. Summa. Conc. fol. 320. would not willingly yeeld & ſurrender one inch vnto the Emperour, of that which his predeceſſour had arrogated, he made no more of the matter, but quite expelled him the Sea, and conſtrained the Cleargie to admit and receiue Leo 8. into his place.Leo 5. Otho. 3. Grego. 6. R. Reynold de vit. imparat. The like minde reteined Otho 3. who hauing preferred Gregorie 6. to the See, and hearing that Iohn had expelled him, and vſurped by the counſell of one Creſcentius, he leuied an Armie, entred into Italie, tooke Rome, killed Creſcentius, put out the eyes of the vſurper, and reſtored Gregorie againe.

6. Although the Nicene Councel (for orders ſake,
Nicen. Con. ca. 6.7. d. 65. quoniam. & Mos antiq. Item. in Antioc. Con. ca. 9. q. 3. d. 6. per ſing.
Hier. ad Euge. d • ſt. 93. ca. Olim. & for the better gouernment of the Church) thoght it right good, and permitted that Metropolitanes and Arch-biſhops ſhould bee placed in and ouer diuers prouinces: yet was not that in any other meaning, but that neuertheleſſe, euery Church ſhould reteine and enioy it owne honour. But that one man ſhould bee exalted in the Church aboue all Patriarkes, Biſhops, Miniſters, yea, aboue all Kings and Caeſars in the world, to whom only all perſons of whatſoeuer eſtate, condition or order, ſhould yeeld and obey, as to their vniuerſall and Supreme head, the ſaid Councell neuer gaue one lote of conſent. There wer conſtituted 3. Patriarkes in the 3 parts of ye world: Aſia, Affrica, Europa, & the B. of Rome was, but as one of the three Patriarkes. Eccle. hiſt. In this Councell was the Biſhop of Rome numbred among the Patriarkes, as one of them, but not aboue any one of them. And it was decreed, that hee ſhould haue no greater authoritie nor iuriſdiction in his owne Prouince, then either the Patriarke of Antioch, had in his Prouince, or that the Patriarke of Alexandria had in his Prouince. And beſides that, if he did not perform
his dutie in his place, that he ſhould be reputed for neither a prieſt nor a patriarke. The great Aphrican councell worthily reiected the proud petition of that ambitious Prelate of Conſtantinople, Aphrican Conc. apad Carthag. which ſought to exalt himſelfe ſo contrarie to the word of God, and expreſſely decreed, that the Biſhop of that See, though he firſt ſpake in ſundrie Councels, and vſed to take the firſt ſeate in the congregation, ſhould not (for all that) be called Princeps Sacerdotum, aut Summus Sacerdos, aut aliquid huiuſmodi, that is,Diſt. 99.
the Prince of Prieſtes, or the cheefe Biſhoppe, or by any like title, but onely the biſhop of the firſt See. Neither, that the Biſhop of Rome ſhould bee called the Vniuerſall Pope or high Prieſt. And thereunto Gratian addeth the wordes of Pelagius, Pelag. to all other Biſhops. Nullus Patriarcharum, Vniuerſalitis vocabulo vnquam vtatur: The title of vniuerſall pope or biſhop was odious in thoſe daies. quiaſi ſummus patriarcha vniuerſalis dicitur, Patriarcharum nomen caeteris derogatur, Sed abſit hoc a fidelibus, hoc ſibi velle quempiam arripere. Let not any one of the Patriarkes (ſaith hee) at anytime take on him the name of Vniuerſalitie: for if the cheefe Patriarke ſhould bee called the vniuerſall Patriarke, the name of Patriarke woulde bee taken away from all other. But God forbid that any Chriſtian man ſhould be willing to take on him this title.

Aug. li. 3. ca. 3. de baptiſmo contra Donatiſt. Neque enim quiſque noſtrum, &c. And Auguſtine againſt the Donatiſts to that ende, reciteth the wordes of Cyprian, ſpoken in the Councell of Carthage: for neyther hath any of vs (ſaith hee) made himſelfe a Biſhop of Biſhoppes, or a cheefe Biſhop, nor conſtrained our fellow brethren to the neceſsitie of obedience with a tyrannicall feare.

Gregor. 1. withſtood this title. Epiſt. 35. ad Ioan. epiſ. Conſtantinop.
et epiſt. 38. li. 4.
in An, dom. 590.
Gregorie alſo (ſometimes Biſhop of Rome) verie ſharpely reprooued Iohn the Biſhop of Conſtantinople,
for that hee preſumed to vſurpe this Title, well neere a thouſande yeares ago, and ſayde in an epiſtle which hee wrote to him, that the King of Pride, namely Antichriſt, was neere. Moreouer, hee reprooued Eulogius the Patriarke of Alexandra, for that in the preface of an epiſtle which hee had written vnto him, hee called him the Vniuerſall Pope, hee charged him to doo no more ſo, for that his deſire was to proſper and excell in vertues, and not in Titles. Neither accounted hee that thing to bee to himſelfe an honor, wherein hee acknowledged that his brethren did looſe their honour.

7 Howbeit, they would willingly recure this deepe wounde that Gregorie hath giuen them that ſo proudely aſpire: but how? Note (ſaith one) the humilitie of Gregorie, whiles he reprehendeth the Patriarke of Alexandria:Comment. ſuper, decret card. Alex. d. 96. Ecce. hee might haue added▪ marke the ambition of our Popes, which impudently aſpire and aduaunce themſelues not onely in all titles of worldly glorie: but alſo in all power, rule, and dominion ouer their Churches, aboue Kings, Princes, Emperours, and all that is called GOD. Hee ſayth not ſo, but Note Gregories humilitie: yet thus he ſayth. Inſtruit Gregorius ad humilitatem Romanos Pontifices, Hee teacheth the Romane Biſhops humilitie.

And heereof was it,The Pope is called a ſeruant, yet holdeth hee authoritie aboue kings that the Pope (though fore againſt his will) yeelded to bee called Seruus Seruorum Dei, and to call the other Biſhoppes brethren. But ſo accepted, partly for the conformitie of Name, as Chriſt called his Apoſtles
his brethren, and ſaid that himſelfe was their ſeruant: partly, for the equalitie of merit: and partly, for the condignitie of order (as they ſay) and not in any wiſe concerning the authoritie of iuriſdiction, which yet he reteineth wholy to himſelfe. But yet, Gregorie him ſelfe made it not ſo light a matter, as that the gloſſe or glaunce of a Commentor, or any ſuch accidentall tytles (for onely ſhewes) could appeaſe ſo mightie a tempeſt. For he ſaid plainly, and denounced it with no ſmall vehemencie of words and geſture, that the tytle of Vniuerſall Biſhop, was A proud, a ſacrilegious, a prophane, and an Antichristian Name. And hee ſaide moreouer, that whoſoeuer taketh on him that name, he is
Grego. his opinion of this Title: Vniuerſal Pope.
Nomen arrogans, ſacrilegum, profanum, Antichriſtianum eſt.
This Gregory ſpake whē the B. of Conſtan. would be ſo called: & therin he prophefied of the Pop. of Rome, that after him ſhould indeed ariſe and be that very Antichriſt, whoſe forerunner this B of Conſtant. was, as this title declared him, by the teſtimony of Gregory: About the yeare of our Lord, 600. Aeneid. li. 3.
the Prince of Pride Lucifer, an Apoſtate, and the heraulde of Antichriſt.
