Theſe wordes hee vttered at what time Mauritius the Emperour would that the Biſhop of Conſtantinople ſhould be entituled (as hee would be indeed) the Vniuerſall Pope. As if he would haue ſaid in a word: This is Monſtrum & portentum Mundi, That Monſter, and only miſcreant of the worlde. Neither hath Platina letted ſo to entitle ſome of the Romane Sea, in regard of their Satanicall doctrines, and abhominable liues: as vnto whom, that hobling verſe which ſometimes Vigil compoſed of that huge Cyclops (a verie ſemblable Monſter) may not vnaptly be applied, howſoeuer the Poet ſeemeth by way of propheſie to point at this perſon.

8 And as he hath beene intituled,Papa. ſo hath hee reuealed himſelfe to all the world in the time appointed. At the ſight wherof, men may call him, as well worthie, not Pappas which is a father: but may well ſay of him with admiration in his owne language, Papae, noua figura oris: Beholde that ſtraunge and newe formed thing, ſuch, as the like was neuer ſeene before! And ſo is he tearmed by ſome of his owne, Admirabilis Papa, & ſtupormundi. The Pope admirable, Iohn Ianuen. Peter Egid. in dict. Papa. Anorlicus. VVhat is ment by a monſter.
and the wonder of the worlde. That is called a monſter, which either much differeth from Nature, or that which is farre degenerated from the natural forme. But lo; what can bee more ſtraunge, and further off from the nature of a true Chriſtian, then that a man profeſsing Chriſtianitie, ſhould (in contempt of the worde of God, and of all holie Religion) chalenge, exact, and vſurpe among Chriſtians an vngodlie power, both ouer the Church, and the Common wealth, with more then a tyrannicall or heatheniſh force? Is not hee therefore a Moſter? VVhat can bee more monſtrous, then that a man ſhoulde bee metamorphoſed from an humble perſon, to a proude tyrant: from a father of peace, to a worker of warres: from a patterne of honeſtie, to a myrrour of luxurie? to bee chaunged, from a meeke ſheepe, to a rauening woolfe: to be turned from godlineſſe to Atheiſme: from Chriſtianitie to Epicuriſme: from the childe of God, to a member of the deuill? If the light become darkeneſſe, Alas, howe great is that darkeneſſe? What huſbandman, woulde not wonder, that after his great labour, the beſt Grape that he planted, ſhould yeelde him ſowre Grapes, and the cleaneſt ſeede that
he ſowed in his field ſhould bee ouercome with tares?Amongſt whō Antichriſt was borne. Eraſ. in 1. Iohn 2. And who can but maruaile, that Antichriſt, that is, a perſon contrarie to Chriſt in life, in doctrine, and ſtudies, ſhoulde haue beene begotten, conceiued, borne, and brought vp in the Church among them (before all others) that profeſſed the holie Religion of Ieſus Chriſt? If the holie Apoſtles, and Diſciples of our Lorde wondred not a little when they perceiued by the doctrine of Chriſt, that the Scribes and Phariſees, which were ſaide to ſitte in Moſes Chaire, did verie little or nothing reſemble Moſes: but rather were contrarie to him in their liues, doctrines, and ſtudies: then worthilie may wee wonder at this Vniuerſall perſon, which is ſayde to ſitte in Peters Chaire, and is called the Vicar of Christ: when wee ſee, that hee is ſo contrarie to Peter, as euer Simon Magus was, (except onely in this, that he denied his Maiſter; woulde haue hindered his Maiſter; did ſleepe when he ſhoulde haue watched in his curious noting of Iohn; and in ſuch other his ſinnes and imperfections) yea, and ſo contrarie to Chriſt, as Iudas was, which betraid him? Chriſt ſaid of Iudas, that hee was a diuell, though Iudas came to kiſſe him: and hee called Simon Peter, Satan, and commanded him back behind him, when he would haue hindered him in the performance of his dutie. Now, what to iudge of ſuch a perſon, which reſembleth the Iewes in their hypocriſie, and Iudas in his treacherie, & Simon in his worldly deuiſes, & Magus in his ſorceries, we may reſolue without long deliberatiō, hauing throughly viewed the image of his counterfet holy life, and ſo we may call him a monſter in deed.

9 Againe,The Pope teacheth a contrary doctrine & law. what place hath the doctrine of Chriſt in that new formed perſons mind? what more oppugneth the law and the goſpel, then his erronious and falſe gloſſes, decrees, Canons, traditions, doctrines? Chriſt teacheth Truth: but the Pope diuulgateth vnwritten fables and lies. Chriſt requireth faith to iuſtification: but the Pope extolleth mans merits. Chriſt preacheth peace, charitie, brotherlie loue: but the Pope moueth vp diſcord, wrath, hatred, wars, murthers. Chriſt commandeth vs to be obedient to the law of God: but the Popes folowing the hypocriticall Phariſee, maketh void the law of God, through his owne traditions. Chriſt expreſly forbiddeth, that any man ſhould either ad vnto the word of God, or withdraw any thing frō the ſame: but the Pope moſt preſumptuouſly nowe addeth,Irenaeus. li. 4. ca. 25. de tradit. ſen. now detracteth, & thereof giueth ſuch interpretations, as his owne fantaſie affoordeth, as the ancient heretikes haue accuſtomed to do. Chriſt cōmanded his apoſtles and diſciples, to ſearch the ſcriptures, to write vnto the churches, to preach the Goſpel to all creatures, & to publiſh that opēly, which he taught them in ſecret: but the Pope forbiddeth the tranſlation of the Bible into diuerſe tongs, wherin the people may read the ſame: hee inhibiteth the preaching of the goſpel, & ſhutteth out the people of God frō the reading, hearing, and cōferring of the ſcriptures and word of God: & imitating that vngodly Antiochus king of Graecia, and that prophane Iulian the Apoſtate: he ſtraitly chargeth, that the cōmon people ſhall neither reade, nor write, nor talke, nor ſing, of Religion, or of anie part of the worde of God, excluding them out from all participation of
thoſe holie myſteries and precious iewels, as dogs, and ſwine, making houocke of Chriſtian people, whom he proffereth to Satan to bee led blindfold into errours and damnation. Our Sauiour Chriſt hath both by his worde taught, and by his owne example commended vnto his Apoſtles, and Diſciples, 1. Theſ. 2.4. all due obedience to Princes, and a willing ſubiection to all manner Ordinaunces of man for the Lordes ſake: But the Pope, exalting himſelfe aboue all that is called GOD, bindeth all Kinges and Caeſars, to yeelde and ſubmit themſelues to his Cenſures, to bee ruled by his Canones, and Decrees, to followe his deuiſes, his Traditions, his Councels, his Lawes, yea, to kiſſe his foote, and to humble themſelues vnder his footeſtoole. A ſpeciall note of Antichrist, in that hee exalteth himſelfe aboue Kinges, and Princes, which in regarde of their high place and dignitie next vnto GOD, are called goddes. Finallie, Christ hath taught and commended vnto vs, all Chriſtian vertues, as faſting, prayer, humilitie, chaſtitie, holineſſe, religion, and the true worſhippe of GOD in this worlde:The Pope vnder pretence of Religion, ouerthroweth all religion. but the Pope beeing choked with that ſubitle euill, that ſecret poyſon, that hidden venom, that ſhew of vertue, that moath of holineſſe, I meane hypocriſie, vnder a cruel Art, he heweth downe vertue, with vertues ſword: vnder a ſhew of faſting, he ouerthroweth the true faſt: vnder colour of prayer, he aboliſheth all holy inuocation: vnder the name of humilitie, he foſtereth the hautieſt pride: vnder a ſhadow of virginitie, he baniſheth all chaſtitie: vnder the title of holineſſe, he practiſeth all abhomination:
vnder the faire face of Religion, hee aſſayeth to throw downe all Religion: and vnder the profeſſion of Chriſtianitie, hee perſecuteth Chriſt in his members. Is this that Succeſſour of Peter? is this that Seruant of the ſeruants of God? is this the right Vicar of Chriſt? Nay rather, this is the perſecuter of Peter: this is that abhominable Tyrant, the which (as Lactantius once ſaide) onely imagineth miſchiefes, Lanct. de dion praem: li: 7. ca. 25.
and baniſheth that light which ſuſtaineth the world: this is that Antichrist pointed at by Saint Iohn, Apoc. 13. Therefore we may thus argue and conclude againſt him.

VVho ſo is moſt contrarie to Chriſt in doctrine, in ſtudies, in life, eſpecially of them that pretend the greateſt holineſſe, and are chiefeſt in the profeſſion of Chriſtianitie, the ſame is that Antichriſt. Apoc. 13.

p.hi: But the Biſhoppe of Rome, amongſt all them which ſhew the greatest holineſſe, and are cheefeſt in the profeſſion of chriſtianitie, is moſt contrarie to Chriſt in his Doctrine, in his ſtudies, in his life.

div.p: Ergo, the Biſhoppe of Rome is that Antichriſt. The Maior cannot bee denied: and the Minor is ſufficiently proued by that which hath been in this chapter produced. Therefore they alſo that ſtriue to ſupport him, are the very miniſters of Antichriſt, as their owne Gregorie would tell them,Greg. li 4. Epiſt. 30. & 38. if hee yet liued among them.

10. And it is likely enough that the ancient Sibyle, whom Lactantius remembreth, expoſtulating the olde Graecians for their Idolatrie, in the exaltation and worſhip of earthy Tyrants in the place of God, did therein alſo by the way of propheſie, point at them and their folly, which extoll, proppe vp, and honour this monſter.

q.l: O Graece: thy Gods of Tytanes proude
what mean'ſt thou thus to faine?
VVhy dedicateſt thou thy gifts
to dead men thus in vaine?
To Idols thou doſt ſacrifice,
Alas: what furie brought
This erroer in? the great Gods Law
the whiles contemn'd for nought!

div.p: Pſal. 12.9. But this is moſt certain, that the holy Pſalmiſt accounteth the Children of men moſt worthy of rebuke and ſhame, for the exaltation of ſuch vngodly perſons. And the Lord God himſelfe deriding their follie, and abhorring, their great madneſſe, feedeth them with wormewood, and drencheth them with the water of bitter gall. The tempeſt of the Lord goeth forth againſt them in his wrath, & a violent whirle-wind falleth down vpon their heades. Ier 23.15. And this haue they gotten for their reward in the ſetting vp and defending of this their Idoll. It ſhal be good for them therefore, who haue bin dreanched with thoſe venemous dregges of the fornication of Antichriſt, to forſake him in ſeaſon, to purge out the venemous humours of their abhominations, by a true repentance, in the bloud of Chriſt, and henceforth yeeld themſelues obedient to God, and dutifull to his annointed (our moſt Soueraigne Princeſſe) in all gratitude and right contentation, and that before they feele the intollerable effect of the heauy curſe of almightie God, and be conſtrained to beare theyr open reproach and ſhame among men.

div.head: CHAP. V.
The Biſhoppe of Rome is yet more plainely deciphered to bee that very Antichriſt which was reuealed to Saint Iohn. Apoca. 13.
div.p:
THe Biſhop of Rome (as before it is declared) making the greateſt ſhew of holines in the world, as if he were not only a Saint, or the ſon of God, but euen God himſelfe: hath entitled himſelfe with many holy, high, & wonderful names, and ſet himſelf fourth, as one moſt ready and beſt able to helpe and relieue the Church of Chriſt, both in the world & out of the world at euerie need: Howbeit, when he is thorowly conſidered of, and wiſely obſerued touching his doctrine, his ſtudies and his conuerſation, the former ſemblance and ſhew of high holineſſe, ſhall bee ſo ſhadowed and blemiſhed in his perſon, that nothing ſhall be found inhabiting and reſting within him indeede, beſides deepe hypocriſies, great abhominations, and horrible ſins. And that this faire ſhew of Angelicall holines is nothing elſe, but a guile to deceiue the Saints of God, as the Woolfe which is cladde in ſheepes clothing, the ſooner to take and deuour the ſeely ſheep. But as the rauening woolfe be wrayeth himſelfe by his voyce, by the maner of his feeding, and by other woluiſh euil qualities, to be no ſheep, but a wolfe, an enemy to the ſheepe: euen ſo I ſay again, hath the Biſhop of Rome ſufficiently deciphered
himſelfe by his falſe doctrine, by his diuelliſh practiſes, and his abhominable life, behauior, and fruits, what he is indeede, that is to ſay, that very Antichriſt, to the horrour and dreade of all Chriſtians. Neither were al men ſo blinde in the time of his appearance,Ioh. Hus in An. Dom. 1415. but that by many of them he was plainely perceiued and abandoned. When Iohannes Hus in his time had founde him, he could not bee ſilent: and when Eraſmus had deſcried him, he pointed at him directly with his finger,Eraſmus. as who would ſay, I haue deſcried that hidious monſter, and lo there he ſitteth in the Temple of God,Th • y eſpied. Antichriſt, as a God. Hauing ſpoken of the dignitie of Chriſt our high prieſt, hee ſayth, Cum huius dignitate, compone vnius Templi Pontificem, qui Sacerdotium vnius anni, Inparaph raſ. In marc. 1 1.
ab impio rege turpi precio redemerit. Confer nudum Ieſu caput, cum huius auro gemmiſque Lucente Tiara. VVith the dignitie of Chriſt, compare a Biſhop of one Temple, which hath bought a prieſtood laſting but for one yeere, of a wicked King, for a filthie ſum of money. Compare the bare head of Ieſus, with his tyre or Myter, all gliſtering and ſhining with gold and precious ſtones, &c. But when that Martine Luther in the ſame age,Luther. being about one hundred yeares after Iohn Hus, and in the yeere of our Lorde 1515, had eſpied the Romiſh iniquitie,Bulleng. in Apoc. 11. heming. Euchir: ca. 10. de Ordine. Ecclae. hee did not onely point at, and diſcouer him, but alſo very earneſtly thencefoorth purſued him in hoate chace, maugre the loud lowing of all Romiſh Bulles, and the madde malice of Apollyon that deſtroying Diuell.

And thus haue Iohn VVickliffe, and Zuinglius, and Ochinus, and Bucer, and Bullenger, and Munſter, and Caluine, with many other right learned and famous men in the Church, iudged of the Biſhop of
Rome, and written agaynſt his abhominations, nothing fearing to depaint him forth as that Antichriſt ſo much ſpoken of, and to purſue him to the death, with the moſt profounde Arguments of Gods worde. Neither may we thinke that anie of thoſe men before named, haue beene the firſt Authours of this opinion: but that Irenaeus, and Arnulphus, and other holie Martyrs and Fathers of the Church, which liued full manie yeares before them, haue in theyr tymes conſidered and after a ſort reuealed the ſame: whoſe wordes and teſtimonies thereof here to write, woulde bee too tedious, and to no purpoſe, beeing by others alreadie ſo often and plainly noted.

Moreouer, it is certaine, that Baptista Mantuan, Laurentius Valla, Franciſcus Petrarchus, Marſilius Patauinus, Hieronimus Sauanorola, and Ioachim Abbas, who ledde theyr lyues in the Citie of Rome, euen in the face of the Pope, and his Cardinalles, and were ſometymes partakers of the ſame fayth and Religion, haue in theyr wrytings much complayned of the wickedneſſe of the Church, and did not onelie vnder certaine ſimilitudes, and darke ſpeeches couertlie, but alſo ſometimes in plaine tearmes openlie declare to the VVorlde▪ that Antichriſt reigned in the ſucceſsion of the Popes, or among the Biſhoppes of that Sea. And of this wee alſo are not ignoraunt, that from the Popes holineſſe, there is gone foorth a farre greater hypocriſie into all the worlde, then that which went foorth from the Prophets of Ieruſalem into all the lande of Iuda.
Ior. 23.15. Howbeeit the moſt part of all men (hauing
their eyes enchaunted with his ſorceries, and their hearts hardened through vnbeleefe) can neither feele, nor perceiue ſuch a thing, vntill that they, with the Kings of the earth, and earthlie minded men, haue deepelie pledged him in the venemous dregges of his fornications.

666 The number of the beaſt.2 Others alſo hauing good vnderſtanding, haue reckoned the number of the beaſt, and haue founde it to bee (as Iohn ſaide) Arithmos Anthropou, The number of man, that is to ſay, either ſuch a number as may bee by mans reaſon vnderſtoode, or ſuch a number, as concerneth man, as that Antichriſt ſhoulde bee a man, or in and among men. And that his iuſt number is, ſixe hundred ſixtie and ſixe. In the which number indeede is contained, not onelie the Time when Antichriſt ſhoulde bee borne, when he ſhoulde be reuealed, and how long he ſhould raigne in his might and great pompe: but alſo the nation, the place, the pride, the ingenie, the power, and nature of Antichriſt.

How to reckon the number of the beaſt.Some haue taken the time to commence, from the Conception of Chriſt, and from thence to bee reckoned vnto the yeare of our Lorde, 666. And this reaſon they haue for it, that as euerie vertue hath to it a vice oppoſed, and agaynſt the light is ſet the darkeneſſe: ſo Chriſt findeth his Antichriſt.Chriſt and Antichriſt are in the world at one time. Chriſt was no ſooner conceiued by the holie Ghoſt, but by and by Antichriſt was conceiued by the ſpirite of the Diuell: the one in the wombe of the Virgine: the other in the hearts of worldly men.

Indeede, it is true, if this place bee vnderſtoode of that generall Antichriſt. For there is not onelie a Christ, to ſaue, but alſo an Antichrist to deſtroy, as the ſeede of the woman, and the ſeede of the Serpent. But it is certaine, that Saint Iohn by prophecie poynteth at ſome ſpeciall and notable Antichriſt to come afterwarde.Bul. in Apo. 13. con. 611 Aret. in. apo. 13. And in that reſpect, the learned haue taken the ſupputation of the time from the Reuelation of this myſterie to Saint Iohn in the Iſle of Pathmos, the which was (after the iudgement of Irenaeus) in the latter time of Domitian the Emperour, who was a mightie perſecutour of the Chriſtian Religion, and a contemner of Chriſt.A Chriſte nat. anno. 97. ad anno. 764. And this was (as Euſebius ſayeth in his Chronicles) about nintie and ſeauen yeares after the Natiuitie of Chriſt. Nowe from thence, if yee reckon 666. yeares, that is to ſay, vnto the yeare of our Lorde 764,The begetting conceiuing, &c. of Antichriſt. and diuide thoſe yeares into ſixe ſeuerall ages, or times, (accounting for euery time 111. yeares) yee ſhall find, 1. How that Antichriſt was begotten: 2. How hee was conceiued: 3. Howe hee was formed: 4. How he was quickened: 5. How his Dame groaned towardes the birth: 6. How hee was borne and brought foorth. Then from thence againe, if yee reckon 666. yeares, that is to ſay, vnto the yeare of our Lorde 1430. and part that number into ſixe other ages or times, ye ſhall perceiue therein: 1. The nourſing: 2. The growing vp: 3. The policie: 4. The practiſe: 5. The power: 6. The chiefe pompe and triumph of that Antichriſt. And ſo yee ſhall haue for his begetting and conceiuing 222. yeares: for his forming,
and quickening 222. yeares: for the groning and birth, 222. yeares: for his nurſing and growing, 222 yeares: for his policie and practiſe, 222. yeares: and for his power and chiefe glorie, 222. yeares: being in the whole 1332. yeares. And I thinke my coniecture probable enough, that the Angel in Daniel, 12, 12. ſpeaking of the two times: and alſo of the 1335. dayes, rightly aymed to the ende of thoſe 1332. yeares, beeing about the yeare of our Lord 1429. For if from this number 1335. ye take 3, and then diuide the remainder into 2. parts, according to the rule of Mediations, ye ſhall finde the verie number 666. in either part. Thirdly, that which remaineth of the time, whether halfe a time, or the diuiding of the time:The declination and ruine of Antichriſt. or part of a time (as the Lorde in his ſecrete councell hath decreed it) concerneth the deteſtation, the purſuing, the wounding, the languiſhing, the waning, and the ruine of that Antichriſt. And this, who ſo waiting commeth to beholde in the ende of thoſe 1335. dayes, is accounted happie, Dan. 12.12 by the teſtimonie of the Angel. Therefore, as we doubt not, but that we are happie whom the Lord hath reſerued to theſe times, wherein that Antichriſt is loathed, is purſued, is wounded, doth languiſh, droope, and runne daylie towards his ruine and vtter decay: ſo do we alſo expect in faith, that (as the Lord hath promiſed) for the choſens ſake, the time of his raigne ſhall be ſhortened and that his finall deſtruction is neare at hand.

That Antichriſt whereunto Iohn poynted is found in Rome.3 VVhat things haue beene wrought and done in the Empyre, and Sea of Rome, as manifeſt notes of that Antichriſt, and well worthie the obſeruation, within euerie one of thoſe
ſeuerall times or Ages, I minde not heere at large to diſcourſe: but after a fewe wordes thereof, to referre them, that are willing to vnderſtand the ſame, vnto the generall Councels, the Centuries, the Eccleſiaſticall hiſtories, the Chronicles, and writers of thoſe times. It is moſt certaine,VVhen the miſterie of Iniquitie began to worke. that this miſterie of iniquitie beganne to worke effectually, euen then, when S. Iohn ſawe theſe things reuealed vnto him, and wrote of them vnto the ſeauen Churches in Aſia, and ſayde alſo in his Canonicall Epiſtle, that euen then was that laſt time, wherein that Antichriſt (before propheſied of) ſhould come; & ſo from thence continued working from age to age, vnto the yeare of our Lord 764. At which time the monſtrous Babe was borne at Rome, The birth of Antichriſt. and (after a ſort) reuealed in the world with no little wonder. And then foorthwith the Biſhop of Rome beganne to forget all Chriſtian humilitie, the former pouertie of the Saints, the miniſterie of the word, and ſuch like; and (beeing enriched with thoſe great rewards which king Pipine, and other princes beſtowed on him) hee exalted himſelfe beyond meaſure, and gladly embraced that proude name Vniuerſall Biſhop; which was giuen to Antichriſt by the tyrant Phocas, Phocas named the childe. whereof alſo Gregorie had before propheſied, when hee ſayde, that the Biſhop of Conſtantinople which before that, vſurped that Name, was the fore-runner or herauld of Antichriſt: meaning that he, that ſhould next after him accept of the ſame title, was indeede that Antichriſt. Neither hath there beene any other (beſides the Biſhops of Rome) ſithence that time, that hath challenged and retained this Title. From thence forth the Pope exalted himſelfe more & more, in the church
aboue al other Biſhops,Decret. Nicol. 1. papa. D. 21. in tant. & Nunc. D. 22. c. 1. d. 9. S. 1. Rom d. 96. vniuam. Patriarks, prieſts, miniſters, preachers: and alſo departing from that obedience which belonged to the Emperor, he vſurped on the ſeculer & ciuill power: ſo much that the Emperour decreaſed in authoritie, which the Pope arrogated to his own holines, & in proceſſe of time, preſumed moſt impudent (as a malepert babe) to face his Lorde the Emperour,De Maiorat & obed. Solit. Carion in Iuno. to thruſt downe his crowne with his foote, & by way of an odious compariſon, to preferre himſelfe to the Emperor, as the Sunne is preferred to the Moone in beautie and brightneſſe, with the abuſe of that place of Scripture:The Pope would no longer obey, but rule ouer the Emperour. Gen. 1.16. God made two great lights: a greater light to rule the day, and a leſſe light to rule the night. Yea, beyonde all this, he aduaunced himſelfe in all things aboue Peter, whoſe ſucceſſour hee is called, and whoſe ſword hee would beare, aboue Chriſt Ieſus, whoſe vicar he is ſuppoſed, and, (if not aboue, yet) equall with God, a ſeruant vnto all, whoſe ſeruants he was named. Lo here was that departing of which ſaint Paul propheſied, 2. Theſ. 2.3. For now the chriſtians for a great part reuolted frō the faith of Chriſt, and from their obedience to their kings & Emperors, & willingly yeeld themſelues thrals and bondmen to the biſhop of Rome: that is to ſay, to Antichriſt, that child of Perdition, their rebellious head and Captaine.

4. Surely, if we conſider thoſe 111. yeeres which immediatly followed ye former 666. yeares,The nourſing of Antichriſt. & were referred to the nourſing time of Antichriſt, we ſhal perceiue how prettily he pearked vp, and began to diſcouer himſelf in the church of Rome. And by that age & time we ſhal eaſily conſider & iudge of al the ages ſucceeding: that is to ſay, by the conſideration
of this nourſing time of Antichriſt, we may coniecture of his power, policy, practiſe & pompe. About the end of thoſe former 666. yeeres,Adrian 1. An. 764. in An. Do. 764. Pope Adrian the firſt, occupied the See of Rome, and held the ſame about 23. yeeres. As this Pope exalted himſelfe aboue his brethren, & hunted after the riches and glory of the world: ſo alſo he was a great Idolater. In this Popes time was holden the 2. Nicaene Synode, VVorſhipping of Images. which the Greekes call the 7. general Synode, in the raigne of Irene and Conſtantine her yong ſonne. In this Synode by the commandement of the Pope, fortified by the power & authority of the Emperor, Baſilius, the Biſhop of Ancyra, Theodorus Cyrus, the B. of Myron, & Theodoſius the B. of Amorie, Sum. con c. fol. 277. Baſilius Theodor. 9. and ſome other biſhops, were conſtrained to recant their opinions againſt ye worſhipping of the Images of Saints. And in the ſaid Synode it was decreed,Theodoſius Biſhops of the Epheſians. by the cōmandement of the pope, & the conſent of the ſaid Irene, that Images ſhuld be reſtored & placed in the churches, that ſaints ſhuld be worſhipped as the ſons of God, that their reliques, and the aſhes of the martires ſhould be reuerētly honored: that alſo was then & there confirmed by a general conſent, which Phocas had before that time cōmanded: namely, that the B. of Rome ſhould be the higheſt in authority ouer al other biſhops, & yt the church of Rome ſhould be the head of al other churches: & that whoſoeuer ſpake or taught contrary to this decree, he ſhuld be anathematized & cōdemned.Teraſius patriarke of Conſtantinople, In conſideratō therof Teraſius, then patriark of Conſtant. which was preſēt at that Synod being demanded by the popes cōmandemēt, whether we wold conſent to theſe & ſuch other matters which wer cōtained in a certain epiſtle
which the Pope had written to the Emperour and Empreſſe: he, fearing what would enſue the contrarie, anſwered in theſe words. Nos patrum, praeceptis imbuti, Sum. Concil. fol. 277.
ſic confeſſi ſumus, & confitemur, concordamus, & vim, Literarum Lectarum confirmamus, & Imaginum picturas, ſecundum priſcam patrum traditionem, recipimus, & has deſiderto noſtro adoramus. That is, VVe being inſtructed in the precepts of the Fathers, haue ſo confeſſed, and do confeſſe, concord, and confirme the force of the Letters, which haue beene read: and the pictures of Images, according to the ancient traditions of the Fathers, wee doo receiue, and the ſame with all our deſire we do adore. Theſe and ſuch like notes of Antichriſt, appeare in the Romane Biſhoppe, euen in the nourſing time of the Babe which (as ye heard before) was commended in the dayes of Pope Adrian, Adrian. 1. the firſt: 666. yeeres from the acte of his conception, and was continued vnto the 777. yeere of the ſame, about the yeere of our Lord and Sauiour, 875: that is, vnto the latter time of Pope Adrian the ſecond,Adrian. 2. Iohn. 9. and at the beginning of Pope Iohn 9. which ſucceeded the ſaid Adrian 2. Both theſe Popes hunting eagerly after the kingdome and honour of the world, worſhipping ſtraunge goddes, vſurping authoritie ouer all Biſhops and ciuill magiſtrates whatſoeuer,Cent. 9. ca. 10. ſtirring vp and broaching bloudy warres, commanding diuers errours, idolatries, and ſuperfluities to be vſed and obſerued for their owne honour and filthie Lucre, did rather encreaſe, then any way let or diminiſh the iniquitie of that place. Neither vnlike vnto theſe, were all the reſt that ſucceeded them in that See, as namely Martine 2. Agapetus, Adrian 3, Baſile, Stephan 5. Formoſus, Boniface 6, Stephan 6, Romanus,
Theodorus 2, Iohn 10, Benedict 4, Leo 5, Chriſtopher Sergius 3, Anaſtaſius 3, with others: vnto the yeere of our Lord, 986. and the yeere of Antichriſt, 888.

5 Al this was yet in the noneage of Antichriſt,
The time of the thouſand yeeres.
Apoc. 20.23.
and within the cōpaſſe of thoſe thouſand yeeres wherin Satan was bound vp from ſeducing the Saints of God. Apoc. 20.2. But it ſeemeth very ſtrange that Antichriſt could be gotten in the Church and brought forth into the world, within this time of Satans reſtraint & thraldome: were it not that the Lord had permitted this Deceiuer to worke the miſterie of iniquitie, and to ſeduce by ſtrong deluſions, them that would not beleeue the Goſpel. And if that Antichriſt preſumed to be ſo malepert in that time of his nonage, what may we think that he did then, when he was come to his full growth and power? that is to ſay, the ende of thoſe 1000. yeeres, at what time his curſed Sire was lette looſe to deceiue the world. Although by the 1000. yeeres, may be vnderſtood all the time of the free preaching of the Goſpel, and light of the word of God, whereby the diuell is reſtrained his libertie: yet may we not imagine, but that as the Lord hath appointed yeeres, dayes, and times, in yt which he hath wrought & doth worke, and bring things to paſſe for the comfort of his choſen people: ſo by 1000. yeeres, & 1335. daies, and by this number 666. & ſuch like, he would ſtir vp the godly to a due conſideration of his prouidence, & a diligent ſearching out, and triall of the truth of his word, which performeth al things yt hee hath foretold vs by the Prophets in the due time. A notable ſtay to our faith, and comfort to our ſoules. And indeede, after the full expiration of a thouſande
yeeres, beeing reckoned from the birth of Chriſt, which bounde vp the diuell vnto the time of Pope Silueſter the ſecond,Silueſter 2. who (as it is written of him) gaue himſelfe to the diuell to be made a Pope, and by wicked Arts aſpired to the Popedome, wherein hee neuer ſerued God, but daily ſerued the diuell: then the diuell raged indeede in the Papacie, like a ramping and roaring Lion, lately lette looſe from out of his Denne, and ſo continued (by the ſufferance of the lord) for the little ſeaſon, Apoc. 20.3. that is to ſay, vnto the end of thoſe latter 666. yeares, about the yeere of our Lorde 1430. In and by all the which time, to the ende that he might ſeeme holy and moſt glorious, and not to doo any manner of hurt then,The policie of Antichriſt. when hee did moſt harme and villanie; and that the deceiued world might not perceiue his trecherie and legerdemaine, hee tooke away from the people the light of the Goſpel, without the which the worlde could not but periſh, that beeing blinded and nooſeled vp in ignoance and groſſe errours, they might not be able to diſcerne betweene truth and falſhood, and beeing terrified with his excommunications and tyrannous crueltie, they might take on them the marke of the Beaſt: and then hearing none other doctrine deliuered to them, but that onely which tended to the exaltation and worſhip of the Beaſt, and the deſtruction of Chriſtian ſoules, they might beleeue that not Ieſus Chriſt, but the Pope onely, could ſhut vp the Gates of hell and death from them, and open vnto them the doore of heauen with Saint Peters keyes, which they thought he alone had in his power and poſſeſſion.
Heereof it enſued, that the ſeduced ſoules worſhipped him with all holy reuerence,Names and Titles attributed to Antichriſt. honoured him as a God, and accounted him woorthie theſe and ſuch like high Titles: vz. The moſt holy Father, the head of the Church, the Prince of Prieſts, the Vniuerſall Biſhoppe, the Popes holyneſſe, the Lorde of Lordes, the Kings of Kings, the Vicar of Chriſt, the Succeſſour of Saint Peter, the God of the Earth. And hee hath beene taken among them of that Religion, for his Primacie, as Abel;Bernard. conſ. li. 2. ad Engen. for his gouernment, us Noah: for his Patriark-ſhippe, as Abraham: for his order, as Melchizedech: for his dignitie, as Aaron: for his authoritie, as Moſes: for his iudgement, as Samuel: for his power, as Peter: and for his annointing, as Chriſt. Wherevppon his Legates alſo and proude Cardinalles and Prelates were aduanced, not onely in the ſeculer affaires equall with Kings and Princes, but alſo in the Church aboue them and all others. And heereof was it, that the Clergie gaue him theyr firſt fruites and tenths, and daily remembred him in theyr Maſſes and Oriſons, that euerie man that had fire made within his Houſe, was contented to pay his Romeſcot and Peterpence to his holyneſſe, and that the more parte of all perſons, then deemed their landes, Money, Plate, Iewels, and ſuch things as they had, beſt beſtowed, deuiſed, and diſpoſed, (cheefely at the time of their departing out of this worlde) when with the ſame they could bee perſwaded by theyr ghoſtly Fathers, to purchaſe from the Pope, Indulgences and pardons of their ſins, and promiſes of releaſes out of the faigned fire of Purgatorie,
by Maſſes, prayers, and ſuperſtitious obſeruations after their death: then the which there was neuer any deceit and trecherie more heinous & diuelliſh: wherat the diuel laughed, & was moſt glad, that by ſuch a meane he could ſo multiplie his members, & enlarge his kingdom with the ſeruice of ſo many dammed ſoules.

The wounding of Antichriſt.6 Now within this age, and towards the latter end therof, that notable member of Chriſt, Iohn Hus the Bohemian, and that worthie preacher of the Goſpel, Iohn VVicliffe the Engliſhman,Iohn Has Ioh. VVicliffe did both preach and write againſt thoſe enormities and abhominations,
Sir Iohn Oldcaſtle.
Lord Cobham.
Anno Dom. 1413. for the which they were both condemned for hereſie, by the counſell of Conſtance, and moſt vniuſtly martyred. For the like Sir Iohn Oldcaſtle, the Lord Cobham was martyred. And very neere vnto this time, Hierome Sauanarola taught in Italy, that the pope of Rome was that very Antichriſt, for the which Alexander 6. cauſed him to be cruelly burned at Florence. Hierome Sauanarola. Yet the Lord letted not to ſtirre vp others that ſhould (as faithfull witneſſes) declare his truth,Anno. Dom. 1499. An. 1517. to the diſcouerie and wounding of the man of ſinne, and to the ſhame of the diuel. Among others, Martine Luther preached againſt the Popes indulgences and pardons,Martin Luther. he wrote an epiſtle to pope Leo 10. concerning the ſame argument, and called many things in queſtion, touching the ſupremacie of the Biſhoppe of Rome: for the which hee was alſo troubled and condemned moſt falſely for an Arch-heretike, who neuertheleſſe preached the Goſpel, wrote many-bookes, and proſpered vnder the happie defence of that noble Frederike Duke of Saxony. Fredericke the Duke of Saxonye.

Soone after this, not onely the ſaid duke of Saxonie, Philip of Heſſ. and alſo Philip the Landgraue of Heſſa, Germanie. with all Germanie, forſooke the Biſhop of Rome, and refuſed any longer to obey vnto his falſe and erronious traditions: and the whole ſtate of religion was altered among them: but alſo Clement the Pope,
Pope Clement.
Charles 5. grewe contemptible in the hearts of the Emperor Charles 5, and other Princes: for about that time the ſaide Pope (notwithſtanding his pompe and glory) was aſſaulted by the duke of Burbone,
Duke of Burbon. Polid. Virg. de prodi. li. 1. and driuen to the Caſtell of Angelo, where he was beſieged, and conſtrained as a priſoner; in the conceit whereof, and through ſome other ſuch pearcing wounds, he ſhortly after ended his daies, & gaue a farewell to all happineſſe. England alſo, about this time,England. groned to be eaſed of his intollerable yoke; and in the yeare of our Lord, 1533, and the 25. yere of the raigne of that moſt worthie king of happie memorie Henrie the eight,Henrie the eight king of England. King of England, in his high Court of Parliament, an eſtatute was concluded & made, which authorized the ſaid king, to be ſupreme head of the Church of England, Graft. in Chron. next vnder Chriſt: whereby alſo the Pope, and all his Colledge of Cardinals, with all their Indulgences and Pardons, were vtterly aboliſhed out of England. In this Parliament were giuen to the Kings highneſſe, the fruits and tythes of all dignities and ſpirituall promotions, which before that the time were paid to the Pope and his Cleargie.

7 Thus the beaſt was dayly pricked,The fall of Babilon. and pearced, and Babylon was ruinous, and fell more and more. For, many other mightie penſions and payments, taxes, and exactions, were withdrawne and deteined from the Popes holineſſe; diuerſe Monaſteries,
Frieries, Abbaies, Nunneries, Colledges of Idolaters, and Cels of Superſtition, were throwne downe to the ground, & made deſolate: the pompe and glory of Antichriſt nowe being at the full, by theſe & ſuch like meanes, was wonderfully abated: wherby he languiſhed, drooped and drew towards his death. For in this time, the cleare light of the goſpel being preached, which had ſo long time bin ſhadowed with obſcure cloudes of errours, Satan was ſeene where he rouſted in the church of Rome, to the loath of all good men: and that olde Serpent which had deceiued the world, was by ye powerfull word of God haltred vp again, and that child of perdition was purſued, and in eagre chaſe ſo neare tired, and the chaſe ſo continued, that he ſhall (I hope) ſhortly be forced to giue ouer, & yeeld to vtter confuſion, and Babylon ſhall be laid waſte: which the Lord in mercie graunt for the comfort of his people, and his owne high glorie.

The continuance of the raigne of Antichriſt. Mart. in Chro. Sigebertus. Platina. Ranulph. li. 5. cap. 32.8 There be ſome which by this number 666. haue noted the continuance of the raigne of Antichriſt (and that not without ſound argumēts) from the time of Pope Iohn 8: otherwiſe Pope Iohan (being indeed a woman, which diſſembling her ſexe, and at length (by the wicked ſocietie of a carnall Cardinall) was begotten with child, in the trauaile and deliuerie whereof, ſhe died in the open aſſemblie) in Anno dom. 857: vnto the dayes of Pope Leo 10. in An. do. 1523. Others haue accounted the time from the dayes of Pope Benedict. 3, in Anno. dom. 860. and the beginning of Pope Nicholas his ſucceſſor which both had in them notable markes of Antichriſt (as in their doctrines and liues conteined in
hyſtorie it appeareth) vnto the latter time of the forenamed Leo 10,
Platina. Baleus diſt. 96. lib. pontif. Granzius. Cent. 9. ca. 10.
Antichriſt was fully reuealed.
and the beginning of Pope Adrian 6: about the yeare of our Lord 1526.

In or about this time, Luther, and Oecolampadius, and Zuinglius, and Eraſmus, liued, and ſpake, and wrote many things touching this Argument. And before the which time (eſpecially within the compaſſe of 222. yeares) the Roman Biſhop was plainly diſplayed to be that verie Antichriſt: the Popedom was become a verie carnall Prieſthood: Rome was a filthie Cage of all vncleane birds, and the Church of Rome was throughly ſtained with all Idolatries, and wicked fornications, wherewith alſo the kings of the earth were polluted. At the ſight whereof, the right godly men of that time yearned in their hearts, and could not be ſilent to the death.

9 Laſtly, if we ſhould account the whole time of the raigne of Antichriſt, from the looſing of Satan,The end of the 1000. yeres when Satan was looſed. which was (after our account) in the dayes of Pope Sylueſter 2, being now about 596. yeares ago, at what time the light of the Goſpel was ſhadowed; the word of God was not preached, but neglected of them that had chiefe places in the church: wherat Satan had libertie to breake foorth, and to worke this myſtery of iniquity: yet, cannot his time be continued full three ſcore yeares now to come, which are nothing elſe but his drooping dayes, and time of his trauell and ſorrow, and the which alſo, the Lord may (if he will) diuide and ſhorten, for the comfort of his Saints that daily cry, How long wil it be, O Lord, holy and true, ere thou iudge and auenge our blood on them that dwell on the earth?

div.head: CHAP. VI.

Mahomet was not that beast which Saint Iohn noteth vnder the number 666. But the verie number 666. is contained in certain Greeke, Hebrew, Latin, and Engliſh words, and ſentences, which concerne the Church of Rome, and the Biſhops thereof.
div.p:
IN the former chapter we haue ſeen the time and raigne of Antichriſt, vnder the number 666. Now alſo in this Chapter by the ſame number (being well counted) we ſhall eaſilie finde out the Nation and place,The time whē Mahomet died. the power and pride, the ingenie and qualities of this miſcreant. Albeit Lyrae reckoneth that Mahomet the falſe Prophet of the Saraſins or Turks died in the yere of our Lord, 666 whereof ſome woulde that he ſhould be that Antichrist of the which Saint Iohn had prophecied: yet cannot this prophecie be properly referred to Mahomet: for this number may not be reckoned from the death of Antichrist: but rather from the time of his conception, and riſing, as it is before declared, and ſo to bee continued for the whole tearme of his raigne in the Church. Secondlie,VVhere Antichriſt ſhould be borne. Antichrist was to be borne in the Church among the Chriſtians, in the which he ſhoulde occupie a chiefe place, and bee accounted of the Chriſtian beleeuers: and that afterwarde, Hee ſhould apostate and depart from the ſame, according to the wordes of S. Iohn, in his firſt Epiſtle and ſecond
chapter. And as Paul ſaid, 2. Theſ. 2.3, Apoc. 13.11. & 17.9. that he ſhould ſit in the Temple of God, as God: and that his ſeate, or the Citie of his Sea, ſhould be the ſeuen headed beaſt with the tenne hornes: which (as S. Iohn propheſied) roſe vp out of the ſea, vppon whoſe hornes were tenne crowns, & vpon his heads the name of blaſphemie. But it is certaine that Mahomet (although he be indeed another great Antichriſt, or a mighty mēber of Antichriſt, as Nero was in his time, or in reſpect of the cauſe, as were in the former times, Nimrod, Nabucadnezar, Antiochus, & ſuch like: yet was he neuer in the Chriſtian church, nor did he neuer ſhew him ſelfe as a member of the ſame: but hath been alwaies eſtranged and ſeperated from that number.

Beſides, that the Throne of Mahomet and the Turke is placed farre off from the ſeuen headed beaſt with the tenne hornes,Rome is that beaſt with ſeuen heades and tenne hornes. the which all the beſt learned haue expounded of the Citie and policie of the Romanes. For indeed within the walles of that Citie are ſeauen ſeuerall hils or high places, bearing ſo many ſundry names: as Palatine, Capitoline, Tit. liu. Plin. 3. ca. 6.
Auentine, Exquiline, Caelius, Viminalis, Quirinalis. The former foure of thoſe hilles Romulus encloſed,The names of the ſeauen hilles. and to enlarge the Citie, Seruius Tullius encloſed the other three, wherof Rome was made the ſeauen headed Citie. To this, concorded the policie of the Romans,The policie of Rome. who were gouerned firſt by kings: next by Conſuls: thirdly by Decem viri: fourthly by Dictatores: fiftly by Triumviri: ſixtly by Caeſares: ſeuenthly by Emperours: to whoſe gouenrment were alſo ſubdued ten kingdomes: as namely Neapolis, Hiſpania, The tenne hornes of the Beaſt. Portugalia, France, Polon, Bohem, Hungary, England, Denmarke, Suedia. Therefore this propheſie cannot
ſo well be expounded of the Turke, nor of his Mahomet, not of any other Heathen Potentate: nor (indeede) of any other Synagogue or Church, as of the Citie of Rome, the Church of Rome: the Biſhoppes of Rome in that See, ſo farre degenerating from the holy ſinceritie of the Apoſtles of our Lorde, whome neuertheleſſe they would ſeeme to reſemble in an externall ſhew of holineſſe with their apoſtolicall titles and grace. Gratian. Ca. 24. q. 1. Officii.

2. Now it ſhall be conuenient, that we examine ſome certaine words and voyces containing the number 666. which is the number of the Beaſt,VVordes containing the number. 666. and the number of his name. Apo. ca. 13.17.18. And firſt, thoſe words, which others both of yore, and in this age, haue founde out, and thereof counted the ſayde number.

Irenaeus a very auncient writer hath found the number in this word,Latinus 666. Ire. li. 5. contra. hereſ. ca. 15. li. 35.
Lateinus, a man of Italy, a Romane, written in Greek letters. The biſhop of Rome (indeed) is both of that Nation, an Italian Prieſt, and the ſame which both in his Church, and in his Courts, &c. preferreth the Latine and Romane tongue, to the Hebrew and Greeke tongues (in the which the worde of GOD was firſt and beſt written.)

The ſame number was deciphered in this word Teitan, Teitan. 666. the title of the ancient Tyrants: vnto whom rightly alludeth the policie of the Pope, who (as it is ſaid) hath healed vp the deadly wound of the former Beaſt, Apoc. 13.12. that is, of the ancient Empire of the Romans, and hath renewed his old crueltie againſt the Saints, ſurpaſſing the tyrannie of all the auncient
Tytanes and Tyrants, that euer raigned and raged before him, as the Hiſtories which are extant ſithence the former yeeres 666. expired: that is, from the time that the Diuell was let at libertie, after the thouſand yeeres, but cheefely ſithence the yeere of our Lorde, 1000. doo plainely teſtifie. Some others haue counted the number,Apoc. 20.2. Romiit. Aret. 666. in this Hebrewe worde Romiit, that is, a Romane: and likewiſe: in this voyce, Romanus, written in Hebrew Letters. By the which they aſſure themſelues of the ſplace and ſeate of the Beaſt. Roman. 9.666. After this, they finde him within the Church of Rome: for Eccleſia Italica, written in Greeke Letters, 666. Aect. in Apoc. 13. & Nichol Collado. 666. yeeldeth the number. The Italian Church, or the Romane Church: and then by one other ſentence wherein they reckon the ſayde number, they diſcerne his Luciferian pride and ambition, as, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : that is, I am a God vppon the earth. But vnto whom can this ſentence bee better applyed, then to the Biſhoppe of Rome, which exaleth himſelfe (as it is before ſayde) againſt all Kings and Caeſars, Princes, Magiſtrates, and powers in the world. Yea, hee ſitteth in the Temple of God as God, and woulde as God be worſhipped.

This thing Franciſcus Zarabella the Cardinall perceiuing, ſayde plainely: Papa facit quioquid libet, etiam illicita, & eſt pluſquam Deus: that is, The Pope doth whatſoeuer him liſteth, though it bee vnlawfull: and hee is more then a God.
Lo! what is this perſon then, but that verie Antichriſt and who beſides that Antichriſt, extolleth himſelfe in that abhominable pride?

3. Furthermore, after diligent ſearch and due examination of words and ſentences (as the holy Scripture,The number 666. found out in certaine words & ſentences which concerne the Biſhop of Rome, and his miniſters. which openeth mans vnderſtanding, hath directed) I haue found out certaine other words, voyces and ſentences, containing not only the like argument, but alſo the number Sixe hundred, ſixtie and ſixe, and that not alone of the Greeke tongue (in the which Saint Iohn wrote both his Epiſtles, & alſo the Apocalypſe, wherein hee left a note of this Number and argument vnto the Church, but alſo of the Hebrew & Latine tongues. And I do verily beleeue, that the ſaide number and name is contained in ſome certaine words and voyces of the like argument, of euery other language and tongue in the worlde. And for their ſakes which are willing to count the number of the Beaſt, The Greeke words and voyce, of the number of the Beaſt. 666. thereby the ſooner to eſchew him and his deſtruction, I preſently note (among others) that follow. vz.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , That is, I am a Romane, as ſpoken by that Antichriſt, diſplaying his nation and cheeſe Seate.

666.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is: The God-like Pope. Thus (indeed) that holy Father the Biſhop of Rome muſtereth forth himſelf, and would that ſo al men ſhould eſteeme him, a diuine power, a God-like father: the vicar of Chriſt: the head of the Church. There followeth another like voyce.

666.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . that is: The Pope-like God. This is to be vnderſtood in ſuch ſort, as that which Paul ſpeaketh of the diuel, which Tranſformeth himſelf into an Angell of light. For how ſoeuer he would ſhew himſelfe, hee is founde to be ſuch an one, as the next word declareth him to be vz.

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That is: The Catholike man, 666 is a plague or infelicitie. His chaire therefore is worthily called the Chaire of peſtilence, wherein whoſoeuer ſitteth, findeth no meane deſtructions and woes awayting on him. Apo. 16.2. Moreouer, he is not only deſcried to riſe out of the earth, as wholy earthly minded, but alſo to be in very deed that Beaſt which Saint Iohn ſaw to riſe from thence, by the which hee would (without all doubt) that wee ſhould vnderſtand Antichriſt. Apo. 13.11, 12.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That is, The Sacerdotall Emperour, 666 and King for euer.

In euerie one of thoſe former ſeuerall voyces, I haue deciphered 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . that is, ſixe hundred ſixtie and ſixe, which is the number of the Beaſt. Apo. 13.11: of the which argument, I could produce yet manie more: but theſe ſhall here ſuffice.

4. After the premiſed,Hebrew words and voices of the number of Antichriſt. hauing examined certaine Hebrew words, and voices of the like argument, I haue from thence happily deciphered the foreſaide number: vz.

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , That is, As a God, or, God-like. 666 But who aſpireth to this dignitie, as doth the Pope? he would be worſhipped as God: he would rule ouer all kings and Ceaſars, as God: hee ſitteth in the Temple of God as God: and he ſaith in his heart:666 Anchicalh bmyzith, I am as God in munition and ſtrength: alluding to that place in Dan. 11.38. Hee ſhall honour the God Mayſim; that is, the God of munition or ſtrength.

Another worde trieth him to be of or among the Tyrants of the earth: as namely, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That is:666 Thoſe Emim or Giants, ſo called, for that they are a terrour to their ſubiects whom they oppreſſe with cruelty.
With ſuch (indeed) the Pope hath ſhaken handes, to the honour of true Chriſtian hearts. Neither hath he onelie daunted meane and poore perſons, but terrified the mightie Potentates, who hath bin forced both to ſtoope to his vnmeaſurable crueltie, and alſo to pledge him in the vnſauerie dregges of his filthie fornications: wherein (no doubt) appeared a fearefull iudgement of God vpon the inhabiters of the earth, and of the Sea, vnto whom it pleaſed his Maieſtie to ſende foorth that vngodlie Tyrant, as a iuſt recompence for theyr ſinnes, and therefore hee is called in another worde of the like number, Marath Iehouah, That is, The bitterneſſe, 666 or plague of Almightie God: as the inſtrument of his wrath on the earth.

And becauſe the Emperour himſelfe hath beene compelled to ſtoope vnto his holineſſe, as ouerwhelmed with the terrour of his mightie crueltie, to the decay of the Emperiall honour, wee haue another Hebrew worde of the ſame number, which ſayth:666 Clh. mlch, Almightie King decayeth: as then, when the Pope aſpiring, exalted his throne to the abaſing of the Romane Emperour, his Lorde and Maiſter, and as then, when the people gaue that vnto the Pope, which (in verie deede) was due vnto Caeſar. This is that Departing whereof Paule prophecied. 2. Theſ. 2.3. Vnto the which they vnhappilie adioyned their faythleſſe Apoſtacie, attributing that alſo to the Pope, which was proper and due vnto Chriſt, the true bread of life, the which is alſo bewrayed in other Hebrew voyces following.

666 Lchm hchih: The bread of viuification: or, food of reliefe.
An horrible blaſphemie, in that the people eſteemed ye Pope for their euerlaſting food, which came from heauen, derogating the honor of Chriſt.

Moreouer, this voyce is not vnaptly applied to the Popes VVafer-cake, the which they taught to bee tranſubſtantiated into the bodie of Chriſt, which therefore the blinded people adored and worſhipped as their verie maker and Sauiour.

Another voyce noteth his damnable Apoſtacie, from the faith of Chriſt, how ſoeuer hee ſhew himſelfe, Srtho: His turning away: or, his abhomination:666 For notwithſtanding the priſtine puritie of the Biſhop of Rome, the latter Biſhops being called the vniuerſall Popes, haue wonderfully degenerated and apoſtated, forſaking not only Paul, with Demas, and Peter with Magus, but alſo Chriſt Ieſus with Iudas. Howbeit, with the Angel Apoſtate, they giue faire ſemblances of holineſſe, whoſe egregious hypocriſie therein, another word bewraieth.

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : This word with the Hebrews,666 ſignifieth Hiding, keping ſecrete: Alſo, an Hider, and by tranſlation an Hypocrite. The Caldeans by the ſame, vnderſtand a deſtioyer, a waster: but the Greekes by the like voyce (as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) note a Sauiour. Although there bee in this one voyce contrarie ſignifications (after the diuerſitie of tongues), yet may the triple ſignification therof, be aptly applied to him that hath that triple Crowne: who notwithſtanding that he bee indeed a waſter and deſtroyer of ſoules, and a diſturber of the Chriſtian peace, ſetteth forth himſelfe as a Preſeruer, a Sauiour, diſſembling to be that which he is, and ſembling to be that which he is not. Further, hee is found within the borders of Italie, yea, and
among the Prieſts, as this word importeth, vz.

There be ſome other words and voyces which rightly decipher, not onely his proude exaltation, but alſo his chiefe ſeat: in the view & conſideration whereof, we may point at the Roman Prelate, and ſay: Lo, there is that Antichriſt.

666 Ha a noſch, ciihorah beromi, That wretched man, which is likened to the highest Lorde, is in Rome. Yea, another ſayth. Neged maſchiach Romah, Antichrist of Rome, or, the Romiſh Antichriſt. Vnto this may bee added an other like ſentence:666 as, Hoiah cozeb maſchiah Beromah: Antichriſt is in Rome: or, a falſe Christ is reſident in the Citie of Rome.
666By another worde he is found among the holy Fathers: as, Abboth Haromah: The Abbots: or, Fathers of Rome.

666Another voice findeth him in the Church, as the chiefe perſon: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , That is: The head of the Church or Congregation. And who is he which vſurpeth on this title and dignitie? Euen the Romiſh Biſhop. Therefore another voice diſcrieth him, not onlie in the Church, and in a principall ſeate, but in the Church of Rome:666 as Royi chahal Romah: The high Prieſt: or, principall Prelate of the Romiſh Church. I am ſure the Pope will not abandon this title, howſoeuer he acquit himſelfe in the place.

In euery one of thoſe ſeuerall places, I find 666. being the number of Antichriſt. Moreouer theſe Hebrew letters beeing tranſcribed or conuerted and placed after the Hebrew order, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : haue affinitie with a worde which ſignifieth an eleuation, 666 a lifting vp, an offering: wherof (as it ſeemeth) was borrowed the worde Miſſa, or Maſſe: which is the note of the
Popes Idoll. Now, of ſo manie wordes propoſed, the reader may take the meeteſt, and apply them with right iudgement.
5 There bee alſo found certaine Latine words and ſentences of the former number and argument, whereof I onelie note thoſe that follow, to bee likewiſe conſidered.

Dux Cleri, The Captaine, the Leader, or,Latine words and voices of the number of the beaſt. Doxlvi.
the Head of the Cleargie.
Lucrodoxi: Gaine worthie: or, Glorious through lucre.
Doctoris vniuerſalis initia: The beginnings of a Catholike Doctor.

Pontifex, altus Sacerdos: The Pope, an high Priest: or, The filth of the Sea, an high Prieſt. The Pope is as the excrements of the Roman Empire: (which is that beaſt that roſe vp from the Sea, Apoc. 13.1, 11.) yea, and of the ſame Sea.
Pſeudo epiſcopales vſus: The falſe Biſhoplike Maiſters: or, The vſe and conuerſation of the falſe Biſhops. Such are the Popes and his Cleargie.

p.hi: Socerdotale ſurrexit: A ſacerdotall thing is riſen vp.
Vicarius titulo Christi, fel ſansta a Eccleſiae: hee, who is entituled the Vicar of Christ, is the gall of the holie Church.

div.p: Alſo this Monoſtich following, is of the like number and argument.
div.q: Icon, pax, pixis, crux, lux, fex, cantica, Cleiri.
div.p: Thus engliſhed.

q.l: The picture, Pixe, and Paxe,
the Croſſe and lights:
The drowſie dregges and Canticles,
of Cleargie wights.

div.p:
Further, to ſhew in what place, and amongeſt what perſons Antichriſt was borne, bred, and maintained, wee haue this ſentence of the like number. Per Epiſcopos vniuerſales ſanctae Eccleſiae, ſurrexit Antichristus,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . VVhat is ment by this worde Antichriſt. Rex, ſeruus, ſuperbus. Amongeſt the Catholike Biſhops of the holie church, Antichrist is riſen vp, both a King, and a proude ſeruant. And here wee may note, that this word Antichrist, is not the proper name of anie one ſingular perſon, but a name common to all them that bee contrarie to Chriſt (as it is ſayde before:) but beyond all others to them who when they be contrarie to Chriſt, do ſeeme to be for him. Therfore the Roman Biſhops haue worthily merited this title, who notwithſtanding their holy ſemblances of vertues, do both vſurpe tyrannie, Lordſhip, and dominion, ouer and aboue all Kings and Caeſars, the which our Lorde Chriſt neuer attempted, nor taught. And in ſtudies and doctrine are to him oppoſed & contrarie. Neither can it be, but that this is that notable Antichrist, the which Iohn in the ſpirit of prophecie deſcried in the Romane Monarch. Nor is that prophecie to bee expounded of anie one Pope▪ or of anie one particular perſon: but of all thoſe wicked and vngodlie miſcreants, either conſederating in one conſpiracie agaynſt Chriſt, and his Saints, or ſucceeding one another in that Antichriſtian Sea, and
Church of Rome. So that, though one Pope die,Antichriſt is continued in the world yea, in the ſea of Rome. or be remoued from that Sea, or Church, it followeth not, that therefore Antichriſt is dead, or that Antichriſt is remooued wholy with him: but that Antichrist, is neuertheleſſe continued and foſtered in the ſame Sea, by them that reteine this proude title of vniuerſalitie, and worſhip a mortall man in the place of Chriſt.

In euerie one of thoſe Latin words and ſentences, we may alſo gather the nūber of Antichriſt,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Pap'eſt. 666 Delx vi.
Moreouer, this voice Pap'eſt: that is, he is the Pope: or Papeſt, written in Greeke letters, and reckoned, yeeldeth the foreſaid number.

6 I hope that the true Chriſtian will neither diſdaine nor condemne this my plaine dealing, nor iudge the paper combred with curious and vnneceſſarie inuentions and deuiſes: but rather, as he is willing with wiſdome to count the number of Antichriſt, thereby the ſooner to abandon him, and flie from his deſtructions, ſo will hee gladly embrace thoſe meanes which are to him exhibited to that end, by the helpe of the diuine ſpirit, in the feare of Almightie God.

7 Moreouer, the ſeate or place of Antichrist, The ſeate of • Antichriſt. is well knowne, partly by the tytle, partly by the deſcription of the ſame. The title of his Sea is after the name of his Cittie 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Rome, and is interpreted pride, exaltation, eleuation, mightineſſe, ſturdineſſe, abhomination, and by them of yore, called Vngodlie Rome. After the which his Church is entituled, Eccleſia Romana, the Romane Church: which is as much to ſay, as the proude, the ſtately, the ſtrong, the hautie, and the
abominable Church,Chriſt hath not ſet forth his church in proud titles. as oppoſed to the holy Catholike Church of Chriſt. For Chriſt hath not ſet foorth his Church before the worlde in proude tytles, but vnder the notes of humilitie, meekeneſſe, and ſobrietie, as a little flocke, an oppreſſed people, a deformed Spouſe, the poore, the Lambes, the Doues, little children, little ones, and ſuch like: and hath commended vnto them humilitie, ſobrietie, ſimplicitie, innocencie, patience, watchfulneſſe, faſting, obedience and ſuch like. Therefore not onelie Daniel, Dan. 7.8. Reu. 13.1. & ca. 17.9. when he ſpeaketh of the 4. Monarke, being of the Romanes, and Saint Iohn when hee telleth of that Beast which roſe vp out of the Sea, Antichriſt was diſcouered as ſoon as he was borne, and pointed at in euerie age following. with ſeuen heades, and ten hornes, doo plainlie poynt at the Citie and See of Rome: but alſo the auncient Martyr Irenaeus, nowe little leſſe then a thouſand fiue hundred yeares ago, and Gregorie a Biſhop of Rome, and Hierom, and Auguſtine, and Haymo, and Hylarius, and Tertullian, and Lyra, and Thomas, and Bernarde, with wany others, both godlie and learned in their times, haue conſented in this, that Rome is that myſticall Babilon, and the ſeate of Antichriſt.

8 But becauſe that of this Argument, both they, and manie others, both of yore, and in this preſent age, haue written both learnedly and largely: therefore vnto that which hath beene ſayde, I will adde onelie that auncient prophecie of Sybilla Erithraea, This Sibyll prophecied to the Greekes when they beſieged Troy. Bull. in Apo. 13. con. 61. who liued manie hundred yeares before the byrth of Chriſt: brieflie comprehending the things premiſed, and ſo conclude this argument. This Sibylla hauing fore-ſpoken of the taking, the ranſacking, and the burning
of Rome, which was performed by Totilaes king of the Gothes, in the time of Iuſtinian the Emperor, did alſo prophecie of fifteene dilicate Kings which ſhould raigne there after that: and that then immediately, there ſhould riſe vp one other king in ſuch ſort deſcribed and ſet foorth, as beſt beſeemeth the Popes holineſſe.Sibyll. Erith. in li. 8. Sibyl. oraculorum. The words of her prophecie being Engliſhed, ſound much after this ſort.

q.l: In time to come (O bragging Rome)
on thee ſhall fall from hie:
Celestiall plagues, as ſcourgesiuſt,
for all thy tyrannie.
Then ſhall thy necke bow to thy doome,
and groueling to the ground,
The fierie flames that knowes not hoe
ſhall fiercely thee confound.
From thence when fifteene kings ſucceed,
(So dilicate) the reſt:
And haue with cruell ſeruitude
The world full ſorely preſt:
A king ſhall riſe, whoſe white hoare head,
ſhall ſhine and gliſter gay:
His title ſounding like the Sea,
(as Pontifex men ſay.)
Reſpecting wholie earthlie things,
and promiſing men bliſſe:
VVith putting forth his filthie foote,
(to them, the ſame to kiſſe.)

div.p:
According to this prophecie, Ri. Reynol. in his Chronicle of the Empire. if ye number vp 15. Emperours, or Caeſars, after the raigne of Iustinian, yee, ſhall come into the raigne of Irene, with
her yong ſonne Conſtantine, Adrian 1. in Nicaen.Synod. 2. al. 7. at what time Pope Adrian occupied the See of Rome, who with the conſent of the Empreſſe , commaunded that wicked decree in the Nicaene Synode, for the reſtoring and worſhipping of dumbe Images, as it is before declared.

9. Lo, this is that Dagon whom they ſtriue to ſtay vp! this is that Baal, for whom they contend ſo eagerly, and therein much diſquiet Ioas, and Cedeon, with their families, and vtterly diſturbe all godlie tranquilitie: and this is their cauſe, wherein they do not onely reſemble, but exceede thoſe old Iſraelites which the Lorde deſtroyed: yea, thoſe heathen, whom he caſt out before the children of Iſrael, after that he had long ſuffered them to walke their owne wayes, in the lewdneſſe of their minds.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
The puniſhment of traiterous Papists is iustly inflicted: their ſufferings are deſperate: and finally they are confounded with Antichriſt their Prince.
div.p:
AS the ſecrete Papiſts ſauour moſt odiouſlie of wicked conſpiracies, and dangerous treacheries againſt the Lorde, the Lordes annointed their owne Nation, and the whole church of Chriſt: ſo, hauing no better arguments to defend the cauſe they pleade, then had thoſe Idolatrous Baalites, which pleaded for Baal, in the time of Gedeon: they do no leſſe deſerue that rewarde which Ioas
did award them, ſaying: Iud. 6.30.31. Hee that will contende for Baal, let him die ere the morning. Neither can it bee, that they ſhall bee freed from that trouble, which Moſes, Dauid, and the Prophets ſaid to bee due vnto ſuch, as contemning the right worſhip of the true God, do runne a whoring after ſtraunge gods:God will not neglect to puniſh traitors. the which trouble, albeit neither the Prince, nor the ciuill Magiſtrate (which is the miniſter of God to do iuſtice) either by fauor or by negligence, inflict not, ſhalbe yet iuſtly paid thē in their day, with ful meaſure, by him that is much higher then the higheſt vpon the earth, and that will not giue his honour to another.

2 Beſides that, as their cauſe is both wicked and damnable, wherein they iuſtly deſerue to bee afflicted: ſo is the maner of their ſuffering no leſſe deſperate and without all comfort of the ſpirit of God,1. King. 18.28 which hath included them within the compaſſe of thoſe Baalites that launced themſelues with kniues, till the blood ranne forth in abundance, but all in vaine: and within the number of thoſe hypocrites which ſay to god: VVe haue puniſhed our ſelues and thou regardest it not; being reicted thus:Iſay 58.3.
But who hath required theſe things at your hands? For as they ſuffer not for a good cauſe, ſo they ſuffer not as they ſhoulde, nor to that end for the which the godlie endure afflictions. Indeed, they ſuffer not as Chriſtians,The maner of their ſuffering. but as malefactors, and tranſgreſſors of good lawes: as buſie bodies in other mens matters, as workers of euill: yea, as rebels, as traitors, as theeues, as murtherers, in ſuch ſort as Saint Peter forbiddeth that Chriſtians ſhould ſuffer. But looke on thoſe Baalites: behold, what turmoyles take they? what troubles
endure they? what daungers incurre they? what miſchiefe broach they, vnder the benedictions and diſpenſations of their moſt holy fathers? how wickedly cōſpire they, & conſult againſt the Lord, and againſt his anointed? howe often deuiſe they to murther true Chriſtians; to ſteale away the hearts of ſubiects from their lawfull Princes: to depoſe Kings and Emperours: to ouerturne all good gouernments? how bold are they, to deale in matters of ſtate, to meddle with Princes affaires? how impudent are they in the exaltation of their moſt holy father, to controll them and their lawes? yea, how preſumptuous are they to aſſault them, & cowardly to murther them, and to cenſure them to eternall torments? Be theſe Chriſtians? nay, rather diuels incarnate. Are they in theſe their deuiſes and practiſes tollerable? Not at all: ſhould they not be puniſhed, or rather plagued among thoſe Baalites? Right worthie, and that vnleſſe their cauſe were better, it were good their courage were leſſe. For albeeit that ſuffering be the common recogniſance of Gods children, who euer beare in their bodies the markes of the Lord Ieſu: yet they who ſuffer not in the Lord,How Chriſt ſuffered, that is, in a good cauſe, and for his ſake, and in ſuch ſort as Chriſt by his example hath taught vs to ſuffer, are neuer the neare to the croſſe of Chriſt, though they be toſſed and croſſed neuer ſo much. Chriſt died, the iuſt for the vniuſt, when there was no guile found in his mouth: hee died innocentlie: hee ſuffered patientlie: hee died to redeeme vs from ſinne, and to reconcile vs vnto GOD. To this ſuffering aymed the Pſalmist, when in the perſon of the afflicted Iſraelites,
he ſaide vnto the Lord: For thy ſake are we killed all the day long: and are accounted as ſheepe appointed to be ſlaine! And thus ſaide the prophet Ieremy in his ſuffering: Know that for thy ſake (O Lord) I haue ſuffered rebuke. So Zacharie the ſonne of Iehoida, beeing commanded to death by Ioaſh King of Iudah, he patiently ſuſtained it and ſaide: The Lord looke vppon it, and require it. Vnto theſe, and ſuch like examples looked Auguſtine, and therefore being greeuouſly afflicted, he ſaide not, Lord looke on my puniſhment: but he ſaid, Reſpice in cauſam meam domine: Lord reſpect my cauſe.

3. Vnto theſe ſufferers hath the Lord Ieſus promiſed peace and happineſſe, when the others are left without all comfort. As,Matth. 5.
Bleſſed are they which ſuffer perſecution, or beare affliction patiently for righteouſneſſe ſake: for theirs is the kingdome of heauen. Again: Bleſſed are yee, when men reuile you, and perſecute you, and ſay all manner of euill againſt you falſely, for my ſake.
Iam. 5.10. Therefore Saint Iames counſelleth vs to take the prophets for an example of ſuffering aduerſitie, & of long ſuffering, which haue ſpoken in the name of the Lord: as if he might haue ſaide to them vnder the croſſe: Looke on the cauſe and patience of Iſayah, of Ieremy, of Dauid, of Zacharias, of Amos, of Daniel, of Moſes, of Michaeah, of Vriah, of Iohn the Babtiſt, and ſuch others, which haue beene perſecuted, and patiently ſuffered afflictions in the good cauſe, for the Lords ſake. S. Stephen in his ſermon, charged the Iews, that they had murthered them,Acts 7. that had foreſhewed them of the comming of that iuſt: that is, of Chriſt Ieſus our righteouſnes. This was the cauſe of the prophets, the ſame was Stephens cauſe, and Paul pleading
the ſame cauſe, waxed both bold and cheerefull at the barre. For hauing declared that hee mooued the people to repent and turne to God, and to doo the workes woorthie the amendment of life, hee ſayde: For this cauſe the Iewes caught mee in the Temple. Moreouer, touching the ende of his ſuffering, hee thus proteſted with no ſmall ioy of Spirite: I would that yee vnderſtoode brethren, that the things which haue betided mee,
Phil. 1.14. are turned to the furthering of the Goſpel: ſo that my bandes in Chriſt, are famous throughout all the iudgement Hall, and in all other places: inſomuch that many of my Brethren in the Lorde, are emboldened through my bandes, and dare more frankely ſpeake the word, &c. Thus, that olde Eleazar, 2. March. 6.24.28. hauing pleaded this good cauſe, he would ſuffer in the defence thereof, not onely. to declare his faythfull conſtancie, and diſcharge of dutie, but alſo to giue a good example thereof vnto the yonger ſort: and ſo he endured the paines of Martirdome, with patience and great comfort in the Spirit.

The like we reade of the woman who died with her ſeauen ſons in the Machabees, the law of the Lord. 2. Mach. 7. Thus Iames, Peter, Iohn, & other holy Martires of the Lord, haue with no meane comfort of the Spirit, ſuffered and borne the Croſſe of their maiſter Chriſt, and are bleſſed in their death. But wo vnto thoſe miſerable caytiffes,VVo to them that ſuffer in an euill cauſe. whoſe puniſhments and ſufferings are neither for righteouſneſſe: neither for ſpeaking in the name of the Lord: neither for declaring of that Iuſt: neither for mouing the people to turne vnto God: nor that others by their bandes ſhould be emboldned, more freely to ſpeake the word: nor
for the Lords ſake: nor for any good, but all contrarie. For lo! the Lorde of heauen is riſen vppe, and ſtandeth againſt them as a ſwift witneſſe, and a ſeuere iudge to condemne them, and to deſtroy them for euer, except they repent. Therefore it ſhall be good for them to learne truely to repent of their rebellions and ſinnes timely, and to pray vnto God in the ſpirit: yea, and to deſire others alſo to pray for them, that the thoughts of their hearts may be forgiuen them: for as their hearts are not right before God (a cauſe of their worthie iudgements with Simon Magus) ſo run they forward in the high way of perdition. Now, if theſe and ſuch like words moue them not, but as enemies vnto the true contentation and peace, they will with the deaffe adder ſtop their eares, prepare themſelues to battaile, & continuerebellious; it ſhall ſaid vnto them by the true proteſtants, as Ioſuah once ſaid to that theeuiſh Achā: Inaſmuch as yee haue troubled vs, the Lord doth trouble you this day. Neither ſhal the walles of great Babilon protect them, nor the Prince Nimrod defend them: for neither ſhal the one, nor the other of them, be able to eſcape deſtruction, when the Lord God of heauen, which maketh wars with Amalech from generation to generation, Exod. 17.16. Gal. 5.10. ſhall force them to beare their iuſt condemnation for troubling the Lords people.

4. For as God decreed, and his decree did ſtand, Nom. 16.32. 2. Sam. 17.23. &. 18.9. that Agag ſhuld be deſtroyed: that Chore & his confederates ſhould deſcend down into hel: that Achitophel, Hamā, Abſalom, Iudas, & ſuch like, ſhuld ſwallow vp their mortal morſels: ſo hath he decreed, & it ſhal be performed in time, that Babilon mother of whoredoms & abhominations ſhal be confounded:
that Antichriſt ſhall be caſt out, and his louers and friendes ſhall be laughed to ſcorne. And in the conſideration thereof, not onely they that be yet liuing (whom they haue depriued of peace and tranquilitie) ſhall enioy their deſired reſt, quietneſſe and gladneſſe, but alſo the verie infernall Sprits and Hell, ſhall be mooued at their ſodaine fall and comming downe, no leſſe then they were mooued at the fall of the King of Tyrus, and of the King of Babilon, to whome tauntingly, Eze. 28.2. Iſa. 14. and in diuiſion, they ſhall ſay, Lo!Antichriſt is diuided of the infernall ſpirits. are not yee alſo touched with infirmities as other men? and are ye not made like vnto vs? yea, thou alſo, which (being blinded through malice, pride, and magnificence,) haft thought thy ſelfe to be a God, and not a mortall man, and farre more excellent then anie Emperour, Prince, King, Caeſar, or Potentate on the earth: and ſitting in the temple of God, wouldeſt bee worſhipped as God: euen thou art fallen from heauen, and become one of them that dwel below. Therfore, we iuſtly take vp againſt thee, in ſteede of ſalutations, bitter ſcoffes and reproches. And ſeeing thy naked ſoule, & moſt feeble ſpirits now depriued of all glorie, pompe, & power, not able to oppugne the ſpirits infernal, but compelled perforce to yeeld, not onely to the common lot of other damnable miſcreants, but to a torment ſo far greater then the torment of others, by how much more thine abhominations haue exceeded others: and hauing put from vs all feare of thy bloudy tyrannie, and beholding the reward of thy great hypocriſie, wee are nowe worthily moued to deride thee.Bern. de conſider li. 2. ad Engen. Ha, ha, Art thou that Abel for Primacie? that Noah for gouernment? that Abraham for Patriarchſhip? that Melchizedech
for order: that Aaron for dignitie:Antonin. tit. 22. ca. 2. d. petiſtate Papae. that Moſes for authoritie: that Samuel for iudgement: that Peter for power: that Chriſt touching annoynting? yet lo, thou art caſt downe and couered with confuſion: Art thou he, whom al men feared? Art thou he, that ruled in heauen and in earth, and in hell? Couldeſt thou looſe and binde after thine owne will? haft thou beene taken for the moſt holy father, the Prince of peace, the head of the Church, the God of the earth, the king of kings, the Lord of Lords, higher then the Heauens, harmeleſſe, vndefiled, moſt perfect, ſeperate from ſinners, and inuinceable among the Gods: yet behold, thou art come downe vnto the depth of hell! And there, there, thou lyeſt!

5 Thou art fallen into a place not of pleaſure,Note heere a great alteration and change. but of paine: not of ioy, but of anguiſh: not of ſolace, but of diſcomfort: not of happines, but of extreame wretchedneſſe. Thy Balſame and thy Mirrhe hath not beene able to preſerue thy body from corruption, nor all thy Riches, pompe, power, and glorie, can ſaue thy ſoule from eternall torment! The wormes of the earth deuour thy body, the wormes of an euill conſcience bite thy ſinfull ſoule, and all the infernall ſpirits torment thee in both, without remiſſe for euermore. This that is declared haue I heard of the Lord of hoaſts, the God of Iſrael, Iſa. 21.10. Eccle. 12.13. which bringeth euerie worke into iudgement, and will be wel knowne in the iudgement,Ezec. 28.10. and therein highly aduaunced, for he is the ſame God, to whom the kingdome, and the power, and the glorie belongeth. Iſa. 14.27. So it is decreed, and it is ſo determined in the time appointed.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
The fooliſh zeale and ſingular conceites of certaine, who iuſtifie themſelues only, and diſlike all others: with their eager deſire of haſtie reformation, of that which they conceit to be amiſſe.
div.p:
8.4.2. Socrates. In many things the meane is beſt ALthough in proportions Geometrical, the leſſe number is nearer the middle then the more, and therfore in regard thereof, to do ſometimes leſſe then ſhuld be done, when the whole cannot be done, is more incident to the vertue in many things, thē it is to exceed it.Eccleſ. 7.18. And that alſo, not only the wiſe Preacher counſelleth that men ſhould not be oueriuſt, nor ouerwiſe: but alſo the Apoſtle aduiſeth them, not to be wiſe in their owne conceits: yea, & Chriſt himſelf condemneth the hypocritical righteouſneſſe of the Phariſees, that eſteeme ſo much of themſelues, & contemne other men, from whoſe ſocietie, they are ſeperated and diuided: yet lo, there be found euen among vs, ſuch kind of perſons, as, whiles they ſeeme to deteſt the pope & his dānable doctrines, & pretend a ſingular zeale or iealouſie, tending to reformation beyond al other mē, do neuertheleſſe far eſtrange themſelues from that right Chriſtian zeale, which combineth with perfect knowledge and chriſtiaen loue. Therfore they cannot yeeld themſelues to be either content, or cōtained within their due bounds and dutie of life, or to be friendly admoniſhed by any others, to obſerue & performe
the ſame. But as they which haue their brains buſied with ſome ſtrange enchauntment,Theſe renew the Sect of the Pariſees in their ſtrāge conceits and hypocriſie, they are moſt ſingularly conceited, & are become more phariſaicall. I meane not in this, that they yeeld tithes of Mint of Anice, & of al that they poſſeſſe for there be none which tithe their cōmodities to the benefit of the labourors in the lords vinyard, worſe then ſome of them: nor in this, that they faſt twiſe in the weeke, for there be none which gurmandize more thē they: nor in this that they expreſſe a kind of ciuil iuſtice in their life and demeanure: for in no perſons is there found leſſe good conſcience, and more deceitfull and cruell dealings in any trades, then there is well approoued to bee in many of them. And would to God they did not alſo doubt of the Reſurrection of the dead, which yet the Phariſees beleeued, nor did think that the doctrine of immortalitie is but a pleaſant errour to holde men in a vaine hope, as ſome heathen men haue fondly imagined▪ But in this they diſplay their ſect: namely,Tuſe. queſt. that they eſteeme themſelues onely wiſe, righteous, holy, and perfect, & in this their pleaſant conceit, they diſlike, diſdaine, & contemne al other men, of whatſoeuer order, calling, or degree they be, whome they giue ouer to Satan, and cenſure to the Pitte of Hell, as fooles, Publicans, and prophane worldlings. With the Egyptians, they thinke it abhomination for them to eate with the Hebrewes:Egyptians. Iewes. with the Iews, they hold it not lawfull for them to meddle with the Samaritanes,Gen. 43.32. Iohn. 4.9. Act. 10.28. or to haue any fellow ſhip with them which are of another nation. And therfore ſpread they this proud banner of defiance vnto all others: Depart from vs, for wee are
more holy then yee, more iuſt, more pure, more perfect then ye are: and that which is lawfull for vs to do, is not lawfull for you.

2 Thus flie they would from Charybdis, but they fall on Scylla: they feare the fire, and are drowned in the water: not conſidering how good & commendable a thing it is, to keepe the kings high way in the feare of God, and in the peace of a good conſcience.
