From hence they fall into high diſlike of the preſent State, the time, the perſons, the place, and as lettle children of variable affections; & as the foole which changeth with the Moone, they deſire nouelties, they hunt after innouations, they are much buſied in words, in endleſſe genealogies, in vaine queſtions, and in ſuch matters, as are both vnprofitable & vnneceſſarie: about the which (in the heate of their contentions) they veritfie Homers ſentence.

q.l: The haſtie man condemneth the ſame,
VVhich doth at all deſerue no blame.

div.p:
Whereby, with the vndiſcreete, they forſake the honour,Eccl. 5.14. and take on them the ſhame of the tongue, and ſo draw on themſelues iudgement and deſtruction. In their opinions and cenſures, they reſemble well nigh the fooliſh Maſons of Leſbia, who (as the prouerbe is) hauing leaden ſquares, would rather bow them to their works, then work vnto them: for they preſume without bluſhing, to draw the lawes, the ſtatutes, and conſtitutions, to their proper conceits: yea, they wreſt the holy Scriptures (as hee did which called them a noſe of waxe) to their ſelfe-wils and phantaſtical opinions,
notwithſtanding the perrill of that terrible woe threatned vnto them which cold euill good, and good euill: and vnto them, which preſume to adde vnto, or to diminiſh from the pure worde of God.Iob. 13.7. As in the 2. Chap. 1. Luke 15.27. Bern in cant. ſer. 73. A. Iſay 6.20. Reuel. 224.18. But they pretende the defence of Gods cauſe, and therefore thinke that they may therein ſpeake at their pleaſures. Laſtly, they verie notablie reſemble that angrie Elder brother in the Goſpell, as did the former ſort: for through pride; enuie, and diſdaine, they rather chooſe to ſtande and ſtay without the doore in moſte miſerable manner, then vouchſafe to come, and enter into the houſe of ioy and gladneſſe,Pſal. 133. there to proue howe good and ioyfull a thing it is for brethren to dwell togither in vnitie, though they alſo bee there unto both inityted, and gentlie entreated, by a moſte louing and mercyfull Father.

3 Miſtake me not (charitable Brethren) God forbid that I ſhould condemne or diſlike the godlie zeale of the faithfull Chriſtian,The life of Religion. which with a good conſcience I do reuerence and ſingularly eſteeme, as the verie Life of Religion, and the right Ornament of them that feare the Lord. It is good to bee zealous in a good cauſe: and the ſeruaunt of God is euen rauiſhed with the zeale of the Lorde▪ betweene the which, and, that Euill zeale which is not according to knowledge, it muſt bee diſtinguiſhed.

The Good zeale, or the zeale of God is,The good zeale. that affections or deſire • oman, whereby hee is indeed and with all his heart, zealous for the Lorde, according to knowledge. And this is an ardent
loue of the glorie of God, of righteouſneſſe, of iudgement, of wiſedome, of pietie, of chaſtitie, and other godly vertues. A vehement diſpleaſure conceiued agaynſt vnrighteouſneſſe, oppreſſion, fooliſhneſſe, vngodlineſſe, filthineſſe and ſin, whereby the glorie of God is deformed, and the Church of Chriſt offended: alſo a feruent deſire to puniſh the tranſgreſſours of the lawe of God, to withſtande vngodlineſſe, to depreſſe and aboliſh ſinne.

4 This vertue ſhined in meaſure in Abraham, in Moſes, in Daniel, in Loth, in Ieremie, in Phinez, in Dauid, in Eliah, in Paule; and without meaſure in our Sauiour Chriſt. And they in this outrage doo expreſſe the ſame: who, beleeuing in the Sonne of GOD, are marked with the note of contrition: which are ſorie for Ioſephs affliction: which are greeued for the common and dayly tranſgreſsions of the Lordes people: which doo earneſtlie deſire the aduancement of Gods glorie, and the aboliſhing of ſinne: which doo groane for the deliuerie of the Church, from thoſe horrible perſecutions wherewith ſhee is dayly oppreſſed: that doo hunger and thirſt after righteouſneſſe: that pray for an ende of thoſe dayes of ſinne, and waite for the ioyfull comming of our Lorde Ieſus Chriſt: who ſhall chaunge our vile bodies, that wee may bee conformed to his glorious bodie. This affection is ingendered in the heart,VVhereof this zeale is engendred. or in the concupiſcible part of man, by the effectuall operation of the Spirite of God: the ſpirit of wiſdome and vnderſtanding, the ſpirit of counſell & fortitude, the ſpirit of knowledge; and of the feare of God. This zeale enſueth
faith and hope, and is ſo combined with charitie, that though between them we may diſtinguiſh, yet diuide them wee may not:Cant. 5.8. for the zealous Chriſtian is euen ſicke with holy loue. Therfore Auguſt. ſaith thereof, Qui non zelat, non amat; & è contrario, qui non amat, non zelat: That is, He that is not zealous doth not loue: and againe, he that loueth not, is not zealous. And this vertue hath both affinitie, and familiaritie, with that vehement affection of loue which is called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or Iealouſie,The godlie iealouſie. as that of a man to his wife, or of a wife to her husband, when either of them is ſorie and diſpleaſed for ſome vnworthie or ingratefull action or thing which is perceiued in the other of them. For this affection is not able to beare the hurt or contempt of the thing loued: and it is right ſorie, that the thing which is onlie proper to it ſelfe, ſhould bee made common to others. The Lord God himſelfe, though he be not touched with mans infirmities, nor ſubiect to paſſions, ſpeaketh 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , after the maner of man, for the inſtruction and cōfort of man, and ſaith, that He will be iealous ouer his land: that is,Ioel. 2.28. that he will not ſuffer his own children which repent them of their ſinnes to be any further vexed and troubled as they had bin: as of whō he ſaid alſo in the ſame affection. He that toucheth you, toucheth the apple of mine eye. And the ſame Lord beeing a iealous God, beareth not, that his people ſhoulde runne a whooring from him, and giue his glorie to another. Neither could his Sonne abide this, that his holy houſe ſhoulde be made a denne of theeues. Vnto this alſo belongeth that zeale which is defined a ſorrow conceiued of that good which we ſee to bee in ſome others,
which we our ſelues do want: ſo that therein wee do not enuie that good in them, nor do wiſh that they had it not, nor ſorowing for that they be in better caſe then our ſelues are, (though they bee not alwayes worthie the ſame): but onely, we are greeued and do lament the want thereof in our ſelues, and in ſome others alſo, whom wee would ſhould enioy that good thing with them and vs: yea, and it congratulateth with them their good lot. And hereof is it, that we be ſo ſorrowfull, becauſe ſome other men are holier then we are: that is, becauſe we be not ſo religious, ſo deuout, and ſo perfite as they be. Againe, we are ioyfull when we ſee, that ſuch as are worthy for their vertues, are honoured accordinglie: but yet we be ſorrowfull, that we ourſelues, and ſome others are either not ſo worthie as they, or being worthie, are yet in contempt, and not eſteemed with them in thoſe things which appertaine to the glory of God. The Lord God make vs all right zealous and iealous for his glorie, according as himſelf in his word, his deare ſon in the Goſpel, and his holy Patriarkes, Prophets, Apoſtles and Martyrs, both by their diuined doctrines, and worthy examples of life haue taught vs. For it is certaine, that the God of the Spirits of all fleſh, Pſal. 51.17. Nom. 25.11.13. doth neuer deſpiſe the woful and troubled ſpirits, and the broken and contrite hearts of his people, as a moſt pleaſant ſacrifice vnto himſelfe, and he accepteth their zeale and holie iealouſie, as a vertue worthie the remembrance from one generation vnto another.

Cacozelia, Euill zeale.5 But there is a Iealouſie which is not cōmendable: & there is a zeale which is not according to knowledge: for if it were not ſo, then might we neither
condemne them that crucified Chriſt, nor reproue them that perſecuted the Apoſtles and holy Martyrs of Chriſt, which did therein they knewe not what. And there is a kinde of zeale, and a kinde of Iealouſie, wherewith they be enflamed, which cenſure and condemne all other men, and onely cleare and commend themſelues, with thoſe their chiefe heads & authors whom the word of God condemneth. Theſe be they, who in the heate of their paſſions, and carnall affections, pretend reformation of things which are amiſſe, & make great ſemblances and ſhewes of religion, honeſtie, and vertue: when as (that notwithſtāding) they hunt after the wealth, eſtimation, & glory of the world: they would gladly be enriched before others: they would be preferred to al others: they would be praiſed in their actions beyond all others, as they conceit themſelues to be better then all others. And for this purpoſe they labor to inuent, diuulgate, & thruſt into the church, ſingular and ſtrange opinions of their owne heades, which they wold ſhould be eſteemed, eſtabliſhed, and defended, as equall with the ſacred worde of God. Such were the Epicures, the Phariſees, the Anabaptiſts, and Heretikes of the former times: ſuch are the Sciſmatikes, and diſcontented heades of this time, which ſo much trouble the Church with their opinions, & endanger the peace of good Common-wealthes, with their ſiniſter practiſes. And yet they are not pleaſed (as indeed they knowe not the right Contentation) but they breake foorth vnorderly into a vehement griefe of minde, and angry countenance againſt the cōdigne preferment and good of ſuch other men, as far ſurmount them
in learning, godlineſſe, and vertue: neither can they conceale, but are moued dayly to vtter and expreſſe their longing deſire of the hurt and ſhame of thoſe men, not reſpecting their preferment and good, but onely that euill and hurt they wiſh them, for an obiect:Luke 15. and ſo they apprehend that Good, not as Good, but as Euil, with that angry Elder brother, of whom our Lord ſpeaketh in the Goſpel. And this is that zeale, and that kind of iealouſie, which hath none affinitie nor fellowſhip at all, with fayth, hope, and charitie, nor any part of knowledge and the feare of God: and therfore, it is either blind zeale, & doting iealouſie, Gal. 5.20. or rather that very wicked Enuy, hatred, furie, and worke of the fleſh: yea, the tyrannie of the ſoule, & partinacy of the hart, which is ingendred of that Luciferan pride, and diueliſh ambition grafted in mans corrupt nature by the ſubtile ſerpent, by the which a man thinketh himſelf better thē other men: and therfore would be in all reſpects not only equal with others, but alſo more excellent, & aboue them al. A vice, which the Lord abhorreth from his heart, and tieth them which are therewith prouoked, in puniſhment among the hollow hearted hipocrites.

Note this.No doubt ſuch kind of zealous perſons were theſe friends of Iob, who pretending the glorie of God, diſputed with him wickedly in the cauſe of God: for the which he ſharply reproued thē in theſe words: VVill ye ſpeake wickedly for Gods defence:
Iob. 13.7.9.10. and talke deceitfully for his cauſe? he wil ſurely reproue you. As if he ſhuld ſay: will ye preſume in the diſplay of your zeale, to reaſon raſhly and fooliſhly of the holie and diuine things of God? do ye thinke that the Lord needeth the wits and arguments of ſuch perſons for the ſetting forth of his glory? No, no, ye grate too much
on his diuine iuſtice, and take his name in vaine: for the which doing, he will not hold you guiltleſſe.

6 But yet,Some haue a deepe conteſt of their owne zeale and puritie, howſoeuer it be. there be ſome that wold (if they could) perſwade vs, that there is no zeale to their zeale, no iealouſie to their iealouſie, no wiſdom to their wiſdom, no iuſtice, no temperance, no charity, no faith, no vertues, to their iuſtice, to their temperance, to their charitie, to their faith, to their vertues, & that if their diſcipline were once practiſed in our Church, and their inuented lawes prouided for our Common-wealth, and al things ruled & ordred in points as they haue deuiſed, and could direct through the abundance of their ſpirit,They dreame of ſuch a puritie, as yet neuer was, nor ſhall be ſeene among men in this world. then the Moone which is ſo oftentimes obſcured, would ſhine in the night, yea, & alſo in the day, without the apperance of any cloud or blemiſh: vntil then, ſhe is iuſtly to be ſhunned (in their conceit) nor be they diſpoſed to take in good part the benefit of ſuch light as ſhe yeeldeth. They imagine that the Church, which is yet but blacke, and deformed (as ſhee is compared with Chriſt her glorious head) woulde then haue in her neither ſpot nor wrinckle, nor any ſuch thing. And this puritie, they expect to be yet ere they die, euen here in this life: vntill the which time, they be not willing to ſerue God (as it ſeemeth) in that holie Communion. As if they woulde ſay to God: well, let all things be thus, and thus perfected, or elſe will we not honour thee, nor ſerue thee, as thou wouldeſt that we ſhould honour, and ſerue thee. Yea (as the Bethulians that appoynted God a time at their pleaſure,Iudith 7.31. and 8.11. within fiue dayes) they dreade not to tie the wiſedome of God vnto theyr deuiſes, and to their appoynted times: Let this thing thus bee done ſhortlye: wee, wee will hasten reformation, and do
it our ſelues ſpeedily, and not wait any longer for the performance of words and promiſes. As if (forſooth) it were not onely lawfull for them to make, alter, & change lawes, and reforme al things at their own pleaſures: but alſo, that it were poſsible themſelues could reforme all, and conſtrain euery action of man to anſwer to right perfection in this world, wherein the very beſt things that be, do ſauor of imperfections, through the contagion of mans concupiſcence and ſin:Eccles. 3.16. neither can they be corrected, as Salomon cōplained. They imagine, that if they did once attempt it, they were well enough able with Aratus Eudoxus, Aratus. to number the ſtars in the firmament of heauen: the which is a matter ſo ſoone, and ſo eaſie to be done, as it is to count and to number the ſand by the Sea ſhore. Wherin they deal far more impudently then euer that Aratus, or any other skilfull Mathematitian in the world durſt, to defend his knowledge & abilitie therin.Diogenes trampled with his fowle feete on Platoes cleane bed clothes, when he ſaid ſo. They pretend with Diogenes to tread downe Platoes pride: but yet, with a more hawtie pride, then euer harboured in Platoes heart, howſoeuer Diogenes, and they in outwarde appearaunce would ſeeme to be. Howbeit, dreaming (neuertheleſſe) of Platoes Common-wealth, they waxe both extreame wiſe, and extreame iuſt, not conſidering the whiles, how much they decipher themſelues therein,Extreame wiſe both extreame fooliſh, and extreame wicked: as, not onelie Ageſelaus, but alſo Salomon, iudgeth of ſuch perſons, to whoſe moſt graue cenſure, Saint Paule condiſcendeth, when hee woulde not, that men ſhould bee wiſe in their owne conceits. Thus wandring at large in and through manie matters, both ſtrange & extrauagant, they leaue
the body, and take the ſhadow: they depreſſe the truth, and maintaine errors: they go from the matter,VVhiles men ſtriue in opinions, they neglect the preaching of Chriſt Ieſus. and take hold of the trifles (as Hierome once ſaid of ſuch vaine perſons) would to God they would conſent with vs, that Ieſus Chriſt be preached ſincerely and plainely: for it is too manifeſtly ſeene, how this neceſſarie argument is neglected, betweene them that ſtriue and contend to maintaine, opinions God helpe vs.

7. But there is no conſideration with them (the whiles) that extreme Law is meere wrong, Summumius. as the common ſaying is, or that the Lawes regarde rather generall then priuat and particular things, One thing muſt be conſidered with another. which are often referred to the equitie and wiſe moderation of the magiſtrates. Neither do they remember, how that the wiſe man alſo offendeth ſometimes as the foole doth: and that ſuch an exact iuſtice and diſcipline, as they labour to eſtabliſh, ſauouring little or nothing of Equitie, hath decayed many kingdomes, and troubled many Churches.It is eaſier to throw downe, then to build vp. Wee are bound to bend to the beſt in euerie deliberation (wherin the Lorde in mercie fill vs with the graces of his ſpirit) but it is no point of wiſedome for a man which hath a well builded houſe alreadie, to pull the ſame downe, before hee hath made his reckoning, and bee aſſured of his abilitie, and meanes to build the ſame better. It is much eaſier to throw downe, then it is to build vp: to kill, then to cure: to rent aſunder, then to ſette together: to moue warres, then to procure peace: though the fine thereof be not ſo profitable. And to trouble a Cittie (ſaid Pindare) it is a thing quickly doone;Pindar. but to reduce the ſame Citie into a quiet ſtate, it lieth not in the power
of man, but in the gift of God. Paul is very peremtorie in this, that wee ſhould not do euill, that good may come thereof.
VVe muſt do good things and do them well.
G. Nazan. de Y. beol. li. 1. Ariſt. eth. 2. Good things are foreuer commendable: but theſe good things ought to bee done directly and well: leaſt whiles we beare men in hande that wee doo iuſt things, by dealing in and about them, moſt vniuſtly we depriue them of their proper graces. Of this minde was learned Ariſtotle, who vſed alſo to ſay, that he was not iuſt and wiſe, which did ſuch things, but he onely which ordred them well. And of this Argument Iohannes Gerſon (if it were not ſome other) bringeth in two Souldiers diſputing:Io. Gerſ. in dial. duorum militum. They that haue made of men Martyres (ſayde the one of them to his fellow) haue made a good thing? to whom anſwered the other, yea, but yet they haue not made that good thing well: Et Deus remunerator Aduerbiorum, non Nominum, And God rewardeth not Nownes, but Aduerbes. That is: God doth not ſo much regard what things men do,God reſpecteth rather the qualitie then the quantitie of works & faith. as hee doth in what ſort they doo them. The death of Chriſt was a good thing, when as through the ſame al them that beleeued are freed from death and damnation, which Chriſt in his death ouercame and deſtroyed: howbeit, the Iewes, the high Prieſts, Pilate, Caiphas, Annas, Herod, Iudas, and the diuell, haue conſented together, and dealt therein moſt wickedly, vngodlily, traiterouſly, and diuelliſhly. Wherefore they haue their iudgement and heauie condemnation, taken from the manner of their labours therein. Therefore, as wee are willing to do good, ſo lette vs haue this regarde to retaine the right grace of good deedes: that is, as Nazanzen ſayde, To do them well. In li. 1. de Theolog. And this ſhall we doo indeede, if wee
deale in the feare of God and with a good conſcience, according to the methode and rule of the word of God, which ſhall neither deceiue vs, nor cauſe to to repent our trauailes beſtowed about the ſame. And this is that which Zacharie entended when hee ſaide, that wee being deliuered from the handes of our enemies, ſhould ſerue God, in holineſſe and righteouſneſſe, all the dayes of our life.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the Malepertneſſe of certaine priuate and ignorant perſons, which preſume to cenſure the Prince, the Magiſtrates, the Miniſters, &c.
div.p:
IT is right and meete that faults ſhould be reprooued, corrected,Euerie man is not to be a corrector or reproouer of other mens faults. or contemned, ſo farre, that neither heinous ſinnes in perſons, nor horrible inconueniences or miſchiefs in lawes, ſhould vnder tearmes of honeſtie and iuſtice, bee defended. Amici vitia ſiferas, facistua, If thou ſuffer the vices of thy friende (ſaith Seneca) thou makeſt them thine owne. He ſpeaketh of thoſe vices which no man by the Law of friendſhip, ſhould winke at in his deere friende. And Eraſmus in his Moria, will that the faults of our friendes ſhould be corrected,In lib. de amicit. alluding vnto Cicero, who in his book of friendſhip,
will haue nothing diſſembled in friendſhip. And indeede, he that in ſuch a caſe ſo winketh at the hainous offences of others,Leuit. 19.17. that he yeeldeth obſequie to the ſinner, committeth a double ſinne. This is the general law: Thou ſhalt in any wiſe rebuke thy neighbor, and ſuffer not ſinne to reſt vppon him: but thou ſhalt not hate him in thine hart. Euerie man is not meete to be a reprouer of others. Howbeit we be alſo taught, that it is not meete that therefore euery priuate perſon ſhould be a fault finder, a reproouer, a correcter, a iudge of euerie law, of euerie perſon, of euerie offence, in euery ſort, in euerie place, and as him liſteth, without diſcretion and difference: for then, how ſhould the law be anſwered, Honour father and mother? howe ſhould Peters rule be obſerued: Loue couereth the multitude of ſinnes? how ſhould the words of Chriſt be followed, Iudge not: condemne not? how ſhould Iames be vndeſtood, Bee not many maiſters (my brethren) knowing how that wee ſhall receiue the greater damnation: for in many things we ſin all? P. Berthor. in. 1. Sam. 24 5, 6. Item, de orig. Concil Nicen: ſub Conſtan. hiſto. Eccl. li. 10. ca. 1. The Emperour Conſtantine holding it vnlawfull for priuate men or inferiour perſons, to cenſure or iudge the Magiſtrates and Biſhoppes, cauſed all thoſe Libelles to be burned, which contained the accuſations of certaine Biſhoppes in a generall Councell. Indeed there be not many called to this function, much leſſe euerie perſon. Therefore albeit that Mardochai the Iew, was an eſpecall inſtrument appointed by the Lord to work with Heſther, the reuerſion of the kings commaundement,Exo. 18. Nom. 16.1. yet did it not become Haman to face hir preſumptuouſly. Though Iothro was heard in his good counſaile which hee gaue to Moſes, yet Dathan vrged him both vntimely and vniuſtly. And notwithſtanding
the Prophet Nathan, and the prophet Gad, were ſpecially rayſed vp and ſent to Dauid by the Lord,Luth. in Eccl. ca. 10.20. to reproue him for his faults: it became not Michel (for all that) to mocke the king her huſband, and to call him foole. Nor was it meete and right, that malicious Shimei ſhould ſo vnreuerently rayle at the Lords Annointed, and curſe and checke him. For this buſineſſe belonged not onely vnto him, nor did he deale therin diſcreetely. Moreouer, to teach how vnſeemely a thing it is, either for children to note or diſplay their owne fathers faults, or for the inferiours to be iudges and correctours of their ſuperiours, the Scripture telleth, that Shem and Iaphet, Shem and Iaphet winked at and couered their fathers faults. the two ſonnes of Noah, did ſo diſſemble their fathers faults, that they did not onely care, not to behold them; but alſo had great regarde to couer and conceale them and therefore they went towards him to couer him, their faces being turned away. And the ſame Scripture ſaith, that becauſe Cham had vnreuerently reuealed his fathers fault,Cham reuealed his fathers fault. he was much diſliked of his brethren, and of his father. Alſo the Poets tel, that one Actaeon for ſuch a thing was deuoured of his owne dogges;Actaeon deſcried the nakedneſſe of Diana. as a puniſhment meete for him that taketh pleaſure to deſcrie and diſplay other mens faults, eſpecially of them whome he ought to reuerence, honour, and obey.

2. Next, as wee ſhould not ſpeake wickedly though for Gods cauſe, ſo alſo in thoſe cauſes,In what ſort faults muſt be reprooued. in thoſe places, and of thoſe perſons, wherin it becommeth well Moſes himſelfe to be iealous, and Paul to be zealous, there ſhould be no curſed and vngodly ſpeeches vſed among true Chriſtians, either of them in authoritie and office, or of any other whatſoeuer.
It is expreſſely forbidden in the law, that any man ſhould rayle vpon the Gods: that is, vpon the princes and magiſtrates, or to ſpeak euill of the ruler of the people.
Eccl. 10.10. Which alſo Salomon intendeth when he ſaith: Curſe not the King, no, not in thy thought: Neither ſpeake euil of the rich, that is of the magiſtrate, in thy bedchāber.

VVhat to eſteeme of the Lawes, and how wee ſhould deale one with one another.According to the true meaning of that law, the Apoſtles of our Lord, Peter, Iames, Paul, and the Lord himſelf haue moſt prouidently taught & aduiſed vs, aſwell by example, as by word, that we ſhuld ſpeak, iudge, and eſteem of the lawes, magiſtrates, and miniſters of the word, with great reuerence & regard. And with whomſoeuer we ſtriue, or of whomſoeuer we talk, our words ſhuld be ſo ſeaſoned & tempered, yt no note of bitter curſing paſſe our mouthes: & this Michael our cheefe captaine hath alſo taught vs in his contention with the diuel, by the teſtimoby of S. Iude. Iudae. ver. 9. And that, as touching the infirmities & offences of priuate perſons, we that be Chriſtians, and ſhould immitate our maiſter,Priuate offences. muſt take heede, how we take on vs haſtily to iudge of them, and ſo to condemne them: nay rather we ſhould by charity couer the multitude of ſins, and knowing our ſelues to be ſpiritual & ſtronger then ſome others, we ought neither to quip them with bitter ſcofs and vnſeemely taunts, Gal. 6.1.3. nor too rigorouſly reprehend & reproue them: but (as it is the propertie of the righteouſneſſe of faith and ſpiritual iuſtice) to beare with the weak, and gently to enforme and aſſay to reſtore them, as the Apoſtle Paul aduiſeth, whereto he addeth this reaſon, Leaſt thou alſo be tēpted. He that obſerueth not this rule, had need to feare, leaſt the Spirit of God reproue him of iudgement: and that out of his own
words, there be not gathered againſt himſelf, Ioh. 16.8. matter both to iudge and to condemne him. So dangerous and ſo dreadful a thing it is, to be a cenſour, a iudge, a reproouer of others.

3. But (this notwithſtanding) curious Caliſthenes diſliketh all things in the Court of Alexander,
It is the nature of ſome perſons to diſlike all things, and to check the beſt men, but to amend nothing in themſelues. Sen. li. 3. de Ira.
Iuuenal. ſat. 8. Homer. Il.
and talketh therof his pleaſure without wiſedom, reuerence or feare. Demochares alſo that ſaucie Parrheſiaſtes of Athens, is ouer-bold with king Philip of Macedonia, and that impudent and deformed Graecian Therſites, bluſheth not to taunt and prattle moſt malepertly againſt noble Achilles and other mightie men of his Countrey. Yea, the verie baſe Seriphian (that cannot liue though hee were an Athenian without ſhame) obiecteth, as it pleaſeth him, to Themiſtocles the Athenian (who though he were a Seriphian, would not liue without honour.) And who perceiueth it not, how well this is digeſted of thē that emulate others, that ſome priuate perſons, Iob. 30, 8, 9, 10. ignorant mē, yea, ſuch as are diſtained with whoredoms, dronkennes, vſury, theft, piracie, murthers, & other vile ſins, ſhuld preſume to cenſure the prince, the iudges and magiſtrates, the biſhops and paſtors, with open mouthes, and that (which is moſt horrible) they ſhould blaſpheme the prince, the magiſtrates, the miniſter, the lawes? Be theſe zealous perſons? be theſe reformed people? haue they beene ſchooled and learned the true diſcipline? Nay, Iudae. 4.16, 19. 2. Pet. 2.10. Shem and Iaphet turned away their faces, as not willing to behold it. rather they be the ſame (among others) of whome S. Iude ſpeaketh in his Epiſtle▪ and ſuch of whome Saint Peter propheſieth, which haue a pleaſure (not with Shem and Iaphet, to diſſemble and to aſſay to conceale their Fathers fault, but vnreuerently
with Cham the father of Chanaan to diſcouer and divulgate the ſame) to ſpeake euill of them that be in authoritie, to walke after the fleſh in the luſt of vncleanneſſe, being perſons preſumptuous, and ſuch as ſtand in their owne conceit. To yeelde vnto the prouiſion of any good Law, or to exhibit any gratefull aſſiſtance or obedience to the wiſeſt makers and beſt executioners of Lawes, they be farre behind all others, whatſoeuer they make ſhew of; and who ſeeth not what they bee contented to yeeld vnto for the good of the Church and common wealth, without bitter murmur & grudge? Beſides that, in their common cenſures,Mat. 24. Luke 19. they expreſſe ſuch charitie towards their brethren and neighbours, as thoſe latter times, wherof Chriſt propheſied, do affoord: and yet they would ſhew deepe deuotion, Iam. 1.26. not conſidering what Saint Iames had ſaide:It is the nature of charitable chriſtians, to be ſory for other mens faults and infirmities. If any man among you ſeeme to be devout, and refraineth not his tongue, but deceiueth his owne heart, this mans deuotion is vaine. The right charitable chriſtians, ſeeing that the Iuſt man falleth ſeauen times in a day, that the very Iudgement Seate ſauoureth of oppreſſion, and that the Fathers and Elders of the Church haue had their particular faults, do rightly conſider of mans nature;Eccleſ. 3.16. incident to ſlidings, and they be moſt ſorie, not onely for the falles of their brethren and friendes, with Moſes, Nehemiah, and Paul:Dolendum ſi quis inter nos m • lus. but alſo for the tranſgreſſions of their mortall enemies and ſtrangers▪ with Dauid, Daniel, the Apoſtles, and their Maiſter Christ: hauing the like ſimpathie and compaſſion that one membe • hath ſuffering with another.Bucer in Mat. 26.
•• arra: Sect. 4. Aboue al, they lament the imperfections of them that bee in authoritie and publike places, as of Salomon, of Peter, of Dauid, of Iehoſophat;
which are in them (though they be otherwiſe gods ſeruants) as the paine of the heade enflaming the whole body and as oughly ſpots in a tower of excellent beautie, to the vnſpeakable griefe of the godly.

But, as for theſe vncharmed,Vncharitable tongues. and vncharitable perſons, which haue not yet learned to ſpeake well of any,Pindarus. they eſteeme ſlaunderous wordes for moſt daintre morſels (as Pindar ſaid of ſuch) when comming togither they cannot onely cut with theyr tongues (as with ſharpe raſors, Iob 30, 8, 9, 10 that pierce and diuide aſunder) but alſo, as hungry Rauens which feed on the carkaſſes, they deuour thē that be abſent with gredineſſe and delight: But if that a perſonage of account or name fall into their mouths, oh God!
The play of the Cat the death of the Mouſe.
Boet. de cont. ſol..
Philo. li. 2. Met. 7. how he is toſſed, turned, gnawne and rent in peeces among them, with iolitie and pleaſure? They play with him as the Cat plaieth with the Mouſe, and they draw him to the extremity of that ſecōd death; wherof Boethius ſpeaketh, wherby (to their power) they depriue him of al good name, honour, and authoritie, both in his life, and after his departure alſo, with all greedineſſe.

In the maner of this iudgement,Haſtie and raſh iudgemēt touching other men. Alexander.
Alexanders example is ſet a ſide, for he would cōmonly ſtop the one of his eares, when he heard and accuſation againſt any man, vntill the partie accuſed could come to anſwer for himſelfe. But with them, impudent Actaeon can no ſooner deſcry naked Diana, Inſcius Actaeon vidit ſine veſte Dianam. Ouid. and ſhameleſſe Cham diſcouer his owne fathers fault: but by & by, there be mightie occaſions profered as they thinke, to Momus of reprehēſion, to Zoilus of railing, to Timon of deteſtation. So Doeg accuſeth, Nabal ſlaundereth, & Shimei curſeth the Lords anointed: the viper
hangeth on Pauls hande, aſſaying to hurt and ſting him to death: and the vnnurtered boyes mocke Elizeus in great ſport and play. As if they would ſay: There, there, for ſo would we haue it! Now is his holy life brought to light! Of ſuch Dauid complained in his daies. Mine enemies ſpeake euill of me: when ſhall he die, and his name periſh? And if he come to ſee me, he ſpeaketh vanitie, and his heart conceiueth falſhood within himſelfe, and when he commeth forth he telleth it. Is this religion? Is this charitie?

Puniſhment of ſlanderers and mockers.
2. Sam. 16.9. 1. King. 2.8. 5 But this kind would be better aduiſed (in mine opinion) if Dauid would but hearken to Abiſhai: or if his bent againſt Nabal were perfited: or if his charge which he gaue to Salomon touching Shimei, were in euery ſuch caſe ſeuerely executed: or if euerie true Chriſtian had that abilitie & wil (with Paul) to fling the viper into the fire: or, that the Lord did ordinarily execute his vengeance with ſhee-Beares on ſuch mockers now, as he did on thoſe vnnurtured boyes then. Neither would they be half ſo malepert in this malice, if euerie ſuch viper incurred the impriſonment,Ariſtogeton. condemnation and ende of Ariſtogeton the Athenian, for his faucineſſe againſt Phocian, and for his diſturbance of the Citizens: or at the leaſt, if but only that ſentence of Calipho (whom Plaute bringeth in ſpeaking to Pſeudolus) were exacted of thē by ſome lawfull officer.Plaut. in Pſeudol. Homines qui geſtant, quique auſeultant crimina, &c. Let both the ſlanderer (ſaith he) and the listner to the ſame, be hanged vp, the one by the tong, the other by the eares. And wel worthy: for (ſaith Bernard) as the one carieth the diuell in his mouth: ſo the other carieth the diuell in his eare: And they both being execrable offenders,Pſal. 15.3. are denied the right of Paradice.

But, foraſmuch as this ſentence wanteth an executioner;Hypocrites eſpie moates in other mens eyes, and perceiue not beams in their owne. neither is Peter euer ready with his ſword to cut off Malchus ear (which is ſo open to receiue ſiniſter reports) in the defence of his Maiſters innocencie, they wanting all charitie to couer the verie manifeſt ſins, preſume yet ſo to prie moſt curiouſlie with eager emulation on other men, in whoſe eyes they haue a delight to eſpie litle thin motes, whē yet they perceiue not the big beams in their own. Such an one (once pointing to a married Miniſter) ſaid of him in ſcorne: lo, this is he, that hath maried a wife,
Luke 14.26. and therfore he cānot come: not cōſidering the whiles, that himſelfe had not only maried a wife too, but had alſo fined a farme, and bought fiue yoke of oxen, and was ſo gone to ſuruey the one, and to proue the other, that he came not indeed: Howbeit, is the eie ſeeth all thing ſauing it ſelfe, ſo could he not ſee into himſelfe, though he gliked at his brother,Mat. 4. with the wreaſting of Scripture in ſuch a diſdainfull ſort, which is a part of the diueliſh diuinitie.

6. So curious are they in noting the liues of other men, ſecretly to accuſe them, bitterly to rip them;Their vanitie Gregor. hom. 36. ſuper illud Iuga beum emi quin
que . & moſt negligēt the whiles to ſee into themſelues, and to cleare themſelues of al their filthy abominations! Of all the vanities vnder the Sunne, this is not the meaneſt (by the iudgement of Saint Auguſtine. In libro. confeſſ. 10. ) But how neare they come to the nature thoſe hypocrites, of whō Bernerd ſpeaketh, let themſelues (whē they haue well ſearched and examined their owne hearts and conſciences) be the iudges: Volunt eſſe humiles fiue deſpectu, &c. They would appeare humble, but not in contempt: they would ſeeme poore, but without any want: well cloathed, without carefulneſſe: they woulde haue eaſe
without labour: flattering ſome: backbiting others: byting like Dogges: deceiuing like foxes: proude as Lions, and inwardly as rauening wolues. As beares they ſeeke the ſweeteneſſe of the honie of vaine glorie, and ſecrete delights. They will bee Iudges without authoritie, witneſſes without ſight, falſe accuſers without all truth. As if hee ſaide in one worde: Theſe bee verie Neroes, which yet would bee eſteemed Catoes. Might not Dauid ſay in this part of them, as hee ſayde, when hee expoſtulated with the counſailours and flatterers of Saule, who had ſecretly accuſed him, and openly ſlaundered him? Pſal. 58.1, 2. Is it true? (O Congregation) ſpeake yee iustly? O ſonnes of men? Iudge ye vprightlie? yea, rather ye imagine miſchiefe in your heart: your hands execute crueltie vpon the earth: And worthilie of them ſpeaketh Agur in the Prouerbs of Salomon.
Pro. 30.11, 12. There is a generation that curſe their father, and bleſſe not their mother. There is a generation that are pure in their owne conceit, and yet are they not waſhed from their filthineſſe. Our Sauiour in the Goſpel reproueth ſuch hypocrites;Mat. 7. and a verie heathen man (not able to ſuſtaine this curriſh kind) flingeth to thē this opprobrious ſtone
Horat. Cum tua peruide as oculis mala lippus in vnctis: cur?
Good counſaile. Plato. VVhat meaneſt thou with Serpents ſights,
ſo ſharpely to deſcrie
Thy neighbours faults; ſith thou maiſt ſee
thine owne with bleared eie?

7. But as hee which reproueth, ſhould not giue a iuſt occaſion to be reproued, leaſt in reprehending others he condemne himſelfe: ſo by Platoes aduice, if one find another man committing a fault, he ſhould looke by and by into himſelfe, and ſay ſecretly: Am not I ſuch an one?

Thus alſo counſaileth Syracides. Ecclus. 5.15.
Be thou not a priuie accuſer, as long as thou liuest, and vſe no ſlaunder with thy tongue: for ſhame and ſorrow goeth ouer the theefe, and an euill name ouer him that is double tongued: but he that is a priuie accuſer of other men, ſhall be hated, enuied, and confounded. Aboue all, Chriſt commaundeth:Christ, Iudge not, condemne not. Cast out the beame of thine owne eye. And Iames his holie Apoſtle,Iames. would that wee ſhould not backbite one another. This is the rule of the Goſpel, this is the Lawe, this is the Prophets.K. Henrie 8 Graft. in Chron. An. H. 8.37. And this thing reſpected that moſt noble King of famous memorie, Henrie the eight: when in open Parliament he ſayde among other things: Beholde, what loue and charitie is amongst you, when the one calleth the other Heretike, and Anabaptiſt: and he calleth him againe, Papiſt, Hypocrite, and Phariſie? Are theſe ſignes of fraternall loue betweene you? No, no. Againe, Alas, how can the poore ſoules liue in concord, when ye Preachers ſowe amongſt them in your Sermonms, debate and diſcord? Againe: yee of the temporaltie bee not cleane and vnſpotted of malice and enuie: for ye raile on Biſhops, ſpeake ſlaunderouſly of Priests, and rebuke and taunt preachers, both contrarie to good order, and Chriſtian fraternitie. If ye know ſurely that a Biſhop, or Preacher erreth, or ſpeaketh peruerſe doctrine, come and declare it to ſome of our Councell, or to vs, to whom is committed by God the high authoritie to reforme and order ſuch cauſes and behauiours: and bee not iudges your ſelues of your owne fantaſticall opinions, &c.

div.head: CHAP. X.

Of certaine proude, curious and diſcontented heades, which diſdaining the plaine ſenſe of holie Scriptures, and the iudgement of all the Antient and learned fathers and wiſe men, do hatch ſtrange opinions, and thruſt them into the Church, which they rather robbe and throwe downe, then any way benefite, or holde vp: yet vnder a godlie pretence. Againſt Polypragmoſine.
div.p:
Good menare heedfull not to offend others. Tit. 3.9. Excles. 18 THe charitable good men, being well ſchooled by Salomon, and the holy Apoſtle Paul, are very warie of ſtraunge doctrines, and of ſuch kind of queſtions, as do offend the weake brethren: neither deſire they to deale in ſuch actions, as rather annoy then profite the Church and Common-wealth. But in theſe dayes, many making ſhewe of zeale and vnderſtanding, doo neuertheleſſe farre eſtrange themſelues from both.Ecclus. 5.10. And whereas they ſhould ſtand faſt in the way of the Lord, & be ſtedfaſt in vnderſtanding, ſhould abide by the word, and follow peace and righteouſneſſe: ſhould be gentle to heare the word of God that they may vnderſtand it, Pſal. 58. Some preſume to argue verie raſhy of God and moue vp vnneceſſarie and perillous queſtions. and make a true anſwer with wiſdom: they notwithſtanding are moſt froward (as it were from the womb) they go aſtray, and ſpeak lies. Among theſe, there be found the hatchers of many ſtrange & fearfull opinions, the mouers vp of matters moſt vnneceſſarie, the brochers of many curious & dangerous queſtions: and they preſume to touch euen the high maieſty of our moſt gracious God, whom only, that
a man ſhould name without great reuerence and feare, is ſin: & of whoſe cauſes, that any man ſhould preſume to argue, without humilitie and Chriſtian wiſdome, it is well worthy of a heauie iudgement. But they, as blind men, run towards the pit of perdition, readie to fall into the ſame before they perceiue it: neither wil they withdraw their vnwaſhen hands frō polluting the moſt holy things. And albeit this be moſt plaine, that all power both in heauen, Apoc. 1.
and in earth, belongeth to our Lord Ieſus Chriſt, and that the man Chriſt Ieſus is our mediatour, and Lord ouer all the kings of the earth, the which alſo hath bin gladly granted by thoſe Chriſtian Emperors, Conſtantius, Conſtantinus, Theodoſius, and Iuſtinian: yet, there be, who in their contentious diſputations about wordes and queſtions (in their vnſauorie diſtinctions) dread not to abridge the kingdom & power of Chriſt, & ſtrain curteſie to admit him into Samaria, becauſe he is apparelled like a Iewe: no maruell then, if they contemne his miniſters, and faithfull ſeruants.

2 Theſe men (as thoſe antient Gnoſtikes) being exalted in the conceit of their owne ſinguler wiſdom, Gnoſtici, a kind of heretikes, ſo called of their ſingular conceited wiſdom. Cap. 24. q. 3 decipher themſelues to be ſuch, as are aſhamed of our ſimple Ieſus, whom they haue tied vp; and of his plain doctrine, which only edifieth. For they ſtudie to vtter rather loftie things, then meet things, and in the pride of their harts imagin themſelues to be rather kings raigning with God in heauen, then men liuing amōg men on ye earth (as Auguſt ſaid of ſome ſuch in his time).Hanibal. Phormio. Cicer. 2. de orator. Homer. Theſe do nor only think (with Hanibal) that the old philoſopher Phormio d • reth, whē he telleth of a captains dutie and yt among the Poets great Homer noddeth & alſo that Sanct • s Bernerdus
non vidit omnia: Bern. Saint Bernerd was ignorant of manie things: and that other the holy Fathers, and learned doctours of the Church, haue doated in their Sermons, opinions, and diuine writings exceedingly, (whom indeed in all things (I ſay) we may not iuſtifie, foraſmuch as they being mortall men haue had their errours) but they proceede alſo to thinke that euen thoſe Apoſtles of Chriſt, whom the holy Ghoſt had repleniſhed, haue in their doctrine doated alſo: and were it not for ſhame, the corner ſtone and author of all wiſdome and truth, ſhould not eſcape their partial cenſures in this caſe. In the meane time, it is apparant, that themſelues doate deeplie indeed. But they will not haue it ſo: being better conceited of themſelues,Marcion. Montanus. learning their wiſdome (as it ſeemeth) of the two Heretikes, Marcion and Montanus, who (as it is reported of them) vſed to ſay, that themſelues knew many more and better things, then either Chriſt, or his Apoſtles euer knew. If it be ſo, then would they, that men ſhould honour them, and keepe them on line, Leaſt that whenſoeuer they depart the world, Iob. wiſdome ſhould alſo depart and periſh togither with them.

The end of their knowledge. Bern. 3 Oh Lord, that euer men ſhould be ſo impudent! It is apparant to what end they haue hunted after that knowledge which they haue: for ſeeing they vtter no iote of wiſdome, in that they haue thereby inſtructed themſelues, nor any ſparkle of charitie, in that they be not deſirous to edifie others, nor be any thing zelous therwith for the Lord of hoſts: it is plaine, that either with a couetous minde, they ſhoote at the wealth, riches, promotions, dignities, friends & fauor of ye world, or with a vain curioſitie
they ſtriue & contend to anſwere their proper conceits, or in vaine glorie expect the ſingular praiſes and commendations of worldly men, whome they would ſhould extoll them with high titles, though the Poet bee iuſtly moued to point at their follie.

q.l: Scire tuum nihil eſt: niſite ſcire hoc, ſciat alter?
By knowledge thine haſt thou no name:
Leaſt others know thou knowſt the ſame?

div.p:
Socrates, who was ſo excellent among the philoſophers, ſayde of himſelfe, that he knew nothing but this, that he knew nothing. But theſe men,Reuelines Ladder to knowledge. although they neuer aſcended the full grades of Reuchlins Ladder, know all things. This Ladder hath tenne ſteppes or ſtayes, as namely, the Obiect, the diſcord, the ſence exteriour, the ſence interiour, the imagination, the iudgement inferiour, the iudgement ſuperiour, the reaſon, the vnderſtanding, and the minde her ſelfe, from and by whoſe light, all other inferiour vertues are directed and gouerned. This is the Ladder, by the which a man aſcendeth to the knowledge of all things, which are either by ſence, or by knowledge, or by faith comprehended. They that haue not diſcreetely gone through all theſe grades, are moſt vnable to diſcerne and iudge betweene truth and falſhood, betwixt good and euill, and more vnable to teach and inſtruct others. Neither could theſe perſons without the fame, contriue and compaſſe any thing, were it not that they are ſo well conceited of their owne ſupernaturall ſpeculation, and inſpirations,Bucer. in Mat. 4. to the admiration of the ignorant, wherein they doo moſt
proudly tempt the Lord God.

Many ignorant men aduenture to reaſon raſhly of the higheſt myſteries,4. Very neare to the former commeth another crew, the which, albeit they neuer reade ouer in their mother tongue (I ſay not the Bible, but) that common Pſalter booke which the yonger children reade in the ſchooles, do yet (neuertheleſſe) nothing bluſh to exalt themſelues in learning & knowledge before others, of whome in reaſon they ſhould bee contented to learne: and preſume moſt arrogantly and proudly, to argue, reaſon, & diſpute of far higher matters, then their knowledge can extend vnto, and beyonde that it pleaſeth God to vtter, not onely vnto them, but vnto any man liuing, and that in this conceit, that themſelues are well able both to vnderſtand and argue of ſuch matters, with all kinde of dexteritie. indeed, this kind is not newly conceiued and brought forth, as in this age, or of late: for it hath beene of olde, of the which a certaine learned man thus ſpake:Petr. Rau. in ſermone. Quidam antequam diſciplinis clementartis, imbuantur, &c. There be ſome, which before they know theyr letters, enquire of a point, of a line, and of the ſuperficies and quantitie of the Soule, of deſtinie, of charge, and freewill, of the matter and moouings, of the beginnings of bodies, of the propagation of the multitude, and the ſection of greatneſſe: what thing time is: what is that ina • e •
voyd thing: what thing place is, and of the flowing and e •
bing of the great Oceans of the ſundrie ſecrets of hidden nature: of the diuers figures of cauſes: of the beginnings of things: and of many other ſuch like matters. Indeed theſe things require a more full knowledge and vnderſtanding, then the moſt in number haue attained vnto. And yet none more ready to talke argue, and diſpute of this and other ſuch high matters, other they are yea, euery ale-houſe and tauerne, euery market
place & feaſt houſe, and to be breefe (as Nazanzene once ſaid) euery company of men,Greg. Nazan. in de Theolog. libro. 1. euery aſſembly of womē is filled with their diuinity, wherby our faith and the holy religion of Chriſt beginneth to waxe nothing elſe, but as it were a ſophiſtrie, or a talking craft. And therin euery of thē, hunteth after ſtrange deuiſes, and new coyned conceits of his own head.Eccleſ. 12.

5 We are warned in the word of God to abandon ſuch proude conceits of our own wits,The word of god teacheth modeſtie and not curioſitie nor raſh iudgement of Scriptures. and ſuch curioſitie, and al irreuerent and raſh diſputations of the holy law of God: for the doctrine of the Spirit, doth not edge on curioſitie, but enkindleth the fire of charitie: therefore Chriſt ſent foorth his Apoſtles, not to ſpreade ſingular opinions of their owne heades, but to preach the Goſpel.Bern. in Cant. And to preuent their vaine boaſtings, and their haughtie mindes of their owne integritie, he put them in remembrance of Sathan that fell from heauen, after that hee had vaine-gloriouſly exalted himſelfe in his pride.
Luke 10.18. The wiſe Syracides giueth good counſaile when he ſaith: Eccleſ. 3.22.24. Seeke not out the things, that are aboue thy capacitie: and ſearch not the ground of ſuch things as are too mightie for thee: wherin he would not that men ſhuld be negligent in that which they ought to exerciſe thēſelues in, nor that they ſhuld leaue one iot of that, which they are cō manded to ſearch & learne in the word of God: but his meaning is, that they ſhould beware that they preſume not to enter into the ſecrets of God, which his will is not to reueale vnto men in this life, & that they take not on them to argue raſhly of thoſe diuine things, which yet they know not: for, as it is not good to eate too much honey,
Prou. 25.28. ſo curiouſly to ſearch out the glorie of heauenly things, it is not commendable. Saint Paul teacheth vs this by his owne example.
Albeit he had beene taken vp into the third heauen, and being in Paradice,2. Cor. 12. heard & ſaw many wonderfull and ſecret things: yet knowing how vnable mans infirmitie was to declare them, beeing neither ſhewed vnto him for that ende, hee did not ſtriue to vtter them, not to diſpute of ſuch things among men: but ſaid, He would refraine, leaſt any man ſhould thinke of him aboue that he ſaw of him, or heard of him. And when he had at large diſputed of the caſting out of the Iewes, and the receiuing in of the Gentiles; and perceiuing how farre the wiſedome and knowledge of God therein ſurmounted his capacitie, he ſtayed himſelfe, and ſhutte vp his diſputation and admiration. O the deepeneſſe of the riches both of the wiſedome and knowledge of God, how vnſearchable are his iudgements,
Rom. 11.33. and his waies paſt finding out! for who hath knowne the minde of the Lord, and who was his counſeller.

6. Nowe albeit theſe teſtimonies and examples be made perpetuall, and may well bee learned of them in our age,Some be neuer the better for the preaching of the word. vnto whom the ſame things are preached and made apparant by the light of the Scriptures: yet all this ſerueth not their turne, they are neuer the better, as thoſe Carions, that ſtinke with the heate of the Sunne, which to the creatures is ſo comfortable. For (as Bernard ſayd) Sol non omnes quibus lucet, Ber. ſuper. Cant. ſer. 23.
etiam calefacit: Sit Sapientia multos quos docet quid ſit faciendum, non continuo etiam accendit ad faciendum, &c. The Sunne doth not warme all them to whom he ſhineth: ſo neither doth wiſedome ſtraight wayes enflame them whom ſhe teacheth, to performe that which they ſhould do. It is one thing to knowe what riches is: it is another thing to haue riches in poſſeſſion. Neither doth
the knowledge of riches make a man rich: but the poſſeſſion of riches. But ſuch is the arrogancie of theſe perſons, that becauſe they haue ſeene the Sunne,They thinke better of thē ſelues then they deſerue. they thinke they be ſufficiently warmed by his light only: becauſe they haue heard tell of riches, they imagine themſelues right rich: becauſe that VViſedome hath ſent forth her maidens in the higheſt places of the citie, Prou. 3.9.
and inuited them vnto her though they came not, nor would be inſtructed: therefore they bee (as they conceit it) ſo well furniſhed, that they need no more teaching: yea, that they be ſo wiſe, as wiſedome her ſelfe. Heereof it is, that in their proude conceits they are led and carried away with the winde of vanitie, and wander in euerie bie-path with the double tongued ſinner: they rather delight in fables and endleſſe genealogies, which breede queſtions more then godly edifying, then in the words of the wiſe,Eccleſ. 12.
which are like goades, and like nailes faſtned by the maiſters of the aſſemblies, and giuen by one Paſtour: that is, they be led about with new and ſtrange deuiſes, & their words are like the ſcumme vpon the water: they regard not thoſe words of the wiſe, nor thoſe wholſome bookes of the learned, which are accepted and authorized by the fathers and rulers of the Church of Chriſt, nor deſire they to be as a flocke of ſheepe vnder the true Paſtour and head of the Church Chriſt; wherby they knowing not the right way to the Citie, do erre, and wander egregiouſly, not conſidering the whiles what euill they commit. For notwithſtanding all their arguing, reaſoning, diſputing and talking of God and thoſe diuine things, it is apparant by their fruits, and by thoſe effects which follow that ſuch is their faith, their hope,
their charitie, that they neuer yet ſaw the Lord Ieſus ſo clearely, as euen that blinde Burtimaeus ſaw him when he cryed on him for mercie: Mark. 10.46. that they neuer apprehended him, as the very theefe did, which hanged on his right hand: that they neuer receiued him as Zacheus did: that they neuer followed him, as Leui the toll-taker did: that they neuer heard his words as Mary did: neither mind they to die in his truth as. Stephan did. Therfore, except they change their opinions and truely repent, they ſhall be placed among thoſe fooliſh virgins, which haue neither light nor oyle in their lamps: and then though they ſay vnto the Lord: Thou haſt preached in our ſtreetes, and wee haue eaten and dronken in thy preſence,
Luk. 13.26. therefore open to vs: he will neuertheleſſe thus reiect them and their petition: Depart from me ye workers of iniquitie, I know you not whence ye are.

7 Now therefore, ſeeing it is not for all perſons, and in any ſort to reaſon,VVho are meete to diſpute of diuine things, and in what ſort, and how farre. diſpute, and talke of the matters of God (as Gregorie Nazanzen ſaith) let vs in this place conſider to whom this belongeth, then, at what time, in whoſe preſence, of what things, and how farre. The ſame Doctour both in his former booke of diuinitie, and alſo in his booke of the Arrians, Grego. Naz. de theolog. li. 1. Et in libro de Arriaenis, quod non liceat ſemper & publice de Deo contendere. ſpeaking of this argument, hath the like matter and words in effect. And thus he ſaith. It belongeth not to euerie man (O yee wiſe and Chriſtian men) to reaſon of God: it is not meete for all men to diſcuſſe the diuine Nature. This thing is not ſo baſe, that ſuch as creepe on the earth and are buſied with terrene affections and worldly cogitations, ſhould take it in hand. But this appertaineth to them onely, which beyond others declare themſelues
meete for the matter, by deep contemplation and ſtudie, and which haue cleanſed as well theyr ſoules as their bodyes from filthie affections, or that at the leaſt haue a deſire to be cleanſed in the vſe of the ſame. For like as the ſore eyes taketh harme by gazing on the Sunne: ſo hee that is vncleane, cannot without daunger preſume to touch that thing which is moſt cleane. Next,The time. the time muſt bee conſidered: for it is not meete to argue of thoſe things at all times, but then indeed, when wee bee repoſed and at reſt from the groſſe and troubleſome cares of worldly affayres: otherwiſe, as it is for an eloquent man to write in crabbed Letters, and to mixe precious oyntment with filthie Dirte, ſo ſhall it bee with vs, if without regarde the cheefe facultie of the minde, which is capeable of the diuine contemplations, ſhould be confounded with the filthie and guilefull imaginations of vaine things: He muſt therefore take his time thereunto, that handleth theſe high matters, and know God.

Thirdly, this muſt bee done in the preſence of thoſe that reuerently eſteeme of theſe things,In whoſe preſence. and take not a pleaſure to trifle therewith, as men accuſtome to doo in worldly matters, or as thoſe men which after the regarde of theyr Horſes, after their games, after their ſongs and delights, after the care of theyr bellies, and of thoſe ſhamefull things vnder the ſame, doo at the leaſt betake themſelues for recreation and exerciſe of theyr wittes, to the reaſoning and diſputing of the things which are moſt high, beyonde their abilitie and knowledge.

Fourthly, it is to be conſidered of what things and how farre to wade in theſe diſputations, namely of thoſe things whereunto euery mans owne capacitie is able to extend,Of what things. and ſo farre as the condition and vnderſtanding of the hearer ſhall be able to beare: leaſt that, as too great a noyſe harmeth the eare, too much meate annoyeth the body: too heauie burthens oppreſſe the bearers thereof, and ouermuch raine hurteth the ground: fo thoſe hearers be greeued, and both the one and the other be confounded by ſuch high and more then ſounde diſputations. Let vs not attempt any thing beyond the higheſt ſtrength of mans frailtie: that is, beyonde that it hath pleaſed God to enable man to conceiue.

8. Howbeit, I would not that men ſhould ſo vnderſtand me herein, as if it were a ſinne for any man to remember God alwaies,This is not ſpoken to diſcourage any man from reading the word and talking of God with reuerence. for in my minde, wee ſhould euer be mindfull of God: yea, more often then we draw breath: and I thinke it good for a man to ſpend all his life therein, and in nothing elſe, if it were poſſible for him ſo to liue. For I am one of that number, which allow that in the law of God ſhuld be the cheefe exerciſe of a man both day and night, as the ſcripture teacheth, and that he ought to praiſe and bleſſe the lord in the euening, in the morning, at noonetide, and at all times: and as Moſes ſaith, lying down, riſing vp, going by the way and whatſoeuer elſe a man doth, he ſhould haue God, and the memorie of God fixed in his heart. I forbid not any man (I ſay) to remember God, but I forbid him to reaſon of God: neither diſlike I that a man ſhuld reaſon ſo far as that godlineſſe be not neglected: but I like not that, which is done out of ſeaſon:
〈1 page missing〉
as if I ſhunned this part of doctrine, but that it bee done with meaſure, and reuerence. For a man may eate too much honie, and what is ſweeter then honie? To be ſhort: I am of Salomons mind in this, that there is for euerie worke an appoynted time. And wee ſee, that the things which are of themſelues good, do loſe the grace of their goodneſſe in them which handle them euill: as when a flower is out of ſeaſon in the winter, and the apparell of a woman becommeth not a man, nor the mans apparell beſeemeth a woman: neither is mirth meete at funerals, nor mournings at mariages, &c. If therfore we can obſerue and keepe that which is comely and timelie in other things, ſhould we not then do the ſame in thoſe holy and diuine matters? Gregorie Nazanzen ſaith again. Let vs keep our ſelues within the boūds of our calling, and let vs not go either too far on the one ſide, leaſt wee returne into Egypt againe, or too far on the other ſide, leaſt we bee caried away into Babylon: Let vs not ſing the Lords ſong in a ſtrange land. Pſal. 137. That is to ſay: Let vs not argue and reaſon of the worde of God at all aduentures, aſwell there where it is not to bee reaſoned, as there where it is, and as well the eares of them that bee not fit for the ſame, as of them that be fit, and the ſame likeneth thoſe raſh and vnreuerent diſputers and talkers of the holie Scriptures vnto madde men, that deſtroy their owne houſes, kill their owne children, and beate their owne naturall parents, taking them for other men.

9 But all this cannot ſatisfie thoſe hawtie conceies. For Gregorie Nazanzen that learned Diuient (in theyr opinion) doateth among other
doctours. For doo not theſe wiſe perſons know as much as hee? Can they not giue as learned an interpretation of the hard queſtions of diuinitie as hee hath giuen? Are they not inſpired with that Spirite which dooth teach them all things, and leade them into all truth? Indeed (as I ſayde) this is their imagination: they take on them the knowledge of all things, neither is their anie thing ſo difficult in the holie Scriptures, which they eſteeme not eaſie and readie enough by themſelues to bee diſcuſſed, when yet they knowe not whereof they ſpeake, nor whereof they affirme. VVoulde to God that they knewe alſo this one thing, to keepe ſilence (as, Iob wiſhed that his friendes woulde) then happilie they ſhoulde bee taken for wiſe men: Iob. 13.5. Pro. 17.28. but that will not bee: therefore agaynſt them wee may conclude, eſteeming them fooles, as they bee indeede, and ſuch as are willing to decipher their follie in theyr vntimelie and erreuerent verboſitie. Yet that notwithſtanding, Peters heade is full of Proclamations,Peters veine. yea, and hee is ſo farre in, that whiles hee ſhoulde in reaſon hearken to his Maiſter, hee deuiſeth to builde Tabernacles, and he meeteth with ſuch as are willing to ſhake handes with him, no leſſe readie then thoſe that with one minde attempted the buylding of Babel, after the floud. But to bring this to paſſe, they endeuour to raſe and pull downe the little Chamber which the noble Sunemite erected and prepared for holie Eliſha to lodge in.2. King. 4.10 And obſerue this who that will, hee ſhall ſoone eſpie, that Dionyſe (though an Heathen Tyraunt) hath no ſmall number of immitatours,
euen among theſe in tytle Chriſtians, which vnder a cloake of zeale and pretext of reformation, doo without all ſcruple of conſcience robbe the Church, and diſpoyle her of her lawfull treaſures. Neither care they whether God bee honoured, or not honoured in the aſſembly of his faints, ſo as they may bee permitted as greedie Cormorants to prey on thoſe little Chambers, or thoſe landes, liuings, rentes and reuenewes, the which by the prouidence of God, and the good regarde of Chriſtian Princes, haue been prouided and appointed for the maintenaunce of the houſe of God, which ought not to be neglected (as ſaith the Prophet) and the reliefe of the Miniſters of the worde, who thereof ſhould liue and reape reward, as the Apoſtle ſayth. But what did the Tyraunt Dionyſe? Hee robbed and ſpoyled the Temple of Iupiter Olympius, Dionyſe robbed the Temple of Iupiter. Cicero de Nat. deo. lib. 3. when hee thirſted after the Treaſures of the ſame, and defended his ſacriledge therein by a fayre pretence and ſhewe of honeſtie. Firſt, entering into the Temple, hee behelde the Image of Iupiter, which had on it a coate of pure Golde, of great waight, and valew, wherewith the Tyrant Gelo had adorned the ſame, of the ſpoyles of the Carthaginenſes. This coate Dionyſe tooke away with this ſaying, That it was too heauie for Iupiter in the Summer, and too colde for him in the VVinter. Therefore in ſteade thereof, hee put on him a coate of Lynſie-woolſie, as more meete for eyther ſeaſon of the yeare. Next, looking on Aeſculapius Epidaurus, and perceiuing to haue a long bearde of Golde, hee bereaued him alſo thereof, ſaying, It was not meete that the Sonne ſhoulde haue
ſuch a beard whoſe father in all Temples was painted beardleſſe. Laſtly, looking on the other Images within the Temple, and ſeeing them to haue ſome golden crowns, ſome tables and diſhes of ſiluer in their hands ſtretched forth, he tooke them all away, and ſaide, that he yet did not take away anie of theſe things violentlie, but onelie receiued them gladlie of their hands that proffered them vnto him, and that it was a meere folly for a man, not to accept thoſe good gifts of their hands, to whom he prayeth for them, when they ſhall offer and giue them vnto him. This was the deuiſe and practiſe of Dyoniſe, when hee would enrich himſelfe by the ſpoyle of a Temple! We ſpeake not heere of the Idolatrie of the heathen beautifying thoſe Images: but of the couetous minde of the Tyrant, which putting all Religion apart (notwithſtanding his pretence and ſhew of iuſtice and honeſtie, thirſted after thoſe treaſures which were dedicated to holy vſes. I would the like were not in practiſe among title Chriſtians: but it is ſo common, yea and ſo manifeſt, that euery one that hath wit cannot but perceiue it. Alas that euer ſuch perſons ſhould ſo fowly diſgrace the honor of ſo noble a title.

10 But when this commeth into examination, and vpon complaint into exclamation, then the anſwer of Iulian to the poore afflicted Chriſtians is by them renewed,The Emperor Iulians anſwer to the perſecuted Chriſtians, that complained and came to him for iuſtice. It is your Maſters commaundement that ye ſhould ſuffer theſe things with patience. Your maiſter willeth you to poſſeſſe neither ſiluer nor golde: and Peter and Iames confeſſed that they had not ſo much as one croſſe of coyne to beſtow on a poore lame man. Such is theyr madneſſe, and ſuch ſhiftes haue they to defende the ſame in the horrible abuſe of the
holie Scriptures: they remember not that the wil of Chriſt is, that as his ſeruants ſhould patiently beare afflictions: ſo alſo they ſhould be right farre off from oppreſsing one another of them. But this is the diuels policie, which he alſo vſed againſt Iob. For hauing gotten leaue of the Lord to depriue him of his children, health and wealth, hee thought that Iob feeling the wāt of thoſe things wherwith the Lord his God had bleſſed him, he would ſoone faint, hee would murmur againſt God, he would ſweare and denie him, and all charitie, almoſe deeds, and godlie vertues decay in him. This practiſe hath he taught to many of thoſe title Chriſtians, ſo well contented to imitate him therin, who euer diſdaining the ſtate of the church, and of the miniſters of the word, and enuying the bleſsings that by the great zeale, regard and benefite of good princes, it hath pleaſed God to exhibite vnto them, & thinking that the litle chamber which the noble Sunemite prepared for Eliſha the man of God, is too large for him,2. King. 4.10. and the furniture thereof too magnificent: they ſtirre moſt eagerly to diminiſh this portion, to pull down the chamber walles. Neither make they any ſcruple at this, that the ſpoiles of ſacriledge fill their owne coffers: nor care they for this, that the poore Leuite being caſt into a lowe ebbe, be conſtrained to ſerue with Micha the Idolatour,The Leuites hard lot. Iudg. 17.10. for a thinne yearely ſtipende at his bare neede. To bee plaine, as they robbe Chriſt of his power on the earth, ſo woulde they waſte his inheritance, and defraud his labourers of their lawful wages, therby compelling them either to giue ouer, or to vſe many hard ſhifts, which yet they rather wiſh them to do, then that any of their
maintenance ſhould riſe from thoſe things which they ſo thirſt for, and eagerly purſue.

11 Oh my deare brethren, let Dionyſe, and Iulian folow their own bents:Ioſ. 24. Iohn 4.23. Mat. 7.24. but let vs that be the Lords, ſerue the Lord in ſpirit & truth. Let vs hold faſt the anker of our faith, and build vpon our rocke Ieſus Chriſt. God forbid that men ſhuld preſume ſo much as to thinke to prophane the moſt holy power of God, through their vain ſtudies and fantaſtical conceits. The holy ſpirit is euer the ſame, he is neuer contrarie to himſelfe: to oppugne this ſpirit, is of all other ſinnes the greateſt, and moſt fearefull. And howſoeuer he enflame mens minds, he inſtructeth them ordinarily by the holy word of God: Act. 10.5. elſe why was Cornelius commanded to ſend to Ioppa for Peter? All that labour might haue bin ſaued. But this ſerueth not: for though the word teach men neuer ſo wel,
Some mens good pretence and their own conceits make any thing lawful for them to do without feare.
2. Chro. 18.1. and 19.2. 2. Sam. 15.9. and the wiſe charmer do his beſt endeuour: yet if they ſo cōceit it, they aſſure ſaftie to Plinie, though he approch neuer ſo neate Veſuuian hill: and Bellepheron, vpon this warrantiſe, may boldly preſume to mount the flying Pegaſus: yea, Iehoſophat the ſeruant of God, ſhall of them haue diſpenſation to ioyne hands with wicked Achab: and Saul (vnder pretence of godlineſſe) may lawfully preſerue wicked Agag, the Amalekite, againſt the Lords expreſſe cōmandement, for they pretend well: yea, it maketh no great matter, Gen. 19.8. though Loth in his extremitie, offer to proſtrate his two virgin daughters to the luſt of the filthie Sodomites,
Num. 22.28. vnder a colour to defende the two Angels from their beaſtly furie: And Balaam alſo at the earneſt requeſt of Balack, and the Lords of Moab, may deale partially, and make ſhew of that, which
could not be performed, hoping (for all that) that his death ſhall be with the righteous, and his laſt ende like his. So in like ſort, may Vzzia take on him the Prieſts office: And Vzzia may touch the Arke to this ende to hold it vp from falling. For all theſe things are lawfull for them (as they take it) though not lawfull for other men. But Peter (alone) thinketh, that this prerogatiue is his owne, and therfore perceiuing that euen the beſt beloued Apoſtle of our Lord, is willing to follow his maiſter with a ſingle heart, hee looketh on him with a curious eie: Iohn 21.20. ſaying, And what ſhall hee do here? Yet Peter and the reſt pretended well.

12 But behold! ſo approched Plinie to the hill,The reward of fooliſh preſumption. Sueton. in li. de illust. vir. Hom. Iliad. lib. 6. that hee was ſmoothered with the fume and ſmoke aſcending on the ſame: neither could his warrantice helpe him. Thus alſo mounted Bellepheron on Pegaſus the flying horſe, that ſuddenly he is vnhorſed by him that diſdaineth to beare ſuch ambicious heads. The holy Scriptures alſo tell vs how that Vzzia was ſtriken with leproſie,2. Chro. 26.16 and the prieſts draue him out of the Temple. And, that Vzza was plagued, ſo that he died. Beſides that,1. Chro. 13 10 the wrath of God which fell on Saul for his diſobedience in the caſe of Agag, is manifeſt to all poſterities,1. Sam. 15.3.9 Nom. 22. and 23.10. as alſo the anger of the lord towardes Balaam for his halting. And had not the Lord by his eſpeciall grace miraculouſly preſerued his two ſeruants, Loth and Iehoſaphat, they had both periſhed alſo in their trouble: for howſoeuer they pretended, apparāt it is, that their deuiſes & practiſes pleaſed not the Lord.The pretence of the Iewes. Iohn. 11.50. It ſeemed to the Iewes that the high Prieſt pretended right well, when he ſaid: It is expedient for vs, that one man ſhould die for the people,
and not that all the nation periſh. But was it expedient therfore, that they ſhould be the betraiers and murtherers of Chriſt? Act. 2.23.38. Then would not Peter haue reproued them, and willed them to repent of that their deed.Hazael. • . King. 8.15. Thus Hazael being certified by the Prophet Eliſha, that he ſhould be King of Syria, would haſten the ſame by his wicked deuice: for vnder pretence to refreſh Benhadad the King of Syria (his Lord and maiſter) hee ſtiffled him with a thicke cloath which he dipt in water, and ſpred on his face.

Dauid.13 But Dauid (that ſeruant of God) was of an other heart, and of a better reſolution: for though he were anointed to be King ouer Iſrael, by Samuel the Prophet, and had diuerſe opportunities offred him to kill Saul then king, he yet refrained and ſaid: God forbid that I ſhould lay mine hands on the Lords annointed. 1. Sam. 24.7. It had bin better for Abſalom alſo that he had bin of the ſame mind:Abſalom. but he, aſpiring to the kingdome in the life time of his father, with another mind could glaunce pleaſantly before the people, ſaying vnto them,2. Sam. 15.4.12. Oh that I were made Iudge in the Land, that euerie man which hath any plea and matter in the law might come to me, and that I might do him iuſtice? A faire pretence! and many no doubt beleeuing him, and expecting the performāce of his words, did in the time of Dauids trouble ſhake hāds with Abſalom, Dauids enimy.

Apud Terentium.This vnthankefull people wiſt not, that Abſalom ſpake much like him, which ſaid, Me Regem eſſe oportuit, Meete it were, that I were made King. For now, if Abſalom had beene preferred according to their deſire, as Hazael was in Syria, the peruerſe gouernment of Roboam had too ſoone ſucceeded: not much vnlike that of Hazael in Syria, wherin he wold ſo oppreſſe
the children of Iſrael, as the very cōſideration thereof, made the Prophet to weepe. But it was the Lords pleaſure this to preuent by the continuance of Dauids gouernment, and of that of Salomon in ſucceſſion, to the great ioy of the true Iſraelites. For,A time for euery thing. as Salomon ſaith, as euery thing hath his time which may neither be preuented nor paſſed ouer, ſo wee which are but mortall men (ſayth Aratus) haue not learned all that is in Gods minde:Arat. ſolenſis but (as yet) there be many things cloſed vp from vs, ſome part wherof God will, when his pleaſure is, hereafter reueale vnto vs. In the meane time, it is no eaſie matter to giue newneſſe to olde things, authoritie to new things, brightneſſe to ruſtie things, light ſomeneſſe to darke things, Plin. in praefac. ad Veſpac. and fauor to ougly things, (as Plyny wrote to Veſpaſian.) But this time, the vanitie of mans mind thinketh to preuent, and, in the glorious pretences, imagineth, that if that could be permitted which he hath deuiſed, all things ſhould ſoone be ordered, and perfected ſo in poynts, as yet neither our ſoueraigne Lady Queene Elizabeth, nor hir worthie brother king Edward, Salomon did complaine, not ſo much that impieti was founde in the place of iuſtice, as of this, that impietie cannot be fully corrected. nor King Dauid, nor King Salomon, nor King Iehoſophat, nor King Hezekiah, nor King Ioſiah, euer ſaw in gouernment, nor that any Prince or magiſtrate whatſoeuer, hath yet compaſſed.

But, as he that ſearcheth the diuine glory beyonde his capacitie, is oppreſſed with the ſame: ſo theſe men, vrging ſo far beyond the limits of their vocation & abilitie, in matters not only of Religion, but alſo of State and ciuil gouernment in their good pretēces, do worthily draw ruine & decay on their own heads, and hurt to many others: as wherof (beſides the holy Scriptures) euen the hiſtories of the
prophane Gentiles, are ſtored with examples.

Cicero with al his wiſedome, eloquence, great dignity, & ſmall conſent of people, aſſaied to reſtore the Roman cōmon-wealth to the priſtine ſtate, but he tooke not the Lordes counſell & deuiſe with him:The vaine labour of Cicero and his lamentation. therfore could he accompliſh nothing of his deſire. But this he was ſure of, that he drew danger to his own life, & hurt to many others. There was a time, wherin he glorified himſelf in this ſort: O fortunatam natam me Conſule Romam! O happy Rome, thy Conſul that I am! yet afterward ſuch a time ouertooke him, wherein he was iuſtly occaſioned to acknowledge his folly, & to ſing this ſorrie ſong. O me nunquam ſapientē! In Epiſt. ad Octauium. &c. Alas, wiſe was I neuer in al my life! and yet ſomtimes was I vainly eſteemed to be that, which indeede I was not. O ye Romanes, how much hath your opinion bin deceiued concerning me? Thus alſo Pericles prouoked the Lacedaemonians,Melanth in Prouerb. Ageſilaus & Lyſander the Thebāes, Demoſthenes the Macedonian king, & Solon the Athenians, declaring thereby, how dangerous a matter it is to ſtir vp the ſleeping lion, without poſſibilitie of the effecting of any worthy thing.

Polypragmoſyue.15. This enterpriſing of matters that appertaine not to our calling, of a ſingular curioſitie, is a very peſtilent thing, euen in conomical & priuat affaires; but much more noyſome it is proued to be in polyticall & eccleſiaſticall matters. Neither can it be aſſured, by any ſufficient teſtimony, example, or argument, that God either bleſſeth or helpeth ſuch kind of practiſes: but rather, that hee rewardeth the contriuers and dealers of & in ſuch actions, with an hel of torments and troubles. Beſides that, let a man do his beſt, and preuent the worſt with al his wiſedome
and circumſpection: yet his own imperfections & natural pollutions make thoſe things, which are of themſelues pure and vnſpotted,The beſt things ſeeme impure to mā by reaſon of his ſinne: how much rather are mans owne deuiſes vnpure. to ſeeme polluted & vncleane. As cleare as is the ſun, as bright as is the Moone, either of them, by the meanes of terrene exhalations, is oftē ſo ſhadowed, as they ſeeme blemiſhed to our eies. So is ye church in this world: ſo is the gouernment both Eccleſiaſtical & ciuill, by meanes of humane infirmities: and, as the latter age of man is weaker, and ſo leſſe apt to vertues: ſo,The world is feeble and periſheth. Iſay. 24.4. this latter age of the world abounds with vices, and is leſſe apt for loue, charitie, peace, and contentation.

In regard thereof, the Church ſeemeth blacke and deformed, and the very ſeate of iudgement ſauoureth of oppreſſion and impietie. Howbeit,Cant. 1. Eccleſ. 4.1. God by his miniſters of grace, in either ſtate ſendeth his ordinary conſolations, inſtructions, and helps, ſo far as it pleaſeth him: wherein men muſt be ſtudious,Men muſt bee faithfull in their places, and referre the perfection of all things vnto almighty God. faithfull, and diligent in their places, in the feare of God, to ſtrengthen their faint harts & weake knees, and to employ the talents to them committed, referring the fruite and ſucceſſe of all vnto the grace of God, who may in all things (if he will) ſupply mens wants. But whoſoeuer ſhall preſume to take on him to correct & amend all things in euery point among the ſons of men (God onely excepted) he ſhal with Choraebus that ideot, which could not reckon any number aboue fiue,Choraebus. take on him to number the waues of the ſea, and make that which is badde enough, to be tenne times worſe, as one ſingeth.Luther. in Pſal. 120.

q.l: Some maladies, in cure of thē, proue worſe & worſe, we ſee,Eraſ. in Diatrib.
VVhich therfore not to touch at all, far better might it be.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
VVe may not dreame of better euents of our ſtudies, then others haue dona before vs. Againſt innouations.
div.p:
King. 3.12.
AS the Lord himſelfe ſaid and teſtified of King Salomon: Lo, I haue giuen thee a wiſe and vnderſtanding heart: ſo that, there was none like vnto thee before thee: nor after thee ſhall any riſe like vnto thee. So euery man is contented to grant, that Salomon in wiſedome and vnderſtanding, was worthily preferred to all other Kings, Princes, and Magiſtrates. Howbeit,Salomon was neuer able to conforme all things to the rule of the Law. Salomon confeſſed of himſelfe, that hee was by ſo much the more fooliſh, by how much he ſought to eſtabliſh wiſedome, and to expell follie, and to perfect al things within his kingdome according to the law: yea, and the more wiſe he thought himſelfe to be in this deuiſe, the more he bewrayed his owne weakneſſe and infirmities.

Neither can wee be certified by the report of any hoſtorie, either humane or diuine, that euer any magiſtrate in the Common wealth, or Biſhop in the Church (notwithſtanding there haue beene moſt good and perfect Lawes prouided for the aduancement of vertues, and the aboliſhing of vices) hath been able to purge and expell all manner of corruption, blots, blemiſhes, wrinckles, maladies, and imperfections from either ſtate, and ſo reduce the ſame into perfect beautie and puritie: but that the beſt of them all were contented onely to amend that
which was curable, and could by their miniſtery be amended, and to leaue and commit the reſt vnto that Supreme King, that ſeeth and ruleth all after his will, both in heauen and earth. And that ſuch of them as haue vrged further, haue purchaſed the torment of themſelues, and the hurt of many others, as in the Chapter before it hath beene declared.
