2 Almightie God himſelfe,God himſelfe ſuffereth many imperfections heere among men, not that hee wanteth power to correct, but in that he will ſo ſuffer them. notwithſtanding his diuine lawes (which no man was euer able to empeach of imperfection) looking downe from heauen vppon the children of men, hee findeth them faultie in many things, They do daily runne out of the way, and are become abhominable in his ſight, there is none that doth good, no, not one of them in this ſinfull world. And he is iuſtly moued to complaine of the ingratitude of his own people the children of Iſrael, vnder the ſimilitude of the vineyard, and in the parable of the perfidious huſband men: yea,Iſay 5.1. Mat. 12. he hath bin ſometimes moued to repentance, that he hath made man on the earth: & hath bin right ſorie in his hart (as the ſcriptures teſtifie.) Though al theſe defects the lord God is well able (when he will) to correct and amende: yet lo, ſo many of mans faults and imperfections, as he ſeeth moſt meete to be puniſhed and corrected, doth he puniſh and correct accordingly: and theſe are the ſame onely, which hee hath made curable, and to be amended, according to his prouidence and wiſedome; the reſt hee permitteth and ſuffereth (through his great mercie and goodneſſe) for many cauſes, whereof ſome be concealed from vs, and ſome are reuealed and made knowne vnto men in his holy word.

3 Alac, why then ſhould men in this our time,
dreame of bitter euents and effects of their ſingular deuiſes? and why ſhould they vndertake not onely to renew Plato his Common-wealth, but alſo to warrant a full reſolution, and to reſtore a perfect puritie of all things, both in the Church and in the Common-wealth, by theyr deuiſes and practiſes?They that end •• uour a perfect puritie in this world, do as if they would purge men from ſin, wherein they derogate from Chriſt, that appertaineth to him. What do they otherwiſe therein, then ſeeme to diſdaine our godly wiſe Princeſſe and her proceedings: to be wiſer then God himſelfe: and to vndertake that mortall men ſhould liue in this world without ſinne, as Adam did in Paradiſe before his fall, and ſo ſhould not ſtande in neede of the merites of Chriſt and free graces of Gods Spirit? then the which deuiſe and practiſe, what can bee more proude, more haughtie, more arrogant? And what elſe may wee deeme of them, but that they bee alſo thus conceyted, that they are able to ſay, not onely as the proude glorious Phariſee ſayde in his prayer: I am not as other men, extortioners,
Luke. 18.11. vniuſt, or as this Publican: but alſo, to proteſt that of themſelues and their families (which the Church of Chriſt neuer durſt to ſay of her ſelfe) as thus. VVee are not blacke, nor deformed: wee are not ſpotted, nor blemiſhed: wee are holyer then other men:Cant. 1.4. they are all prophane and abhominable vnto vs. VVee goe not aſide at any time, they doo erre moſt egregiouſly: wee are as Angelles and heauenly Spirites without ſinne: for wee be elected, but they bee carnall, all polluted with ſinne, and reprobated: better were it, if they were conformed vnto vs, or baniſhed further from vs, then that thy ſhould ſo liue and teach, to offende vs. Theſe be their wordes, and ſuch is their zeale and proude conceit▪ how much better were it both
for themſelues and many others, that as dutifull ſubiects and right Chriſtians, they do learne to feare God, to honour our noble Princeſſe, and to liue in concord as brethren, then ſo to iudge and condemne their brethren in their malice, and to exalt themſelues in the pride of their hearts, and in their conceited wiſedome, to preſcribe vnto the Church their phantaſticall opinions and lewd deuiſes, to the diſquiet of the right Chriſtian peace? Surely, of all the nations vnder the Sunne,VVee are to ſhew our ſelues thankfull to God for our bleſſings. wee Engliſhmen haue worthie cauſes to praiſe and glorifie the Name of God, who (of his great mercie and grace vnto vs in his Sonne) hath opened vnto vs the gates of the Temple, hath vnſealed vnto vs the Booke of his holy Miſteries, and hath taught vs all the wayes and meanes towards the Kingdome of Heauen. Lette vs therefore reuerently enter into the holy Temple, lette vs heare Chriſt preached, and embrace his Doctrine, with faythfull and thankfull hearts: Lette vs edifie one another of vs in holy Loue: lette all our contentions and ſtriuings bee, howe wee may beſt immitate our Lorde Chriſt, and therein runne towardes the happie Goale of eternall life, taking the benefit of good opportunitie: and, lette vs beware, that wee offer not any iuſt occaſion of offence, either to the Prince and magiſtrates, or to the Paſtours and Miniſters of the Church, or to any other the right Proteſtants.

This no doubt the Lorde himſelfe did reſpect, when he ſaid: I charge you, Cant. 2.8.
O yee Daughters of Hieruſalem, by the Roes and Hindes of the fielde, that yee
wake not vp my loue, nor touch her, till ſhe be content her ſelfe.

The opinions of heathen men, againſt innouations of lawes, &c.4 The learned and wiſe men of the heathen, haue beene of this minde, that there where euery man had free libertie in a Common-wealth, either to change a law prouided, or to make new lawes, the credit and authoritie of the ſuperiour Lord was contemned as vile, and good order was ſubuerted by them,Plato in Pol. 4. who being diuerſly conceited, abandon al vnitie & peace. And they much blamed ſuch as endeuoured to remedie miſchiefes by the innouation of Lawes, the which practiſe they denied to be, as the cutting off of one of the heades of Hydra, in the the place whereof ſeauen other heades did ſodainely ſpring vp: and therefore they held it much better to beare with ſome ſmal faults and imperfections in lawes and magiſtrates, then to endeuour to alter and correct them to the ruine and decay of the whole ſtate: which is as a great frame made of diuers peeces, ſo conioyned and ſet together, that it is impoſſible to alter or take away the leaſt part thereof, but the whole muſt feele it.Solon. Demoſt. Therefore Demoſthenes reporting the ſentence of Solon againſt innouations of lawes, deemeth them worthie of death. Octauius Caeſar, Octau. in the caſt of Cato the Vticenſian, eſteemed that man onely a good Cittizen, a right member of the Common-wealth, and an honeſt man, which being well pleaſed with the preſent ſtate of his time, was vnwilling to alter or change the ſame.VVith what lawes and wayes men ſhould liue contented. But to teach vs Chriſtians, wee heare what almightie God (whoſe words and authoritie is preferred to all men, ſayth by his Prophet: Go into the ſtreetes, conſider and make inquiſition for the olde way: and if it bee
the good and right way, then go therein: Conſider the ordinaunces of thine Elders, if they bee good,
Iere. 6.16. 2. Kin. 17.15. and not contrarie to that lawe of the Lorde, obſerue them, and change them not.
2. Chro. 38. For though wee ſhould not bee ſtiffe-necked and vngodlie like as were ſome of them of yore, whom the Lord in his wrath deſtroyed: yet ſhould wee not refuſe to immitate them that haue gone before vs in holie Religion: and to content our ſelues nowe with ſuch meete Lawes and ordinances as right well pleaſed them in the feare of God: and to knowe, that the honour of the Prince, and the obedience to lawes, and Magiſtrates, is enioyned vs by the King of all Kinges in his holye worde, by whome (as hee ſayeth) Kinges doo raigne, and Princes prouide iuſte Lawes.

5 The altering of conſtituted Lawes,The Iewes feared the inconueniences of innouations. ſeemed ſo odious to the Iewes, that the high Prieſts (which pretended the maintenaunce and defence of the Lawe of Moſes) was not a little mooued, when the falſe witneſſes had accuſed Stephen,
Act. 6.24. that hee had preached, that Ieſus of Nazareth ſhould chaunge the Ordinaunces that Moſes gaue, and this lawe that was deliuered by the miniſterie of Angels. VVhereof (indeede) Stephen was faultleſſe, Act. 7.20.38.35. as his aunſwere plainlie teſtifieth. For Moſes (ſayeth hee) was aceeptable to God, and was learned in all the wiſedome of the Egyptians, and mightie in words and deedes: hee was in the Congregation in the wilderneſſe, with the Angels which ſpake to him and with our fathers. And this was hee, who receiued the liuely Oracles (that is the Lawe and wordes of the Lorde) to giue vnto vs. And vnto
the Iewes, he ſaid: Ye haue receiued the Law by the ordinance of Angels, and haue not kept it. As for Chriſt, hee came (as himſelfe ſayth) not to deſtroy the Lawe,
Chriſt came to fulfill the Law.
See Cap. 12.4.
but to fulfill the Law. The true ſence and meaning whereof, hee plainlie openeth in the Goſpell: and therein hee breaketh not, but ratifieth the ſtrength of good Lawes, agaynſt them, that (with the Scribes and Phariſees) inuent and preferre theyr owne Gloſſes and Traditions, to the Lawe of God, which is the ground of all good Lawes. From this Lawe may no man withdrawe anie thing: neither to this ought hee to adde any thing at all: from the rule of this Lawe, we may not erre: betweene the which, and the ſentence of the ciuill Magiſtrate, there ought to be a perpetuall affinitie and conſent.

But as the depriuation of laudable conſtitutions, and well prouided lawes, is a thing vniuſt and pernicious to humane ſocietie: ſo it is moſt certaine, that ſuch perſons doo moſt egregiouſly offend and ſinne againſt God,
It is a moſt dangerous thing to go about to alter the Law of God.
Apo. 22.18, 19. and the Common-wealth, that excogitate or endeuour to alter good lawes, eſpecially the Lawe diuine. For thereby they blaſpheme God, draw mens mindes from the true knowledge: and caſt ſoules headlong into no ſmall perill and danger of damnation. Therfore ſhall God adde plagues vnto them, and take away their part out of the booke of life. But what hath occaſioned thoſe diſcontented perſons to condemne our Lawes?They haue no reaſon to diſcent from vs. what hath moued them to diſcent from vs? what reaſon haue they to diſtruſt vs? why doo they thus contemne vs? Thinke they, that wee know not good from euill? or that we would not gladly tend to the
beſt, and ayme to that right good, as they would? Or are they of the minde, that wee (Chriſtian Proteſtants) doo not wiſh for, Rom. 8.19.23. and would with all our hearts ſee the adoption of the ſonnes of God, and the puritie of gouernment in either ſtate, as all good men do deſire? And are not our lawes made and ratified accordingly? would to God, that in that regard it might be ſayd to vs: Now bleſſed are your eyes, for they ſee that, which your forefathers (from the beginning of the Creatures of God) haue longed to behold,
Gen. 3.24. An heartie deſire of contentation. Phil. 2.2. and could not: for that Cherubim ſtande at the doore of Paradice with the bright blade. In the meane time, would to GOD wee coulde bee contented in thankefulneſſe to God, with the preſent graces freelie beſtowed on vs, that wee may bee like minded, beeing of one accorde, and of one iudgement: that noting bee done amongst vs through contention, or vaine-glorie: but that in meekeneſſe of minde, euerie man eſteeme other better then himſelfe (as the Apoſtle well aduiſeth vs) that ſo God may be pleaſed.

6 But nowe let it bee, Eccles. 10.5. VVhat a change we ſhould ſoone ſee, if their conceits were anſwered. Aurelius. that all things leaned to their lure: what ſhoulde wee ſhortlie then ſee? would none of thoſe euils appeare, which Salomon once ſaw vnder the Sunne? Surely it is very likely, that wee ſhould haue a ſudden Metamorphoſis: but yet (I feare me) this ſorie change, that little learned Aurelius (as one ſayd) ſhall bee in all the haſte made Biſhop of great Carthage, Auguſtine. Arſaſius. Chryſoſtome. Nicepho. li. 3. cap. 28. Iuet. when great learned Saint Auguſtine ſhall be Biſhop in little Hippo: and ignorant Arſaſius ſhall ſucceed eloquent Chryſostome: whereat not onely Simeones may wofullie exclaime, Pro pudor, quis? cui? Fie for ſhame! whom haue we heare? what a ſupplie is this? But alſo,
Cicero his exclamation will bee therein verefied: O domus antiqua: quam diſpari Domino dominaris? VVhat Lord vnworthie thee poſſeedes, oh auntient houſe? Yea, Eliah the Prophet perceyuing it, will not omit thereupon to expoſtulate agaynſt Achab in the name of the Lorde:1. King. 21.19. VVhat! hast thou killed, and ſo taken poſſeſsion?

The inconſtancie of theſe deuiſes and altring of opinions.Beſides that, how long time would the ſame ſtate be ſuſtained and cōtinued? how conſtant? how contented? what perſeuerance? what ſtabilitie? It is thought, that the rule of Iſocrates, would ſound but prophane in their eares, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : Affect the ſtate preſent:Iſocrates. or be wel contented with the preſent things: and that alſo of Syracides woulde ſeeme loathſome: My ſonne (ſaith hee) make much of the time: Ecclus. 4.20.
Cleo a buſie headed perſon For why? the buſie headed Cleo cannot be quiet (as the Greeke Hyſtorie telleth) hee commenceth Orations with ouglie outcries, he renteth his garments, he heateth on his thighes, he ſhuffleth with his feete, and runneth too & fro on the ſtage. So theſe fools that leaue their owne neſts,Ecclus. 27.11. Pro. 27.8. wil not long abide contented, but vnto them 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : Euer irkeſome is the preſent ſtate: Thucidides. as ſayde Thucidides touching gouernments: And a verie difficile thing it ſhall be for them (as Ariſtotle ſaieth) to containe themſelues within the compaſſe of their owne decrees.Lib. 3. Eth.

VVhat a ſtur they make in Church matters.
Their choiſe of diets. 7 But yet let vs further heare, what a ſhuffling they make in the church: Apollo is very wel learned, ſayth one: Paule is better then Apollo, ſaieth another: but Peter goeth for my money ſaith the third man. Againe, as for Dauid, he with a ruſticall harpe twangeth Paſtor-like: but Salomon hath a courtlike phraſe. Moſes alſo falleth vnder their cenſure, and he
ſtutteth without eloquence: and Amos is but a plaine ſot, more meete for the Countrey, then the Court. Michaeas is too eager againſt Achab: ſo is Eliah againſt Ieſabel: ſo is Iohn agaynſt Herod: but the Prophets of Baal pleaſe them both right well.They proceed from cenſures to accuſatiōs, ſlaunders, perſecutions, &c. Pasſhur will not ſticke to bobbe Ieremie on the face: and Paule being in diſlike, anon is brought to the barre to be arraigned, where he is both accuſed by Tartullus, threatned by the Iewes, and ſtriken at the cō maundement of Annanias. Neither may they be diſſwaded from their opinion (ſo full of enuie is the Serpents head) though that Boanarges the ſonnes of thunder, ſhould ſound the worde in their eares. No,Boanarges. Mark. 3.17. nor yet, though that verie Prophet ſhould admoniſh them, whoſe voice not to heare, deſerueth an extirpation frō the people of God. Is not this good diuinitie?

Such ſhaking reeds declare their weake foundations, when no ſtate, no condition, no good order can content or pleaſe them long. Simon Magus may be a dayly hearer of the Sermons,The tree is knowne by the fruites. and words of Peter, and of the other Apoſtles and diſciples of Chriſt, as a moſt feruent louer of the true doctrine: he may alſo come to the baptiſme, and take the externall ſigne of a true Chriſtian, and ſo forth: howbeit, if he be couetous and worldly minded, if he chop and chaunge the diuine Graces for a filthie ſumme of money: if he ſeeke and hunt after the vaine-glorie and praiſe of men: If Simon, notwitſtanding his profeſsion, haue an vnquiet ſpirit, and bee not yet well eſtabliſhed in the truth without hypocriſie (which truth as Philemon writeth, hath a more faire beautie then that which anie painter or carrier in the
world canfeigne) he ſhall ſoone decipher himſelfe: for nothing feigned can bee of long continuance. So Caine, ſo Saule, ſo Demas, ſo Iudas, ſo Nicholas, ſo Iulian the Apoſtate, are in the end well knowne by their works and endeuours, as the trees are by their fruits. Thus alſo haue theſe ſtraunge conceited perſons egregiouſly declared themſelues, notwithſtanding their bombaſed words and angelical ſhew of holy deuotion, that not onely wiſe men, who haue their eyes in their heads, but alſo little boyes and yong children may eaſily perceiue their palpable and groſſe infirmities, ſlidings, and fins, beyond many other mens faults, howſoeuer they diſſemble them to themſelues: and wee doo plainlie diſcerne, that they both much diſcent from the pure ſpirite, meeke mindes, godly loue, humilitie, and ſinceritie of Chriſt, and his Apoſtles, Diſciples and Martyrs; and alſo are farre eſtranged from that ſimple ſpirit, and godly integritie of thoſe gratefull men that liued of yore in that golden age of the worlde,The gratefull men of the old time. the which the moſt antient and beſt Poets and Philoſophers haue commended with high praiſes to the people: perſwading them to aſſay to reſemble them therin, as thoſe which are ſet forth and remembred for worthy patterns of immitation to all poſterities.

Arat. Sol. 63. 8 The antient Poet Aratus, writing of that golden age, and of them that liued in the ſame, hath among other, theſe verſes:
Men knew not then pernitious brawles.
nor that contentious ſtrife:
Nor yet had broacht ſedition fell,
the foe to quiet life.

But this golden age is paſt, and ſithence that, a copper world hath ſucceeded a ſiluer world. It is true and therfore haue men the more cauſe to looke to themſelues. Wel then, let vs giue eare to the doctrine, of our chiefe paſtor Chriſt, and do that which is commanded therein, then ſhall we be builded ſo ſure on the Rocke, that all the noyſome ſtormes and winds in the world ſhall not ſhake vs downe. They that obſerue not this, ſtande fleeting on the ſand: they be not of any continuance, nor free from great annoyes.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

The ambitious perſons which want preferment, beginne to ſlaunder, condemne, and contemne the Magiſtracie, and the Lawes. Howbeit, both the Prince and Magiſtrate are to bee honoured, and the Lawes obeyed of good Subiects.
div.p:
ARrius the heretike, hauing a filthie deſire of renowme, aſſayeth (though inordinatelie and indirectlie) to obtain a Biſhopprick, about the which, hee attempteth manie, both vniuſt, and vnneceſſarie actions, in the truſt of his owne learning, wiſedome and power, farre beyond the limits of his vocation: but hee is preuented of his purpoſe therein: for the Lorde (by the miniſterie of the Ordinance) withſtandeth him; and preferreth another to the place hee moſte
affected. Therefore Arrius is ſorely diſcontented, he is greeued to the heart, and vehement lie fraight in his guttes: yea, and thereto hee addeth a hatefull diſlike of them that preferre, and of them that be preferred, with many proud words againſt the place and function he ſo much deſired.The immitators of Arrius. This Arrius hath too many immitators yet liuing, who being debarred of their purpoſe, and being not of abilitie (with Iulius) to execute their proper cōceits, but incurring the paines of their deſerued iudgments, they lamēt their lot, with an enuie and contempt of the lawfull ordināce, & them which are by the ſame preferred, and that ſo farre, that though they be not Caeſars, yet they will not abide ſuperiours: and though they be not Pompeys,
Lucan. Nec Romae, &c.
Cicer. 11. Off. Manicheus. yet woulde they haue no peeres (a kinde of humour in mans minde, which Cicero calleth moſt miſerable). In this they likewiſe ſhake handes with the Maniches, and both teaching and perſwading the people, that the Magiſtrates are not to be honoured in their places, nor the Biſhops and Miniſters of the worde to bee reuerenced in their functions, eſpecially, if that they, or any of them prouide agaynſt anie of their ambitious and ſeditious practices: or elſe, if they, or anie of them, bee once noted, as touched with any kinde of humane infirmitie, the which ſhall ſuddainlie be pleaded in the higheſt Court of Augmentation, by their ſiniſter reportes.A fable of the Foxe. Oh howe handſomely do they immitate that Foxe in the fable? of whome the Prouerbe is ordinarilie beaten. The Foxe will eate no Grape? The Foxe hauing many times leapt vp to catch the Grapes, and yet coulde not come by them, becauſe they were to high for him, and
himſelfe vnable to get them, beeing at length tyred out with often leaping, and forced to giue ouer, ſaide: VVell, it maketh no matter that I haue not thoſe grapes: for why? they be very ſowre grapes, and ſcarce ripe. So ſay they, being forced to giue ouer their ſutes and eagerbents, the Magiſtrates, the Biſhops, the Miniſters, the Preachers, they be ſuch, and ſuch kind of perſons, &c. And ſuch and ſuch be thoſe offices, places, functions, dignities, ſcarce lawfull, full of labour, ſnares to catch men in, &c. And why? forſooth becauſe they be not carued to their tooth, and preſcribed for their Diet. Now if Chriſt ſhould bee again brought to the barre, and Pontius Pilate ſhould be perſwaded of the innocencie of Chriſt, & ſhould labour to cleare him in the iudgement before them all: yet will they bee readie, with thoſe ſpightfull Iewes, to crie out with open mouth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : Let him be crucified: he is a very bad man, he hath a badde office, hee is well worthie to die. Yea, and rather then their bruit bents ſhould be reſiſted, they will not ſticke to riſe vp againſt Softhenes the cheefe of the Synagogue, Acts 18.17. cheefely if they once perceiue that Gallio careth not for theſe things. Such a practiſe contriued Chorah, Dathan, and Abiram, who riſing vp,Chorah. and mouing the people of Iſrael againſt Moſes and Aaron, in their madde diſcontented rage vpon the like occaſion, ſayde vnto them. Ye take too much vpon you, ſeeing the multitude are holy euery one of them,
Num. 16.3. why lift ye vp your ſelues aboue the congregation of the Lord? As if they ſayd vnto Moſes and Aaron, yee are vſurpers of this authoritie ouer the people: they are all as holy as your ſelues are, and ye ought not thus to exalt your ſelues in any ſuch rule and gouernment
ouer them, neither are wee and the people holden in right and equitie, to yeeld you any ſuch honour.

2 But before wee draw authoritie to conuince thoſe phantaſticall perſons from the bowels of the Canonicall Scriptures, let vs alſo heere (as we haue done in the former, touching well prouided lawes and conſtitutions) not omitte to conſider what the very heathen people haue iudged, taught, and perſwaded,VVhat the heathen people helde touching gouernment and magiſtrates. touching Princes, magiſtrates, and gouernment: not in that they ſhall lend vs authoritie for the ſame, but that the very chriſtians might (by their example the ſooner) conforme themſelues both in minde and manners, to that which not onely the written word, but alſo nature, reaſon, and the conſent of all wiſe and learned men, haue receiued and embraced,Sophocles. as things good and profitable. Sophocles hath theſe words: It is meete and conuenient that he bee honoured, whom the Common-wealth hath aduanced. Socrates, Plato, Philemon, Ariſtotle, Cicero, Virgil, Ouid, and other Philoſophers, Poets, and wiſe men, both Greekes and Latines, haue beene euer of the mind, that kings, Princes, Gouernours, are neceſſarie in Common-weales, vnto the which all men ought to be obedient, and to conforme themſelues to the Lawes of that Cittie or Common-wealth, wherein they liue (the ſame beeing honeſt and godly) in like ſort as good Wiues doo conforme themſelues to the manners and faſhions of their owne huſbandes, with whome they are willing to liue and leade theyr liues.Aeſope. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . This Aeſope conſidered, when ſchooling and aduiſing Ennus, hee thus began with him, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is,
My Sonne, worſhip God, and honour the King, with all reuerence: for by this is the ſtate of humaine things maintained, the guiltie are puniſhed, and the innocents defended. And this was holdē for a ſure Axiome with them, that where no gouernment is, nor obedience to Princes and lawes defended, there neither an houſe, nor a Citie, nor a Common-wealth, can either ſtand or proſper, no more then that body liueth, the which either hath no head at all, or is not directed, gouerned, & defended by the head. In the conſideration wherof, they haue likened the prince in his gouernment, to an Archer or ſhooter,
1. The Prince is like an Archer.
2. The people like an arrow.
3. The lawes to a bow.
4. The marke, to the common good. and the people to an arrow, the lawes to the bow, and the marke to the Common-good. For as needfull as is the Archer to draw the bow, and to direct the arrow from the ſame to the marke, ſo needfull is the Prince, to direct and order the people by the wiſedome of lawes to the common good. And as there, where wanteth either an Archer and a bow, the Arrowes are neglected, and the marke not pierced, ſo neither can the people be ordered, nor the Commonwealth maintained, where gouernment wanteth: for there neither vertue can be rewarded, nor euil deeds puniſhed, according to ye rule of iuſtice, the which ought in gouernmēt to be defended, but rather many anoies & huge incōueniences, which waite on diſorder, wil ſoone be ſeene, & wofully felt, to fall on that Common-wealth, on that people. Therefore, when Alexander was dead,Alexanders hoaſt without a captaine. Damades this conſidering, rightly compared his hoaſt vnto that huge Cyclops, which hauing but one eye, loſt the ſame: and after that beeing blinde, hee ſuſtained many deadly ſtrokes or his huge bodie,
Such:Eurip. Heming. De lege Naturae. is the inconuenience that enſueth Anarchies and want of gouernment: this alſo that Greeke Poet perceiued, and therefore wrote thereof thus:
There is not ſeene a greater ill,
then Anarchie: for ſhee doth ſpill
VVant of gouernment.great Citties, and doth caſting ground
whole families, and all confound.
In warres ſhe makes the Daſtards flie,
But contrarie, moſt reuerently,
to yeeld to rule, and lawes or dain'd
brings health to them, who elſe be pain'd.
Therefore the Prince, for this good end,
ought true obedience to defend.

And as thoſe ancient wiſe men haue holden the magiſtrates to be both profitable and neceſſarie for the Common-wealth,VVho were taken for good men among the heathen. and thought it conuenient and neceſſarie that they ſhould bee honoured and obeyed: ſo alſo they eſteemed them onely for good Citizens and honeſt perſons, who yeelded themſelues obedient to the Princes and lawes. Thereof ſaid Sophocies,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is: It is the parte of a good man to bee obedient to the Prince and Magiſtrates. And thereof Horace propoſeth this queſtion: Ver bonus eſt quis? VVho is a good man? and aunſwereth himſelfe in this verſe.
Horat. li. 1. Epiſt. ad quintum.Qui Conſulta patrum, qui leges Iuraque ſeruat. that is, He, who obſerues the Princes lawes, decrees, and rights.

3 And they (I meane the very heathen Philoſophers and wiſe men of yore) haue both obſerued
and taught with no meane wiſedome, that Anarchie or want of gouernment, is worſe then a tyrannicall ſtate: VVant of gouernment is worſe then a tyrannicall State. for though a tyrannical State be both greeuous and vnprofitable to the people, yet as of two hard extremities forced on men, the greater ſhould be firſt eſchewed, and in lieu thereof the leſſe tollerated and borne;Ferre mine • ra vole no grauiora feram. ſo eaſier it is (in ſuch a caſe) to ſuſtaine one tyrant for order, then to ſuffer many tyrants to diſturbe all order. Thus ſayth the Poet, applicable to this purpoſe.

q.l: The meaner greefe would I ſuſtaine,
That I might flee the grater paine.

div.p:
For indeede, where there is no Prince, no magiſtrate, no law, no gouernment,The Image of Anarchie. the vile ſhall preſume againſt the honourable, the boy againſt the ancient, and Homo erit homoni Lupus, One man ſhall deuour another: one neighbour will oppreſſe another:Plaut. in Aſmaria. a friend his friend, a brother his brother, with all kind of iniurie. There be newe lawes and decrees deuiſed euery day, ſo many opinions as there bee heades, and ordinarie deſtructions of companies be daily ſeene. They who a little before were combined in friendly league, are afterward made foes, and they murther and kill one another: they which haue beene worthily honoured for their vertues, are nowe vnworthily caſt into obloquie and contempt: and they who were iuſtly contemned for theyr vices, are now vniuſtly honoured and aduanced with high and glorious titles, and much ſet by among men. Of ſuch a diſcorded State ſpeaketh Iſayah the Prophet in his third Chapter, verſe 2,Verſ. 5.6.7.
wherein hee alludeth to the miſerable time of the Anarchie of the Iſraelites, then when there was neyther a King,
Iudg. 2.11. & 21.25. nor a Iudge, nor a Prophet in Iſrael, and euery man did not that which the Lawe of God and reaſon perſwaded, but that which ſeemed good in his owne eyes. Populus ſiue lege. In a word, this is that higheſt grade of the abuſes of the world, wherein the moſt wauering people, contemning the holy word of God, and all holy lawes, decrees, and good gouernment, runne headlong into the ſnares of preuarication and ſinne, in their erronious wayes, to their horrible deſtruction: the which, there is not any thing in the world can ſo ſoone haſten, as the want of lawes and gouernment, by the which Iuſtice is adminiſtred, and the people protected and preſerued. The ſame Prophet telleth vs,Iſa. 5.5. that when the Lorde would deuour, treade downe, and waſte his ingratefull vineyard, that is, the houſe of Iſrael, and the men of Iuda, he would firſt take away the hedge thereof, wherewith hee had hedged it,The law is as an hedge: for as when the hedge is brokē downe, the vineyard is ſpoyled of beaſts: ſo are the people deſtroyed, when they haue no lawes to gouerne them. Verſ. 1.2.3. and breake the VVall thereof, with the which it was ſtrengthened: that is, hee would depriue them of thoſe good lawes, ſtatutes, and ordinances, which hee had giuen them by his ſeruant Moſes, and would deface the glory of the Temple, which was builded for the beautie therof, and take from them the right ſeruice of God, and his protection, whereof they were vnworthie. And thus he expoūdeth it, Chap. 3, where he ſaith: That the Lord God of hoaſts will take away from Ieruſalem and from Iuda, the ſtay and ſtrength, euen all the ſtay of bread, and all the ſtay of water, the ſtrong man, & the man of war, the Iudge and the Prophet, the prudent and the aged, the Captaine of fiftie, and the honourable, and the Counſeller,
and the cunning artificer, and the eloquent man. The remouing away of theſe things, is the meane to diſorder, and ſo to deſtruction. For deſtruction and ruine followeth Ataxie, and diſorder, as Ataxie followeth Anarchie, and want of gouernment.

4 But I heare ſome to obiect. Chriſt (ſay they) haue ſaide in his doctrine,Mat. 5.
To him that taketh away thy Cloake, giue alſo thy Coate: reſiſt not euill. Iudge not, condemne not: whoſoeuer will bee the Prince among you, let him be a miniſter and ſeruant vnto all the reſt, &c. Ergo, Chriſt ouerthroweth gouernment, and polliticke obedience. Thus indeede when Iulian the Apoſtate heard of theſe wordes of Chriſt in the Goſpel, Reſ. Iulian the Apoſtate miſconſtrued Chriſts words. hee miſconſtruing them, did vtterly condemne & contemne the ſame, as naught and vnprofitable: for he thought that by this doctrine all pollitike order was confounded, that deſtructions of dominions was taken away from men, and that all Iudgements and deſerued puniſhments were by the lawe of the Goſpel vtterly aboliſhed: then the which, as nothing could be more noyſome vnto the people, ſo is there not any thing in the worlde more vngodly and abhominable, then that a men ſhould imagine ſo vnreuerently, and conſtrue ſo peruerſely of ſo heauenly and profitable a Doctrine, as Chriſt in theſe words of his, hath preached and taught vnto his diſciples. But becauſe Iulian had not the Spirite of wiſedome to vnderſtande Chriſt aright, as hee had the reaſon to conſider what inconueniences enſued the diſorder of Anarchie, therefore hee denounced his raſh and wicked cenſure againſt the Doctrine of Chriſt. And in this our time, that Atheiſticall Macchiauile
hath ſchooled no ſmall companie of worldly men to doo the like. But it ſhould bee right farre off from Chriſtians to iudge ſo vniuſtly, and ſo meanely of the doctrine of the Goſpel, as that they ſhould imagine and conceit, that becauſe it hath pleaſed God to call them into the libertie of the Goſpel, therfore they are free from the cenſures of the politicall law and conſtitutions of princes, magiſtrates, and lawes. They that bee of this conceit are willing to take the libertie of the Goſpel,The libertie of the Goſpel doth not deliuer vs from obedience to Princes, &c. but they deceiue themſelues and their followers in the vile abuſe thereof. It is moſt certaine that our Sauiour hath in his Sermon, ſpoken againſt raſh cenſures, and againſt the reuenge of the priuate iniuries of Brethren, in that ſence which Moſes ſpake, when he ſaid, Ye be brethrē, why oppreſſe ye one another? And hee ſpeaketh againſt them that ambitiouſly vſurped authoritie in the pride of their hearts, ouer their brethren, and would teach the effects of the loue, which (as Peter ſaide) couereth the multitude of ſinnes. And he was farre off from that purpoſe (they dreame of) to deſtroy and abandon lawes, orders, and gouernments, either in the church,
Chriſt came not to deſtroy the law.
Se. cap. 11.4. or in the Common-wealth. And to take away that ſurmiſe out of mens mindes, hee ſayde plainely in the ſame Sermon: Thinke not that I am come to deſtroy the Law or the Prophets: I am not come to deſtroy them, but to fulfill them. Againe he ſaith: VVhoſoeuer ſhall breake one of thoſe leaſt commandements, and ſhall teach men ſo,
Mat. 5.17. he ſhal be called the leaſt in the kingdome of heauen. Hee ſpeaketh of that law both politike and morall, which the Lorde gaue the Iſraelites by the miniſtrie of Moſes, the which wee are not to reiect, but as Chriſt, the Prophets, and Apoſtles
haue taught to endeuour through faith in the merite of Chriſt, to obſerue to the vttermonſt of our power. For we are not iuſtified by faith to this ende, that therefore we ſhould reiect good workes,The end of our iuſtification. and folow after that which God in his law hath forbidden; but that henceforth wee expreſſe the light of our faith before men throgh our good works, eſpecially, thoſe which in the law of god are preſcribed. Among all the which, this is a chiefe dutie (next to the feate and honor of God) that men ſhould honour the Prince, the Magiſtrates, and them that be placed in authoritie, included within this, Honor thy father and mother. And this the Lord ratifieth when hee ſaid, Yeeld vnto Caeſar, that which to Caeſar belongeth.

In this ſort, there be, which wreaſt aſide the true meaning of Chriſt, Iohn 8.11. The woman taken in adulterie, was not freed from the ſentence of the law. teaching that abſolution which hee gaue to the woman taken in adulterie, whom the Iewes had brought and ſet before Chriſt, and they would, that in the ſame the Lord ſhould abrogate the ſentence of the Iudge, and that penall lawe, according to whoſe conceite, then it muſt be, that neither whoredome, nor theft, nor murther, nor any other heynous tranſgreſsion of the lawes, ſhould be puniſhed by the miniſterie of the Magiſtrate. But they are much deceiued: for it is moſt plaine, that Chriſt abſolued not the guiltie woman from that temporall puniſhment, which the magiſtrate was to award her for her ſinne according to the lawe: no more then hee deliuered the Theefe which hung on his right hand, from his execution, though hee repented: but referring her and him to that puniſhment which the law awarded for their tranſgreſsions, he onelie abſolued
them both from that eternall death, the which by their ſinnes they had iuſtly deſerued. As hee came not to breake, but to fulfill the lawe: ſo hee gaue this warrantice, that, rather heauen and earth ſhould periſh, then that one iote of the Lawe ſhoulde faile.

Saint Peter knowing well, what the will of his Maiſter was in this poynt, taught accordinglie,Submiſſion to the Prince and lawes. when hee ſayde: Submit your ſelues vnto all manner ordinaunce of man for the Lordes ſake: Whether it bee vnto the King, as vnto the ſuperiour, or vnto gouernours, as vnto them that are ſent of him, for the puniſhment of euill doers, and for the praiſe of them that doo well. And hee addeth a reaſon: For ſo is the will of God, that by well dooing yee may put to ſilence the ignoraunce of the fooliſh man. Lo, howe excellently Peter heere expoundeth his Maiſters doctrine? And of this minde was Paule, Rom. 13. Tit. 1. who, to the Romanes, to Titus, and in other places, writeth much of this Argument.

Agaynſt this power of the Prince, the Lorde forbiddeth anie man to riſe, reſiſt, or rebell, by this woorde in the Lawe (which Dauid alſo remembreth) Touch not mine annoynted, and doo my Prophets no harme.
Pſal. The wrath of God againſt rebels, and ſeditionaries. Num. 16.22.32. And to witneſſe his diſpleaſure agaynſt ſuch as oppoſe themſelues to his ordinaunce, hee hath committed to perpetuall memorie the horrible deſtruction of Corah, with his complices, who indeede died not the common death of all men, nor were viſited after the viſitation of men: but, The grounde cleauing aſunder vnder them, the Earth opened her mouth, and ſwallowed
them vp, and their houſes, their ſeruants and their goods, and they and all that they had went downe aliue into hell, and the earth cloſed vpon them.

5 Theſe things if thoſe ſtraunge conceited heads coulde digeſt, and well weigh,Men be not borne to liue without lawes and gouernment. they woulde not bee ſo eaſilie carryed away, to bee of this brute minde, that men bee borne into this worlde, therein to lope at large without their limitted bounds, as the wandering Birdes which flie in the ayre: but they woulde conceiue and keepe in minde, that, as the nature of man is in no wiſe framed to that libertie, ſo the Lorde GOD (who hath created man alſo, hath ordeined him to liue in this worlde to his glorie vnder lawes and gouernment: and requireth that therefore hee bee ſubiect,Tit. 3 1. Rom. 13.1. firſt and principallie to his moſt excellent Maieſtie the King of all kings: and then next, that hee bee obedient vnto Caeſar, or the King: that is, vnto that chiefe power, which next vnder himſelfe hee hath preferred to all others, as his holy ordinance, to gouerne and tule men in that place of the world whervnto he hath choſen and called him by his grace, as himſelfe ruleth in heauen. This Maro entended when he compoſed this Monostich: Iupiter in Caelis. Caeſar regit omniaterris.Virg.
That is.

q.l: In heauen God, on earth the King,
Aye rules and gouernes euerie thing.

div.p:
Thus therfore ſaith Peter (which he taketh from Salomon) Feare God, and honour the King.
Pro. 24.21. 1. Pet. 2.17. That is to ſay. I woulde that (as it is meete and
right) yee ſhoulde firſt feare God, honour God, worſhip God: and then, that yee honour and obey the King, the Prince, the chiefe Magiſtrate. This thing the Iſraelites obſerued for a time, and were therein happie, for the which Dauid omitted not to prayſe and glorifie the Lorde, who had in ſuch ſort prepared their hearts, as Chron. 29. And this, if our ſingular conceited heades coulde well perſwade, they woulde bee the more willing and readie, both to learne and to know wherein this Honour of the Prince conſiſteth, that ſo they might the better yeelde the ſame where it is due. But (alas) there bee of this kinde that diſdaine to heare and learne, for why, they know inough alreadie: well, let their owne conceites ſatisfie them then, and let them ſounde the depth of their owne errours to theyr owne woe. Howbeeit, for the ſakes of them that will either gladly heare againe, that which they learned and knew before, for their better confirmation and comfort: or that being ignorant therof, and would willingly learne, I haue thought good to compriſe the ſame in thoſe foure poynts, vz.

list.item: VVherein conſiſteth the honour. of a Prince.1 In reuerence, to the Prince.
2 In loue, to the Prince.
3 In obedience, to the Prince.
4 In prayer vnto God for the Prince.

div.p:
1 Reuerence.Firſt it is meete, that wee affoord the Prince a iuſt eſtimation of our minds, with a worthie declaration of his or her honour. And to this wee bee perſwaded (among others) by theſe foure
arguments: namely,Cauſes that moue men to honour Princes. firſt for that the King or Prince is the ordinaunce and power of God, who teſtifieth ſaying: Through me do Kings raigne, and Princes make iuſt lawes. 2. For that the Lord God himſelfe through the graces and power of his ſpirit, is preſent with thoſe Kinges and Princes, in their Parliaments, in their Councels, in their Congregations, in their great aſſemblies, in their places of iudgement: and hee is the principall power and iudge in the middeſt of them all, as ſayeth the Pſalmeſt, whoſe wordes are theſe: Elohim nitzab bayadath oel, bekereb Elohim iiſchpot, That is: God ſtandeth in the Congregation of God: in the middest of the Gods, Pſal. 82.1. (or Princes) he is the Iudge. And this teacheth, that as the authoritie of the King, or Prince (which the Lorde hath ordained, and beautified with that diuine title Goddes, is (indeed) a diuine authoritie: ſo the power of the Prince is Gods power, the coū cell is Gods councell, the Senate is Gods Senate, the Congregation, and the great aſſembly is the Lords: his ſeat is Gods ſeat, and his throne is Gods throne: God is there preſent, God ſitteth, God maketh lawes, God ruleth, God iudgeth, God ordreth all things after his will and wiſedome, howſoeuer the Princes abuſe their places, and the people conceit of their actions: therfore, he that doth rauerence to the Prince as to him whō the Lord hath ordained, placed and beautified, he honoureth God; hee that contemneth this ordinance contemneth God, to his owne deſtruction.The Prince careth for the common good. 3. Thirdly the Prince is to be reuerenced of the people, becauſe that hee watcheth, he warreth, he deuiſeth, he counſelleth, he prayeth, he careth, he endeuoureth euerie way to helpe, to
benefite, to defende, to rule, and to make happie his people, euen then, when they doo ſleepe and take their quiet reſt, and are negligent and careleſſe, both of the common good, and of their owne ſafetie: verefying that rule of Homer, touching the dutie of a Prince.
That is,
div.q: The noble Prince it ill beſeemes all night to ſleepe.
div.p:
This princely vertue hath beene worthily noted in the famous Iulius Caeſar, who therein immetated the noble Troian Aeneas, Virg. Aene. li. 1. & li. 10. of whoſe praiſe Virgil hath written at large: or rather that moſt victorious King Alexander, whom they of the olde time gratefully remembring, woulde ſay in their common talke of him, and his conqueſts, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,Claud. Mino. in Alciat Embl. 3. Pſal.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : that is, King Alexander became famous, not by idleneſſe and reſt: but by his bolde aduentures, hard labours, and actions. But beyond all theſe, the Kinglie Prophet draweth a moſt woorthie example of this vertue, from the King of all Kings, whom in that reſpect he calleth, The keeper of Iſrael, who (as hee ſayeth) dooth neither ſlumber nor ſleepe: to note his continuall care of his Church: in regard whereof, he deſerueth to be reuerenced of his Saints.

4 The Prince is as a father to his people.4 Fourthly, the King is to be reuerenced, for that he is created a Father vnto his people, and to whom they bee as children: therefore they of yore called their Princes, Patres patriae, The fathers of their country. Now then, if it be iuſt and godly, that children do
reuerence their parents: then is it a thing iuſt and godly, that the people do yeeld reuerence to theyr princes: but that it is both iuſt and godly for children ſo to do, not onely nature and reaſon, but the law of God alſo, Exod. 20. teacheth and requireth. Therfore in right and all godlineſſe ought the Princes to bee reuerenced of their people. Howbeit,Ceremonies in reuerence of Princes. we muſt be verie heedfull, that our Ceremonies in this reuerence, be neither too many, nor too few, nor be ſuperſtitious: for if they be too many, they argue a ſeruilitie of the ſubiects, and a crueltie of the Prince. If they bee too few, they declare the ſmal regard and diſſoluteneſſe of the ſubiects towards their Prince: if they be ſuperſtitious, they ſhew forth more barbarity then true Chriſtianitie. Therfore in this thing the iuſt meane is to be obſerued in all godlineſſe,Plato. to declare a moderate gouernment, & a moderate ſubiection. This is that firſt point, wherein (as I ſayd) that honour of the King, or Prince conſiſteth.

6 The next point is Loue. And it is meete that we affect this diuine Ordinance next vnto God,Loue the Prince. with that ſweet delectation of the heart, which taketh pleaſure in deſiring, and ioy in well vſing the thing deſired: which runneth by a deſire, and reſteth by a ioy: running to that, and reſting in this. It is not enough for a man to ſay I loue, & I affect this or that • hing, except that he endeuor to expreſſe this loue, this affection, by ſome external argument. The poet ſpeaking of the nature or vehement affection of loue, writeth thus:
— For who can fire hide:—Quis enim celauerit ignem? Ouid.
VVhich with the light bewrayes it ſelfe, and is diſcride?
〈2 pages missing〉
prouided by his maieſtie for the glorie of God, and benefit of the Common-wealth. It is not inough that the Prince by his power, doo defende and maintaine thoſe good Lawes, which hee together with his moſt prudent Counſellers hath inuented and prouided, and the which hee woulde that his learned and wiſe Iudges ſhould diſcerne and execute in Iuſtice, or moderate in equitie (as the thinges ſhall require) but that alſo his Subiects doo yeelde dutifull obedience, in the right obſeruation of all thoſe good Lawes accordingly.VVhereby obedience is diſcerned. And this vertue is to bee expreſſed by this, that men doo neyther grudge nor repyne againſt thoſe lawes: nor refuſe to yeelde and pay foorth all thoſe Tributes, Tenthes, Taxes, Subſedies, cuſtomes, and ſuch other duties, which are by thoſe Lawes exacted, and in good reaſon required of them: but that they doo with all willingneſſe and gladneſſe yeelde out the ſame accordingly. For as the Labourer is woorthie of his wages, ſo this cheefe Magiſtrate ſhould not bee defrauded nor denyed his right: who laboureth night and day by all wayes and meanes poſſible, for the preſeruation, defence, and ſafetie of the people vnder him: to whome therefore we ſhould bee no leſſe willing, then the people were in the time of Dauid, to contribute to him of theyr wealth and treaſures, towards the building of the Lords houſe. 1. Chro. 29. and ſo readie, as wee bee willing to haue our ſelues, our Wiues, our Children, and our goods preſerued and defended from our mortall and deadly energies. For, indeede, by theſe duties ſhall the State and realme
be the better deſended, the godly on all ſides the better maintained in peace and tranquilitie, the noble Princes right worthily adorned, and the enemie both ciuill and forraigne the ſooner ſuppreſſed. And this ſhall wee yeelde vnto in all dutie, the rather if wee wiſely conſider, that whatſouer wee ſhall yeelde vnto our Prince in this caſe,VVe owe to the prince that which is required of vs. Mat. 22.20. is rather a due debt then a gift. Therefore the Lorde ſaith, Yeelde to Caeſar, thoſe things that are Caeſars: Let the King haue his owne, Pay to the Prince, the Princes dutie.

But thou beginneſt to examine the lawes which the prince hath prouided,ob. Reſ. whether they be good or euill, and ſo doubteſt whether they ſhould bee obeyed or not obeyed. Indeed the lawes that be prouided are either good, or elſe they are euill: if they be good, then are they ſuch lawes as are either godly or profitable, either for thy ſelfe,Good lawes. or for the common-wealth, or for the whole Church, and to the glorie of God: and of theſe there is no queſtion, but that they ought to bee obſerued in all holy and godly obedience. And it is no ſmall happineſſe vnto the people, to haue a Prince that prouideth thoſe Lawes: and no leſſe felicitie for a Cittie (as Xenophon once ſayde) to haue within it Cittizens, that are obedient to ſuch Lawes. And to ſuch a Prince, and of ſuch a people may it bee ſayde by them that wiſely conſidered thereof, with the Queene of Saba: Happie are thy men: happie are theſe thy ſeruants which ſtande euer before thee, 1. King. 10.8. and heare thy wiſedome. And bleſſed be the Lorde thy God which loued thee, &c. and made thee King to do equitie and righteouſneſſe.

Euill lawes.On the other ſide, if the lawes be euill, then are they greeuous and burthenſome either to thy body and wealth, or to thy minde and conſcience, being againſt the righteouſneſſe of God and his glory. If thoſe lawes concerne onely thy body, thy goods, and outward man, they are to bee yeelded vnto for conſcience ſake: for all theſe things, thou maiſt not thinke, but that the Prince hath power to command and take from thee, as his owne, neither are thoſe afflictions which come vnto thee in theſe things, greater and more greeuous, then that hard affliction which the children of Iſrael felt in Egypt vnder Pharao: and more heauie, then that which Naboth ſuſtained in Iſrael vnder Achab and Iezabel: and more irkſome then that which Mephiboſeth ſuffered at the promotion of Ziba, vnder Dauid. And what did they? ſurely we finde it not recorded in the ſeueral hiſtories of theſe three ſeuerall perſons, that either the children of Iſrael rebelled or murmured againſt Pharao theyr king, Exo 2.23 24. in the diſlike of his Lawes (albeit they ſpeake angrily to Moſes in the heauy burthen of their double taſkes, when they thought that the rather by his meanes the king was exaſperated againſt them) but they daily obſerued his word in the accompliſhment of their taſked workes: or that poore Naboth reſiſted the word and law of King Achab though he granted not to ſell away that part of his inheritance,1 King. 21.3. which by Gods law he was forbidden to ſell away. Or that Mephiboſeth denied the worde of King Dauid, touching the diuiſion of his lande betweene himſelfe and Ziba: but hee ſaid vnto the King:2 Sam. 19.10. Yea, let him take all, if the Kings pleaſure be ſo.

8 But yet, if the princes being wicked Idolatours, do make and prouide ſuch diuelliſh, vngodly, and ſuperſtitious lawes and decrees,Lawes againſt the glorie of God, &c. as tend to the diſhonour of almightie God, and the perdition of the innocent people of God, an horror to the conſcience, and a greefe to the mind of al good men: then is the caſe altred, for now not onely nature, reaſon, and autenticall examples, but the word and warrant of God, teach men to beware that they obſerue not ſuch lawes. As the earth is ſet vnder the heauens, and man vnder God, ſo is euery earthly kingdome ſet vnder an higher kingdome,Omne ſub regno grauis ore regnum eſt. Sene. in Thyeſt. tragaed. Act. 3. and all the Kings, Princes, and Potentates in the world, are ſubdued to the King of heauen, and he ruleth ouer all, in reſpect of the which, all others are to be ſet apart, as we ſee how in the preſence of the greater, the power of the leſſe appeareth not, as then, when the Sunne ſhineth bright, the light of the Moone is obſcured. Again,Eccleſ. 1. as al the Riuers yeeld themſelues and runne into the ſea, from whence they take their originall, and come by a naturall courſe, ſo it is, that all dutie ſhould be yeelded vnto him from whom all dutie diſcendeth: that is to the Lord of heauen, the which Dauid gratefully remembred in his prayer to the Lorde, ſaying: 1. Chro. 29, 11. Thine O Lord is greatneſſe, and power, and glorie, and victorie, and prayſe: for all that is in heauen and earth is thine: thine is the kingdome O Lord, and thou excelleſt, as head ouer all: beholde, riches and honour come of thee, and thou raigneſt ouer all. Againe, All things come of thee: 1. Chron. 19.14. and that which came to vs of thine owne hande, haue we giuen thee. And reaſon teacheth vs, that it is much better for vs to obey him and his commandements, with whome
we ſhal dwell & liue for euer, then to rebell againſt him, & to keep his lawes with whom we can dwell and liue but a verie little whiles. In the due conſideration wherof, that wiſe and learned Philoſopher Socrates (though an Heathen man) being requeſted by his friendes to yeeld vnto the Senate of the Athenians in matters of Religion, wherein he ſaw how far they erred from the holy worſhip of God: that by his obedience, that way he might eſcape the ſentence of death,Socrat. apud Plutar. anſwered them in theſe words. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That is: O ye men of Athens, I do both reuerence and loue you: howbeit, I will yet rather obey God, then obey you.

A notable ſaying of an Heathen, well woorthie to be embraced and obſerued of all Chriſtians.Eleazar. 2. Mac. 6.19. The like in effect wee finde of that holy Eleazar in the booke of the Machabees, who alſo choſe rather to die, then to tranſgreſſe the law of the God of Iſrael, at the commaundement of the vngodly tyrant.

9. But in the Canonical Scriptures we haue many worthie examples, among the which we preſently call to mind the Hebrew Mid-wiues in Egypt, The Hebrew Midwiues. who nothwitſtanding they did with their brethren, beare the heauie burthens of their daily taſks without denial, would not in this yeeld to ſhed innocent bloud, againſt the law of God: & to ſhew that in this they pleaſed God, Exo. 1.20. Moſes ſayth: That the Lord builded them houſes, Daniel. & proſpered them. Alſo we reade of Daniel, who notwithſtanding he was a true ſubiect to the King of Babilon in his Captiuitie, Dan. 6.22. as the Prophet Ieremie had before exhorted ye Iews to be, and praied for his peace: yet did he worſhip the Lord God contrary to the raſh & vngodly decree of the king: & to ſhew how wel he pleaſed the lord therin, he preſerued him
from the power of the lions. Alſo Sydrach, Miſach, Sydrach. and Abednego refuſed to worſhip the Idol which the king had ſet vp in Babilon: & to witneſſe the Lords pleaſure therin, He ſent his Angel and defended them from the feruencie of the fiery ouē. For albeit, Ier. 27.8.9. that Ieremie had before exhorted thē to ſerue the king of Babilon, into whoſe hand the Lord had deliuered thē in his diſpleaſure, & Ezechiel had according to the ſame, Ezec. 17.13. perſwaded them to keepe their oath & promiſe of obedience to him: yet did neither the one nor the other of them giue them any aime to commit idolatrie, to prophane the glory of god, & to do things abhomiminable in that ſeruice. But rather, according to the contents of that epiſtle of Ieremy which Baruch copied our for ye children of Iſrael which were in Babilō, Darach. 6.4.5. this was their charge: Beware therfore, that ye in no wiſe be like the ſtrangers, neither be ye afraide of thē (that is, of their gods) when ye ſee the multitude before them and behind them worſhip thē: But ſay ye in your harts, O Lord we muſt worſhip thee. Therefore when Chriſt had ſaide,Mat. 22.21. Apodote. Yeeld ye to Caeſar that which is his: he addeth by and by, And yeeld ye that to God which to God belongeth. His meaning is that we yeeld to Caeſar only that wherof Caeſar hath right and power: as wealth, lands, bodies,VVhere of the King hath right. childrē, ſeruants, cattell, yea, & our mortall liues to do him ſeruice, without denial or grudge,1. Sam. 8.11. Neh. 9.37. if it be by Caeſar required: but yet ſo, as wee omit not to ſerue God: neither in this, may we cheefely honor and obey the earthly king, & then after that honor and obey god, he meaneth not ſo, for he teacheth not any ſuch thing:Mat. 6. Eccleſ. 8.2. 1. Pet. 1.13. but he teacheth that we firſt ſeeke the kingdom of god & the righteouſnes therof: before al other things: & that in the obedience of our princes we ſhuld order our ſelues ſo, as therin we might alſo obey God.
And truely, when wee ſhall in theſe two poynts ſo wiſely concord, we ſhal ſoone perceiue how handſomely and worthily one grace will ſupport another, Sophocles. one vertue will defend another, in a moſt ſweete harmony and conſent.Men ought not to rebell or reſiſt the princes power But yet, this is to be noted, that as it is a thing repugnant to nature, that the members of the body ſhould riſe vp and annoy the head, wherein they perceiue greefe and imperfections: ſo vnnaturall is it, yea, and againſt all law and reaſon, that the ſubiects ſhould be in armes againſt their lawfull Prince, or rebell, or reſiſt his power, notwithſtanding that he be an euill Prince, and his lawes are euill alſo. This intendeth the Apoſtle when he ſayde: He that reſiſteth the power, receiueth to himſelfe damnation: and that iuſtly, becauſe he reſiſteth the Ordinance of God. For though the Lord in his anger giueth ſuch kings ouer the people, as being wicked, may be ſcourges vnto thē for their ſins, (as Elihu ſaid to Iob:
Iob. 34.30. 2. Sam. 8. The Hypocrite raigneth, and the people are ſnared) yet muſt they eſteeme him the Lords ſeruant in this place, and yeelde to him that which to a prince appertaineth. We haue of this a notable example in Dauid,
Dauid obeyed Saule.
1 Sam. 24.6. & ca. 26 1 • . 2. Sam. 1.14. who notwithſtanding he was hardly handled of Saul that vngodly king, whom hee knew that himſelfe was to ſucceede in the kingdome: would not (for all that) ſtrike him, nor oppreſſe him, albeit he had diuers opportunities offered him. And his reaſon was, for that Saul was the Lords annointed, his power was of God, and Dauid (as yet) was not a King, The Iſraelites ver • commā ded to ſerue the king of Babilon. but a Subiect, owing dutifull obedience to Saul whom he acknowledged for his Lord and King: and in conſideration thereof, when Ezechiel ſaw how little the Iſraelites regarded
this, after the king of Iſrael had giuen his oath to the King of Babylon,
Iere. 27.8. and 29, 7. Bar. 1.11.12. Eze. 17.13 whom he was thenceforth to ſerue as a ſubiect, according to the words of Ieremie: hee verie ſharpely rebuked him and them, ſaying: Shall he proſper? ſhall he eſcape that doth theſe things? or ſhall he breake the couenant and be deliuered? As if he ſhould aunſwere himſelfe, no, no: hee ſhall neither proſper, nor eſcape an heauie iudgement, that breaketh his alleageance, and rebelleth againſt his lawfull Prince.

10 But I heare ſome ſay, what is this? What, may wee not obſerue an vngodlie decree? nor yet reſiſt ſuch lawes? nor withſtande the power of them that prouide them? What then? May wee neither ſpeake nor write agaynſt ſuch lawes in the high diſlike of them? No doubt, although wee neither obſerue them, nor reſiſt the power of thoſe that prouide them, yet may we lawfully ſpeake or write againſt vngodlie lawes: howbeit,How men may ſpeake againſt vngodly lawes. with ſuch reuerence and modeſtie before ſuch perſons, in ſuch times, in ſuch places, and with ſuch wiſdom, as that thereby the people bee not incenced nor moued againſt the Prince, the Magiſtrates, and them that be placed in authoritie: yea, and ſo, that not ſo much as anie little occaſion be therby miniſtred to ſchiſme in the Church, or Sedition among the people. But yet the redreſſe and reformation of thoſe thinges muſte wee commit vnto the King of all Kings, who vpon the heartie prayers of the people,Men ought to pray to God for redreſſe, and not to rebell. will take the matter into his owne hande: wee ought to deſire his diuine Maieſtie to reſpect the miſerie of his people, to maintaine his owne glorie, to turne the hearts of Princes, that they bee
moued (with Ahaſueroſh) to reuoke all vngodlie lawes and decrees, and with that noble Cyrus) to encline the heart of Zorobubel, and the people of God, to further the building of the Citie and houſe of God. And if this preuaile not, let vs then arme our ſelues with patience,Chriſtian patience. that ſpirituall and diuine vertue, which the Lord ſo much cōmended and enioyned to his Apoſtles and Diſciples, by the which the godlie do beare with quiet minds, & thoſe croſſes and afflictions which the Lorde ſhall lay on their ſhoulders, knowing well, that God is faithfull, and will not ſuffer them to bee tempted aboue that they be able,1 Cor. 10.13. but will giue them the iſſue with the temptation, that they may be able to beare it. In this ought we to poſſeſſe our ſelues, howſoeuer we be dealt with for the Lords cauſe, eſpecially by them that bee placed in authoritie,Exod. 22. and Not in anie wiſe to raile vpon the gods: That is, the Princes and Magiſtrates,Eccles. 10.10. 2 Chro. 24.22. Ierem. nor to wiſh the King euill in our hearts. In this ſort did Zacharias, and Ieremie behaue themſelues. Thus Chriſt Ieſus, when his time was come, yeelded himſelfe to the Emperors power, as he was a man, & ſharplie reproued his ſeruant Peter, for that he drew his ſword, with a purpoſe to reſiſt: adding to the ſame,The iudgemēt of ſuch as reſiſt their Princes. He that ſtriketh with the ſword, eſpecially in ſuch a caſe, to rebel, or reſiſt, or oppreſſe the Princes power, Shall periſh with the ſworde. That is, He ſhall not eſcape his deſerued iudgement in his due time, as a perſon both hatefull to God, & vnworthie to liue among men. And thus alſo that cōſtant Protomartyr Stephen, patiently endured the rage of his perſecutors, Act. 7.60. and omited not to pray for them, after the example of his Lord and maiſter Chriſt. Theſe
be patterns for vs to folow in all godlineſſe, chieflie in this point of obedience to Princes and lawes.

12 Finally, it becommeth vs Chriſtians to declare the high honor of our Princes,Pray for the Prince. in wiſhing wel vnto them, and in hearty & godly praiers to the lord God for them, without wrath or reaſoning. If we know the Prince to be euil and wicked, we muſt deſire the Lord to conuert his heart, and to conforme him to the rule of his holy law in all things, as it is before ſaid: & in this law to grant him peace and proſperitie, to his glory, and the ioy of the Church. If the Prince be good and godly, adorned with the right princely graces and vertues, as whom we may perſwade that the Lord God in mercy hath annointed and exalted for the good of his people, and defence of his cauſe: let vs vs not forget nor omit to bleſſe & praiſe the Lord for this chiefe benefite, as the people did in the raigne of Dauid,
1. Chro. 29. & let vs beſeech his moſt high maieſtie, to encreaſe yet more and more, and to cōtinue thoſe his diuine graces and bleſsings in this princely perſon, with the greateſt proſperity & happineſſe.1. Tim. 2.1, 2, 3. To this dutie S. Paul was moſt careful to exhort, & would that Timothie ſhould be no leſſe carefull to moue and perſwade the people to the ſame. And this is indeed a generall doctrine, yt men ought to pray for, and wiſh well vnto thoſe powers which the lord hath ordained & placed ouer thē. Ier. 29.7. This was Ieremy his coūſel to the Iſraelites now going into Babylon, Ye ſhall pray for the peace of Babylō. And he addeth a reaſon. For in the peace thereof your peace conſiſteth. Ier. 20.7. And ſo wrote Baruch in a booke to the Iewes: Pray for the proſperitie of Nabuchadonozor King of Babylon, and for the welfare of Balthaſar his ſonne: Bar. 1.11.
And hee addeth the reaſons therof, as Verſ. 12. And to perſwade the ſooner to this dutie, Paule alſo addeth to his exhortation two mightie Arguments, the one he taketh from the end of this ordinaunce, ſaying: That wee may lead a quiet and a peaceable life, in all godlineſſe and honestie. The other, hee taketh from the equitie and goodneſſe thereof, ſaying: For this is good and acceptable in the ſight of God our Sauiour. The former Argument containeth three neceſſarie fruites of a good gouernment: namelie, Argument. 1 Firſt, a peaceable life: for the ſworde is committed to the Prince to conſerue the common peace and Argument. 2 tranquilitie in the vſe of iuſtice. Secondlie, the conſeruation of pietie: for the Prince defendeth and maintaineth the right Religion, and feare of God Argument. 3 in the Common-wealth. Thirdly, the regarde of publike honeſtie among the people: for hee prohibiteth them from running into thoſe barbarous and beaſtly demeanours which defile men, and deface the beautie of good order; and he draweth them to that modeſtie and moderate behauiour, which beſt Argument. 2 beſeemeth men. The ſecond argument hath alſo two branches. Firſt, It is good: that is, right and lawfull. Argument. 1 Next, It is Acceptable and pleaſant vnto God. And Argument. 2 this confirmeth the former argument in this ſort: It is good and acceptable to God, not onely that men lead a quiet life in all godlines and honeſtie, but alſo that they pray vnto him for Kings, and for all them that be placed in authoritie, that by their miniſterie, this peace, this godlineſſe, and this honeſtie, may be defended and maintained. And that ſentence folowing may not amiſſe be taken to belong vnto the premiſſes: namely, That God will haue all men to be ſaued,
and to come to the knowledge of the truth. The end of a good gouernment. Which (beſides the large mercie and good will of God to all nations, ſexes and degrees of perſons therein declared) teacheth the end of a good gouernmēt: which is, to preſerue and ſaue the people, & to draw them to the knowledge of the truth, by the conſeruation and defence of the right faith and religion. Well then, if by the help and miniſterie of this ordinance, we haue the right peace maintained, godlineſſe conſerued, honeſtie regarded: If it be a thing ſo good and acceptable to the Lorde, and if it be the will of God by this meane to preſerue his people & nurture them in his feare and religion, let vs acknowledge and remember, that of them alſo the people ſhould haue a cheife care and regard, that they ſhould not only reuerence them, loue them & obey them, but alſo pray for them, & wiſh them euer al proſperitie.

13 The verie heathen people thought this alſo to be iuſt, godly, and conuenient, that the people did yeeld this poynt of honor and gratitude vnto them, on whoſe peace and proſperitie they conſidered the peace and proſperitie of the common-wealth to depend, perſwading that the King or prince was no leſſe ſtay to the people,The Prince is to the people, as the foundation to an houſe. then the foundation of an houſe to the ſame houſe, on whom they leane and reſt themſelues, and the which being taken away from them, they ſoone fall down and periſh.Baſileus. Therfore of the Greekes, a King was called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which is a worde compounded of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a foundation, or ſtay: and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the people: as, The foundation and ſtay of the people. In the like ſenſe, the Princes were by them called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , The Paſtours or ſhepheards of the people. For as the paſtour is vnto his flocke; ſo is the
Prince vnto the people: but the Paſtour feedeth, ſalueth, keepeth, defendeth & preſerueth his flock, and without his ordinarie helpe and care the flocke periſheth. And hereof alſo, the Prince was called ſometime a Captaine, ſometimes a Biſhop, an Ouerſeer, or Lawkeeper. Xenophon. Neither thought theſe men that it was ſufficient for them, to haue good lawes prouided, except that alſo they had ſuch noble Princes, as were both willing and able to ſee them performed and kept accordingly.

14 Many ſuch arguments might bee to this purpoſe produced, were it not, that theſe before alledged enough, on the one ſide to diſſwade men (if they may bee diſſwaded) from that vnreuerend and monſtruous opinion which ſome in there vnquiet ſpirits haue conceiued of the Magiſtrates and lawes; and on the other ſide, to perſwade them (if it may be) to honour the Prince (being the Lordes holie annoynted, and chiefe head of the Church and Common-wealth next vnder Chriſt) with that reuerence, that loue, that obedience, and thoſe Chriſtian prayers to the Lorde for the ſame, which are meete and godlie to be vſed: and that withall, they woulde eſteeme of thoſe good lawes and godlie conſtitutions, which are made and prouided for the aduauncement of the glorie of God, and for the benefite of his Church (by the heauenly wiſedome of the chiefe ſeruants of his grace in the ſame) moſt gladly and dutifully, without murmur or vaine diſputations.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Sedition is a vile and noiſom thing. Euery good man knowing the daunger thereof, doth wiſely flie and eſchue it.
div.p:
IT is too true, and a thing too often proued, and the griefe of the tryall likewiſe felt in all ages: that as ambitious heades haue much diſquieted the peace and tranquilitie of the Church with moſt perillous Schiſmes: ſo ceaſe they not to enhazarde the ſafetie of our eſtabliſhed Common-wealth with manie high contentions, diſcordes, and noyſome Seditions. And I feare much (indeede) that they haue alreadie pearced ſuch deepe wounds, as they ſhall bee neuer able to bind vp and recure: neither can their owne wiſedome, or anie their beſt deuiſes finde out howe to ſtoppe or preuent the manifold inconueniences enſuing the ſame. For, the beginning of ſtrife (as Salomon thereof ſayde) is as one that openeth the waters.
Prou. 17.14: That is to ſay:A fit compariſon. Euen as the waters (which were ſometimes bound and encloſed in ſome veſſels, or within ſome bankes) are now let to runne out, and cannot be reſtrained from fleeting abroade, nor gathered togither againe by him or them that ſo let them to runne foorth: ſo neither can thoſe ſtrifes and contentions bee appeaſed, nor the inconueniences of the ſame ſtopped, or remedyed by thoſe ſeditious perſons who haue broached the ſame. Therefore Salomon counſelleth, Before the contention
be medled withall, leaue off. This is good counſell for them which haue not yet warmed their handes at thoſe furious fires,Pro. 28.25. Minſinger de ſedit. C. which proud ſtomacks enkindle among men. As this is an vniuerſall argument, that Ambitious perſons do ſow the ſeedes of diſcord among the people. So it is moſt certaine, that Seditious perſons doo ſeeke onely euill,
Pro. 17.18. as Salomon ſaith. For Sedition bringeth after it calamitie (as Euripedes ſaid) yea, Sedition bringeth after it deſolation. For ſhe diſsipateth and throweth downe the ſtrongeſt Caſtels, Cities and kingdomes. And this was proued of old in that memorable example of the builders of the Tower and Citie of Babel,
Gen. 11.8.9, 10. who ſoone after the diuiſion of their languages, left off to built the Citie, which thereon fel to ruine, and themſelues were ſcattered abroade on the face of the earth, to bee for a perpetuall document to all the poſterities. But let vs yet a little conſider the nature of this hurtful vice with her effects and fruits, and thereby loath and contemne her, as the good citizens are heedful to preuent thoſe noyſome fires,The nature of Sedition. which riſe vp of little ſparkles, and burne manie houſes, to the dread and trouble of their whole Citie. Maro depainteth her thus:
Verg.— Ac veluti in populo cum ſaepe coorta eſt
Seditio, &c.
2 As, when in middes of mightie troupes
of men, doth oft ariſe
Sedition fell, the mindes of all
the vulgar ſort are madde:
The Torches frie, and ſtones be flung,
and furie forceth warre, &c.
And this Petronius, Arbiter amplifieth,Bul. in Act. 19. deſcribing this noyſome Sedition, in theſe words. Intremuere turbae, &c.

q.l: The Common people mou'd, then diſcord
with rough rented heares
Doth lift aloft her Stygian head,The Image of ſedition.
and in her face appeares
The bloud congeal'd, her ſtaring eyes
as weeping now are ſeene:
Her gnaſhing teeth their cankred filth
diſplay with gaping greene.
Her driueling tongue is ſwolne, about
her lippes the Dragons beene.
Yet more, within her torne attyre,
her bloudie hand doth make
The trembling light of life in breaſt,
with mortall daſh to quake.

div.p:
Of this matter Luke hath ſet foorth to be ſeene a memoriall example, when he reporteth how thoſe Seditioners in Aſia behaued themſelues at the inſtigation of Demetrius the ſiluer-ſmith.An example o • ſedition. Acts 16.28.29. They were (ſaith he, Full of wrath, and the whole Citie was full of confuſion: and they ruſhed into the Common place, ſome cryed one thing, and ſome another: for the aſſembly was out of order, and the more part knew not wherefore they were come together. It is a verie dangerous thing to thruſt in ſuch vnneceſſarie and troubleſome opinions among the people, with whome (all wiſedome and counſell beeing ſhut out) theyr praue affections and furie beare all the ſway: and euerie one among them is haſtie to preferre the decree of his own mind, howſoeuer
it be, and no maruel, ſeeing that like as in one water there appeares diuers faces, euen ſo, diuerſe men haue diuerſe mindes, Prou. 27.19. as ſaith Salomon: of them therfore the Poet thus aduertiſeth: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That is, Truſt not the vulgar ſort: for they be diuerſly conceited.

Iſay. 9.18.3 The Prophet Iſayah likeneth Sedition to a fire among bryers and thornes: for euen as fire firſt taketh in drie and light matter, and afterward beeing enkindled,The fruits and effects of Sedition. entreth further & further vntill it burne and conſume the talleſt trees in the wood, and the ſmoke of the burning obſcureth the whole countrey. So, Sedition riſing of light matters, doth in the end conſume great peace, trouble many men, and bring endleſſe annoyes. Neither is the ſame vnaptly likened vnto that freating Canker whereof Saint Paul ſpeaketh, Hoſ. 10.14. 2. Tim. 2.17. which had too deepely annoyed Himeneus and Philetus. Moreouer, the Prophet Hoſeah ſheweth the effects of this Canker and conſuming fire, when hee ſayth: There ſhall grow a Sedition among the people. All her ſtrong Citties ſhall be layde waſte, euen as Salma deſtroyed Bethardel in the day of battayle, VVhat is ſedition? where the Mother with the Children were daſhed in peeces. Therefore Sedition is defined not onely a tumult, a diſſention of Citizens, a moouing vp of the people againſt the Magiſtrates of a deſire to change & ouerthrow the gouernment eſtabliſhed,Schaah. Schaon. or the lawes, but alſo (according to the ſignificatiō of the Hebrew word) A waſting, a deſolation, a calamitie, a ruine, a deſtruction, a caſting down headlong of any thing, eſpecially of families, Cities, ſtates, and kingdomes: for as concord and agreement is the ſtrength & maintenance
of all families, cities, ſtates and kingdomes, ſo doth ſtrife and ſedition, diſpatch & ouerthrow the ſame. The Prophet Iſayah vſeth that word, where he ſaith: Iſa. 6.11. Reade alſo 2. Chro. 15.5.6 Vntill the Cities bee waſted without an inhabitant, and the houſes without men, and the land be vtterly deſolate: and the Lord hath remoued men away, and there be a great deſolation in the middeſt of the land.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . To this conſent the Greekes, which call Sedition not onely 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . that is: inteſtine and ciuill warre: but alſo 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is Engliſhed, a cutting off, a diuiding in ſunder, a tearing abroad, a diuorcing, a chāging of a thing into that which degenerateth from kind: a diſſipation,Cicero. li. 1. de fin. & 3. Tuſc. Auguſt. de abuſ. ſaeculi. F. Petra. de bello ciuili. Puniſhment of ſuch. Com. ſuper decret: Cardin. d. 45. c. Seditionarii. an vndoing and diſſolution of a thing. All which are indeed the very fruits and effects of Sedition, which therfore is accounted a moſt peſtilēt thing amongſt men, a contention moſt miſerable, one of the abuſes of the world, and the greateſt of all humane euils.

4. In the due regarde thereof, thoſe of priſtine time haue decreed no mean puniſhments for Seditionaries. There was an ancient law, that ſuch ſhuld be either hanged on forks or gibbets, or caſt to wild beaſts to be deuoured, or baniſhed into farre countreys.Plutarch. Plutarch telleth of a kind of tithing of the ſouldiers, in an hoaſt which were ſeditious, that was,Neſtor. where euery tenth man was taken out from the reſt and put to death. And that ancient Neſtor, which had liued a mans double age, and had had a ripe experience of theſe matters, cenſured ſuch a perſon in this ſort:
A wretched Exile, godleſſe wight, and runnagate be he:Homer. Iliad. 9.
That by ſedition, ciuill broyles, and warres procures to be.

So hatefull haue theſe thriftleſſe perſons beene
after the iudgement of meere Heathen men, who by reaſon & common experience haue noted them to bee moſt vnprofitable to all Common-wealths, and that their practiſes did much annoy them at home, when bloudy warres abroade were not felt at al, nor ſcarce thought on. No leſſe execrable haue they beene eſteemed by them that knewe God by the light of his word. Prou. 6.16.19. Salomon placeth him that ſoweth Sedition among brethren or neighbours in the higheſt grade of thoſe ſeauē things which the Lord deadly hateth: yea, this is that (ſaith he) which his verie ſoule abhorreth. Neither is any place more fit for him that ſoweth ſedition betweene brethren or neighbors, then the Synagogue of Satan, for why? he is the child of the diuell, & not the child of God. For Chriſt ſaith, that Peacemakers ſhall be called the children of God: as they are indeed, and not the breakers and diſturbers of peace. And if they be the children of God, then muſt he which ſeeketh euill bee of the diuel. For he is againſt God which is not with God: and who are againſt God? euen the diuell and his children. But let vs heare the cenſure of Salomon, touching the puniſhment of ſuch an one, he ſaith: A cruell meſſenger ſhall be ſent againſt him. Meaning indeede, that the Lord vſeth many meanes to puniſh ſuch kind of people. Prou. 24.22. He ſaith againe: The deſtruction of them that be ſeditious, ſhal riſe ſodainely, and who knoweth the ruine of them both: that is, who can tell what kind of deſtruction ſhalbe inflicted vpon ſuch perſons, either by the Lord, or by the King, or by them both, againſt whom they haue tranſgreſſed by their wicked practiſes: for is is certaine, that whoſoeuer it be, they ſhall not eſcape puniſhment, and that no
meane puniſhment. As in the fearefull deſtruction of Corah, Dathan, and Abiram, it is before declared. Moreouer, Act. 5.36. the learned Doctour Gamaliel) as we read in the Acts of the Apoſtles) citeth two notable examples, the one of Theudas, the other of Iudas Gallilaeus, two famous Seditionaries, Act. 5.36. which were both rewarded according to their deſerts, by the iuſt iudgement of God,Theudas and Iudas. and the miniſterie of his lawful ordinance. This Theudas beeing a witch, promiſed many things: hee gat vnto him no ſmall rout of Spendthrifts, banckrupts, murtherers, theeues,Ioſeph: Antiqui. li. 20.4. and vngodly perſons, which oppoſed thēſelues againſt Lawes, magiſtrates, and all good men. But this fellow the Lord diſcomfited and deſtroyed by the hand of Fadus the gouernour of Iudaea, Idem. ca. 5. Item. li. 18. ca. 1. and they al which agreed vnto him were ſcattered abroade. That Iudas Galilaeus, (which was otherwiſe called Gaulonites) had taken vnto him one Saducus a Phariſee, and raiſed alſo great ſedition among the Iewes: he denied that tribute was due to the Emperour, which hee ſaid was nothing elſe but a perpetuall ſlauery of the Iewes. For this cauſe Cyrennius and Copinius comming from Rome into Syria, ſlew Iudas, puniſhed his confederates, and taxed the people,Luke 2.1. as Saint Luke reporteth it.
