5 Theſe bee notable examples to teach vs,VVe muſt not moue ſeditions vnder colour of reformation. that neither vnder the colour of Religion, diſlike of magiſtrates, and lawes, nor of any deſire of reformation of things amiſſe, wee contriue or moue vp any factions, ſects, diuiſions, ſchiſmes, ſeditions, wherby wee would reuolt from obedience to that power which God hath ſet ouer vs, and vnto the which he would that wee ſhould be ſubiect in feare. For
God himſelfe is the reuenger of ſuch practiſes, and heapeth on ſuch perſons woorthie deſtruction, as vppon them that endeuour to ouerthow all good order, and deſtroy Citties, Kingdomes, people, and places, which without vnitie and concord cannot ſtand nor continue, as Chriſt himſelfe witneſſeth.

Cauſes to feare inuaſions.There is nothing (next to the diſpleaſure of God conceiued for ſinnes) cauſeth me to feare ſo much the inuaſion of the forraigne enemie vpon our land, then this diuerſitie of mindes and mutuall diſſention. Neither is any thing more to be dreaded. Such an occaſion had the Infidelles gotten againſt the Romaine Empire, when the Arrians ſo troubled the Church with ſects & ſchiſmes in the time of the Emperours Conſtans and Conſtantius, to the greefe of that good father Athanaſius. The like opportunitie had Iulius Caeſar to inuade this realme, when ye Troynouants enuying the ſtate of Caſſibelan the king of London, as domeſticall traytors, opened a gap to the ruine of the Realme. And whatſoeuer haſtened the ouerthrow of that famous Hieruſalē, in to whoſe gates the kings of the earth, & al the inhabiters of the world would not haue beleeued, Veſpaſ. & Titus hoſ. 10.14. Lam. 4.11
that the aduerſary and enemy ſhuld haue entred? Such fruits hath ſedition, which permitteth neither quietneſſe in mens minds, nor peace in their houſes, nor ſafety within the ſtrongeſt wals of their Cities, Hoſ. 10.14. nor any long proſperity, peace, and continuance of kingdomes.

6. Of this inconuenience feared the high prieſts & Phariſees, when they heard that Chriſt in his doctrine had ſaid, Mat. 10.34.35. Luke. 12.51. That he was come not to ſend peace on the earth, but a ſword, and to ſet variance betwixt the father and the ſon, the mother and the daughter, and to cauſe enmitie
betweene them of one houſe. And therupon he was falſely accuſed to them, that hee was a moouer of the people, and a perſon ſeditious: they thereon reſolued and concluded againſt him: If wee lette him eſcape thus, all men will beleeue in him, the Romanes will come,
Ioh. 11.48. and take both our rowme and the people. I produce not this example as though I allowed of their reſolution, touching the doctrine and dealings of Chriſt, (for they beeing carnally minded, and of a corrupt iudgement concerning the things of god, miſtooke him, wreſted his words, & cōſtrained al things peruerſly againſt him, & therfore they could not auoid the determinate inuaſion & their deſtruction in the time of their viſitation, notwithſtanding yt they killed him: but rather, beeing themſelues ſeditious indeed, & breakers of the true peace, they drew worthy vengeance on their owne heads.) Onely by the true vnderſtanding of this place, I would preuent them, that are ready to take from thence an obiection. But in very deed, if Chriſt had not bin the fal and riſing again of many in Iſrael, How Chriſt came to ſende a ſword, yet he was not ſeditious. the ſigne that ſhuld be ſpoken againſt, & that only Meſſiah & ſauior which reſtored man to that true peace & loue of god, from the which theſe degenerated Iewes, were ſo farre eſtranged through their owne malice: but had bin a troubler of the common tranquilitie, & a ſeditious perſon (as they falſely iudged of him) thē their reſolution & ſentence had ſauoured of wiſdom & good policie (ſeeing that ciuil controuerſies, motions, & ſeditiōs, drew on ſo many noiſom incōueniēces) but they knew not what was ye right end of Chriſt his cōming into the world. Neither knew they the time of their viſitation either in grace and mercies, or in wrath
and iudgements: and that which pertained to their peace. indeed was hidden from their eyes. And as for that moſt excellent propheſie of Iſayah touching Chriſt and his office (ca. 11, Luke 19.42. Iſay 11.2.3.4.5.) they neuer rightly vnderſtood the ſame, being ſo cruelly minded.

The ende of Chriſts comming.7 Chriſt came not to prouoke the Subiects againſt their lawfull Princes, as Chorah did: nor to moue the Commons againſt the Magiſtrates and lawes, as Theudas did: nor to ſow diſcord among the children of God. Hee was no ſeditionarie. The Cryer in the wilderneſſe would not ſo much as contrarie his owne voyce: the King would not ſo oppoſe himſelfe to his Embaſſadour, who (as Malachie propheſied,Mal. 4.5. Luke 1.16.
Turned the hearts of the fathers to the children, and the diſobedient to the wiſedome of the iuſt men. Chriſt came to call ſinners to repentance: to ſaue them that were loſt: to bring peace: to preach peace to his people: to recouer that which was taken away: to redeeme them whom the diuel had captiued: to gather together in one thoſe which were ſcattered abroad, & ſo to preſerue thē: contrarie to the nature of ſedition, which diuideth, diſſipateth, & deſtroyeth.Iſay 11.4. Now againſt this the diuel (being the prince of the maligne world, with high bluſtering windes rageth the world (beeing by him moued) with many ſwelling waues ſtirreth, and the fleſh (which he alſo ſuggeſteth) with many a luſtfull attempt, is diſordred. And ſo euerie of theſe enemies make no ſmall adoe, to retaine and hold faſt thoſe in the bondage of ſinne, death, and damnation, whom Chriſt came to ſet at libertie, and to reconcile to God.

The Chriſtian warfare is Spirituall.Againſt thoſe peſtilent enemies of mans ſoule, Chriſt encourageth them that be deliuered to ſtand
faſt, beeing furniſhed with all the Armour of God, in regard of whoſe ſeruice and glorie, they muſt be wel contented to forſake father, mother, wife, children, brethren, ſiſters, and all that they haue, yea, they muſt cut off their right handes, put out their right eyes, which are offenſiue to them, or that hinder them in this ſeruice, and take vp their croſſe and follow Chriſt their Captaine. Neither could this diuine office of our Sauior be otherwiſe performed but by binding of that ſtrong man which poſſeſſed the houſe, by treading on the ſerpents head,There is no concord betweene good and euill. and by caſting out the Prince of this world frō his vſurped hold: and that the people of god being ſo recouered by his might & mercy, and gathered togither by his word, might be ſeparated and kept apart from the power of darknes, betweene the which & the kingdom of Chriſt there hath bin, there is, and there ſhal be continuall warres, and enimities, as naturally between the woman and the ſerpent: her ſeed, and his ſeed: betweene light and darknes, Chriſt and Belial. This is that ſpirituall warfare, ſo much ſpoken of by the holy Ghoſt in the Reuelations of S. Iohn. This is the ſword which Chriſt ſendeth on the earth.

8 Howbeit our Sauiour both cōmandeth,The doctrine of Chriſt teacheth loue. and by his own example cōmendeth vnto his apoſtles and diſciples, patiēce peace, cōcord, loue, as the recognizance of his ſeruants, ſaying: By this ſhal al men know that ye are my diſciples, if ye loue togither as I haue loued you. And he yeldeth another reaſon therof in this, that he calleth them ſometimes his freends, and his brethren. True loue & peace apperteineth to true friendſhip, and it is both good and comfortable for brethren to dwel togither in vnity: but diſcord, cōtentions, wars among ſuch ſeeme moſt monſtrous, vnnaturall and
hatefull, as not onely the worde of God, but alſo the verie heathens teach. By argumēt, Abraham perſwaded his brother or coſin Loth, to concord & peace. VVe be brethren (ſaid he) let there be no controuerſie betweene thee and me, thine and mine. The ſame argumēt vſed Moſes to the two Iſraelites that cōtended, Ye be brethren, why contend ye ſo? And Ioſeph hauing dimiſſed his brethren from Pharaos court towards their own country, Gen. 45.24. charged thē, not to fall at variance on the way.

Rom. 15.5.6.Moreouer, Paul writing to the Romanes, willeth them (as friends and brethren) to be like minded after the example of Chriſt Ieſus, that they all agreeing togither, might with with one mouth praiſe God. And he aduiſeth them, that If it be poſsible, they liue quietly with all men. Alſo he counſelleth the Philippians, whō he calleth brethren,
Phil. 2.3. to be all of one mind, hauing the ſame loue, being of one accord, and of one iudgement, that nothing bee done thorugh cōtention, or vain-glory. S. Iohn hath ſaid much of this argumēt. And the wiſe man aduiſeth wiſely: My ſonne feare the Lord, and the king, and meddle not with them that be ſeditious.
Prou. 24.21. Such is the doctrine of Chriſt.

F. Petrar. de bello ciuili. dial. 7.4. 9 Let vs hearken vnto theſe words of the wiſe, and beware that we be not partakers with them, which either by miniſtring of matter, or by blowing of the coles, maintaine ciuil diſſentions & diſcords amōg brethren, neighbors, chriſtians: for many men vnaduiſedly do perpetrate & commit that, wherof them ſelues do complaine, but all too late, and do bewaile that woūd (as pearced by others) which they them ſelues haue made with their own hands. Many men haue bin burned in the flames of their own fiers. Let vs therfore caſt away this kind of diuerſitie, & once begin to will one thing: then ſhall the peace of the mind be both ſound and vnmoueable, and we ſhall
agree and liue in peace. Otherwiſe as cōtrary & corrupt humors in gender the feuer of body, ſo cōtrarie affections breed the feuer of the mind, which is ſo much the more perilous then yt of the body,Vices ſtriue one with another: but vertues are knit togither in concord. by how much the mind is in all nobleneſſe preferred to the body, & eternal death more terrible then the temporall death. We ſee how vices ſtriue one with another: but vertues are euer knit in concord togither. Let vs therefore through loue embrace vertue, and not commit our ſelues through diſcord as thrales to vnthrifty vices. Let vs not go about to rent in peeces the ſeamleſſe coat of chriſt, but endeuor to eſchue al diſdaine, grudge, murmure, enuy, contentions, ſeditions, & embrace that loue which Chriſt cōmādeth to his diſciples, and which his holy Apoſtles, Peter, Paul, Iames, & Iohn, haue with ſo many praiſes commended to the whole church of Chriſt.The commendation of loue For this is that right and chriſtian vertue, which properly noriſheth concord, keepeth things cōpounded,Greg. hom. 11 conioyneth thē that be diuided, as ſaith Gregory. This is that which (as ſaith Caſſiodore) is ye death of offences, the ſtrength of thē that conētd, the victory ouer vices,Caſſiod. ſuper Pſal. the cōcord of minds, the ſociety of the elect: which faith conceiueth, where vnto hope runneth, and the fruit of al good things ſerueth. To be ſhort, this vertue (ſaith Augu.) is the root of all good. Super Iohn. Therfore when Chriſt had preached that in the loue of God & our neighbor, was contained the whole law & the prophets: a certaine Scribe replied and ſaid: VVell maſter, thou haſt anſwered right, for there is one God, and there is none other but he: & to loue him with al the hart,
Mat. 22.40. Mark. 12.33. & with al the vnderſtanding, and with all the ſoule, and with al the ſtrength, and to loue a mans neighbor as himſelfe, is greater then all the burnt offerings, and ſacrifices.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII.
Stop not one inconuenience with another, be thankfull to God, and preuent miſchiefes timely.
div.p: It is no good policie to moue vp matters, and ſeeke to ſtop them with vaine wordes. AS it is no point of wiſedome for men to fling fire into drie Flaxe, and then to aſſay to quench it with greaſie Oyle: ſo neither is it anie policie to mooue vp matters vnneceſſarie among the people, and then to aſſay to allay and pacifie them with ambages and vaine verboſitie, in the inconſtancie of fleſhly conceites, and wandring luſts. For this is euen as if wee ſhould thinke to ſtop one inconuenience with another. Where offēces be taken and not giuen,How to withſtand offences and their effects. VVo vnto them that take them: but if offences be offred, VVo vnto them that offer them. If the vnthriftie effects of offences muſt be preuented (as they ſhould indeede, and the offences alſo) yet in all good reaſon and learned iudgement, muſt this be done orderlie, by ſuch wayes and meanes as the word of God, and good conſcience and reaſon ſhal direct.

The cōdition of our time ſhould moue vs to thankfulnes to God and feare.And ſurely if we well weigh the nature and condition of this age and time, wee cannot but graunt, how needfull it is that fierce firie flames ſhould bee quenched, by the fountaine of Gods ſpirit, and the miniſterie of the lawfull ordinaunce: and that men ſhuld yet at ye leaſt be moued to expreſſe (with hand and heart, with mind and mouth) ſome good tokens of vnfaigned loue, and right gratefulneſſe vnto
God our heauenly father, for ſo manie his bounties and noble bleſsings beſtowed on them, vnder the moſt happie gouernment of our moſt Chriſtian ſoueraigne Princeſſe, Queene ELIZABETH. It is muſt meete, that we ſhould heare the worde of God, and beleeue in Chriſt Ieſu, that we ſhuld feare God, & honor our Prince: that we ſhould loue one another, as brethren, and help one another as neighbors and friends: that we ſhould abandon all occaſions of wicked cōtentions and diſcords: and that we ſhould liue in godly peace & Chriſtian cōtentation one with another, within the bounds of our lawfull vocations and callings, eſpecially in this time.

2 To and for this ende and purpoſe,VVhy God hath beſtowed on vs ſo many bleſsings. the Lord of all mercies hath vouchſaued vs his holie worde, to lighten and direct vs, wherein hee hath diſcloſed vnto vs the hidden myſteries of his will, hee hath graunted vs the daylie vſe of his inſtituted Sacraments, wherby our ſoules ſhould be ſatisfied to our good euery way. Then the which, what treaſure is there of greater price & eſtimation? By this we may be well aſſured of the loue and fauour of God to vs ward, as to his deare childrē, to whom he hath prouided that bread of life, which he would not ſhould be caſt vnto dogs, and hath cōmitted thoſe precious pearles, which he vouchſafeth not to giue to ſwine, vnto theſe heauenly and ineſtimable legaſies, hee hath added many tēporal bleſsings in this our time, as peace, health, wealth, and proſperity, with free libertie to ſit at home vnder our vines and fig trees,God hath bleſſed vs aboue other nations. when other nations haue bin grieuouſly toſſed and troubled with wars & vexations, euen to the loathſomnes of their liues: oh how many kings, prophets
and righteous men,God hath bleſſed vs aboue other nations. haue in their times deſired to ſee ſuch ioifull daies wherein they might haue embraced theſe and ſuch like bleſsings and commodities, and yet could neuer ſee them? Neither hath the lord dealt with euery other nation in that meaſure of his mercies, as he hath dealt with vs. God graunt that through our vncharitable cōtentions, and vnthankfulneſſe, his holy ſpirit be not moued to complaine of vs, as he did ſomtimes of the ingrateful Iſraelites, that He had riſen vp early,
Eſay 65.12. and in mercy ſtretched forth his holy hand to an vnthankfull people, ſuch as were euer rebelling and running away from him.

This is the deſire of the godly.3 But, would to God, that in this our time wee could content our ſelues in charitie with theſe his great bleſsings, and be right thankful for the ſame in our hearts: that we would not loath, contemne and diſdaine ſuch his precious iewels and ineſtimable treaſures exhibited vnto vs, but in all obedience run to the liuely waters,Iſay. 55. as ſuch as be thirſtie, and come to buy wine and milk of the Lord with them that in holy loue do hunger & thirſt after righteouſnes, thē ſhall we eate of the beſt, our ſoules ſhall haue pleaſure in plenteouſneſſe, and be bleſſed for euermore.

The way how to defend our ſelues againſt our enemies.This is the way for vs to ouercome the diuel and all his aſſaults: by this bulwark and rock of defence, ſhal we be wel able to withſtand the popiſh power, and inuaſions of forraigne enemies, contriued, entended and threatned agaynſt the Church of Chriſt in this Realme, agaynſt the Lords annoynted our ſoueraigne Princeſſle, and agaynſt the whole lande. This is the beſt courſe that can bee taken by vs againſt the beaſtly wilde Bore, to force him from our Gardens, and to driue away thoſe noyſome Foxes
from our Vineyards.Cant. 2.15. And this is the baniſhment of that wicked zeale, ſchiſme,Lib. 3. de vit. contempt. ſedition and vnchriſtian diſſention, the which are (as once Proſper ſaid) the greateſt plagues to the minde that can be.

4 But ambition is a diuelliſh ſickneſſe,
Ambition forceth men to break forth aboue meaſure.
Eraſ. in epiſt. ad Adrian. pap. ſuper Arnob. Pſal. 58. and a pernitious ſpirit (as Eraſmus writeth) with the which whoſoeuer be poſſeſſed, haue both deafe cares and giddy heads: they wil neither giue heed to the good counſell of the wiſe: nor abide within the limits of their owne places, nor will they be pleaſed that any man ſhould endeuour to diſſwade them from dealing in the affairs of other men. But they muſt needs bend to purſue that which they haue diſliked with ſterne faces, and to compaſſe and effect that which they haue conceited in mind, and affected with eager deſires: yea, & that far beyond that they are able to reach vnto, whiles aſpiring in vaine,Some make a ſhew of good when they do euill. they onely commend & glorifie themſelues, and aſſay to tread all other men vnder their feet. But yet this (notwithſtanding) they ſhame not to blaze their good purpoſes, and godly intents. Such a kinde of dealing was taken for an high diſgrace in that noble and eloquent Athenian Pericles, Perecles, Pileus. who in this reſpect was compared to one Pileus, who had woūded his moſt deer friend with his dart, when he thought to haue pearced a wilde beaſt. But I know (as alſo it will bee graunted in all Chriſtian reſolution) that though Pompey emulate the renow me of Iulius Caeſar, Pompey. Anthon. and Anthonie deſireth that Auguſtus were depoſed, ſo that himſelfe might rule alone: yet after the rule of the lawe of God, and the doctrine of Chriſt, ſuch deuiſes and practiſes ſhoulde bee farre off from Chriſtians. Neither may wee bee deceiued,
if we perſwade, that by ſuch means, we may pretēd to weaken our forraigne enemies, but we ſhall endamage our owne Citizens: we may determine to hurt foes, but wee ſhall annoy our friends: and wee may deſire to pearce others, but wee ſhall wound our ſelues to the heart. Howbeeit, when ſuch tragedies bee in action, men endeuour to ſhift off the cauſes of all hard happes from themſelues on others (ſo well conceited are they of their owne integritie,The effects cannot ceaſe, vntill the cauſes be taken away. and ſuch is their hard cenſure of other men) in the meane whiles, they endeuour not to ceaſſe the effects by remouing the cauſes. They are much like vnto the deformed perſon, which accuſed the Glaſſe wherein he gazed, and neuer acknowledged his owne defect, nor deformed himſelfe; but brake the Glaſſe in peeces: and they alſo reſemble that foole, which ſtanding crooked in the Sunne, would not lift himſelf vp from the earth, nor conſider from whence that kind of ſhadow came, but accuſed the Sunne as the cauſe thereof. On that the faults could once be acknowledged and confeſſed, that the cauſes of griefes being found out, the cure and amendment therof might ſoone enſue.

5 But, alas, this alſo is not the leaft hinderance (if it bee not one of the greateſt) to true concord and Chriſtian reconciliation;Hinderances to peace. Gen 3.16. and 25.22. Luke. 2.35. that prophane Eſais is encloſed in the wombe togither with holie Iaacob, wherby Heuah findeth her conception to be greatlie encreaſed, her ſorrowes augmented, Rebekah good woman groaneth with a double trauaile, and the ſword pierceth the heart of Mary. Hence diſtill a thouſand drops of bitter wormwood, & many deep drams of viperous poyſon, Heb. 13.15. as from bitter rootes,
which thoſe, vnquiet heades of either ſort ſo vnſtable as the water, ſo inconſtant as the cloudes, ſo ſubtile as the Serpents, and ſo wilie as the Foxes, haue quaffed forth (though in golden cuppes) to all faculties and degrees, to the great trouble of the Church, and to the decay of the Common-wealth: and (howſoever the Daughters of Hieruſalem can digeſt it) they be no leſſe noyſome and perilous indeede, then rotten and corrupt members to founde bodies: and as a little leauen ſowreth the whole lumpe, and as a little corruption mixed with the ſoundneſſe of the holy doctrine and true Religion: ſo alſo one roote of bitterneſſe, and on ſuch peſtilent perſons that ſpreadeth and maintaineth the errours of the ſame, doth very much moue and trouble the Church, and daily diſquiet the family of Chriſtians, whereof the greefe is ſoone felt in the whole, and too late lamented there, where conuenient medicines are not timely prepared and wiſely applyed to ſtoppe imminent inconueniences. The malady is neere deſperate, and extreme ſickneſſe require the like ſaluès: but wheras the maladyes be incurable, this counſaile of the Poet (beeing ſo like to that ſentence of Chriſt, Marke 9.24. And to the requeſt of Sarah, touching the caſting out of Iſmael the mocker, Gen. 21.9. And to that aduiſe of Salomō, Cant. 2.5. And to that deſire of Paul in ſuch a caſe, Gal. 5.12.) may not be reiected.

q.l: Morbida facta pecus tolum corrumpit ouile:
Ne maculet reliquos, eſt ſeperanda grege.

div.p: Thus Engliſhed.

q.l: One taignted Sheepe among the flocke,
infecteth all the reſt:
Take hence that ſheepe from of the flocke,
and that's the medicine beſt.

div.p: The magiſtrate, the miniſter, the houſholder. Eccl. 11.1.6 Of theſe matters, the magiſtrate in his place, the Paſtour in his charge, and euerie man and woman in his and her houſe, ought to take due regarde in the feare of God. Neither ſhould any Chriſtian doubt to caſt forth his bread as on the face of the fleeting waters, as Salomon ſaide: And that which they cannot accompliſh or performe (when they haue done their beſt to their power) they muſt cō mit vnto that high God Iehovah, which with his power made the earth, and with his wiſedome prepared the rounde world, and with his diſcretion ſpread out the heauens, which onely is wiſe; and eſteemeth all men (as they are in compariſon with him) fooles: and then without al doubt, he will not denie to take vpon himſelfe this thing to redreſſse.

1. Sam. 25.37 38. The iudgements of God ouertake the rebellious in their time 2. Sam. 16.10 1. King. 2.46.Then Abigail may entreate for Nabal; and Dauid may be perſwaded to ſpare him: but yet Nabals heart is dead within him as a ſtone, the Lord ſtriketh him for his wickedneſſe, and he dyeth with ſhame. So Dauid may reſtraine Abiſhai from the killing of curſing Shimei, for a time: but yet, the Lord which feeth all, and taketh vengeance in a duetime, cauſeth Benaiah (at the commaundement of Salomon) to ſmite Shimei, that he dyeth, and the kingdome is eſtabliſhed in the hand of Salomon.

7 This thing when the godly do behold, they are the rather moued thereby to feare God, and to ſay of thoſe rebellious people nowe ſubdued:
Beholde the men that tooke not God for theyr ſtrength: but truſted in the multitude of theyr Riches, and putte their ſtrength in their malice! Pſal. 127. And theſe vngodly themſelues (ſeeing howe vainely they haue riſen vppe earely, how much labour they haue loſt about their owne buſie toyle, and now into what miſerie theyr owne wiſedome, theyr great vanities, their inconſtant deuices, their ſingular conceits, Ier. 23.32. and carnall cunning hath caſt them) they ſhall accuſe themſelues of folly, with him that ſaide: Iſa. 29.15. & 47.10.
Ingenio perii Naſo Poetameo.Ouidius proſpero.
Ingenio experior funera digna meo.
Lo, thus (álas) haue I now tane,
through mine owne wiſedome, mine owne banel

8 Therefore, let not Cham chop in twixt Shem and Iaphet to diuide them,A caueat for rebellious and vnthankfull perſons. for God in time will ioyne them againe, and wring out Cham from his vſurped holde. Lette not Achitophel counſaile abſalom againſt his Father Dauid, contrarie to all equitie and good conſcience: for God wil cauſe Chuſai to turne his Aduiſe into fooliſhneſſe, and Achitophel ſhall be forced to hang himſelfe for his labor. Ioſ. 7.28. Neither let Achan trouble Ioſuah and his hoaſt by his cloſe iugling any longer: for God will trie him out well inough, and trouble him with a iuſt meaſure.

In concluſion, as when an hungrie man dreameth that he is eating, & when he awaketh, Iſa. 29.9. his ſoule is empty: or as when a thirſtie man dreameth that he is drinking, and when hee awaketh he is yet faint, and his ſoule hath appetite: euen ſo ſhall the
multitude of all nations bee, that fighteth againſt Mount Sion. Iudg. 5.31. So let all the Enemies of the Lord, of his Church, and of his holy annoynted, periſh and bee confounded: but let them that loue him, that pray for the peace of Ieruſalem, and that liue in godly obedience, be as the Sun that riſeth in his might: that yet the land may haue reſt, and the fruition of the right peace, full fortie yeeres.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Happie bee they that proteſt well, and walke accordingly. There be three kinds of Proteſtants.
div.p:
NOw, how commendable a thing is it, and of al men to be deſired, that thoſe onely which haue taken on them to walke in the kings high way, and to fight vnder the banner of their Captaine Christ by their Proteſtations, could both containe themſelues therein, and alſo to content themſelues, as they would not ſtarte aſide, either to the right hand or to the left hand, from that feare of God and true obſeruation of his lawes, which of them in dutie is required? Surely, the light is a moſt pleaſant thing (as ſaith Salomon) and theſe men,Eccleſ. 11.7. being in their choyſe, ſo wiſe as Mary was (who ſate at the feete of Chriſt and heard his word) and ſo diligent in doing the works of their vocation, as Martha was (who with carefulneſſe prouided for Chriſt and his Apoſtles) doo with a ſweete harmonie of hearts, and right concord of mindes, comfort the
Church, benefit the Common-wealth, and glorifie the Lord in their liues.

And the godly wiſe, which behold them ſo walking and pleaſing God with them, ſeeing that wiſedome is iuſtified of her children, doo moſt ioyfully apply vnto them, & with them, to themſelues, that ſweete conſolation of the Chriſtian Philoſopher.

lg.l: O faelix hominum genus:Boeth. de conſol. philo. li. 2. Met. 8.
Oh happie kinde of men are yee, whiles Gods good loue,
So rules your hearts, as heauen high he rules aboue!

div.p:
And thus ſaith our Lord: Bleſſed are they that hunger and thirſt after righteouſneſſe:
Mat. 5.6.7.14. Bleſſed is hee that heareth the worde of God, and keepeth it: for he is that wiſe man which buildeth vppon the Rocke. Therefore, when the Pſalmiſt in the conſideration thereof, had aſcribed them bleſſed which are vndefiled in the way, and walked in the law of the Lord, he vttered this deſire of his heart vnto the Lord: Oh that my wayes were made ſo direct, that I might keepe thy Statutes. So ſhall I not be confounded,
Pſal. 11.9. while I haue reſpect vnto thy commandements.

2 But, there be of them that profeſſe and proteſt with vs too,Euery talker is not a walker in the way of the Lord. which yeeld vnto the Lord and his holy annointed, many ſharpe and eager grapes, whiles (hauing their eyes euill becauſe God is good) they verifie that ſaying of the ſame Philoſophers Nemo facile cum fortunatae ſuae conditione concordat: that they can hardly holde themſelues pleaſed with their
owne eſtate of life. Therefore abuſing the bleſſings preſently offered them, they do with the craftie Gebeonites endeuour to dazle the cleere eyes of Ioſuah,
Ioſ. 9.4 9. with a miſticall vale, whiles by their Cananitiſh conueyances, hydious hypocriſies, and mindes inſaciate, they climbe to pleaſe their haughtie hearts and ambitious heads. Howbeit, they cannot chooſe but bewray their own folly, for ye light wil appeare.

This faigning of fealtie, and making ſhew of obedience,To make a ſhew of good, and to do euill, is an olde leſſon taught by the diuell. Gen. 3.1. when there is nothing leſſe meant then that indeed, is an old leſſon that Satan taught long ago, when in the perſon of a ſerpent he beguiled Heuah, and aſſayeth the ſame yet daily among men, reſembling in ſhape, an angel of light. But good hope aſſureth the godly well-wiſhers, that the ſeer of al ſecrets, & gide of all gouernors will from time to time diſcouer both the one and the other, by pulling off the vizards frō diſſemblers faces, as in times paſt he hath done to many of them, that ſometimes ſate in the higheſt mountaine in the view of terrene kingdomes, and ſemblable renowne, whom after theyr moſt daſtardly yeeldings to Satans aſſaults) he hath deciphered to their ignomie and perpetuall ſhame. For his holy wil and decree is, that Haggar the bondwoman, and Iſmael her ſonne, ſhal both be caſt out of Abrahams houſe, that Iſaak the ſonne of Sarah may be & remain the only right heyre. But to paſſe ouer many ſuch ambagious circumſtances (without ſhame or offence to the true Chriſtian be it ſpoken) among too many of them that paſſe vnder the title Proteſtants in this time, Vileſcunt quotidiana. The word of God which is daily preached is loathſome vnto them. The miniſters of the Goſpel liue in contempt:
The truth is not eſteemed: the preſent peace is vnpleaſant: The quiet gouernment is diſliked: Righteouſnes is not entertained: holiness hideth her face: faith is famiſhed: hope is quayled: charitie is cleane put out: men be ingratefull for all the good things enioyed: they be diſcontented, & groane for that whereof they know not the experience, in the diſdaine of yt which they haue liberty to vſe to their profit. And in a word, they declare thēſelues to be without ye true zeale & the fear of god, which at no time wil neglect the obſeruance of his commandements. Vnto ſuch ſaith Bernarde: Qui vobis cum virtutibus, qui Dei virtutē Chriſtam ignoratis?In Cant. ſer. 22. VVhat right haue ye in vertues, which are ignorāt in Chriſt the vertue of God? yea, vnto them ſaith God himſelf: Pſa. 50.16.17 VVhat haſt thou to do, to declare mine ordinance: that thou ſhouldeſt take my couenant in thy mouth: ſeeing thou hateſt to be reformed, and haſt caſt my words behinde thee.

3 But of Proteſtants we may diſtinguiſh, for of them there be three ſorts: that is to ſay:Three ſorts of Proteſtants. 1. A ſingle proteſtant. 1. A ſingle Proteſtant. 2. a Chriſtian proteſtant. 3. a formal proteſtant. The ſingle proteſtāt anſwereth to his title in this, that hee maketh declaration of his mind in any matter whatſoeuer, for ye better conſeruation of the right, & notwithſtāding of the wrong, either generally in any ſort, or ſpecially before witneſſes: or in that that he manifeſtly denoūceth the thing wherof men are to take heed, & yt which ought to be done: or that hee proteſteth boldly the truth of a matter doubtfull or in queſtion. And this title is diriued from the latin Verb Proteſtor, to proteſt, or witneſſe openly. The name of Chriſtian proteſtant,2. A Chriſtian Proteſtant. was firſt vſed in Germany (as Sledan noteth) then when as the Princes Electours openly withſtood that vngodly
decree which Antichriſt made againſt the Goſpel of Ieſus Chriſt, in the yeere of our Lord 1529, vnto whoſe proteſtation certaine of the cheefe Cities of Germanie did alſo ſubſcribe. And he is aright chriſtian Proteſtant, who in the feare of God and honour of his Prince, doth witneſſe, ſubſcribe, and proteſt againſt the vngodly decrees, damnable doctrines, and filthie abhominations of Antichriſt. Hee is a good proteſtant, which acknowledgeth and confeſſeth the doctrine of Chriſt for his true wiſedome; the mercy of Chriſt for his true righteouſneſſe: the life of Chriſt for his true holyneſſe: and the death of Chriſt for his true fortitude. He is a true proteſtant, that taketh the truth in hande for his cauſe, dealing truely therein, and rendeth zealouſly to the peace of the Goſpel of Ieſus Chriſt. He is a true proteſtant, which is like that true Iſraelite, whoſe ſpeech agreeth with the truth, whoſe hand conſenteth with his heart, whoſe walking concorded with his talking, to the glorie of God. This is that ſheep which heareth the voyce of the true Paſtor; that little one which beleeueth in Chriſt; that wiſe virgin which wayteth for the bride, with a burning lampe in her hand; and that gratefull gueſt which commeth to the wedding with his marriage garment. This is that Chriſtian, which taketh vp the croſſe, his maiſters recognizance, and followeth the Lambe whereſoeuer he goeth. This is that ſouldier, which hauing taken on him 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,2. Tim. 2.3.4 Eph. 6. All the armour of God, wherewith hee is ſtrong in the Lord, and in the power of his might, ſtandeth and fighteth not againſt peaceable men, true dealing men, plaine and honeſt perſons, and the Chriſtian brethren: but againſt Rulers, againſt
powers, againſt worldly gouernours of the darkneſſe of this world, agaynſt ſpirituall wickedneſſe in the heauenly places: That is, agaynſt Antichriſt, and all his miniſters: againſt the diuell, and all his Angels. This is that proteſtant, which knowing that the ende of his Redemption is, To ſerue God in holineſſe and righteouſneſſe all the dayes of his life,
Luke. 1.75. though hee hath receiued a kingdome immoueable: doth endeuour himſelfe accordingly to ſerue God with reuerence and fear, Heb. 12. 1. Pet. 2.16. Rom. 8. and dayly expecteth the reuelation and glorious libertie of the ſonnes of God, with continual praier, and this heartie deſire: Oh come, good Lord Ieſu.

4 Such a Proteſtant was Nathanael, Nathanael was a good proteſtant Iohn 1.47. Apollos. Acts 18.24. whom Chriſt himſelfe commended for a true Iſraelite without guile. Such an one was Apollos, who aided them much that beleeued through grace; who mightily and that openly confuted the Iewes with great vehemencie, ſhewing by the Scriptures that Ieſus was Chriſt. Such a Proteſtant was Paul, Paul. Act. 20.18. which kept backe nothing that was profitable for the Church: but had ſhewed and taught them openlie, witneſsing to the Iewes, and alſo to the Greekes, the Repentance that is towards God, and the faith which is towardes our Lord Ieſus Christ. And from this his dutie (hauing ſet God before him) he was not mooued, neither accounted hee his life deare vnto himſelfe, ſo that hee might fulfill his courſe with ioy, and the miniſterie which hee had receyued of the Lorde Ieſu,Nichodemus. Iohn. 3.1. The blind man. Iohn 7.50. and 9.30. to Testifie the Goſpel of the Grace of God. Such a Proteſtant was Nichodemus, who did not onelie come to Chriſt, but alſo witneſſed the trueth, and defended his innocencie before the high Prieſts and Phariſees, without
feare: Such a Proteſtant was hee, which being borne blind, and reſtored to his ſight, both beleeued and worſhipped Chriſt, and teſtified, and mightily reaſoned for him againſt the malignitie of the ſpitefull Iewes:Stephen the Protomartyr. Act. 6. & 7. Chriſt the worthieſt Proteſtant. and ſuch a Proteſtant was Stephen, who, for his good proteſtations was woorthilie called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , That is, The firſt Martyr or witneſſe of Chriſt, which ſealed his teſtimonie with his blood. But aboue all other, Chriſt himſelfe was the worthieſt Proteſtant, who, as he in all things ſubſcribed to the will of his heauenlie Father, and made the beſt Confeſsion that euer was made, before Pontius Pilate, when hee teſtified, that He came into the worlde to beare witneſſe vnto the trueth, and that all they which are of the trueth do heare his voyce: So alſo hee ſealed and confirmed this Teſtimonie with his moſt precious and innocent blood, as neceſſarie it was for him to doo, ſeeing that the Lorde GOD required not Burnt Sacrifices, but a Bodie, which this Ieſus offered vp, according as hee had ſayde, I am readie to doo thy will, O God, as in the beginning of the Booke it is written of mee. And thencefoorth all they which beeing enflamed with an holie zeale, and in the feare of GOD haue confirmed their doctrine and teſtimonie of Ieſus by bearing of his recognizaunce (I meane the Croſſe of Chriſt) haue beene woorthilie entituled Martyrs. That is, VVitneſſes, Martyrs are Proteſtants. or (as I may ſay) Christian Protestants, of the Greeke Verbe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , To teſtifie, to witneſſe the trueth of the Goſpel, without feare or fainting, euen vnto the death. Theſe bee the true Martyrs, and true Proteſtants. Theſe haue their prayſe, I ſay, not with men, but with GOD, in
whoſe fight their blood is precious, and they bee in their death bleſſed.

5 The formall Protestants, 3. The formall Proteſtant. beeing of an other minde, are not conformed to this rule: For notwithſtanding they ſeeme to ſpeake in the language vſed in this time: yet loue they to liue after the manners of the corrupt olde time: but not according to theyr manners whome Fauorinus the Philoſopher woulde that men ſhoulde followe: howſoeuer they ſpeake and would be eſteemed. In this, they rightly reſemble them, who bowing their knees before Chriſt, ſayd, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Mat. 27.29. Haile King of the Iewes: but mocked him, and dreanched him with bitter vineger. For, notwithſtanding their proteſtations, they be (in verie deed) blaſphemers of Ieſus, and tormentors of his poore diſciples.2. Pet. 2.16. The libertie of the ſacred Goſpel they vſe for a cloake of maliciouſneſſe, and not as the ſeruants of Chriſt. They are therefore well like ſome of thoſe in Iudaea, but not like the right Iewes: for all thoſe in Iudaea were not the true Iewes: for had they beene true Iewes, Chriſt would not haue reproued them ſo ſharpely for their great hypocriſie, and likened them to painted Sepulchres. Neither would Saint Stephen haùe called them ſtif-necked, & of vncircumciſed hearts,Acts 2. & 7. Reu. 3. and ears: nor would St. Peter haue called them murtherers of the iuſt: nor would the holy ghoſt by the miniſterie of Iohn haue ſo vehemently reprooued them, and haue cenſured them of the Synagogue of Sathan. Such kinde of Proteſtants through their vnnaturall degeneration and Apoſtacye, are rightlie noted among thoſe Monſterse, which Nature ſo much abhorreth, beeing therefore not
vnaptly likened to the cankred Apoſtate Lueifer, Counterfait Proteſtants likened to Lucifer. altogither ſo contrarie to that light and beautie, which his name noteth. Thinke they, it is not true that the Spirit fayeth: I knowe thy workes! I see thy thoughts! And doo they imagine, that the ſearcher of the hearts and reynes, will not ſet in order before them all that they haue done? Bee not deceiued: God will not be mocked: but know for a ſuretie, that euerie man ſhall reape according to that which hee ſoweth. Haue a care therefore to ſowe good ſeedes, that yee may reape thereof good fruit.

6 To theſe kinde of Proteſtants is made applicatorie that Song of Bernarde, which is wholſome enough, howe harriſh ſo euer it ſoundeth, and includeth them within the rabble or number of monſters.In lib. de conſider. ad Eugen. Neither feared hee to write it to Pope Eugenius. Monstroſa res est, &c. It is a thing monſtrous (ſayeth hee) to haue a chiefe place, and a minde baſe: to bee highest in ſeate, and lowest in life: to haue a vaunting tongue, and idle handes: much talking, and little walking: to haue a countenaunce of grauitie, and workes of lenitie: to bee in great authoritie, and to bee ſubiect to a nodding inconstancie. As if Bernarde woulde haue ſayd in a woorde: To make a great ſhewe of holineſſe, when men be moſt diuelliſh, is a thing moſt abhominable before God and good men. It is then certaine, that all they which beare one title or name, are not by & by of one condition, nor children of the ſame parents, nor ſouldiours vnder one Captaine. And it is no maruayle that alſo in theſe dayes, manie of them which paſſe
vnder the title Proteſtants., haue beſides that onelie title, nothing, or verie little belonging therevnto. But ſhall they therein bee holden guiltleſſe? No, no. If the Scribes and Phariſees, which were ſayde to ſitte in Moſes Seate, and pretended great holineſſe, and zeale, for the lawe and Traditions of theyr Fathers, and could not eſcape the commination of that woe, and terrible vengeance which to Hypocrites is due: Alas, then, to what heauie doome bee ſuch appoynted, as vnder a faire proteſtation and ſhewe of perfection, will neyther faſt, nor pray, nor giue almoſe, nor yeeld tythes, nor tributes, nor yeeld any manner of true obedience to GOD, or their Prince, or anie way performe any of the workes of Chriſtian charitie? And to what thraldome bee thoſe appoynted, that rather dedicate themſelues dayly and hourelie to heynous perfidies, thefts, piracies, ſacrileges, ſimonies; to enuie, ambition, auarice, backbiting and ſlaundering to petiurie, lecherie, luxurie, pride, and idleneſſe: to gluttony, drunkenneſſe, ſtrifes, iniuries, and wickednes? are not theſe the things that pollute a man? do not theſe matters confound him vtterly? and are not manie towns, cities, countries and kingdomes, ſpoyled and quite waſted through theſe inormities? Then what can ſuch perſons expect and looke for beſides ſuch deſtructions? Surely nothing at all. And yet, as men that haue no feare of God, and ſo no religion, they dread not thoſe vnhappie euents, vntill they come: but ſitting downe in the Chayre of Peſtilence, wherein they ſcorne God, and all godlineſſe, they liue without feare, and die without hope.

7 I ſlaunder not the title or name of Christian Protestant, no more then Paul did offend the Angels of GOD, when he ſayde, that Sathan tranſformeth himſelfe into an Angell of light. The Lorde which ſeeth the ſecretes of all hearts, knoweth well that I rather reuerence and honour the right Proteſtant with all mine heart. And I am ſorie, that ſo noble a name ſhoulde bee impoſed on ſuch perſons, as doo iniuriouſly vſurpe thereon, abuſe and prophane it, to the high diſpleaſure of God, the diſcredite of the Goſpel, and the offence of good men, in ſuch their groſſe palpable abhominations: But this is the nature and policie of the olde Serpent, wherein, hee is moſt willing that his children ſhould immitate and follow him, who being aſhamed to ſhew himſelfe as hee is, taketh on, him the beautifull face of an Angell of light: who hateth the light, becauſe hee dooth euill, and who knoweth it to bee the eaſieſt way to beguile: for as treaſons are committed vnder truſt, ſo are great annoyes compaſſed vnder the cloake of honeſtie. There is no ſuch fooliſhneſſe, as that which hath a ſhewe of wiſedome: no ſuch ſinne, as that which is coloured with righteouſneſſe: no ſuch filthineſſe, as is faced with holineſſe: no ſuch thraldome, as that which pretendeth libertie: neither are there like abhominations perpetrated and and wrought in all the worlde, as thoſe which beare a ſhewe of the feare of GOD, and Religion. VVoulde to God that theſe groſſe enormities were not founde among them that bee called Proteſtants! VVoulde to God, that rather trueth, fayth, righteouſneſſe, holineſſe, charitie
zeale, knowledge, and the feare GOD indeed, might yet one day, bee more familiar, and of greater eſtimation amongeſt men, as thoſe good giftes, which the more common they bee, the better, by ſo much the more they appeare to be in the eyes of all good men! Then might not our dreade bee ſo great, ſeeing wee ſhoulde not neede to feare ſuch dreadfull euents, as thoſe heynous ſinnes engender in all ages, among all Nations.

8 The Lorde God of Iſrael ſayde thus of the Iſrailites: The more they encreaſed in multitude, the more they ſinned agaynſt mee. VVhat followeth? Therefore I will chaunge their honour into ſhame. Againe: Hoſe. 4.3, 4, 5, 6, 7. For as much as thou hast forſaken the Lawe of thy God, I will alſo forget thy children. Heere is ſorrowe: heere is woe inough: yet worthilie threatned on ſuch a viperous broode.

This entended the Prophet Iſaiah, Iſay 3. when hee ſayd: The Lorde ſhall haue the heades of the Daughters of Syon, and ſhall diſcouer their filthineſſe: Therefore ſayde our Sauiour thereof: O ye Daughters of Hieruſalem, weepe not for mee: but weepe for your ſelues, and your children. And he added the reaſon, namely, that great miſerie and ſorrowe ſhoulde ouertake them, which indeed came to paſſe vpon them, about fortie yeares. And of ſuch a plague the Prophet Amos forewarned them, when hee ſaide,Amos. 5.13. that except they did ſeeke good and not euill, that they might liue, there ſhould bee mourning in all ſtreetes, and they ſhoulde ſay in all high wayes, Alas, alas: and they ſhould call the husbandmen to Lamentation, and ſuch as coulde mourne, to mourning.

God reproued and threatned his owne people for their wickedneſſe.Now let vs conſider (I beſeech you) what theſe were, whom the Lorde ſo reproued and threatned with theſe plagues and wo: were they of the Gentiles? No trulie: they were of Iſrael, yea, of Syon. They were thoſe whome the Lord had enriched with bleſsings far beyond all their neighbors: For he had not dealt with anie Nation, as he dealt with them in his mercie. And what did they? As perſons moſt ingratefull, they did not any way beautifie; but euerie way pollute Syon gates. The more that God expreſſed his loue towards them, the more they daily prophaned themſelues in the abuſe of his bleſsings. They ſaid, with that ſon in the Goſpel: Father, we wil go forth at thy commaundement, and worke in thy Vineyard: But yet they performed their promiſe nothing at all: but went a whooring in their owne inuentions, and forgat him that had exalted them, and diſdained that right godlie humilitie which beautifieth them that enter into Syon gates. Therefore (as it was meete) hee which adorned them, bereeued them of their garments,VVee muſt hereby take heede, not to abuſe the gifts of God. made them naked againe, and diſcouered their ſhame, to their horrible confuſion. A notable example to terrifie them, that nothing regarde how they abuſe thoſe excellent bleſſings of the Lord, in their wicked & vngodly waies, and ingratefull hearts! Oh that it might pierce and enter into the hearts of thoſe our carnall Goſpellers, who though they cannot denie, but acknowledge Gods great goodneſſe towards them, do neuertheleſſe, eate with the gluttons, drinke with the drunkards, liue with the adulterers, ſweare with the blaſphemers, robbe with the theeues, kill with the murtherers, ſting with the backebyters, that
ſo, they might bee fearefull to beare the diuell in their hearts, whiles they hold Bibles in their hands: and learne, that it were much better that they were ſtone cold, then that (like thoſe ſtinking ſnuffes whoſe lights bee lately quenched) they ſhould by their warmeneſſe continue their loathſome ſauour, ſo hatefull to God, and offenſiue to good men.

9 Surely, when they haue euery way aſſayed to ioyne God and Mammon in concord, and to combine Chriſt & Beliol together in loue (becauſe they loue the world, and would ſerue to the time) they ſhall well perceiue by the manner of Gods iudgements vpon them, that he doth ſee theyr harts, doth know their deuiſes, and meeteth with them therein well inough. For though they once ſaide in theyr hearts, VVe be rich and encreaſed with goods,
Reu. 3.15. & haue need of nothing. Yet now they ſhall know themſelues, to be wretched, and miſerable, and poore, and blinde, and naked. And when all theſe things ſhal be well accounted, & the reckoning truely made, they wil change their opinions, and will not ſay (with him that hath bought a good peni-worth) It is good, It is good: but with him that hath not money inough to pay for that which is bought: Deere, deere, it is too deere; Pro. 20.14. and I had it at an vnſeaſonable hande. What good hath all our toyle brought vs? But whiles this wages is made ready for them, by him which rendreth to euery man according to his deedes, they ceaſe not to ſinne yet more and more, and that becauſe they loue and take pleaſure in the vaine and tranſitorie things of this world, which they eſteeme farre beyonde the treaſures and pleaſures of the Kingdome of heauen, and which they worſhip
before the higheſt God. And although that it be true, which Auguſtine ſayd, Laudabilior eſt animus cui notaeſt infirmitas propria, &c. That is, that mind to whome his owne infirmitie is knowne, is more to be prayſed, then hee which neglecting that, ſearcheth out the walles of the world, the wayes of the ſtarres, the foundations of the earth, and the pathes of the heauens: yet they (in theyr conceit) are wiſer then all theyr inſtructors, neyther will they knowe their owne infirmitie. And therefore, we may pipe to them, but they will not dance: we may teach them, but they will not learne: yea, as the foole, which though he be brayed in a morter like firmentie corne, will not for all that forgo his fooliſhnes: they wil not be perſwaded to know themſelues, theyr owne condition, their ſickneſſe, theyr danger, their miſerie, their imminent deſtruction, and euerlaſting woe.

Adulators are occaſions of mens often ſlidings into ſinne.10 And into this miſerable caſe many the more be pleaſantly drawne by the Adulations and ſeductions of thoſe immitating Apes, (I meane Flatterers) which beeing (indeede) of no Religion, but Epicures, Atheiſts, meere deriders of all holy worſhippe, zeale, and diſcipline, and the verie polipragmones of Sathan, to beguile men and to take them in their ſnares, haue learned ſuch a peſtilent Arte, and guilefull Sophiſtrie, as ouerthroweth all other laudable Sciences. They learne of the Camaelion to counterfeit all colours ſauing White,Camaelion. and in theyr dealings ſhewe all things ſaue honeſtie.Eccho. They learne of the reſounding Eccho, to ſooth them cunningly with yea Sir, no Sir, whoſe fauour they ſeeke to obtaine.
They be among the Iewes, as Iews: with the Gentiles as Gentiles: with Proteſtants, they bee as Proteſtants: with the Papiſtes, as Papiſts: with Neuters, they bee Neuters: with them that ſpeake well, they bee as good ſpeakers: and with them that ſpeake euill, they will alſo ſpeake euill, euen of thoſe things, and of thoſe perſons they knowe not: and what things they knowe naturally, as Beaſtes that are without reaſon,Iud. ver. 10. in thoſe things they corrupt themſelues. They alſo rightly reſemble thoſe in the Fable, which worſhipped the Golden Image that the Aſſebare on his backe (whereof the Aſſe waxed proude,The Fable of the Aſſe. thinking that all that worſhippe was doone, not to the Image, but to himſelfe) for theſe perſons reuerencing onely the Wealth, credit, power, and authoritie of them whome they Adulate, doo beare them in hande, that all theſe fayre wordes, obſequies, and worſhippes yeelded by them, onely vnto the perſons for theyr goodneſſe, qualities, and vertues. And in regarde thereof, they giue Titles vnto many of them moſt falſely. They call him wiſe, which is as fooliſh as Nabal was: They call him righteous, which is as wicked as Achab was: They ſay, that hee is louing, which is as enuious as Cayn was. They call the Prodigall man, liberall: the Couetous man, frugall: they call him a boon companion and a good fellow, who is a Theefe, a Whoremaiſter, a glutton, a drunkard.

Theſe doo likewiſe reſemble the craftie Foxe, which, ſeeing that the Crowe hadde in her Mouth a morſell of Meate, commended
her for her ſweete note in ſinging,The fable of the foxe and the crow. and requeſted her to ſing: this when the Crow aſſayed to do, ſhe opened her mouth and let fall that morſell; which the foxe catching, ranne his way with it. So, faith the Apoſtle, they reuerence men for aduantage ſake. Neither let they to further the deſtruction of them whome they perſwade, in ſuch ſort, as the fowler deſtroyeth thoſe birds which hee allureth to his ſnares, by his ſweete whiſteling. Theſe bee they which (as Auguſtine ſaid) doo binde men in their ſinnes,Aug. ſuper Pſal. 9. Iſa. 5. Hier. ad Celant. and drawe ſinnes vnto them (as ſaith the prophet) with cords of vanity. Theſe be thoſe Syrenes (ſaith Hierome) which haue deadly ſongs to drown men in ſin, of whō men ſhould be very heedy, and careful to eſchew them, as the ſtrongeſt poyſon, and the ſoreſt perſecutors. For it is true,Aug. ſuper Pſal. 69. that (as Auguſtine ſaith againe) Plas ſequitur lingue adulatoris, quam manus perſequentis. More cruell is the flatterers tongue, then the perſecuters hand. Therefore againſt them praieth Dauid, who had of them ſufficient experience: Lord, keepe mee from the ſnare and grens of the workers of iniquitie,
Pſal. 141.5.9 that theyr ſmooth Oyle, and pretious balmes breake not myne head.

Chriſt was no flatterer.12 They neuer learne this art of Chriſt, for hee neither flattered any man, nor liked of them that vſed it; but he commended the truth vnto his diſciples, hee liketh them that ſpeake the truth to theyr neighbours. When Chriſt would commend and prayſe Iohn the Babtiſt hee did it not without good reaſon, Mat. 11.7. conſidering his office and rare vertues: neither did he ſo commend him either in ye preſence of Iohn or Iohns diſciples: but when they were departed from him, then hee ſpake to the people concerning
Iohn: By the which,VVho inuented the arte of flattery. he freed himſelfe of all ſuſpition of flatterie, and gaue none occaſion of vaine-glorie to Iohn. But this art of adulation was inuented by the Serpent, which by the ſame beguiled both Adā & Heuah in Paradice, to their ouerthrow, Iob. 32.21.22. and to his owne damnation. Elihu in Iob conſidering this, ſaide: that he would giue titles to no men: and he alleadgeth a reaſon: Leaſt my maker ſhuld take me away ſodainly. He ſaw that ſuch perſons as imitated the Serpent, were with him to be damned by vertue of the curſe. And therto concordeth that ſaying of the prophet Iſayah. c.a. 5. VVo be vnto them that put light for darkeneſſe, and darkeneſſe for light.
Prou. 17.15. That iuſtifie the vngodly for rewardes. For as a flame of fire deuoureth the ſtubble, and as the chaffe is conſumed of the flame, ſo ſhall their roote be as rottenneſſe, and their bud ſhall riſe vp like duſt: that is, Prou. 28.10. both they and their poſteritie ſhall periſh: and they that cauſe other to go aſtray ſhal come to ruine.Hiero. ad Demet. Therfore happie be they that do neither adulate others, nor be by others adulated: but that edifying themſelues in their moſt holy faith, and praying in the holy Ghoſt, do keepe themſelues in the fauour, loue, and feare of God, which euer hath, doth, and will, commend & worſhip them, that ſerue him in holyneſſe and righteouſneſſe. For theſe men haue neither iuſt cauſe to be angrie with themſelues, and to bee ouercome with furie, as thoſe others be occaſioned, which haue bin led as birds to the ſnare, and fooles to the torment: nor ſhall they bee moued to execrate and curſe others, as thoſe be conſtrained to do, which in the middeſt of their miſeries, doo call to minde by whoſe ſubtiltie and guile they haue beene drawne into theſe their endleſſe calamities and woe.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
The example of ſome particular parts of title Proteſtants.
div.p:
Num. 23.22. ALthough there was a time when (as Baalam ſaide of the Iſraelites) God founde none iniquitie in Iaacob, nor ſaw tranſgreſſion in Iſrael: yet did the Lord complaine againſt the Iſraelites, Deut. 32.5.6 not onely by Moſes, but alſo by the Prophet Iſayah: Frowardly haue they done againſt him (ſaith Moſes) by their vices, not being his owne children, but a wicked and a froward generation. And therefore he thus expoſtulateth: Do ye ſo rewarde the Lord: O thou fooliſh Nation and vnwiſe?
Iſa. 1.2.24. Is not he thy father that hath bought thee? hath he not made thee, and ordained thee? And thus ſayth the Lorde by Iſayah: I haue nouriſhed and brought vp children, and they haue done vnfaithfully againſt me. And therefore he ſaith againe. Ah, I muſt eaſe me of mine enemies, and auenge me of mine aduerſaries. Euen ſo in theſe latter times, we may eaſily deſcrie, but not ealy beare, among ſuch as ſeeme to be of Iſrael, and make faire proteſtations of Chriſtianitie, ſuch kind of perſōs as not only Moſes & Iſayah had to do withal:2. Pet. 2.13.14 2. Tim. 3. Mat. 25. but alſo ſuch as both Peter and Paul do ſpeake of, when they allude to the wordes of Chriſt in his Sermon of the laſt dayes, to the great greefe of the godly, and to the ſhadowing of the Goſpel of Chriſt among men. And ſurely, as Paul once ſayde, and not
without ſorrow of mind, after the Poet Epimenides, touching the particular nature and condition of the Cretians: ſo I am ſorie to ſee, howe neere Engliſh men verifie that olde Prouerbe, Tit. 1.12. in their vnthriftie natures and euill conditions.

q.l: Krētes aeiplſeuſtai kaka theria gaſteres argai.
The Cretes are liars, bad natured beaſts, and ſlow bellies.Epimen.

div.p:
2 And I preſume,There is little fayth and truſt among men. when other men haue with me examined the particulars, they will confeſſe the ſame: for howſoeuer it be, it is true that Synons periurie, Iudas trechery, & Ananias hypocriſie take ſuch large row me, that this counſaile,Epicarmius. Take heed thou truſt no man, is holden for the verie ſtrength of wiſedom, euen among brethren, families, friends, & acquaintances: yea, between father and ſonne,He that wil be truſted muſt not lie. mother and daughter. For what credit can a man repoſe there, where no truth is: Truſt ſtandeth on truth: where there is no truth, there can be no credit at all: there though men ſweare, they ſhall not bee beleeued. And this is that which lyars and breakers of promiſe gette, that men will not beleeue them, nor put truſt in theyr wordes and promiſes, though they happily report a trueth, and intend to performe the worde neuer ſo conſtantly: for as the craſed glaſſe or veſſell is euer ſuſpected, though it may perchaunce containe ſome kinde of licour for a time: ſo are they a kinde euer doubted of, touching any truth or aſſurance of theyr worde, who haue once fayled the ſame. The Poets haue remembred Caſſandra, the Daughter of Priamus, Caſſander verg.
for an example of this thing, who (as they tell) for breaking off her promiſe made to Apollo, had this puniſhment laide vppon her, that ſpeake ſhe neuer ſo truely, no man ſhould credit her words. And the moſt part, conſidering how little men eſteeme of honeſty and plaine dealing,Valer. max. li. 7. doo willingly admit Demoſthenes cenſure, when being aſked what thing he thought to be of moſt efficacie in ſpeaking (among the Athenians) anſwered 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Hypocriſie:VVhen men make ſhew of that which is not, nor minde not to performe. and being yet further asked againe, and again, what thing was of the greateſt force in ſpeaking, he ſtill anſwered Hypocriſie. Therefore men bee moſt fearefull to truſt further then they ſee (as the prouerbe is) though they deepely ſweare before theyr faces, and haue no leſſe colour howe to couer their miſchiefes vnder the beautifull verniſh of honeſtie, religion, and truth. This practiſe is in no ſlender regarde, beeing taken for a way moſt ſafe and ſure among men, which alſo the heretike Priſcillianus thought the word of God confirmed,Priſcillianus the heretike. and that in ſome caſes lying was not forbidden, nor diſſimulation to be eſchewed, but was a thing tollerable inough euen among Chriſtians. Alas, where is faith? where is truth? Shall Chriſt come (indeed) and finde neither faith, nor truth vpon the earth: yea, yea, for himſelfe hath ſayde it, to the ſhame and condemnation of ſuch perſons.

Thraſones proud boaſters3 Next, it is noted, that Thraſo beareth no meane ſway: he walketh after the fleſh: he ſtandeth not a little on his own valor: he ſpeaketh ſwelling words of vanitie, being proud, heady, high minded, couetous, a louer of himſelf. Howbeit, he can ſometimes reſemble Iacob in voyce, though with the rough handes of Eſau. Eſau. Alas, who euer thought to ſee ſo
many of theſe in this age; and againe, ſo few of them that in Chriſtian charitie are contented to couer the multitude of ſinnes?Peter. Peter himſelfe (though a Paſtor of the Church) ſpeaketh words of vanitie, he is ready to ſtrike with the temporall ſword, and therewithall to note his fellow Iohn, touching his maner of walking, with a curious and diſdainful eie, when as he himſelfe ſhould rather remember howe hee aſſaied to hinder his lord and maiſter from his godly purpoſe, when hee ſhould haue furthered him therein: howe himſelfe ſlumbred then, when hee had moſte neede to watch with his Maiſter: howe himſelfe denied his Maiſter three times, when hee ought to haue confeſſed him, and haue repented thereof. What is this Peter? Is this Simon Barionah? Nay, this is rather Sathan, as Chriſt called him, when he bad him go behind him.Sathan an hinderer. Thus (indeed) is one mā moſt ready to make another man a publike example with open mouth: and one brother diſplaieth his full deſire of reuenge on another brother, reſembling not onely Thraſo, but alſo that heathen Achilles, who (as the Poet ſaid) expreſſed his furie againſt his foes,Achillis. Homer. being as ſweete to himſelfe as hony melting vnder his tongue. I ſay not they reſemble that valiant captain in his famous nature and proweſſe, but in furie and reuenge, as if in ſtead of being angry without ſinne, they might deſire a reuenge for ſinne, and thirſt after the blood of them,Pſal. 4. whom they hate and diſdaine in their pride: as if they might without offence to God, and breach of charitie, hate one another, face, threate, and beate one another, yea, and kill one another of them. To this they bee willing to pike occaſions
agaynſt their brethren,The fable of the wolfe and the lambe. as the Woolfe in the fable did agaynſt the ſielie Lambe, when he dranke beneath him in the Riuer: whoſe Logicke they can choppe better then anie good diuinitie: Hee drinketh when I drinke: Ergo, hee troubleth the the water whereof I drinke. And yet they retaine the title of Chriſtians.

4 If they had anie reſpect to the commaundement of Chriſt, the good leſſons and examples of holie men, and the woorthineſſe of the Goſpel, they woulde bee more wiſe, and expreſſe better fruits to declare their Religion. Pro. 20.22. Touching the reuenge of iniuries giuen & taken, Salomon coūſelleth: Say not, I wil recompence euill for euill (that is not good) but waite vppon the Lorde, and hee ſhall ſaue thee. Chriſt teacheth: Mat. 5.39. Reſist not euill: For this worde, An eie for an eie, a tooth for a tooth, was ſpoken for the Iudges, and not that it might bee lawfull for euery man to apply it to the reuenge of his priuate quarrell. He ſaith againe: Loue your enemies. For that ſaying, Hate your enemies, was added to the wordes of the lawe, by the falſe expoſitors of the ſame. And Paul exhorteth thus: Rom. 12.18.19 Auenge not your ſelues: but giue place to the backebiter, for it is written, vengeance is mine: I will repay, ſayth the Lord. For as nothing better beautifieth a Chriſtian, then humilitie, loue, mercie, courteſie; ſo is there not anie thing that more diſgraceth him, then pride, hautineſſe, boaſting, diſdain, wrath, vengeance. Therefore when the wiſe woman Abigail the wife of Nabal, had pacified Dauid, and turned away his diſpleaſure conceiued agaynſt her huſband, Dauid was right glad in his heart, prayſed the Lorde, and called her and her counſaile bleſſed,
in that ſhee had ſtopped him from his purpoſe of ſhedding of blood in his wrath,1. Sam. 25.32.33. which might (as hee thought) haue tended to the diſgrace of his profeſsion, and to the diſpleaſure of God.

5 But let vs proceede: Oh good Lord! how few finde wee of the one ſort,More be giuen to luſt, then to actiuitie and godlineſſe. that are readie to take vp with King Alexander, the Harpe of Achillis to play on? And howe fewe finde wee of the other ſort, that make right good melodie on Dauids Harpe? But on the Harpe of Paris the Troian, how manie of either ſort finde wee to twang moſt odiouſlie? they endeuour not with Hercules, for the loue of Ladie Arete to reiect the hagge Kakia,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : vertue. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , vice and pleaſure. but with Sardanapalus, in the loath of Arete, to embrace Kakia. Few be giuen to actiuitie, leſſe to godlineſſe:Gens inimica Deo. too manie (as enemies to God, and foes to all vertues) are bent to luſt, to loue dalliaunces, and luxurie.

And this kinde of Muſicke is without meaſure delighted in with them, both in youth and age,Aug. de doct. Chriſt. to the honour of Bacchus, and Venus, moſt farre off from that honeſt ſhamefaſtneſſe, and abſtinence, which to women is beautie, and to men an ornament; and which beeing wanting in either, they care not what wickedneſſe they commit. Quantas Leones domuit vna infirmitas delicata: id eſt, Idem de ſingul. cler. luxuria? VVhat mightie Lions (ſayth Auguſtine) hath one delicate infirmitie, namely, luxurie tamed? VVhich though vile ſhee be and wretched, yet ſhe maketh her prayes of great and valiant men. Ʋal. Max. lib. 9. This flattering euill, is eaſier to bee accuſed, then to bee eſchewed:
this is that which betrayed Hanniball into the hand of the Romanes: what vice more vile? VVhat thing more hurtfull?In ventre pingis, non in eſſe ſapientiam. By this helliſh hagge are vertues quayled, victories doo languiſh, glorie is deuoured of infamie, and the powers both of bodie and minde are ſo weakened, that a man ſhall hardlie diſcerne whether it bee more pernicious to bee captiued either of that, or of his mortall foes.Bed. de temp. Sol. This is that (ſayeth Bede) which effeminateth the minde, weakeneth the bodie, defileth the ſoule, and corrupteth the perſon. Therefore Hierom exclaimed thereof: O ignis infernalis luxuria: O luxurie that fire of hell, the matter whereof is gluttonie, whoſe flame is pride, whoſe ſparckles are euill wordes, whoſe ſmoke is infamie, whoſe aſhes are vncleanneſſe, whoſe end is hell?

6 Surelie, theſe thinges are not ſo much to bee maruailed at, becauſe they bee ſo common: howbeeit, they may bee lamented, becauſe they cannot bee amended, nor throughly corrected among men, with whome this diuell dwelleth to theyr deſtructian: but yet woulde they bee ſomething better, were it not that they alſo, who ought to bee lightes,The good examples of the teachers are auailable to them that ſhould learne and good examples of life vnto others, bee polluted in the ſame Puddles. Can thoſe young Schollers learne well to write, which haue no good Copies and examples giuen them of their Schoolemaiſter? No trulie: ſo neither can the people behaue themſelues like chriſtians, when their teachers haue no light in them, or at the leaſt,The names of certaine ſherpheards ſhine not before men in holie doctrine and Chriſtian behauiour! Alas, it is too manifeſtly perceiued, that Tyterus, Battus, and many like
paſtorall perſons haue quite forgotten Salomons affixe to the concluſion of his laſt ſolace: Eccles. 12.9.10. Pan was ſaid to be the God of the ſhepheards. Virg. Egl. 1.2 Ouid. li. 2. & 3. Metā. and being fatte and full, they bee willing to commit the regarde of their faint flockes to that ruſticke Pan, as forgeth the Poet:
Both ſheepe and ſhepeard now let Pan
Regard, and cure them as he can.

In the meane time,Theoer. Idyl. 3. they bee in flamed with the paſsion of an idle mind: (I meane, with that which ſpringeth vp of leaſure and idleneſſe, and is allayed through exerciſes and want of idleneſſe, as both the Poets and Chryſostome write) for the amourous conceyte of Narciſſus beſottes them:Nar. enamored with his owne beautie. Hyena a beaſt that deceiueth the ſhepherds. Names of certaine wanton women. Hyenas voyce allures them, and they harpe luſtilie for Amarillis, and Galathaea, and Phyllis, which had lately enamoured them: which alſo in fine, doo prooue as Dalila to Samſon, to deceiue them: as Hyena to the paſtour to deuoure them: as Syrenes to the Nauigatours to drowne them. Of this ſayeth Augustine: Aug. deſing clericorum. Quanti & quales Epiſcopi, & Clerici, &c. Oh howe manie, and what notable Biſhoppes and great Clearkes, (after manie tryed battailes of confeſsions and victories, after manie great woorkes and maruailous tokens, are knwon to haue made ſhipwracke of all theſe thinges, when they haue beene willing to ſayle in this fraile bottome. This Vice diſtained Nicholas, and vtterly defamed Demas. Nicholas. Demas.

7 Neuertheleſſe, this deuiſe better delighteth them, then that they ſhoulde watch in the colde nights, and labour in the feruent hote dayes, and that ſo much the ſooner,Herod. becauſe that Herode the Tetrarch,
ſo well affecteth Iohn the Tell-truth (whatſoeuer face hee ſhewe before the people) that hee had leauer his head were taken from his ſhoulders, and preſented before him in a platter, at the requeſt of a wanton Girle, then that hee ſhoulde liue any longer to be a reproouer of him for his daliaunces with Philips wife: although hee bring his authoritie with him from God. And for that Pope Boniface the ſeuenth,Boniface the ſeuenth. Fulgoſus. commaunded the eyes of Cardinall Iohn to bee pulled out, becauſe hee preſumed to tell him of his open abhominations, as his dutie was to doo: And for that Pope Innocent did ſo well digeſt it,Innocent. to bee reproued for his negligent prouiſion againſt ſchiſmes, that he cauſed them which vndertook to tell him of the ſame, to bee caſt downe headlong from the loftie windowes. Iere. 8.12. VVhat will they anſwer. Cant. 3.1. and 7.14. Fie for ſhame! what abhominable things bee theſe that they do: and yet they bee nothing aſhamed: yea, they knowe of no ſhame! Alas what will they do in the day of their viſitation, and in the morning when that Chriſt ſhall ſee if the Vine bee ſprung foorth: if the Grapes be growne: and if the Pomgranates bee ſhut out? For he will ſurely call an account of them, and the reckoning muſt be made in that day, before his tribunall ſeate. But learne this: as the holie ſpouſeſſe coulde not finde him whom her ſoule loued, by the night times in her bed: ſo neither will Chriſt bee found out of them, either by carnall reaſon, or worldlie luſtes, which obſcure in them the light of true knowledge: and if they finde him not with Iohn the Baptist; howe can they ſhewe him to Andrew? If Andrew finde him not, howe can hee declare him to Simon? And if Philip followe
not the Lorde at his commaundement, how is hee able to finde and perſwade Nathanael? But if anie of them be otherwiſe minded,They that enter into this charge, muſt not ſeeke for any worldly peace. and ſeeke with Demas, Nicholas, and ſuch backeſliders, peace, eaſe, and contentation in the luſtes of their eyes, the luſtes of their fleſh, and in the pride of life (when they ſhoulde rather doo their duties, come what loue ſoever) they may looke for peace:
Ier. 8.15. but they ſhall fare neuer the better: they may waite for a time of health: but they ſhall finde nothing but trouble. For they bee ſet in the battaile to ſtriue agaynſt powers,Epheſ. 6. and mightie aduerſaries in the worlde. VVell then: will yee enter thee fielde, and not looke for ſtrokes? VVill yee followe Chriſt, and neither hunger nor thirſt? VVill yee ſtriue to come into heauen, and liue as yee lift?Iere. 45. In trueth your expectation is vaine: yee doo ſorelie deceiue your ſelues, and your Lord and Maiſter will not allow it ſo. To follow him he muſt take vp the croſſe on your ſhoulders: to come to heauen, ye muſt prepare your ſelues in the feare of God, and a cleane life.Simon Magus. But it is lamentable to conſider what power Simon Magus hath to enchaunt men with his ſorceries: howe prompt that lying ſpirit is to enter the mindes and mouthes of Achabs Prophets, if God once permit him: how readie Aſmodaeus is to ſearch the bedde of Raguels Daughter,2. Chro. 18.21 Tob. 6. if hee bee not reſtrayned by Raphael the Angell? And howe haſtie Satan is to trie the patience of holie Iob, if that once by Gods permiſsion, Iob. 1.10▪ hee can pike out but the verie leaſt occaſion agaynſt him: from this troubleſome ſpirite, and all other his hideous deceites, the Lorde God deliuer vs, eſpeciallie all them,
by whoſe holy doctrine and godly life, the Church is and ought to be lightned and inſtructed.

Pythias a contencious perſon in Athens8 Now to hinder all the good which is expected, that buſie and contentious Pythias, (which ſhould rather haue ſtood to the deliberation of that wife Phocian, within the Citie of Athens, then to haue torne out his owne tongue with long lippe-labour in euerie lire) being prouoked maketh no ſmall ſtirre, not onely in the Church, but alſo in the Common-weale, to the great diſquiet of the wiſe Magiſtrate, to the griefe of the vigilant Paſtour, and to the high diſpleaſure of the Almightie God. And may we call him a Proteſtant: a Chriſtian? No, no: for thoſe qualities beſeeme neither Proteſtants, nor Chriſtians: neither would thoſe title Chriſtians (if they were not more then heatheniſh) aduenture ſuch actions and deuiſes, as the very heathen vtterly abhorred as abhoninable. But Pythias in his contention & ſtir nothing bluſheth to condemne one liberal ſcience, whiles he would ſeem to cōmend one other of the ſame ſort, notwithſtanding, that thereby he incurre more diſcredite in the one, then gain credit by the other: and withal, he maketh no ſcruple of this,Mephiboſeth Ziba. 2. Sam. 16.4. Naboth. Achab. 1. King. 21. Math. 4.9. that Mephiboſeth be quite beggred, ſo as by the ſame Ziba hee be made a gentleman: that Naboth be murthered, ſo as Achab be pleaſured. Oh good Lord! what elſe is this, but the verie worſhip of the diuell? Let the ſhew therof be neuer ſo glorious? The very heathen (according to the rule of naturall reaſon) haue vehemently diſliked this, to take from one man to giue to another man: as to rob one, and enrich another with the ſpoile. Phocian alſo ratifieth this:Phocian. among the Athenians in his time, that was
a farre better thing for a man to ſatiſfie and pay his debts, then to giue and beſtowe on other men, that which hee hath gotten by rapine and deceit. Doth not this redound to the diſgrace of ſuch Chriſtians, as let not to contriue ſuch tragaedies? yes doubtleſſe.

9 Howbeit, that neither the heathen Philoſophers may condemne them in open cenſure, nor the populer opinions point at their faces with worthie infamie, there is a pretie preoccupation deuiſe to preuent all.Ziba accuſeth Mephiboſeth to haue his poſſeſſion. Ziba muſt now perſwade Dauid the King (who fauoureth Mephiboſeth (by one deuiſe or other) that Mephiboſeth is Dauids enemie: neither muſt Ziba ſticke to blow both hoate and colde in this caſe, as did the olde Heremite in the Fable,The fable of the Heremite. who blew on his fingers beeing a colde, to warme them, and preſently with the ſame breach blew on his broath being hoate, to coole it. How we ſhould vſe and eſteeme of the fellowſhip of ſuch kinde of perſons, the fable telleth vs. But ſo it is, that Mephiboſeth is vniuſtly accuſed before Dauid, by him who would ſeeme to commend him to his face. So alſo was poore Naboth accuſed and condemned, and the lande of the one is diueded, and the vineyard of the other poſſeſſed, and all is ſafe and ſure inough, ſo long as the eyes of men be deluded. In the meane time this is not conſidered,Vengeance ſleepeth not. that vengeance ſleepeth not: for as Steſichoras ſayde ſo long ſithence (whoſe ſentence for grauitie the famous Philoſopher Ariſtotle remembred) The very Graſhoppers do ſing in the fields of ſuch kinde of dealings: that is,Ariſt. in Rhetor. the poore afflicted and oppreſſed doo powre forth theyr complaints in theyr fields vnto God, crying for iuſt vengeance on theyr oppreſſors, whom the Lorde God
delayeth not to recompence according to their deſerts & the deſire of his oppreſſed children,Read. chap. 25.7. when they bee forced not onely to acknowledge the vprightnes of the iudgements of God vpon them; but alſo to confeſſe how rightly and orderly that ſentence is verified on thē,Mar. 7.12. Luke 6.3. & there poſterities, which (beſides the words of Chriſt in the like caſe) experience hath hatched in allages.

q.l: Melant. in Argum. 4. in Ecclen. Solon.The man who miſchiefs doth inuent,
To make another man to ſmarte:
Shall others finde, him to preuent,
Therewith to pierce him at the heart.

div.p:
Tit. 1.15.10 Howſoeuer the Cretians haue beene iuſtly cenſured, theſe actions and deuiſes are ſo hainous and loathſome in the eyes and iudgement of other heathen, that they haue iudged them as contrary to nature, to reaſon, to vertue, and all honeſtie, which they) according to their knowledge) both vſed and reuerenced in farre better ſort then many Chriſtians in name, whom therefore (after the example of Chriſt, the Prophets & Apoſtles, which haue produced the birds, the beaſts, and the Gentiles to teach others) we may worthily note & apply without any offence to the wiſe.The heathen haue obſerued oathes and promiſes. Of the very Paganes, ſome haue bin noted firme and conſtant to the death, of their words and promiſes, eſpecially then, when they did ſweare by thoſe Gods which they worſhipped, holding that (which Plautus hath counſelled) for a ſure axiome or ground. Moriri ſeſe miſere mauolet, quā non perfectumreddat, Terent in phormione Plaut in Aſmar. quod promiſerat. Let a man wiſh rather to die wretchedly, then to promiſe a thing and not to
performe it. And that another aduiſeth, Prius mori, quam fidem fallere. Chooſe rather to die, then to falcifie thy faith. And therof thus cenſureth Ouid.

q.l: The way ſeems ſure, & oft in vre, with friēdly face mē to beguile:
VVhich yet, how ſure, or oft in vre, is naught, & eke a practiſe vile.

div.p: Among theſe, ſuch perſons as obſerued not oathes and promiſes haue bin takē diſcredited, vnworthy of all truſt, and moſt infamous for euer: yea,Plagues enſue the breach of leagues and promiſes. and they haue thought that great plagues enſued the breach of promiſes, oathes, & lawful leagues. Therfore when Pyrrhus the king of Epirotes, contrary to his promiſe & vow made to the Argiues in Achaia, had entred their Citie, & in that conflict was ſlaine and his band diſcomfitted by Antigonus the King of Macedon (whoſe aide the Argiues had deſired & obtained for their reſcue and defence) it was thought, that deſtruction was inflicted on him and his ſouldiers by the gods, for his infidelitie, and that well worthie for as the Poet writeth.

q.l: VVhy would'ſt thou not performe in fine,Ouid.
The iuſt effect of promiſe thine.

div.p:
The Sythians, the Medeans, the Arabians, & ye Aegiptiās, haue in ye old time eſteemed ſo much of fidelity & truſt in oathes, words, & promiſes,Silius Italicus. li. 3. val. pun. ſec. that they deemed death but a mean puniſhmēt for perfidious and faithleſſe perſons: & the Romanes iudged that ſcarcely any plague or puniſhmēt whatſoeuer was ſeuere inough, & hard, for ſuch malefactors, whom after yt they had offended, they would very ſeldome pardon, and neuer truſt again, worthily deſeruing
(as they heide) that Iupiter ſhould caſt them out of the ſocietie and companie of al men, and burie their carcaſes in extreame ignomie and vtter diffame.
