Therfore when Metius Fuffetius the Albane King,Metius Fuffe. who had promiſed the Romane King Tullus Hoſtilius to aſſiſt him againſt his enemies, did neuertheleſſe break his oath, and trecherouſly deceiued him: he was at length taken by Tullius Hoſtilius, and tyed to two Carts, his handes to the one, his feete to the other, and ſo the Horſes beeing forced contrarie wayes,Tit. liu. hiſtor. ab vrb. cond. li. 1. he was rent aſunder. Although Titus Liuius diſliked much this puniſhment, as too ſharpe and cruell, wherein hee ſaide was ſmall regarde of humane lawes: yet Virgil, conſidering the greatneſſe of the fault, alloweth thereof with this cenſure: At tu dictis, Albane, maneres.
Anied. li 8. But thou (O Prince of Albany)
thy promiſe ſhould'ſt haue kept.

The Turke reproueth Chriſt • ans.11 The Barbarous Turke hath hard cenſures in this caſe: neither hath he letted to reproue the Chriſtians for their ſlender regard of their promiſes, and to complaine againſt them to Ieſus Chriſt, whom he knew the Chriſtians worſhipped. When Amurathes the Turke, once ſaw how that Ladiſlaus the Hungarian King,Amurathes Ladiſlaus. Iulian. by the counſaile of the Cardinall Iulian, had (contrarie to his oath and promiſe) ſette on the Turks and murthered manie of them, he tooke out of his boſome a Booke containing the conditions of peace, complaining and ſpeaking to Ieſus Chriſt in this ſort. This is the Booke; theſe be the conditions of peace
which thy Chriſtians haue broken! therefore, O Chriſt, if thou be the true ſonne of God, as theſe do affirme, now ſhew openly, that the periurie of thy people do nothing pleaſe thee. See what followed within a while after: the Turke ſetting fiercely on the King and the Cardinall, ſlew them both, and with them no ſmall number of their Souldiers, in the yeere of Chriſt 1444. Although it had beene ſo, that the Turke had falſified his promiſe, (which he would not to the death) yet ſhould not the Chriſtian King haue fayled therein, if hee ſhould haue dyed an hundred times, being no more lawful for him to breake his oath, when he had promiſed to be at peace, then it was lawful for the king of Ieruſalem to breake that promiſe and oath which he had made to the King of Babilon,
Ier. 27.8. in the name of the lord, Ezech. 17.13 15. whoſe periury the Prophet Ezechiel ſharply reproued, and the king himſelfe for the ſame, was hardly puniſhed. Should he proſper? ſhall he eſcape that doth ſuch things? or ſhall hee breake the couenant and eſcape free. Although Synon doo proſtitute his conſcience and credit to periurie and deceits,Synon pariured. Virg. yet ſhould Chriſtians girde themſelues with truth, they ſhould do as they ſay, if they haue ſayd it according to the lawe of God: yea, and albeit that the Papiſts haue taken vp that prophane rule to obſerue,Papiſts regard not theyr oathes made vnto vs. Fryer Foreſt. Grafton. Chro. pag. 1236. Linguaiuro, mentem, iniuratamgero, I ſweare and promiſe with my tongue onely: but not with mine heart: and in that regarde, Frier Foreſt thought he might lawfully breake his oath which he had ſworne to king Henry the eight, ſaying: Hee tooke the oath with his outwarde man, but his inward man neuer conſented thereto: and that thoſe our aduerſaries regarde neither faith nor promiſes made by them vnto vs, whome they call
Heretikes: yet know we right well, that the breach of a lawfull oath and promiſe, is moſt odious to the Lord,Pſal. 15. Auguſt. de ciuit. dei. li. 2. ca▪ 19. Eccleſ. 5.3. and fearefull to the conſciences of true Chriſtians, who loue rather to yeeld to the truth, then to ſeeke to conquere hir, which wil not be conquered. This is Salomons ſaying touching lawfull vowes and promiſes: If thou vowe a vowe vnto God, be not negligent to performe it. Againe, If thou promiſe any thing pay it, Nota. for it is better that thou make no promiſe, then that thou ſhouldeſt promiſe and not pay. Such onely (as Dauid ſaith) are meete to dwell in the Lords tabernacle.Pſal. 15. And this is the rule of the Goſpel preſcribed vnto Chriſtians, whoſe yea ſhould be yea, and whoſe nay ſhould bee nay, and euen ſo, Amen: that being faithfully minded, they might deale honeſtly one with another, and feare not to blaſpheme, leaſt for their blaſphemie and falſe dealing, they be giuen ouer to Satanto be tormented.

12. As touching other particular poynts, I mind not here to rehearſe the particular doctrines, examples, & rules of Hermes, Triſmegiſtus, Socrates, Pithagoras, Plato, Aeſope, Menander, Phocian, Ariſtides, and others, being Philoſophers, Poets, and wiſe men of the Gentiles, the which are yet worthy regard, and may aptly be placed before the faces of Chriſtians, if not to teach them, yet at the leaſt to condemn them, as the Queene of the South, and the Niniuites were ſometimes called forth againſt the Iewes by Chriſt himſelfe: but in ſteede of them all, we will produce that moſt ancient Poet Philemon, whome Iuſtinus Martyr diſdained not (though a Chriſtian) to remember with worthie praiſes. For (indeed) this Poet, hath in few words (among others) gathered together
the cheefe principles and groundes of that ſound doctrine and inſtitution of life, which not onely the Sibylles, but alſo the better ſort of the Poets and Philoſophers helde, embraced and aſſayed to practiſe in their liues, howſoeuer Epicurus, Diagoras, and ſome other of the wayning and latter ſort of the Philoſophers and Poets haue digreſſed from thoſe rules of wiſedome by them preſcribed and taught. Philemon, Heming. de leg. Mat. hauing firſt reprooued the great abhominations and errours of them which thought to pleaſe GOD, with the great multitude of Sacrifices of Bulles, Goates, and ſuch things, hee afterwarde telleth what a man ſhoulde doo indeede to pleaſe God of heauen, and what was required of him in theſe words.

q.l: To God ſee thou do ſacrifice:Phil. touching the worſhip of God.
Thy ſelfe being iuſt, in right iuſtice.

div.p:
A ſaying well worthie of all Chriſtians to be embraced, as vnto whom that ſentence of Chriſt belongeth, and vnto the which, that of Philaemon is neere like. The true worſhippers ſhall worſhippe the Father in ſpirit and truth. That is, as Zacharie ſingeth, Ioh. 4.23. In holineſſe and righteouſneſſe. This thing the very Iewes themſelues ſcarce regarded,Luke 1. which vaunted of the Temple, and entitled themſelues Abrahams children, and the only worſhippers of God, & thought they had pleaſed God wel when they brought great ſacrifices vnto the altar, howſoeuer their liues were diſtaigned with abhominations. Hebr. 4.12.13 But God who ſaw their thoghts, & (as Aeſope ſaid to his ſon 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
ſeeth and knoweth all things, Iſa. 1 & 5. Ier. 7. & 46.
and will not bee deceiued as men be deceiued, loathed theyr hypocriſie, reprooued them by Iſayah and other Prophets, & worthily reiected them and their ſacrifices. Would to God that Philemon and other heathen Philoſophers, might not worthily both reproue and condemne Chriſtians now: yea, thoſe Chriſtian Proteſtants that boaſt ſo much of their titles & dignities, for their vngodlineſſe and vnchriſtian behauiour.

13 Next, the ſame Philemon hath in effect theſe words:Philemon touching the ciuill life. To pleaſe God, it is meete that a man declare himſelfe an honeſt man: that he be not a defiler of Virgins, nor an adulterer, nor a theefe, nor a murtherer: that he couet not another mans goods, nor his wife, nor his houſe, nor his poſſeſſions, nor his ſeruant, nor his maide, nor his horſes, nor his oxen, nor ſo much as one ſmal threed of his: for God which is wel pleaſed with righteous deeds, and cannot abide the wicked, is euer preſent before thee, and ſeeth altogether. A notable doctrine of an heathen Poet, ſo neere the veritie of the legal,Exo 20. Mich. 6. Mat. 6. prophetical, & euangelical doctrine, to the which, as himſelf laboured to conforme himſelf, ſo did alſo others among them, in the perſon of all the which, let Socrates be noted, who touching himſelfe ſaide, that in himſelfe he had ſubdued Nature, (that is, thoſe infirmities whereunto he was ſubiect by nature) through his ſtudie of philoſophie: in the which, as he learned to know God & how to liue, ſo he feared not for the profeſſion of the ſame God, and his good life, to die moſt willingly, notwithſtanding the great entreatie that his friendes made vnto him, to ſubmitte himſelfe to the lawes and wicked opinions of the Athenians, as Plato hath reported it.

14 Oh, that we Proteſtants had this conſcience of our owne profeſsion, and eſpecially ſuch among vs, as are placed and authorized to teach, rule, and informe others, that yet at the leaſt, thoſe heathen men bee not called foorth in the iudgement before GOD to condemne vs, which haue not onely their rules, but alſo the rules, doctrines and examples of Chriſt, and his holie Apoſtles, Euangeliſts, and Martyrs to inſtruct vs: Therefore knowing by theſe lawes and inſtructions, what the will of GOD is, and conſidering that wee bee of the ofspring of God, and as children vnder their parents) doo euer ſtand in neede of his helpe (as Aratus writeth,) and in fine,Arat. ſolenſ. howe much hee woulde that our holineſſe and pure liues ſhoulde ſhine before thoſe Gentiles, to whome the bright ſhining Sunne of righteouſneſſe appeared, not as vnto vs: let vs yeelde our ſelues wholie vnto his holineſſe, and ſo order our liues according to our profeſsion, that the Lorde may gladlie acknowledge vs for his owne Children, and daylie miniſter vnto vs that, whereof wee ſtand in neede, and for the which wee are taught to pray in theſe wordes. Our dayly bread giue vs this day.

Otherwiſe,Seneca, in trag. octan. act, 2. whiles wee woulde bee accounted men, not onelie of the ſiluer age, but alſo of the golden age, wee ſhall bee founde and ſo prooued indeed (by Astraea or Iuſtice) to bee but of the Copper age, from whom this noble vertue (contemning the impietie of men) is departed, as the ſame Poet writeth.

q.l: Astraea ſhe did flie,
this kinde of men,
ſo wicked then,
And plac'd herſelfe in skie.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
The former argument is continued. Men being at peace vnder a peaceable Prince, waxe wearie of well doing: contemne Religion, and liue wickedlie, neither will they take heede by other mens plagues.
div.p:
MOſt men, when they heare tell of Laiſh,
Iud. 18.17. which being waxen fat and wealthy, was ſecure, and feared no misfortune, vntill that misfortune ouerwhelmed her: they do without mouth condemne the careleſſe ſecurity of Laiſh, Men can condemne the fooliſhneſſe of others, and yet not apply their examples to themſelues, being within the ſame predicament. & laugh at her deſtruction. So do they likewiſe, when they heare of Moab, which had reſted long on her lees, and neuer thought of any rolling, till time ſhe ſo ſauoured, that ſhe needed to be changed from out of one veſſell into another. Alſo they wonder at the famous Citie of Hieruſalem, which had forgotten the Lord, and all his benefits, and pampered vp her ſelfe much like vnto Sodom, not knowing the time of her viſitation, vntil the day came, wherin the daughters of Hieruſalē were forced to weep bitterly for themſelues and their children. This and ſuch like fearfull examples men can read of, and heare to be recorded in the holy Scriptures, and daily talke of them: howbeit, the whiles they haue not the grace to applie
theſe & ſuch like things, ſo as therof they may make to themſelues a benefit, with this conſideration, that theſe examples are made perpetuall to inſtruct all men in the poſteritie, that the like ſinnes do euer deſerue, and haue cōmonly the like plagues, without timely repētance. And herein they be much like vnto thoſe Iewes, whō the lord reproued for that they ſaid: Surely, if we had bin in the dayes of our fathers, Mat. 23.
then would we not haue partaked with them in the blood of the Prophets; when yet themſelues ceaſſed not to fulfill the meaſure of their fathers in their bloody perſecution of the Prophets & of the wiſe men which God ſent vnto them: for theſe men ſay, if we had beene of Laiſh, or of Moab, or of Ieruſalem, we wold not haue bin ſo careleſſe, ſecure, & vnthankfull to God for his bleſsings: we would haue conſidered from whence came all our peace and proſperitie; we would haue knowne the day of our viſitation, & what belonged to our eaſe, and bin prouident and wiſe: but behold, whiles they bee excellent in the obſeruing of other men and their caſes, they neglect thēſelues, & conſider not that thoſe examples of yore are made perpetual for the poſteritie, which therby may be happie, if they can be made warie. Men, for ye moſt part, in this caſe do near counterfeit that couetous Euclio, Plaut. Euclio laugheth at the caſe of Tantalus. Mutato nomine de te fabula narratur. who, hearing the Poet to tell of Tantalus, that was thirſtie in the midſt of ye water, was moued to laugh at his folly, whē notwithſtāding, if he had but changed his name, he ſhuld haue perceiued that ye fable pointed at himſelf, being indeed poor in the midſt of his welth. It is no mean furtherāce to helth for a mā to know himſelf ſicke, & with what infirmity he is touched: for he wil theron repair to ſuch a phiſitiō as
(he is perſwaded) can do him good, and not before that: for the whole haue no neede of the Phyſitian, and they that be righteous already in their own cō ceits, thinke themſelues to haue no need of Christ.

Long peace is enemie to good maners, not of it owne nature, but of the corrupt nature of mā, which as the water not moued will ſoone ſmell.2 It is true, that as proſperitie maketh men wantons: ſo long peace (as Iuuenal ſaide) is an enemie to good maners, and maketh bad ſouldiours: not that the fault is in that proſperitie and peace, but in ſuch fooliſh people, as abuſe the ſame: for The foole (as ſaith Salomō) being full, cannot meaſure himſelf. Not only the heathē which know not god, but alſo the very Chriſtians in name, whō the Lord hath enriched and bleſſed euerie way, farre beyond the heathen, being growne fat and reſtie, do kick with the heele, as vnbrideled colts agaynſt God, and degenerate frō their former fauour through their abuſe of the creatures,Epheſ. 6. Iude. 7.3. Rom. 13. and their manifold abhominations. Inſomuch that when the Lord preſſeth them foorth to fight for him, and Gedeon, that is, in the Lordes warres, they want the Armour of Chriſtian ſouldiours: they bee feeble, they bee faint hearted, they lappe water as Dogges, they can neither go wiſelie, nor walke honeſtlie, nor ſtande worthilie, but by their cowardly cowching, and reuolting from their profeſsiō, they ſhew forth the fruits of their long peace which they haue abuſed, and decipher themſelues (in a kinde of rebellion) to bee the very enemies of the Croſſe of Chriſt, whoſe enſignes ſometimes they had diſplayed. VVould to God, that neither my ſelfe, nor anie other man coulde iuſtlie include any of our Engliſh Proteſtants within this predicament, that ſo, they might bee well able to pleade for themſelues againſt euery one that would either
condemne or accuſe them of ſuch a fault! But I am right ſorie, becauſe I may ſay, that it toucheth manie of them ſo neare, that they cannot bee excuſed, nor cleared, though that Demoſthenes, and Cicero, were theyr Oratours to pleade for them: nor can they eſcape the deſerued iudgement, if God awarde them execution, though Noah, Iob, and Daniel, dwelt in the midſt of their Cittie, except that they repe •• .

3 In whatſoeuer coaſt they ſtande now,A degeneration from vertue. this is moſt apparant, that too manie of them haue againe admitted him into their houſes, whome it pleaſed God in his mercie, ſometimes to caſt out: whereby their laſt beeing worſe then the beginning, they ſhall neuer bee able to ende with the righteous, (as Balaam deſired that hee might) except they remember from whence they bee fallen, and repent. Though they haue made ſhewe of a good commencement and beginning, yet beholde, they go ſlowlie forward: yea, rather as wearie of doing wel they haue fainted and made ſhipwrack of faith, and a good conſcience, which aboue all things they ſhould haue retained. The nearer they came to the goale, the ſwifter ſhould their courſe haue bin, and from one vertue they ſhould haue proceeded vnto another, vntill they had been perfect men in Chriſt: but alas they haue ſlugged, they haue left the goale of eternal life, they haue declined from the ſtrength of faith, vnto the weakneſſe of mans carnal conceits. They are worſe nowe in their age, then they haue bin in their childhood. In this they are verie much like the Indian Pandora, The Pandora of India. a kinde of people which in their youth haue white hoar heads, as old men, and
in their elder age, they haue blacke haire, as young men. For when they were but yong, and tender as babes in knowledge, they expreſſed ſome tokens of chriſtianitie & grauitie: but now when they ſhould haue put from them childiſhnes, by reaſon of riper yeares, and the longer vſe of the word of God, they vtter more notes of childiſh wantonneſſe, then euer they did before. Neither are they vnlike the Tarſen Hermogenes, Hermogenes was in his old age as a child. who when he was but fifteene yeares old, was reported of, to be an approued Sophiſt, that Marcus Antonius much affected him, and enriched him with many noble gifts: howbeit in proceſſe of time (whether it were through the great abundance of his wealth, or worldly pleaſures, or ſicknes, or want of exerciſe) he did vtterly loſe the habit of his facultie:Antiochus Sophiſta. of whom therefore the Sophiſt Antiochus was wont to ſay: Hermogenes in pueritia Senex, & in ſenectute puer: that is, Hermogenes is become in his olde age a childe, who in his childhood was an old man. And no maruell (for as it ſeemeth to me) they haue quite forgotten the vow and promiſe made in their baptiſme to the Lord, & thoſe principles of religion wherein they ſeeming expert vnder their cathechizers, haue bin confirmed: I pray God, that they do not alſo with Demas forſake Paul in the open field for the loue of this preſent worlde, and that ſo, with Alexander, Himmeneus, Caine, Eſau, and Iudas, they make not ſhip-wracke of altogither in the ende.

Men wane in holineſſe, and become barren as the ſhe wolfe.4 Thus is it not onely apparant how they haue forgotten that which before they had learned in the word of God: but alſo how they with the Moone wane and ſlide backward in godlines and wax barren
of the woorkes of Charitie and Chriſtianitie, wherein they be neither ſo full, nor ſo forward, nor ſo fruitfull, as they were wont to be. But how neare do they follow the propertie of the ſhee woolfe, which (beſides manie euill qualities) hath a yearlie defect in procreation? Surely as neare as may bee: for as the firſt time ſhe beareth fiue, the ſecond time but foure, the third time but three, the fourth time but two, the fifth time but one, and then after that ſhee remaineth euer barraine: So, whereas, in the firſt age of our peace they employed (as it were) fiue Talents, and yeelded thereof the increaſe, in the ſecond age or yeare, they contented themſelues with foure, in the thirde age with three, in the fourth age with two, in the fifth age with one, in compariſon with the former, and ſo are become meere barraine, for the moſt part. For though the worde of God bee preached plentifullie, and the bleſsings of God doo abounde, wherewith men might bee mooued to praiſe him in an holie life: yet there is a complaint vttered, and a Citation ſent foorth from him that hath a controuerſie with the Inhabitants of the lande: becauſe,Hoſe. 4.1, 2.
There is no truth, nor mercie, nor knowledge of God in the land: but ſwearing, and lying, and killing, and ſtealing, and whoring, and blood toucheth blood, & yet none may rebuke them, nor reproue them, they cannot abide it, but will rebuke the Prophets, the Preachers and miniſters, whoſe office is to crie out againſt them and their ſinnes. So little care they to fight the good fight with fayth and a good conſcience: ſo deuoid of counſell be they, & without all vnderſtanding in the word of god,Deut. 32.28. and 44. through yt which they might prolong their daies in ye land wherin the
Lord hath planted them, and liue if they would.

5 Herehence is alſo diſcried, that daungerous ſin which hurteth mans ſoule with a deſperate wound: vz. A deepe diſtruſt of the diuine Prouidence, A diſtruſt of Gods prouidence. by faith in the which, men haue a chief comfort in this life, and without the which, they run into a labyrinth of errors.Diagoras. Diagoras the Atheiſt hath within his Schoole manie ſhrewd Schollers, though Cleanthes the Philoſopher,Cleanthes. by the verie operation of nature, confirmeth the mightie woorking of the high God in all worldlie things: yea, though the Lord teſtifieth in his word plainly,Abac. 1.5. Act. 13.41. and we do ſee it euidently, that the almightie God worketh a worke in our dayes: yet ſay they, Magiſter dixit: Our maiſter hath ſaid, and we will beleeue him.VVhen men do diſtruſt God, they flie to their owne deuiſes. Now vpon this ſuggeſtion, Adam deſireth a more pleaſant place then Paradice to liue in: Lot deuiſeth a ſafer towne then Zoar to dwell in: Peter for feare what wil folow, denieth his maiſter: Annanias and Zaphira, deale deceitfullie to eſchew beggerie. The Gergeſites deſire Chriſt to depart from their coaſts for the ſafetie of their ſwine: Demas ioyneth hands with the world in hope of fauor: and the Protestant is nothing ſcrupulous to pertake with the Peripatike, the Stoicke, the Epicure, the theefe, the murtherer, the periurer, the bragging Thraſo: yea, and (though it bee certaine, that Dagon cannot ſtand neare the Arke of God,1. Sam. 5, 3, 4 and the Iſraelites bee cōmāded to depart frō the tent of Corah, & to touch nothing of his,Proteſtants do halt betweene two as luke-warme. leaſt they periſh with him: yet) a thouſand of them which go vnder this title, ſhame not to halt between God and Baal, betweene Moſes and Corah, betweene Chriſt and Belial, for their worldly reſpects; and ſo, as it be for their aduantage
and filthie lucre, let their trafficks and dealings be either with the Papiſt, or the Turke, or the Barbarian, or the diuell, they nothing regard; nor remember they what the holy Scripture ſayth vnto the Angell of the Church of the Laodiceans, and to them of that Church, which were neither heat nor cold, Apoc. 3.16.
but luke-warme.

6 Further,A contempt of Religion. they proceede and thinke (ſo farre is impietie encreaſed) that it is lawfull for them to wreaſt all Religion to their owne commodities and gaine: the rather, becauſe the diuel perſwadeth thē, that Religion is nothing elſe but a certaine humane inuention and politike rule of mans wit: and that al the profeſſors of Religion are but ſchollers vnto Numa Pompilius, and vaine triflers,Valer. max. li. 1. ca. 3. as Iulian the Apoſtate in that conceit, wickedly cenſured the Chriſtians, and ſcornefully caſt in their teeth the Croſſe of their maiſter. Therefore,Numa Pompilus a king of the Romanes, who to perſwade the people, faigned that the lawes he gaue them, was by the commandement of the goddeſſe Aegera, with whom he ſaide he had conferenced Iulian the Apoſtate. as they nothing bluſh to reſemble hm (ſcorning them that appeare zealous for their God) ſo handle they the moſt ſacred law of the Lord and the Goſpel, as Neanthus. Neanthus handled the harp of Orpheos, when expecting the trees to dance, he did by his confuſed iangling thereon, cauſe the dogges to barke at him. They argue of Religion, as Pilate. Macchiauile. Pilate did of the Truth, wherof when hee heard Chriſt to ſpeake, he ſaide (after a ſcornefull ſort) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . VVhat thing is truth? & ſo went preſently forth, not vouchſafing to abide the anſwere to his owne queſtion. Such an one was that Macchiauile, who perſwaded men to gouerne in this world, partly by fraud, partly by force, and partly by fortune: and not by the diuine prouidence, whereat hee ieſted: immitating therein, not onely Iulian and thoſe prophane
heathen,Pſal. 115. which ſaid of the Iſraelites, VVhere is now theyr God (making a mocke of theyr religion) but alſo (and that effectually) that cankred Serpent, which hearing that God had forbidden Adam and Heuah the Tree of knowledge of good and euill,Gen. 3. ſcoffed at Gods word, and ſaide: Tuſh, it is nothing ſo: yee ſhall not die, but ye ſhall be as Gods.

7 To be ſhort, there be too many of them that here hence reaſon with the Saduces, that there is neither Angell,Saduces. Act. 23.8. nor ſpirit, nor reſurrection, yea, with that ſenſeleſſe foole, that there is no God, howſoeuer they proteſt:The foole hath ſaid in his heart there is no God. for their liues and conuerſations, theyr wordes and manner of languages decipher the ſame. But if they bee induced to graunt the beeing of GOD, yet imagine they, that God is either of no regarde or deſire, or habilitie, to rewarde vertues with honours, or to defende the oppreſſed from theyr foes in this life, or to giue victorie in battaile, or to puniſh horrible ſinnes with horrible plagues, or elſe, that his mercie is ſo great that he will forgiue men all their ſinnes be they neuer ſo heynous: that hee is a patient rewarder, and will not bee reuenged on them that blaſpheme him moſt bitterly:The hereſie of the Origen • ſts yea, and that (as the Origeniſtes defende) the mercie of God pearceth into hell, ſo farre, that not onely all men both good and badde, but alſo, the very Diuelles and damned Spirits ſhall at length be ſaued. Moreouer, hauing ſuch an vnreuerent opinion of God, and of his holy Religion,They that beleeue not well cannot liue well. they preſume with prophane Senacherib againſt the God of Iſrael: they ceaſe not, but with that atheiſticall Cyclops, (whome Euripides bringeth in) doo rayle againſt all diuine powers,
againſt the Prophets, the Apoſtles, and Chriſt, whome (in an vnſauery compariſon amiddeſt theyr ſcurrilitie and carnal companions) they ioyne with Machomet and the Pope, An vnſauory compariſon. which three they ſay doo trouble the whole worlde. Therefore they ſweare, as though they had no ſoules to bee damned, they liue, as though they were very diuelles incarnate; neither is there any villanie and wickedneſſe, which they will bluſh to perpetrate and committe, without all feare of God or reuerence of man. What eares can but glow to heare this? what eyes can abide to ſee it? Howbeit, in deſpight of Gods iudgements, and in contempt of all men that yerne at theyr vngodlyneſſe, Sap. 2.6.7. they endeuour to cheere themſelues with themſelues, and with them that ſayde: Lette vs enioy the pleaſures that are preſent: Let vs fill our ſelues with good VVine and Oyntment: lette there no Flower of the time eſcape vs: let vs Crowne our ſelues with Roſe buds before they bee withered: let there be no fayre medow, but our luſt go through it: let euery one of vs bee partakers of our voluptuouſneſſe: lette vs leane ſome token of our pleaſure in euerie place: for that is our portion, Lucillius. and this is onely our lot. Vnto ſuch hayleth that moſt ancient Satyricall Poet of the Romanes, worthily ſcorning them thus: Viuite lurcones, comedones, viuite ventres.
That is,

q.l: O Spendthrifts, Toſpots, Bellygods,
liue ye, be luſtie.

div.p:
So Salomon by an Ironicall ſpeech dirideth the
folly of ſuch fooles: Be merrie thou luſtie ladde, in thy gallant yong dayes: and let thine heart cheere thee in thy youth: and walk in the wayes of thine heart: and according to the luſt of thine eyes. All this is moſt pleaſant for ſuch Brutes: but thereunto is added that which ſtriketh them dead. Yet knowe this (ſaith hee) that for all theſe things God will bring thee into iudgement. In the meane time,Reu. 2.22. Luke 16. Virgil. Aeneid. 6. there is for them prepared a lodging with the damned diuell in the burning lake of hell, and there be, which waite daily and hourely to bring them to their bedde, they that may go to their owne place, where burning with Diues, Diſcite Iuſtitiam, moniti, & non te nuere Dinos. & boyling with Phlegyas, they may with the one wiſh for water to coole their tongues, and with the other giue warning to theyr mates, that they learne righteouſneſſe, and not be ſo bold thenceforth, as to contemne God and the Saints. For hither muſt they come, walking as they doo, neither from this place ſhall they be freed either by theyr golde or ſiluer, or by their landes or reuenewes,4. Eſd. 9.12. or by their worldly fauour, ſtrength, wiſedome, and policie.

8 But this they foreſee not, vntill that (indeede) with Diues they feele their remedileſſe miſerie, and with Phlegyas their wretched condition,The vngodly man foreſeeth not his owne deſtruction. & be made rather examples for others, then inſtructions for themſelues.

In this point, they reſemble that fooliſh Ape, which hauing once caught an harpe, twanged thereon, daunced and leapt backwarde on the top of an high houſe, ſo farre, till at the length he ſprang ouer the ſame and brake his necke. So hauing ſome high conceite of themſelues, they little regard either their dutie to God, or their owne miſerable
condition, and thinke not of the danger they fall into through their wicked apoſtacie. Therefore they compaſſe many things and build high Towers on ſundry foundations: with the Gramarians they recount the aduentures of Vliſſes, and the wandrings of Aenaeas: with the Mathematickes, they ſtare on the Sunne, Moone, and Starres, and make fleſhly reaſons for thoſe ſupernall things: howbeit, they haue no reaſon for their own looſe & filthy liues, and wandring wits. The former dayes they much commend, and greedily gape for things future: but the time preſent, with their preſent commodities they waſtefully conſume. To bee breefe, in their owne opinion they be the wiſeſt perſons in the world, and yet, how little foreſight they haue for themſelues, it is eaſily ſeene: when wanting wiſedome, they die the fearefull death. Vnto whom therefore may be aptly applyed the cenſure of Euripides (the which Cicero alſo vſed in the like caſe.)
div.q: Misô ſophiſtèn, ost is'ouch auto ſophòs.

q.l: That Sophiſt hate I, and eſteeme
of wit and wiſedome ſmall:
VVho for himſelfe (in time and place)
hath wiſedome none at all.

div.p:
Such perſons be they! ſo liue they! and ſo die they! But (this notwithſtanding) as the fleſhly Epicure (which differeth nothing from a beaſt, cheefely,The Epicure would be taken for a Philoſopher. in that hee defineth all euill to be in the paine and affliction of this life, and all good to be in voluptuouſneſſe, and worldly, and fleſhly pleaſures) doth
neuertheleſſe take vpon him the perſon of a Philoſopher, and would bee eſteemed indeed: ſo thoſe fleſhly and Atheiſticall perſons, bluſh not to call and entitle themſelues Right Chriſtian Proteſtants, and would be angrie with all them who would not ſo take and eſteeme them. And though their kind of wiſedome be that which belongeth rather to Sophiſters, then well beſeemeth men (as did that of Euclides, whome therefore Socrates woorthily reprooued) yet with moſt impudent faces, they challenge to themſelues the higheſt wiſedome, they vſurpe on the beſt titles,The Romanes eſteemed none honourable but the vertuous, and therefore they builded the Temple of honour, adioyning to the Temple of vertue, with none other way to enter into the temple of honour, but through the Temple of vertue. and would be eſteemed honourable (if they might) though they yet neuer entred the Temple of Honour through the gate of vertue: by as good reaſon may the Aethiopian call himſelfe a right Engliſhman.

9 How neere they approach in theſe poynts vnto him that (though hee be moſt foule and ougly) muſtereth foorth himſelfe as an Angell of Light, any man that hath wiſedome may eaſily diſcerne. With him (therefore) that they bee both reproued, iudged, and condemned, it is iuſt and right in equall cenſure, as ſuch to whome it is ſayde, O yee generation of Vipers, how can ye eſcape the fire of hell.

When the Iewes intitled themſelues the children of Abraham (notwithſtanding, that both in life and Religion they were wicked and abhominable) Saint Iohn the Baptiſt verye ſharpely reprooued them,Mat. 3.9. and ſayde, Bee ye not of ſuch mindes, that yee woulde ſay within your ſelues, wee haue Abraham to our Father. And the Lord himſelfe, ſeeing how much they graded on Abraham, when they
were ſo farre eſtranged from him, and from all holy Religion, to ſtoppe their mouthes he plainely tolde them whoſe Children they were indeede, ſaying vnto them: Yee are from beneath: Againe, Ioh. 8.23.44. Yee are of this world: Againe: Yee are of your Father the Diuell. And this hee prooueth by that they did the deedes of the Diuell, and obſerued his luſts, contemning the worde of GOD, deſpiſing Chriſt Ieſus, louing murther and lying, before loue and trueth, and wallowing in all vngodlineſſe. For indeede when men doo neither well beleeue, nor liue well, and yet woulde bee taken for right Chriſtans, and Chriſtan Proteſtants, what doo they elſe but immitate the Diuell, endeuour to ſlaunder the Croſſe of Chriſt, to prophane Religion, and to anger the Lorde much more, then they doo, which beeing Heathens,Pſal. 50. Ioh. 16. Apoc. 3. doo yet ſo continue and declare themſelues, iuſtly moouing him by his Spirite to reprooue them, and threaten them with eternall damnation?

But lette vs heare what Chryſoſtome ſayth vnto thoſe kinde of peſons,In flor. doctor. and ſo conclude this Chapter. O thou Hypocrite (ſayth hee) If it bee a good thing to be good, why wilt thou only ſhew thy ſelf to be that which in truth thou art not? If it be an euill thing to bee euill, why wilt thou be that, which thou wouldeſt not appeare to be? If it bee a good thing to appeare good, it is better good to bee: If it be an euill thing to appeare euill, it is worſt euill to bee. Therefore either ſhew thy ſelfe that which indeede thou art: or elſe be thou that, which thou wouldſt ſhew thy ſelfe to be. Thus ſhuld men make the tree good and the fruit good, ſhew their fayth out
of their workes, and by a good life declare themſelues the Seruants of Chriſt: Neither ſhould the diuell and this Angels either be found in Heauen, or preſume to ſhew themſelues as Angels of light, either in the Church, or in the Chriſtian-Commonwealth.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
An inſtruction for all Chriſtians. A Caueat for Engliſhmen.
div.p:
Ier. 9.1. The godly haue cauſe to mourne.
OH, that mine head were full of water, and mine eies a fountaine of teares, that I might weepe day and night for the future miſeries of my people! For men haue ſo little conſideration, from whome euerie good thing commeth, that they haue quite forgotten that wonderful deliuerance of the little Citie from the ſiege and tyrannie of that mightie King, and all other notable benefits that the Lord hath in his mercie done for them and their fathers. Wherein they reſemble the olde Iſraelites, whoſe vnkindneſſe and rebellion Moſes iuſtly reproued: and thoſe Iſraelites whom Dauid, Deut. 32. Pſal. 106. Iſa. 1. & 5. Hiſ 6. & 7.
Iſayah, Hoſeah & other prophets haue worthily blamed for their ingratitude to the Lorde, and thoſe Iewes whom Chriſt both vpbraided and threatened: with whom alſo, without ſpeedie repentance, they ſhall be caſt out: for like ſinners, haue commonly like plagues and puniſhments. Theſe things if men had the grace and wiſedome to conſider, they would not forſake the
pure fountain of the water of life, which hath thus long ſuſtained them, and ſound the corrupt puddles of vngodlineſſe which poyſoned them, they would not ſo neglect the things that appertain to the kingdome of God, and bend their braines to the wretched things of the worlde, in the which they finde nothing elſe but vanities: they woulde not anie longer blaſpheme with the theefe on the left hand, and ſo forgo the chiefe good: but rather they would, with him on the right hande, confeſſe the innocencie of Chriſt, and their owne guiltineſſe, and ſay, Lord remember vs: they would not wander in the broad way to death, but ſtriue to walke wiſelie in the right and perfect way to eternall life: but their talking, their walking, their ſinnes, their tranſgreſsions, their abhominations, argue their want of wiſedome and grace, and decipher their looſe religion.

2 Such groſſe inormities of the men of yore, occaſioned Lucian to taunt at them: Democrite to laugh at them: Heraclite to bewaile them: and a certaine man thus to exclaime on them: Oh good Lord!Rich. de ſanc. victorie. what great paines men endure to ſeeke after vertue, yet not in vertue, but in vanitie: they haue found out that which they hunted for: yet not for vertue, but for vanitie: and that which is most miſerable, in the wordes of life, they procure the paines of death! So doo they buſie and vexe themſelues (indeed) without any profit at all, when they walke on in their vanities, & prouoke the Lord to anger, who (without their heartie repentance) will ſhortly declare the ſame to their great grief and miſerie,Pſal. 50. but chiefely to the wo and ſorrow of them which had taken the word of God in their mouths,
and intituled themſelues Chriſtians, and yet haue nothing regarded to be by the ſame reformed accordinglie:Vnder theſe pretences, mē ſpoile and take one from another vniuſtlie. of them that haue ſaide, Lord, Lord, but haue not done any thing acceptable to the Lord: of them that haue cried, The Temple of God, the Temple of God, and wee bee the Lordes, in whoſe quarrell wee fight, whoſe cauſe wee defende, whoſe enemies we throwe downe: but yet haue not waſhed their handes from crueltie, and murther: from piracie and theft: from briberie and extortion: from vſurie and tyrannie: frō ſtrife and enuying: from gluttonie and drunkennes: from luſt and lecherie: from ſwearing and periurie: from ſinne and iniquitie: for theſe doth the Lorde ſeuerelie reprooue and condemne without reſcue or deliuerie in all ages. Neither dooth anie thing more prouoke the Lorde of Heauen to high anger,Apoſtacie is a moſt daungerous ſinne. Eſay. 5.5.7. then the degeneration and backeſliding of them that ſometimes reſembled the godly in pietie, and vertue. As hee is moſt pleaſed with them that walke in his holy wayes with faith and good conſciences, and is gracious vnto them, & glad of their creation, and of al his benefits on them beſtowed: ſo is he touched with ſorrow and griefe of heart, when he ſeeth them which haue earſt giuen a glorious ſhew of holines, to walk at lēgth in their own waies eſtranging themſelues from God, and al godlineſſe.

3 Though God when he ſaw the great wickednes of the generation of Cain,
Gen. 6. The degeneration of the ſons of Seth. (in the firſt age of the world) ſuffred them to run after their owne imaginations, for a verie long time: yet, when he perceiued that the ſonnes of Seth alſo (which had ſometimes reſembled the piety of their parents, to whom the promiſe of the bleſſed ſeede was made, which
were men that knew God, of the true Church,Aben Eſra. and called the ſonnes of God) did fall from God into fleſhly pleaſures, tyrannies, idolatries, and other heinous vices, and grew therein like vnto the children of men: yea, and that of the ſonnes of God, they were (by Apoſtacie) made the ſonnes of Sathan: then (then I ſay) the Lorde was highly mooued to diſpleaſure, ſo much, that in his anger hee determined to deſtroy thoſe ſinners vtterly frō off the earth, and the ſame determinatiō he effected accordingly.

The Scriptures report, that the Lord (vpon this occaſion) VVas touched with ſuch ſorrow, God repented that he had made man. that he repented that he had made man on the earth: that is to ſay: his Spirit in the hearts of the godlie, prouoked them to mourne and ſigh, to beholde mans vngodlineſſe. Noah, being a righteous man, hauing the Spirit of God, and ſeeing the great wickednes of man,Noah. he was by the ſame Spirit mooued to wofulneſſe, and The holie Ghost was made ſadde in all the godlie, by meanes of the great malice of man:Epheſ. 4.30 ſo farre that they deſired rather, that man had neuer beene created, then, that by degeneration, he ſhould bee ſo malicious wicked and ſinfull agaynſt God.

4 But what followed this high diſpleaſure?The effect of-Gods Repentance. What was the effect of Gods Repentance? My Spirit (ſayth hee) ſhall not alwayes contend thus in man: I will no longer deliberate, whether I may either deſtroy thoſe vngodly men, or elſe haue ſome pittie, and cōpaſsion vpon them: and foraſmuch as I haue by my ſpirit taught them, & ſcholed thē in godlines, and they be neuer the better, I will not henceforth grant them this benefit of my ſpirit: they ſhal neither
be reproued, nor inſtructed by the ſame any more. I will ſend them a famine of my worde, that they may faint and fall, and not bee able to riſe againe: for they are contrarie to mee in all their wayes, they proceede in their carnall deſires, they ſcorne and deride both mee and my worde, and contemne all good admonitions: they hate and perſecute my ſpirit, in them that faithfully teach and preach my worde. It is moſt meete therfore, that I ceaſſe henceforth from doing them any more good, that I giue my ſpirite eaſe, and ſuffer them as moſt rebellious children to periſh from the earth.

Vpon this reſolution the Lord opened the windowes of heauen, & powred down mighty ſtreams of water vpon them: The fountaines of the deepe brake vp alſo, and the floods couered the higheſt hilles. Then loud cries and clamours, then ſorrow, weeping, wailing, and vtter diſpaire on euery ſide: but no deliuerie, no ſafetie, no comfort they find, but are choked in the waters. One man was not able to helpe another, neither the parents their children. Euery one was forced to abide his lot. And this lot was common to all them which were not incloſed with Noah in the Arke. So pleaſed it the Lord by waſhing away ye filthines of their perſons frō the earrh, in their deſtruction, to eaſe himſelf being ſo grieued in his heart. This was the plague that fell on them, that would not honor God,Pſal. 50. when they knew God! O remember this ye that forget God, leaſt he alſo take you hence, and there be none to deliuer you.

An apoſtrophe to • ngliſh men, warning them to beware.5 Now, becauſe that aboue other Nations vnder the Sunne, it hath pleaſed the goodneſſe of our God to adorne and bleſſe thee (O England) with the like
gifts and bleſsings wherewith hee beautified the ſons of Seth, in that firſt age of the worlde▪ and hath not debarred thee from any of thoſe graces wherwith hee adorned Iuda and Hieruſalem, in the time of their peace: hee dooth therefore expect the like thankfulneſſe of thee, as hee looked for of any of them. Which if thou yeeld not to his Grace, but waxing fat, do abuſe thoſe bleſsings, and ſpurne with the heele agaynſt him, and being called to weeping, mourning and repentance, Iſay. 22.12.13. for thoſe thy tranſgreſsions, thou take vp ioy & gladneſſe, ſlaying oxen, and killing ſheepe; eating fleſh, and drinking wine: what els may be expected to come vnto thee, but a moſt heauie iudgement from the Lord? And of this, the Lord doth forewarne vs by blazing ſtars, earthquakes, fierie Dragons: and expreſſeth his diſpleaſure by famines, peſtilences, threats of warres, and ſuch like. It is not thy bare profeſsion that ſhall excuſe thee in the day of thy viſitation (O England) neither ſhall thy often hearing of Sermons,A bare profeſsion helpeth not. nor turning of the leaues of the lawe, nor bearing of the bible in thine hand, nor thy talking of ſcriptures,1. Cor. 10. deliuer thee in the time of Gods vengeance, no more then thoſe former ſinners, nor then the Corinthians were freed, whom Saint Paul warned to beware by the examples of the old Iſraelites which God ouerthrew in the wilderneſſe, if that God be not entreated by thy timely repentance: nor ſhall the often hearing and ruminating of the ſtrange iudgements of God poured vpon other the rebellious people of the old time, & the knowledge of the will of God, profit or preſerue thee from the deſtruction: if thou wilt not be therby thyſelf inſtructed, reformed and
made better. To this purpoſe, this diſtich which Iuſtus Ionas pronounced a little before his death,Mat. Dreſſerus. is worthy to be daily ruminated.

lg.l: Quid iuuat innumeros ſcire, at que euoluere caſus:
Si facienda fugis: ſi fugienda facis?
The dolefull doome of many a wight,
To know, and weigh, what helpes it thee:
If thou neglect that ſhould in right
Be done, and do that ſhould not bee?

div.p: The Lord grant thee grace to looke timely to thy ſelfe,VVe ſhould take inſtruction by former examples and to thine eſtate, and by the conſideration of thoſe auntient plagues which haue in their times ouertaken the vnthankfull, to repent and take heed: ſo happie ſhalt thou be.

6 O England, if thou didſt conſider thine owne vnthankfulneſſe, and therewith wouldeſt weigh how ful of danger thy ſtate ſtandeth, & what mightie plagues awaite to fall on thee, if the Lorde God would permit it, and ſay vnto the ſpirit of trouble, Go:Many and ſundry daungers wayting on England. Eccles. 12.1. Iere. 9. Luke 19. thou wouldeſt deferre no time to repent, thou wouldeſt Remember thy maker in thoſe dayes of thy youth, before the infirmities of olde age ouertake thee: yea, thou wouldeſt weepe for thy ſelfe, and for thy children, rather with Ieremie, and the Lord Ieſus, before thoſe times of trouble come, thē with the fooliſh daughters of Hieruſalem, when it is all too late. If thou wouldeſt applie the examples of yore, vnto the times preſent, and therof learne wiſedome (as Moſes wiſhed the Iſraelites to do) thou wouldeſt then bee more fearefull, and aſhamed to follow the luſt of thine own heart any longer: thou wouldeſt not truſt
to thine owne ſtrength, nor preſume (in thy ſins) ſo far on Gods goodnes: nor wouldeſt thou put conſidence in vnrighteous Māmon, nor conſent to be led away with euery winde of doctrine, nor make ſo long tarying to turne to the Lord thy God: but thou wouldſt rather ſpeedily iudge thy ſelf, to eſcape the iudgement of God: condemne thy ſelfe, to be freed from the ſentence of Gods iuſtice: thou wouldeſt caſt thy pride down on the earth, rent thy beautifull haire, & without delay turne to ye Lord with faſting weeping & praier. And thus except thou do in ſpirit and truth, thy fall, thy diſhonor, thy ſhame, and thy execration will be horrible, to the dread of all other Nations, for all thy ſinnes, the which the Lorde in mercie forbid.

7 Surely, thou haſt great cauſe to feare (O England) leaſt whē it ſhal pleaſe god (for thine vnthankfulneſſe) to take to himſelf frō ouer thee the life and gouernmēt of our moſt gracious ſoueraigne Queen Elizabeth (whoſe life & gouernment the Lord God in his mercy yet prolong & lengthen (if it may be) to to the daies and yeres of Methuſalah,) that then, thou ſuddenly feele the paine of thy ſins and deſerued miſeries. For the Lord hath ſufficiently warned vs alreadie of ſuch things by ſo many arguments, as we cannot thereof plead ignorance: & that he hath ſuch a work to be done (without thy repentāce) as ye ears of ſo many as heare therof ſhal ſurely glow: and this work is deferred but vnto the appointed time.2. Kin. 20.19. and 22.19 20. Iudit. 16.30. The God of mercy with held the execution of his iudgemēt frō Iuda (according to his promiſe) during ye life time of Hezekiab: & he ſpared the ſame in al the daies of Ioſiah: neither ſuffred he any man to trouble Iſrael
ſo long as the widow Iudith liued: nor would hee caſt downe the fire on Sodom,
Gen. 19.22. Gen. 7.10. vntill Lot was departed out of Sodom: nor did hee powre downe the waters on the wicked world, before that Moah was embarked in his Arke. And who knoweth whether that the ſame Lord hath made this merciful promiſe and couenāt with our right Chriſtian Princeſſe, and with thoſe his faithfull ones in the land (which are by her grace aided, prouided for & defended within this realme, in the name of the diſciples of Chriſt) that he will not alienate the ſame from his delight in her, and their dayes? As his arme is not ſhortned, but that hee will helpe his elect that call vpon him ſo is not the ſame ſo weake, but moſt able to deſtroy his foes, and caſt them downe to hell that diſhonour him.

Note this.8 Therefore (I ſay againe) let vs not flatter our ſelues: bee ſure of this, that if thou continue careleſſe and ingratefull, and imagine him to bee well pleaſed with thee, becauſe hee ſuffereth thee, and dooth not charge thee with follie, but ſeemeth to paſſe it ouer by long ſilence, and ſo thou ad vnto thy former tranſgreſsions, a thouſand more, without remorſe of conſcience, and dreade of Gods iudgements: hee will (in the time of wrath) bring euill vpon thee, and then, hee who was before ſo flowe to anger, will appeare to bee of great might, and ſuch an one, as will in no wiſe holde thee excuſed in thy ſinnes: hee will not winke anie longer at thy pride, thy common ſwearing, thy periurie, thine erreuerēt talking, thy lying, thy ſtealing, thy killing, thine whoring, thine halting, thine hypocriſie, thy prophanation of the Lordes day, thine
Idolatries, thy diſſimulation thy diſcontented mind, thy murmuring mouth, thy ſlaundring tongue, and all other thine abhominations and ſins,Iſay. 21.10. Ier. 25.31. Pſal. 50. which thou haſt wrought and committed, againſt his maieſtie, againſt his Saints, and againſt thine owne health, peace, and proſperitie:Pſal. 2. Prou. 1. but ſeeing that then thou doeſt belong to the Lords corne flower to be threſhed, he himſelfe will ſommon thee to his Court of Iuſtice, in iudgement hee will commence ſuite againſt thee, he will contende with thee, hee will trie out thy ſins, and ſet them in order before thee: he will condemne thee for the ſame, & all to threſh thee, except thou repent. Pſal. 107.34 He that maketh the fruitfull lande barren for the wickedneſſe of them that dwell therin, will force thee to mourne,Hoſ. 4. will cauſe thee to be troubled, to be endangred of thy plentie and peace, except thou repent. Thy people ſhall periſh, thy cattell ſhall be diminiſhed: the ſoules of the ayre, the fiſhes of the ſea, ſhall bee taken away, and euery calamitie ſhal ouertake thee except thou repent. Thy life ſhall euer hang in ſuſpence before thine enemies, as the liues of thy neighbours, and thine heart aking for anguiſh, ſhall in the morning deſire the euening, & in the euening deſire the morning, except thou repent. Gen. 42.21. Neither ſhall thy conſcience denie, but confeſſe with Iacobs ſinnes in Egypt, Verely we haue ſinned againſt our brother, &c. and therefore is this trouble come vpon vs. And others that behold thy trouble ſhall ſay (as Baruch did to Iſrael) If thou haddeſt walked in the way of God truely,
Bar. 3.13.4. thou ſhouldeſt haue dwelled ſtill ſafe in thine owne land. But lo, they that liued ſo delicately, do nowe periſh in the ſtreetes: O learne then where is wiſedome, Lam, 4.5.
where vertue
is, when vnderſtanding is: that thou maiſt know alſo from whence commeth long continuance, and life, the light of thine eyes and quietneſſe.
Iſa. 55.6. Hoſ. 14.2. Returne yee then vnto the Lord your God, for ye are fallen by iniquitie. Take vnto your words, and ſay vnto him: Take away all our iniquities and receiue vs graciouſly. Why wil ye die? Repent, repent, repent, and ye ſhall ſurely liue (ſaith the Lorde of hoaſts) elſe will I make lamentation ouer you, as I beganne, and ye ſhall not be able to comfort me.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
There is no ſtate or condition of man free of his Croſſes and troubles in this life. Of the Prince. Of the magiſtrate. And the diſcontentation of thoſe high ſtates.
div.p:
Euery man is forced to beare his Croſſe. NOW, if (beſides theſe generall greefes) the condition of euerie particular man in his ſeuerall vocation bee duely conſidered, it will ſoone appeare, what mightie obſtacles and ſtrong cords of vanitie there bee caſt abroad (as the ſnares of the enemie) to catch and draw men frō of their places and dutie of life. And that, as ye latter age of man is weaker, & ſo leſſe apt to vertue: & that in this infirme age do encreaſe vices, ſlothfulnes, loue and pleaſure, eaſines of the mind, impatiēce, inconſtancie, perfidie, fooliſhneſſe,
The infirmity of this laſt age.
Iſay. 24.4. as thoſe that dote, do perſwade themſelues to bee wiſe men: ſo ſuch is this laſt age of the the world, wherin both in Churches, & in the cō mon-wealth, are moued vp great troubles, to hinder mens particular vocations or callings. Therfore we muſt pray, and euery man in his place and function,
ought to pray with Dauid, Caſt me not away in the time of mine old age: forſake me not when my ſtrength faileth me. Howbeit, Pſal. 71.8.16, al this the ignorant man knoweth not: the vnwiſe man conſidereth it not: the foole doth not heedfully preuent theſe dangers & imminent inconueniences:Onely the wiſe man, conſidereth theſe things. and therfore as blindfold he is heedleſſe carried away and caſt into manifold miſeries through the ſubtile ſeducer, & the guilefull vanities of this world, to his ignomie and perpetuall confuſion. But the wiſe man, ye man of knowledge, he whoſe eyes be fixed in his head (as Salomon ſaith) knoweth well that theſe be the common maladies, & ordinarie miſeries of mans vaine life. He ſeeth the maleuolēt diſpoſitions of mans inuentions, and the hard changes & chances of al age, ſeaſōs and times. And this mā only paſſeth ſafe throgh thoſe perilous aduenturs, with a due regard of his calling & place: yet not without many vnſpeakable vexations and cares, verifying that ſaying: The more wiſedom, the more greefe.

2 The moſt worthie and good Prince,The good Prince is not without his coraſiue. that doth many times watch to prouide for the ſafetie of his people, euen then, whiles they ſoundly ſleepe (as King Phillip of Macedonia, by the report of Parmenio did) and thoſe Princes that haue made the Cities Marble, which they found builded but with bricke, (as Auguſtus ſaid that he had made the citie of Rome) and they yt haue reſtored liberty & freedom to them which were thrals & in bōdage, & fought for them, defended and ruled them, as Moſes, and Gedeon, and Samuel, and Samſon, and Iiptha, and Othoniel, & Dauid, haue in their times don, performing ye ſafety & good of their people, before their owne liues, and haue
deſerued therby to be called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 herds of the people,Homer. fathers, ſauiours, keepers of the Countrey: yea, beneficiall and earthly gods vnto men. Theſe (I ſay) do meete with and finde out (after all theyr watchfull regardes) moſt ingratefull people, and ſuch, who, when they ſhould in all honeſtie confeſſe thoſe of whom they haue receiued profite (as Plynye wrote to Veſpaſian) doo neuertheleſſe ſcarce acknowledge any benefit at all and yeeld them nothing elſe, but hatefull vnkindeneſſe for recompence of all the good. The moſt of all men in the world, regarde not to immitate thoſe ancient gratefull and golden men, who (as it is ſayde) inuented the three 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or Graces: nor haue they any care to learne,Sen. de ben. ca. 3. Alceat Emb. 163. to and for what ende or purpoſe they inuented them. This conſidered Pindare in his time, when he wrote thus:
Thus are the Graces luld a ſheepe,
and thankfulneſſe is quenched:
For men, vnmindfull of good turnes,
in Lethes lake are drenched.

The vertues of good princes be not conſidered of the ingrateful people.3 There be fewe which haue the grace to conſider this, that, thoſe noble men beeing in place of Gouernment, where (hauing the reynes at libertie) they might haue ſpoyled the Common-wealth, as Nero did, they haue notwithſtanding that, aduentured theyr credit, their wealth, their liues and all, for the ſafetie and good of other men: that they haue taken on them the care and regard not onely of themſelues and of a priuate houſe, but alſo of the Empire or Kingdome, and haue ordred the
whole nation according to the iuſtice and equitie of a Prince. Wherin Salomons ſpectacle is rightly verified, Eccleſ. 9. That no body thought on that man by whoſe wiſedome the Citie was deliuered from the power of the mightie King which had beſieged it. And ſurely, this beeing applyed to the caſe of the wiſe Prince and the ingratefull people, thus importeth in effect. I haue ſeene vnder the Sunne a certain King, who in his gouernment neuer oppreſſed any man by the abuſe of his authoritie: yt iudged betweene man and man without reſpect of perſons: that defēded ſtrangers, pupils, & widowes: ye duly puniſhed theeues and adulterers: that aduaunced not the wicked, nor maintained impudent & vaine perſons: that rooted out vngodly men, & ſpared not murtherers, nor permitted periurers to liue in the Common-wealth: that defended the Church, and relieued the poore people: that placed ouer the affaires of his kingdom righteous men, & had a cheefe regard of moſt ancient, wiſe, graue, and ſober men for his Counſellers: that neuer liſtned to the ſuperſtitions of Witches, Sorcerers, Charmers, Southſaires, and Pithoniſſes: that baniſhed from his preſence, adulterers, flatterers, back-biters, and ſlaunderers: that by wiſedome knowing God & himſelfe, had power to bridle his owne affections, to deferre his diſpleaſure, & to rule himſelf & his family:For his good he hath a baſe reward. that had moſt valiantly defended his Countrey from the forraigne mightie aduerſaries, and had dedicated himſelfe to the right worſhip of God. Yet behold, he hath not bin gratefully requited,Iudg. 8.35. nor in any ſort honoured of his people, according to thoſe his demerites.

4 Yea, I haue ſeene, that a certaine Prince was
choſen by the Lord of heauen to raigne ouer his people,Deut. 17. & to rule them: he neuer multipled horſes to himſelfe, nor purpoſe to bring the people into Egypt, againe: neither did he multiplie Wiues, nor put his truſt in ſiluer and gold: neither did his heart ariſe aboue his brethren: nor turned he from the commandement of the Lord his God, to the right hand or to the left. But, he did write out a copie of the law booke, and did reade therein all the daies of his life, that he might thereby learne to feare the Lord his God, 2. King. 1.6. and to keepe all the words of his law for to do them: according to that deſire of his heart in his prayer to the Lord. And thereby hath bin (of the goodneſſe of God) vnto his people, as an hiding place from the wind,
Iſa. 32.1. & as a refuge for the tempeſt: as riuers of waters in a drie place, and as the ſhadow of a great Rocke in a drie land▪ & gouerned them after the rule of righteouſneſſe, and according to the ballance of equitie. Yet all this notwithſtanding,Senec. in Hercul. he findeth the people ingratum genus, ingratefull towards him, and forgetfull of all: yea, they recompence with euill, for al his great good, to the great greefe of his heart. This is the onely reward which ſuch noble Princes and godly men are to expect of the vnthankfull world, after ſo many Princely vertues and benefits.

5 Abraham, Noah, Moſes, Ioſeph, Samuel, Dauid, and ſuch like, which right well know how to beare this heauie burthen, haue yet continued their places, haue done their dutie, and walked in ye way of the Lord (maugre the malice of the maligne world) howbeit it is true inough, and a thing too often tryed by daylie experience, that a ſlaunderous or ingratefull perſon deſtroyeth a liberall heart, Eccleſ. 7.8.
and be ſotteth many
wiſe men. Such kind of requitals do often diſcourage the good Prince, cauſing him vnwilling to perform his dutie in his place.Many haue beene vnable to beare thoſe burdens. Philip of Macedonia. Neither haue ye moſt part bin able to digeſt theſe and ſuch like morſels: as namely, that the father of Alexander, (notwithſtanding his place, his wiſdom, his dignitie, his renowne, and all the noble aduentures hee had taken for the good of his kingdome) was ſlaine in a publike triumph his Princes & attēdants looking on the ſame. That the valiant Iulius Caeſar (who had atchieued ſo many famous victories and high benefits for the Romanes, and after the ciuill wars ended, had ſhewed to his enemies great mercifulneſſe, and to his friends large bountie, and had left nothing vndone of that which might haue purchaſed to himſelfe beneuolence, fauour, authoritie, and rule, among the Romanes) he was for all that, moſt cowardly murthered among them in the Senate houſe,Iulius Caeſar was cowardly murthered. through the conſpiracie of Brutus and Caſſius, his own moſt familiar friends, whom aboue all others, he had moſt ſingularly enriched with large benefits.

And that alſo the Emperours Tiberius, Druſus, Henry 7. of Germany, and King Iohn of England, The ſorrowful ends of many Emperours and Kings. were poiſoned to death: that Valerianus was ſhut vp in priſon, where hee dyed miſerably: that Scipio was killed by them of his houſe: that Richard the ſecond, Edward the 5. Henrie the 6, Kings of England, and the Emperour Commodus were murthered: that Carinus and Numerianus both Kaeſares, wretchedly ended theyr liues: and that noble Pompey, Pompey. who had atchieued ſo many goodly enterpriſes, profitable to his countrey, for wordly glory happy, for his vertues a mirror to many princes: and had reſtored the
yong king Ptolomy of Egypt to his kingdom, he was at the length conſtrained to flie into Egypt, where he was moſt butcherly killed of the ſame king, and with ſuch beaſtly ingratitude requited. Finally, it hath much yerked many of them, when they haue conſidered how many noble Princes & Captaines of the Romanes, the Athenians, the Lacedemonians, of the Iſraelites, of the Engliſh-men, of the French-men, and other famous Monarches haue founde the like rewards of ſuch ingratefull people, who haue ouercharged them in their times with many partiall cenſures, murmurings, grudgings, rebellions, trecheries, torments, and death. In the conſideration whereof, they haue meaſured theyr places both dangerous, and full of difficultie and feare.Dioniſe ſhewelth to Democes the danger of the regall ſtate. This thing Dioniſius of Syracuſae, being thereof experienced, would pretily declare vnto his friend Democles, when entertaining him very magnificently and Princely at his table, he cauſed a ſharp ſword to be hanged ouer his head by a ſmal haire or threed, with the poynt threof downeward. Wherat Democles, notwithſtanding his princely fare & like cheerings, was ſtriken with a moſt horrible feare, and deſired in all the haſte to bee dimiſſed from the Table.The troubles and the dangers of of gouernment haue tyred out, and made many men fearefull. Charles 5. King Iewe, King Cadwallader. Graft. pag. 127.

6 The conſideration of theſe and ſuch like ſpectacles, hath occaſioned ſome of them, rather Heliogabalus to dedicate themſelues to idleneſſe, ſenſualitie, and vaine worldly pleaſures, which in yong men is fooliſhneſſe, and in old men abhomination, then to the right ditties of their vocations. Some with the Emperour Charles 5. and with King Iewe, and King Cadwallader of the Britaines, haue wiſhed
to reſigne their royaltie, thereby to bee quiet from ſuch daungerous troubles. Some haue with Pompey, Pompey. thought it much better for them to be borne poore mens children, and to lead their liues quietly in the countrey, then to be made thrals in and by ſuch preferments, to ſo many and ſo great vexations. Ardentius thought it wiſdome, and much eaſe for himſelf,Ardentius. to denie to ſucceede Antonius in the Empire. The Marques of Meſſena, Marques of Meſſena. Edward the third. and king Edward the third of England, vpon the offer of the Empire vnto them, haue both moſt willingly refuſed to mount the monſter with ſo manie heads, whereon they might haue beene oppoſed to many ſtrong enemies, and beene made ſubiect to many ſtrokes of bitter torment.Diocleſian. Diocleſian ſaide to one which gaue him counſaile to returne againe to the Empire (after hee had choſen to toile in the Garden, as a Gardiner) that ſeeing he was deliuered ſafely from the plague, he would not drinke poyſon againe.

Theſe (as it ſeemeth) reſolued with Ammian, Ammian. that this kinde of preferment is nought elſe, but the care of an other mans ſafetie: with Antiochus, Antiochus. that it is but a noble thraldome, and with Agamemnon, Agamemnon that Princes are but the peoples ſeruaunts, howe ſoeuer they appeare in ſtate, might, and magnificence. This matter Ioathan intendeth,Ioathan in Iudg. 9.7.8.9.10. by the riddle of the trees of the wood, that went forth to chooſe them a King, when the Figge tree, the Vine, and the Oliue tree, refuſed that, which the Bramble willingly accepted. Demosthenes ſayde,Demoſthenes that he for his owne part, would not ſtoope to the ground to take vp the crowne of a Kingdome: and Antisthenes ſaid, that if two wayes were to him propoſed,
the one to a priuate life, the other to the place of gouernment, hee would rather chooſe the priuate life. Alluding to that ſentence of the wiſe man, The mightie ſhall haue mightie torments.

The Magiſtrates are tormented with many afflictions. Exod. 18.21.7 Moreouer, the worthy Magiſtrates of the Cō mon wealth, which in their places repreſent the roiall perſons of their Princes, and endeuor to obſerue their duties, being (indeed) men of courage, fearing God, dealing truly, & hating couetouſneſſe, according to that rule of Iethro, which gaue Moſes coūſell to ordaine Iudges vnder him: when theſe (I ſay) cō ſider what Salomon ſaith touching ye danger of their places, and vnkindneſſe of them whom they ſhall benefit:Eccles. 10.8, 9. (He that breaketh vp an hedge, ſhal be bitten of a Serpent: he that moueth ſtones, ſhall hurt himſelfe thereby: he that cleaueth wood, ſhall thereby annoy himſelfe:) they haue no meane cauſe of diſcouragement: and when they haue proued it in this, that nothing beſides iniurious vexations of one towards another, and tedious quarels of perſons troubleſome, be preſented vnto them: and that, when they haue done wel, and as the place, the perſons, and cauſe require, they bee partially cenſured, controlled, and many wayes indangered and iniured; they haue bin moued to yrke with him in Terence, Noſtri noſmet poenitet. But when vnto all theſe things is added the ſuperiour diſpleaſure, without any iuſt deſert, and calling to minde, what hard fare that noble Seneca found vnder Nero, Seneca. Papinianus. Clytus. Shatilion, the Admirall of France. and Papinianus vnder Anthonius, and Clytus vnder Alexander, and Iaſper Caligne Shatilion, vnder the French king, to whom although they had bin moſt faithfull and wiſe Counſailours, they were neuertheleſſe vpon ſudden and ſmall diſpleaſures, diſgraced
graced and murthered: they are pearced with a ſore terrour, and holde not onely their places, but alſo their liues, both ſuſpenſiue and loathſome to themſelues. Whereupon many haue more labored to be ſetled on lower ground, then to climbe the pinacle or turret ſo full of perils.

8 This thing Seneca Papinianus, and Shatilion did ſee, and therefore they would gladly haue renounced their power, offices, and places, and haue betaken themſelues to a life ſolitarie, and more ſafe: yea,S. Thom. in Boeth. de conſol. Philo. li. 3. Proſ. 5.
Seneca (for his part) offred to employ and beſtow all his goods and riches, to the vſe and benefit of the Emperour, therby to haue purchaſed his manumiſſion and libertie, which yet hee could not obtaine, vntill his painefull life was cut off by an iniurious death. Thus alſo Themiſtocles among the Athenians, and Lucullus among the Komanes haue beene verie deſirous to exchaunge their publike places for a life priuate, and more free from emulation. Demosthenes reſolued, that better it is, for him which is depoſed of ſuch a gouernment or office, to die then to bee readuaunced. Aeſchines is verie glad, that hee is deliuered from an office, which hee tearmeth a madde dogge. Timon woulde rather bee called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , A contemner of the ſocietie and fellowſhippe of men, then to ſerue other mens turnes in ſuch an vnthankefull and troubleſome place.

Socrates eſteemed vacant time of leiſure, one of the beſt of all the poſſeſsions of the world, meaning, that to be free and quiet from ſuch cumbrous buſineſſe, and the vexations of publike affaires, and from ſuch appetites as trouble the tranquilitie of
the mind, is no menae treaſure. This thing Themiſtocles, Phociā, Demoſthenes, Ariſtides, Cicero, Salpitius, Marius, Boethius, and many others, ſome Greekes, ſome Romans, ſome Iewes, ſome chriſtians, ſome Barbarians, haue alſo too wel approued, & haue acknowledged and confeſſed it, in the ſorrowfull ſenſe of the ſame. This conſideration (no doubt) pearced the mind of Barzellai, Barzillai. 2. Sam. 19.37 when he refuſed to be aduanced by King Dauid, which offred him no meane preferment:Sunemite. 2. King. 4.13. and this moued the wiſe Sunemite, to deſire rather to inhabit amongſt her owne people (with a cōtented mind) then to be ſpoken for vnto the king, when as Eliſha the Prophet would haue done her that pleaſure.Graft. pag. 123. Chron. And hereof was it, that Benet the maiſter of Beda, who diſcended of rich kinred, and was in high fauor with Oſwye king of Britain, did forſake both the kings court, and his owne houſe, & all that he had, and became a Monke. The Chronicles and Hiſtories of the former ages, are not without manie ſuch examples. And a great many noble and wiſe perſonages that preſently liue in the worlde, are not freed from the hard experiment of this thing.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
The troubles and afflictions of the Miniſter, of the houſholholder, of the Schoolemaiſter, of the Scribe, and of other faculties and conditions of men.
div.p:
The paſtour his troubles. THe faithfull Paſtour and Miniſter in the Church, is for his part daylie perplexed & troubled with a mountaine of griefes and heauie woes: for whoſoeuer he bee that takes on him
the miniſterie of the worde, and preaching of the Goſpel (by the Lords authoritie) hee is ſet as it were in an open battaile, and hath foorthwith the Diuell, and the worlde aduerſaties vnto him, and profeſſed enemies, which endeuour to hinder and hurt him with all their power, and pollicies. The Diuell daily watcheth him,The practiſe of the diuell againſt the Miniſters. obſerueth his doctrine, and noteth his life, which hee couetteth to enſnare. He aſſaileth his life and conuerſation, that ſo hee might mooue him to denie in worke, that which in worde hee profeſſeth and teacheth: that ſo, though hee builde with the one hand, he might with the other hande, pull downe and deſtroy: for manie men, eſpecially the ignorant and common people, immitate and follow, rather the life and conditions of the Miniſters and teachers, then their wordes and doctrine. He aſſaulteth his doctrine alſo, that ſuch as heare him, beeing by errours deceiued and ſeduced, may togither with him bee damned, as when the blinde leadeth the blinde, they both fall into the pitte. And that hee might the better compaſſe that which he hath deuiſed agaynſt the ſeruaunts of God,The world is an enemie to the Miniſters of the worde. hee mooueth the worlde in the which hee dwelleth and rageth, which beeing ſet on miſchiefe (as Saint Iohn ſayeth) ſtrugleth and ſtriueth agaynſt him, I meane the Miniſter and his doctrine, ſometimes by Hypocriſie, ſometimes by Sophiſtrie, ſometimes by tyrannie, endeuouring to hinder him and enforce him to denie his profeſsion. To the which, though he bring the glad tidings of peace,Iſay. 53.1. who calleth him happie? though hee preach the truth, and publiſh the miſteries of God, who beleeueth his report?
he talketh, who heareth him? he walketh, who followeth him? he pipeth vnto the people, and they daunce not: hee ſorroweth, and they mourne not. He hath giuen none offence in anything, that the miniſterie be not blamed:1. Tim. 3.2. but he is blameleſſe, the husband of one wife, watching, ſober, comelie apparelled, a louer of hoſpitalitie, apt to teach, not giuen to ouermuch wine, no ſtriker, nor greedie of filthie lucre: but gentle, abhorring fighting, abhorring couetouſneſſe, one that ruleth well his owne houſe, hauing children in ſubiection, with all grauitie, &c. And yet his patience is tried by them of the worlde to the vttermoſt, in afflictions, in neceſſities,2. Cor. 2.6. in anguiſhes, in ſtripes, in priſonments, in ſtrifes, in labours, in watchings, in faſtings, in colde and nakedneſſe, in iourneying often, in perils of waters, in perils of robbers, in perils of his own nation, in perils among the heathen, in perils in the citie, in perils in the wilderneſſe, in perils among falſe brethren, in torments, in death.

2 And in all theſe hard aduentures, whiles he deſerueth a good report, hee getteth an euill report: though he be true, yet is he taken for a deceiuer: he is ſcarcely knowne to his own acquaintance, though he hath bin moſt bountifull vnto them: he is as dying daily, though not killed: he is very poor, though hee enricheth manie; and though by ruling well, and labouring both in the worde and doctrine, hee hath merited that double honour which the Apoſtle ſayeth is vnto ſuch perſons due: yet hath hee no honour at all. Hee hath well deſerued of all men: but of all men hee is badlie rewarded. Thus Amos the Prophette was accuſed
and reprooued. Michea was impriſoned:The Prophets and Martyrs haue bin hardly rewarded for their labours. Zacharias was murthered: Ieremie was caſt downe into a deepe Dungeon, and his feete made faſt in the ſtockes: Iſaiah was cut a ſunder with a Sawe: Eliah was threatned and perſecuted: Ezechiel had bands for him prepared: and Daniel was throwne into the Lions Denne. Chriſt Ieſus our Lorde and Sauiour himſelfe, though hee came into the worlde, not to condemne the worlde, but that the worlde through him might bee ſaued: yet his owne receiued him not, the darkneſſe comprehended him not, the worlde knewe him not: he bound the ſtrong man, and deliuered them that were captiued: yet no man thought vpon him: he was perſecuted, taken, crucified, and reiected. So his Ambaſſadour Iohn Baptist was beheaded: his Apoſtles, Iames, Peter, and Paul, were killed. Alſo his Martyr Stephen was ſtoned to death: Iohn the Euangeliſt was baniſhed: Ireneus, and Policarpus, were martyred: ſo was Laurentius, Iohn Hus, Hierome of Prage, VVicliffe, Ridley, Cranmer, Latimer, Bradford, Tindall, with a thouſande others, which haue beene tried by mockinges and ſcourginges, yea, and moreouer, by bandes, and impriſonment: they were ſtoned, they were hewen aſunder, they were tempted, they were ſlaine with the ſworde, burned in the fire, Heb. 11.38. VVorld is not worthie of good men. afflicted and tormented moſt cruellie, of whome indeede The worlde was nothing worthie, as the Apoſtle ſayeth. So thankleſſe is this office: ſuch is the rewarde of the painfull preaching of the Goſpel, and for labouring hardlie in the Lords harueſt, which the worlde is moſt readie at all times to beſtow. Manie there bee that
cleaue vnto the painfull miniſter fainedly: Dan. 11.34. few there be which ioyne themſelues with him in truth and ſinceritie:Homer. wherein they find this verified: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Benefits beſtowed haue not ſo much as thanks.

A dangerous matter to deal with Princes and great perſons.3 But as it is no meane matter for him to deale in his miniſterie with the common people, to perſwade them to the feare of God, and honour of the Prince, and ſo to liue in Chriſtian Contentation, being as thoſe with whome Ieremie had to do, poore, fooliſh, Iere. 5.4.5. ignoraunt of the way of the Lord, and the iudgement of their God: ſo is their no ſmall wiſedome to bee had in the perſwading of the Princes and great perſonages, to admit the worde of God: for their eares bee ſo tender (as one ſayde) that they can ſcarcelie ſuffer any truth to touch them.P. Mart. 1. 1. King. 20. Therefore, though Ieremie ſay, I will get me vnto the great men, and will ſpeake vnto them: for they haue knowne the way of the Lorde, and the iudgements of their God: yet finding them to bee breakers of the yoake, it ſhall bee booteleſſe for him to commit himſelfe vnto them: Amos 7.10. and ſo is it for Amos to go to the Court, and to preach in the Kings Chappell, except hee can handle his matter with rare wiſedome, and ſingular dexteritie. Yea, Nathan being ſent from God to Dauid the King, dareth not to approach neare the preſence of the King, but with ſuch a Parrable in his mouth, as manie men haue neither the witte to inuent, nor the grace to applie. Chriſt himſelfe vppon this occaſion, propoſeth to the Scribes and Phariſees, learned Parables, and in certain riddles, ſimilitudes and prouerbs, he reproueth them, which otherwiſe would not abide the hearing of plaine words.

4 In the conſideration of theſe and ſuch like things,Ionas. 1. the Prophet Ionas being commaunded to go and preach againſt Nineuy the Metropolitan Citie of Aſſyria, wherein were congregated the mightieſt and wiſeſt men of that Monarch, would haue eaſed himſelfe from the danger therof, by flying into Tharſhiſh from the Lords preſence: that is, from performing of that which the Lord had to him cō maunded. And ſo Ieremy, being firſt called to preach and to propheſie in the name of the Lorde,Ieremy. would haue excuſed himſelfe by his tender age, & by that he could not ſpeake eloquently. And afterward, hauing felt the tight of the burthen, hee complained thus: Oh mother: that euer thou beareſt mee!
Ier. 15.10. & 20.18. Iſay. 49.4. The Prophet Iſay ſeeing what ingratefulneſſe came from worldly men, after his long miniſterie, he thought verily that he had laboured all in vaine: & that godly Polycarpus hauing found the like thanks,Polycarpus. exclaimeth thus: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : O good God! for what times haſt thou reſerued me to feele thoſe torments? Hereuppon was it, that one ſaide to Chriſt when hee was called, that hee would firſt go home and burne his Father: and that another ſaid, he would go & bid his friends farewell at home. This cauſed Peter to denie his maiſter, and Demas to forſake Pauls ſociety. This cauſed the ſtarres to fall from heauen, that the labourers be few, though the harueſt bee full great, and that not many do with wiſedome inſtruct the people in the way of righteouſneſſe. An heauie caſe, the Lord knoweth, and moſt intollerable, without the great mercie of God which ſtrengtheneth.

5 Alſo the good Houſholder matcheth with many afflictions: ſometimes through an vnruly wife,The houſholder hath his afflictions. as
Socrates did with his Xantippe: ſometimes by diſobedient Children, as Dauid did with his ſonne Abſalom, and Eli with his ſonnes Hophnes and Phinez: and Samuel with his Children, Ioel and Abia: and Iacob with his ſonnes, and his daughter Dina: ſometimes by ſeruants, as Philaemon did with Oniſimus: ſometime by badde neighbours, as Tobias did with the Niniuites, & Loth with the Sodomites: beſides many diſorders in domeſticall and houſhold affayres, wherby he is prouoked to diſcontentation, and yet, doing his beſt, Ouid. li. 4. metam. Siſyphus. Auguſtus. hee is tied faſt with tyred Siſyphus, to the daily turning of his ſtone. Auguſtus himſelfe (though in the higheſt authority, yet as an houſholder) as often as he heard mention made of Iulia his daughter, and Iulia his daughters daughter, and of Agrippa his daughters ſon, which he was moued to baniſh from his Houſe for theyr open wicked and diſſolute maners, and odious conditions, he would ſigh and complaine therof with this verſe of Homer.
div.q: VVold god my lot had bin t'haue had neither wife nor child.
div.p:
That olde man in Terence called him happie that was freed from ſuch heauie fetters, to the which the monaſticall life is preferred in the iudgement of many men:1.
