Cor. 7.8.38.40. yea, Paul himſelfe held it good for the widowes, and for the vnmaried perſons, at that time, and on that preſent occaſion, ſo to conteine themſelues, reſoluing that he did better which gaue not in marriage, then hee did which gaue in marriage: that the ſingle life is the beſt kind of life, and that Peter ſpake wiſely when hee ſayde to his Maiſter, If the cauſe ſtandeth ſo betweene a man and his wife,
then it is not good to marrie: notwithſtanding that God ſaide in the beginning:Gen. 2.
It is not good that the man ſhould be alone.

6 The painfull Schoolemaiſter alſo finding few or none of his ſchollers ſo induſtrious and thankful as King Alexander the great was to his maiſter Ariſtotle: or as the wiſe Salomon was to learned Aſaph:The ſchoolemaiſters coraſiues. Ariſtotle. but rather dull of hearing, ſlow in learning,Aſaph. indutifull, ingratefull: yea,Seneca▪ and vppon ſmall occaſions ſo cruell to him, as Nero was to his Mayſter Seneca when hee killed him:Ariſtomenes▪ or as Peholomeus was to his Tutour Aristomenes, Iuuenall Satyr. when hee impriſoned him: and conſidering howe truely Iuuenal ſingeth, Scire volunt omnes, mercedem ſoluere nemo: that men ſcarcely reward well thoſe perſons of whome they would that eyther themſelues, or theyr children ſhoulde learne wiſedome. Hee is quite ouerthrowne with furie and diſpleaſure, and eaſeth himſelfe of his painefull trauailes with finall diſpayre. Oleum & laborem per do: I do but looſe all my labour

7 The learned Scribe alſo neuer or verie ſeldome findeth the one moitie of ſuch bountifull rewards,The Scribe his afflictions. as one Octauius beſtowed on a poore Greeke Poet, who had exhibited to him certayne learned Epigrams (which rewarde, as it is ſayde, was an hundred thouſande peeces of Golde) but hee rather findeth, that his beſt labours doo purchaſe emulation, enuie, diſdaine, and many hard conſtructions, with diriſions: therefore hee accounteth with Baruch, Baruch. Ier. 45.3. that hee hath gained nought elſe beſides paynes for his trauailes, and waxeth wearie of wryting. So alſo many others, both well learned and experienced, from whome at
length the Common-wealth expecteth the fruits of their ſtudies & trauailes,
The cunning and wiſe men haue afflictions and enemies.
Boet. de. conſ. Phil. li. 1. proſ. 3.
Socrates. Ʋaler. max. li. 1.2. & li. 3.3 Zeno.
Anaxagoras. are wonderfully daunted, when they heare, that Socrates (which was by the Oracle at Delphos, teſtified to bee the wiſeſt among the Philoſophers) was through enuie accuſed by Anetus, for the Citizens of Athens: by Meletus, for the Poets: by Lycon, for the Oratours: wherevpon he was forced to drinke poyſon, whereof he died: and that Zeno was tormented by Nearchus, in the ſight of his owne Citizens: and that Anaxagoras with much adoo eſcaped the like: that the men of Delphos threw downe Aeſope off an high Rock, and brake his necke:Aeſope. that Octauius Caeſar baniſhed Ouid the Poet from his Court,Ouid. and ſent him an exile into Pontus:Iuuenal. that Domitian the Emperour exiled Iuuenal the Poet: and that Tiberius commaunded that cunning craftſ-man,A cunning maker of Glaſſe. which had made Glaſſe malleable, that is, to abide the hammer as gold, tinne, or other mettals, to be beheaded. And weighing and perpending how many others alſo, both cunning and well learned in their ſeuerall facluties, haue beene burned in the furious fires of enuie and diſdaine: they do, I ſay, fold their handes and ceaſe from altogether with this account: Terra moueatur: Lette the world wag.

8 Finally, it is daily conſidered and obſerued, that all ſuch (for the moſt parte) as haue aduentured farre, and taken hard trauailes for the good and ſafetie of other men, yea, of Churches and whole Common-wealthes, haue found euen them whom they haue benefitted, and to whom they haue well wiſhed, to be affected towards them, as were the people of Rome towards Telemalchus the Monke, in
the time of Honorius the Emperour. Telemalchus. Eraſ. in praefac ad Paraph. in Marcum. This Telemalchus hearing of the great delight that the people of Rome had in their accuſtomed combats on the common hearer, wherewith no ſmall number of men had beene murthered one of another of them: hee of very zeale came to Rome, with purpoſe to diſſwade them from that barbarous crueltie. And as the ſaw two men now readie to fight, hee ſtept on the ſtage and ſpake unto them thus: Quid facit is fratres? quur in mutuum exitium ferarum more ruitis? That is, VVhat me and yee brethren? wherefore do ye thus like bruite beasts ſeeke one anothers deſtruction? But thus was hee rewarded: the people of Rome roſe vp with one accord againſt him, and ſtoned him with ſtones, that he dyed. This kind of thankfulneſſe towards them which well deſerue, Virgil prettily bewrayeth, and the ſame reprooueth in the table of the ſleeping Paſtour and the watchfull Gnat, thus.The fable of the Paſtour and the gnat. Virg. As a certaine Paſtour ſlept in the fields in the heate of the Summer, there glided towards him a venemous ſerpēt, with full purpoſe to ſting him being a ſleepe. This thing the little Gnat perceiuing, came haſtily, and pight on the Paſtours face, tickling him, with intent to awaken him, to eſchew that preſent euill. But the peeuiſh Paſtour hauing no conſideration either of his owne danger, or of the Gnats good mind, ſodainly put vp his hand and killed the Gnat, whoſe death afterward, but all too late, he thus lamented.

q.l: O little Culex, thus thou gain'ſtParue culex pecudum cuſtos, &c. Virg.
for gard of life, thy death:
By Paſtour, who for thy good deed,
bereaues thy vitall breath!

div.p: But if that men (after their good deſerts) founde not ſuch extreme requitals, yet they ſcarcely eſcaped that thankfulneſſ▪e which the Phiſitians that had cured Triſelaus founde at his handes.Triſelaus and his Phiſitions. For this fellow, beeing ſometimes ouercome with a melancholike paſſion, perſwaded himſelfe to be the right owner of al the graet Nauie that arriued at the Port Pireus: but when through the great cunning and care of his Phiſitians he was healed, he, in ſteede of thankfulneſſe began to curſe them: ſaying, that they had therein robbed him of all his wealth, & vtterly ſpoyled him of his delights. Lo, ſuch be the rewards which the world commonly beſtoweth on thē that do good, & benefit others. Wherfore, not onely the commō ſort, but alſo many of the better account (as in this conceite made wearie of well doing for others) haue bin moued to ſing thus with Catullus.

q.l: Omnia ſunt ingrata nihil feaſſe benigne eſt. Catul.Let paſſe the minde well to deſerue of any wight:
Or to perſwade, that men will reform'd aright.
Ingratefull all things be: that one deſerueth well,
Is nothing elſe but yrkſome toyle, and labour fell.

div.p:
And others, in the conſideration of theſe things, vſe to rumynate that notable ſong of the Lorde touching his ingratefull vineyarde, complayning alſo to him of the maligne worlde: VVhat could wee haue doone more vnto them,
Iſa. 5.1. then that which wee haue done? after our labours wee did onely expect this, that they ſhould be thankfull and the neere to all vertues: but lo, they be moſt ingratefull, and flow with all vices! Therfore they reſolue, that it is a farre better thing to bee medling with nothing at all. My talent (ſayth
one) is mine owne and in mine owne hand: I may burie it in the earth if I will, which yet had I leauer doo, then thus to employ it to any perill and paine. I will (ſayth another) aſſay ſome other thing to liue on, for my more credit, quiet, profit and pleaſure: for I perceiue that in theſe my great trauailes, I am worthily moued to ſing out the hand-maides ſorie Song: Mane furgo & fatigo me, The handmaids ſong. ac manduco panem Doloris, that is: Early vp, wearie toyle, and ſorrie fare.

10 Beſides all this,No man liueth content. looking yet more neere into the particular eſtates and conditions of men in this wretched world, I finde not may that are willing to liſten to that morall ſentence of Ben-Syrah:Sent. Burniſh that boane which falles in thy lot: becauſe they neuer learned Pauls leſſon, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : Phil. 4.11. I haue learned (ſayth hee) in what ſoeuer eſtate I am, to be therewith content. But the Pooreman,1. Tim. 6.8.9. although he haue foode and rayment where with he ſhould be contented (as the Apoſtle aduiſeth) yet hee thinketh his eſtate but miſerable, the rather becauſe hee ſuffereth many an iniurie of them that be rich, which hee is not of power to reſiſt, nor of might to reuenge. Therefore he be pittieth himſelfe, hee bewayleth his lot, he emulateth the condition of other men: yea, hee laboureth to bee made rich, and haue worldly poſſeſſions by all wayes and meanes, though that thereby hee fall into tentation and ſnares, and into many fooliſh and noyſome luſtes, which drawe men to perdition and deſtruction. For the loue of Money is the roote of all euill, which while ſome luſted after, they miſſed the marke concerning the Fayth,
and pearced themſelues through with many ſorrowes. Howbeit, if theſe worldly riches could by him be obtained, then were he the happieſt man (in his owne conceite) and therfore riches is made that Summum Bonum, and cheefe ſcope whereunto the labours of many poore men dotend and are directed. In the meane whiles, hee liueth in high murmur, grudge, and diſcontentation of minde: and why? he hath not yet learned the leſſon of Contentation:1. Tim. 6.6. he beleeueth not that godlineſſe is great riches to him that is pleaſed with that which God hath giuen him: and hee cannot conceiue this, that to labour and to be contented with that a man hath, be it little or be it much,Ecclus. 40.18. is a ſweete pleaſant life, and a treaſure aboue all treaſures. Neither doth hee thinke that Chriſt ſpake trueth, when he ſaid, that it is eaſier for a Camel to go through the eye of a needle, then for the rich men, or for him that truſteth in money to enter into the kingdome of God: or that the poore in Spirit, though neuer ſo poore in wealth, are beloued of God, and bleſſed.

The rich man and his affliction. Eccles. 4.8.11 On the other ſide, the rich man cannot content himſelfe neither, ſeeing hee feeleth ſuch torments as much trouble him too. The more he hath, the more mouthes muſt hee fill: the greater gaine, the greater greefe: he watcheth in the night: hee hath no quietneſſe in the day. When the poore man iournyeth without all feare, and ſingeth before the robbers face, the rich man is moſt fearefull, & ſtandeth in doubt of euery buſh. Where flocke the flyes, but to the Carions? where lurketh the Theefe, but there where wealth is?Euclio, apud Plant. in ſua Aulularia. Therefore the Nigard Euclio, whome Plautus bringeth in, reaſoning with
Megadorus, feareth that euery one which commeth to his houſe, intendeth to rob him of his money and wealth: and that whoſoeuer beginneth any conference or talke with him, mindeth to borrow ſome of his gold: he thinketh that his Cheſts are not made and banded ſtrong inough to keepe faſt his treaſure, nor that the doores of his houſe be barred & locked faſt inough to keepe out theeues. So that in ſuch his perplexitie, hee often calleth him happie, that hauing nothing to looſe, could ſay with a mind content, Omnia mea mecum porto: I beare all my wealth with mee, whither ſo euer I go. Such is his vanitie,The rich man is loath to exchange his condition with the poore man. and vnmeaſurable toyle: howbeit, hee is farre off from the poore mans deſire, to exchange his condition with the poore man, albeit the poore man woulde willingly exchange with him: but rather moſt deſirous to keep al that he hath, and yet to incroach and get in more: yea, and hauing inough, and too much, he neuer ſaith to them that bring in, ho, ho. Neither is rich Craeſus ſatisfied with his wealth,Craeſus. Alexander. nor will Alexander bee contented with the conqueſt of one world. His diſeaſe therefore is a dangerous dropſie, whoſe thirſt is not quēched with much water, but the more haue, the more craue, the more drinke, the dryer: and his deſire is like the bottomleſſe gulfe inſatiable. Surely, this man hath made that to himſelfe euill, which of it owne nature is good: for riches are not euill, but onelie vnto them which ſet their hearts on them and ſo abuſe them. Abraham was a verie rich man, ſo alſo was Loth, ſo was Iſaak, ſo was Iacob, ſo was Ioſeph, and Ioſeph of Aramathia: yet were they neuertheleſſe the friends of God, and righteous men. Therefore
Dauid in the Pſalme did not condemne riches, nor the true vſe of them: but hee ſayde: Set not thine heart therevpon. For the Lord ſayth: Giue mee thine heart. They doo ſet their heart vpon riches, which do in them place their felicitie, and make riches their God, and truſt in them. And as the godlie Saints do euer hunger and thirſt after righteous and the holie preſence of God, vntill they come home to him into his glorie, ſo the worldlie rich man (though not with the like heart) doth euer thirſt for that his God Mammon, and the treaſures of Pluto, and cannot be appeaſed: but he ſaith ſtill, I will pull downe my Barnes, and build them bigger, vntill it bee ſaide to him,Luke 12.
Thou foole, this verie night they ſhall fetch away thy ſoule from thee.

Aug. de Charit.12 Thus are men hardly perſwaded, that he is onlie rich, which in Charitie is contented, and that he is a poore man indeed, which in the middeſt of his aboundance hath not a contented minde. They beleeue not Chriſt in this, that much better it is for a man to be poore Lazarus, then that wealthy Diues in this life. Neither do they conſider, that it little profiteth a man to labour in the winde with ſuch eager thirſting after the riches of this world, when in regarde thereof, he miſſeth King Salomons thouſand: that is, his owne ſoule, and the life euerlaſting. And they remember not (notwithſtanding the common and daylie examples before their eyes) that a man going from hence towardes his long home, leaueth all his riches and wealth behinde him, departing from this worlde as naked as he came into the ſame. In trueth, if they did well weigh this one thing, they woulde not be ſo greedie with the hungrie
Rauen, to pray on the venemous Serpent to his owne deſtruction, as ſayth the Prouerbe. Onlie the wiſe man conſidereth well theſe things, and yeeldeth to this, that Content is rich. And thus that wiſe Agur, the ſonne of Iake, conſidered, and knowing alſo, on the one ſide worldly riches and wealth, was a mightie prouocation of pride, couetouſneſſe, luſt, enuie, diſdaine, rapine, gluttonie, and ſuch like: and that on the other ſide, worldly pouertie was the mother of impatiencie, diſcontentation, blaſphemie, theft, lying, and ſuch like: and that of all others the meane eſtate was the beſt, hee both taught and prayed thus. Two thinges (ſayeth hee to the Lorde) haue I required of thee, denie them not before I die. Remooue from mee vanitie and lies. Giue mee neither pouertie nor riches: feede mee with foode conuenient for mee: leaſt I be full, and doo denie thee, and ſay, who is the Lord? or leaſt I bee poore, and ſteale, and blaſpheme the name of my God.

13 To be ſhort,1. Tim. 6, 8, 9 howſoeuer it bee that Saint Paul aduiſeth men to abide within the compaſſe of their owne vocations and conditions of life, and therein to ſerue God with pure cōſciences, & contentation: yet (that notwithſtanding) wee ſee, that the man which hath a wife, commendeth him that hath not yet married a wife: the woman which is bound to an husband, praiſeth her that remaineth a virgine. Again, few married men (as the world goeth) liſten to Salomons counſaile, to drinke of the water of their owne welles, and of the riuers that runne out of their owne ſprings. They are ſcarcely pleaſed, to reioyne with the wiues of their youth, which
ſhould in all equitie, be to them as the louing Hind, and pleaſant Roe. Their breaſt cannot cōtent them, nor can they bee ſatisfied with their good loue. Therfore they affect ſtraunge women, and aſſay to pleaſe themſelues in other mens houſes. And this is alſo the deſire of many maried women, who would if they could, forſake the guide of their youth, and follow ſtraungers. Furthermore, the ſouldior will not be content with his wages, but he will oppreſſe and proll for ſpoyles, neither is hee pleaſed with his condition. The Marchant man commendeth the husbandman,Baſyl. Mag. and the husbandman liketh well of marchandize. The yeoman would be a gentleman: the eſquire would be a knight: the knight would be a Lord: the Lord would bee a Prince: the Prince would be a king, and Emperor of the whole world. The child would he were a man, the mayd would be a wife, the wife would bee her husbands maiſter. The olde man being ſorie that ſo many dayes of his life be worne out, wiſheth that he were a yong man againe. And thus euery vocation and condition, being loathſome to it ſelfe, euery man looketh with hote emulation on the calling & condition of ſome other man without contentation, wherin the Poets aime, hitterh home on the nailes head.

q.l: Perſ.Optat Ephipia, Bos piger:
Optat arare Caballus.

div.p:
Thus engliſhed:
The lazie Oxe doth wiſh, he were
an Horſe, on backe to beare:
And ſo the Horſe doth wiſh, he were
an Oxe, the ſoyle to teare.
Againe, conſidering manie vnmeaſurable cares and great vanities of mens affaires, hee thus lamenteth the miſerie of the ſame.
div.q: O curas hominum! O quantum est in rebus in ane?
div.p: Thus engliſhed.

q.l: Alas mans cares: how full of paine?
Alas mans wayes: how vile and vaine?

div.p: Indeed right iuſtly (as ſaid Auguſtine) hath the Lord appoynted an vnquiet heart and minde, for a puniſhment to the men of this life, which will not be contented & pleaſed with that which they haue: and this affliction (ſaith Salomon) hath God giuen to the children of men, to humble them.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.

Many men are diſtracted in the conſideration of the diſorders of this worlde. Men are euen in theſe our dayes ingratefull to ſuch as do them any good. The neceſsitie of inſtructions and good admonitions.
div.p:
MOreouer, for that all things bee ſo hard, as a man is not of abilitie to expreſſe them: and he is accounted happy, that knoweth the cauſes of things, the mē of this world are moſt wonderfully afflicted in their owne imaginations: ſo farre, that ſome of them haue euen conſumed away with ſpitefull anger,Ariſtotle died with anger. as Ariſtotle the Peripatike was ſaid to do, for that he could not find out the cauſe of the
ebbing and flowing of the ſwelling riuer Euripis: and others haue bin throughly diſtracted as was Aratus the Aſtronomer:Aratus was deſtracted. Saul. Mithridates. Achab. Brutus. ſome haue bin diſcomfited, as was king Saul, Mithridate, & Demoſthenes, though ſome others haue promiſed themſelues victorie with Achab, and happie ſucceſſe with Brutus, either by force, or fortune, with a vaine expectation.The confuſion of worldly things.

2 But when with all theſe things, that vgly Ataxie the diſorder and manifold confuſions of this life do concurre, beyond all the reſt, this heauy conſideration,Pſal. 73. Iere. 12.1. Abac. 1.3. Iob. 21.7. and 24.12. Eccles. 3.16. and 4.1. that (not only as Socrates, but alſo as Dauid ſaid) The wicked and euill diſpoſed haue oftentimes the moſt abundance of worldly goods and riches, when the better ſort want them: that the godlie and wicked be preferred, and liue in long proſperitie: that the vnrighteous do vnrighteouſly, & God (as Iob ſaith) doth not charge them with follie, or plague them: that iniuſtice and oppreſsion is ſeene in the place of iudgement: that religion often languiſheth, and Atheiſme and prophanitie doth flouriſh: that the gouernment either Eccleſiaſticall or Politicall, or Oecomicall, little auaileth to correct, redreſſe and perfect that which is amiſſe: that many noble men, and wiſe men, haue periſhed togither with the ignomious and fooliſh: that Alexandria, Corinth, Ieruſalem, Sparta, Athens, Thebes, & many other famous cities haue bin made deſolate. That Chaldaea, Babylō, Perſia, Graecia, & other mightie Monarches of the world, haue altered their turnes,The confuſion of things occaſion ſome an argue want of power in God, &c. and chaunged their faces: and that all men be conſtrained to beare with the ingratefull world, howſoeuer it be, becauſe No man can ſtriue with him that is mightier then himſelfe, and things that are bowed,
no man can make ſtraight. The common ſort of men do argue of the want of power and force in God,Nat. deorum lib. 3. (as Cicero ſayth, reporting the wordes of Diogenes) and the rather, for that neither Iupiper Olympius, nor Aeſculapius, (as hee ſayde) plagued the Tyraunt Dionyſius, for diſpoyling them of their Treaſures:Read Iob. cap. 24.12. and for that manie other wicked men are not puniſhed by GOD himſelfe, by and by with ſome horrible plagues for theyr horrible deedes: yea, and manie great and famous perſonages alſo haue conſented to that ſaying of him in the Tragedie:Melan. in Epiſt. praefix. operibus graec. Xenophon. Vitam regit Fortuna Dea: The Goddeſſe Fortune guideth euerie mans life. And if it bee ſo, then, to what ende (ſay they) ſerue all thoſe precepts of wiſedome deliuered vnto vs in the worde, and in Hyſtories? For if mans life be guided, neither by the counſailes of wiſe men, nor by God himſelfe, why then is doctrine propoſed? And ſo the greateſt part of all people, in the gouernment of great matters, direct not their counſailes to any certaine rule and doctrine: but hoyſe vp ſailes to be carried whither ſoeuer the winde ſhall driue, or blind Fortune permit them.

3 And although the Heathen Orator ſayd:Cicero de Nat. decrum lib. 3.
Mala & impia conſuetudo contra Deos diſputandi, ſiue ex animo id fit, ſiue ſimulate: It is an euill custome to diſpute agaynst the goddes, The godlie themſelues do often murmure. whether it bee done of ſet purpoſe, or by ſimulation: yet manie of the godlie themſelues alſo, are by theſe and ſuch like ſpectacles, mooued to expoſtulate agaynſt the Lorde GOD of Heauen, as Ieremie did:Iere. 12.1. Iob. 24.1.
VVherefore proſpereth the way of the wicked? Why dooſt thou (O God) ſuffer the vngodlye to liue in the VVorlde, to hurt
and oppreſſe thine owne children? what iuſtice? what reaſon? what wiſedome is there in God that permitteth it? And ſhould not the Iudge of all the world do iuſtice? And they cannot denie, but that this deepe conceit hath alſo touched them ſo farre, that they haue beene mooued (with Dauid) to ſay: Pſal. 73.2. My feete were almost gone: my ſteppes were well nigh ſlipt: For I freatted at the fooliſh, when I ſawe the proſperitie of the wicked. Eccles. 4.2. Therefore (with Salomon) they commende the deade before them that liue, and, in the ſuddaine paſsion of their afflicted ſpirites they imagine him that is not yet borne, to bee in better caſe then anie of them both. And not a fewe (as deſperate of GOD,VVhat is god, prouidence? and of the diuine prouidence, which is the reaſon that the Lorde God vſeth in the ordering and directing of things to their right endes) in this profound conſiderations, do conſent with Cladianus, thus:
Saepe mihi dubium, &c.This mad conceit vnto my doubtfull minde, is often brought:
VVhat? haue the high caeleſtiall powers, on worldly matters thought?
And is there any God aboue, that guideth all? or no?
Or do th' affaires of wordly men, by chaunce, vncertaine go?

How to expell this imagination of fleſh and blood. Sap. 2.22.4 This vaine imagination being deepely rooted in the heart of the naturall man, which is blinded with his owne malice, which vnderſtandeth not the myſteries of the ſpirit of God, nor hopeth for the reward of righteouſnes, nor regardeth the worſhip
that the holy Saints ſhall haue at the reſurrection of the iuſt: can very hardly be remoued and expelled, and therfore doth require the daily and diligent vſe of that Armour of light, which Paul would,Rom. 13. wee take vp againſt all the deedes of darkeneſſe. And yet it cannot be denied, that not onely Moſes the ſeruant of God, and the holy Patriarkes, and the Prophets, and the Apoſtles haue preached and taught, and Chriſt who came from the boſome of his father, hath witneſſed, and God himſelfe from heauen declareth, but alſo the meere heathē do by the works of the Creation, and the operation of Nature acknowledge and confeſſe, that the God of heauen by his prouidence ordreth and ruleth all theſe things, Howſoeuer they appeare confuſed and without order to them that vnderſtand not the cauſes and reaſons thereof.

5 Such (indeede) be the painefull trauailes wherwith the men of this life haue beene ſo long time burthened, and yet lie yerking vnder the intollerable tight of the ſame. And that becauſe through the malice of the Diuell,The cauſe of thoſe troubled minds. the malice of man is great on the earth, and al the thoughts of his heart are onely euill euery day, wherof there be procreated a thouſand moſt deſperate imaginations, and eager diſcouragements to Religion, dutie, and right. Yea, and ſo much the more lamentable is the cauſe and condition of man,Some of theſe maladies be remedileſſe: and ſome hard to be cured. by how much thoſe his maladies bee ſo remedileſſe and incurable: for whoſoeuer will endeuour and take on him the ſame to correct, and thorowly to purge, be he neuer ſo wiſe, ſo learned, ſo iuſt, ſo ſtrong, ſo rich, hee ſhall but waſh the Ethiope, cleanſe the Leopard of ſpots, and vexe his
ſpirit in vaine. Beſides that, as touching thoſe matters which are curable, and to bee remedied in time and place, who ſeeth not how perilous and vneaſie it is, for any man to aſſay to eaſe that which may bee eaſed, to aduenture to ſalue that, which may be ſalued? for notwithſtanding that Siſinnis the Gouernour of Coeloſyria, 1. Eſdr. 7.1. and Phenice, and Sathrabouzanes and theyr aſſociates, (obeying at length the Princes commandement) are perſwaded to aſſiſt the holy worke diligently, labouring with the auncients and Gouernours of the Sanctuarie, and the holy worke proſpereth by the miniſtrie of Haggaeus and Zacharias the Prophets: yet behold, the ingratefull and diſcontented, find flocks furniſhed for theyr purpoſe, to oppugne the Truth, to reſiſt the Princes proceedings, and to oppreſſe the defenders thereof, in like ſort as the Sodomites forced iuſt Loth,
Gen. 19.9. when they compaſſed his houſe rounde about of all forces, from all quarters: by whoſe ſiniſter deuiſes and Satanicall practiſes, euery good and godly worke is either reiected or hindred by all meanes: and euery good Counſaile and godly aduiſe is conſtrued with great partialitie and groſſe corruption, inſomuch that hee (whoſoeuer hee bee) that aduentureth to admoniſh either the higheſt, or the loweſt, the Princes or the people, the Prophets or the Prieſtes,Homer. the Court or the Countrey, hee is either welcomed as Amos was to Bethel, or aunſwered as Halitherſes Mastorides was at the Gate of Vliſſes: and if hee finde better cheare, hee may account it as ſo much gayned beyonde his expectation,Amos 7.12. and bee thankfull for it. But howe was
Amos welcomed? hee was taken for a plaine ſotte of the Countrey, and vnmeete for the Courte, and therefore Amaſiae the Courtly Prieſt, expelled him thence with this ſaying: Go, gette thee hence into the land of Iuda, and there eate thy bread, and Propheſie there: but Propheſie not at Bethel, Halitherſes. for it is the Kings Chappell. And howe was that Halitherſes aunſwered? the Poet Homer telleth, that when the olde man, who was both wiſe and well experienced in worldly affayres,Eurimachus the ſonne of Polybus. Odiſ. 6. would haue perſwaded Eurimachus the ſonne of Polibus (who was a long ſutor for Penelope) to departe from the houſe of Vliſſes, and not to trouble himſelfe any further in thoſe matters, for feare of ſuch an inconuenience as afterwarde enſued. Eurymachus thinking himſelfe wiſer then the gray head, continued his ſuite, and reiected him in theſe words:
Get home (olde foole) and to thy Children, there preſage good ſpeed:
That future falles they flie: for we excell thee farre in Reed.
Though many birds beneath the Sunne-beames, flie on euerie ſide:
Yet do not all pronoſticate to men, what ſhall betyde.
Againe.

q.l: In that thou multiplieſt thy words, thou getteſt nought therefore:
But in the ſame thou giu'ſt vs cauſe to hate thee yet the more.

div.p:
A miſerable kind of people6 This is a Kind of people of all others to bee lamented, as ſuch as without hope, who knowing nothing, will not for all that vouchſafe to liſten to them which are beſt able, and moſt willing to inſtruct them, then whom, they euer eſteeme themſelues more learned, more wiſe, & better furniſhed euerie way: for they put away from themſelues the holy graces of God, being profered them, and willingly ſell themſelues to death and extreme miſerie. Pſal. 58.4. The Pſalmiſt rightly likeneth thē to the deaffe Adder that ſtoppeth his eare againſt the voyce of the Inchaūter, though he be moſt expert in charming. For they be ſo corrupted with the venome of the ſpiritual Serpent, and ouerthrowne with madde furie, that they either flie from euerie one that would wiſely admoniſh them, or ſo cloſe their eares againſt their words,The Iewes ſtopped theyr eares. Acts 7. that no power of wholſome admonition and counſaile can moue them. Thus the Iewes ſtopped their eares (though not their mouthes) againſt Stephen and his words: and ſo at this time (I ſay) many are deaffe (with the Adder and thoſe malitious Iewes) when rather they ſhould liſten to the word of God and holy and wholſome inſtructions, whereof the preachers and miniſters of the word, haue cauſe to complaine now, as Iſayah did in his time: Iſa. 53.1. Lord who hath beleeued our report? and to whom is the arme of the Lord reueiled? And are worthily occaſioned to lament the great vanitie & miſerie of man, no leſſe then Ieremy and Eſdras were moued in their dayes to be wayle the ſinnes of the people, and the diſtreſſe of the holy land, and the ruine of the Citie and Temple of God: and many ſay nowe as Hezekiah did: The Child is come to the place of byrth, and there
wanteth power of deliuerance. Neither would the Lorde himſelfe (if he were now on the earth) refuſe to weepe ouer the people, as he did ſometimes ouer Hieruſalem, and to admoniſh them alſo to weepe for themſelues and for their Children. Surely, the very conſideration thereof, is able to daunte and diſcourage him that is moſt willing and forward to tender aide, (and not a few are therby diſcouraged indeed) diſpayring of any fruite to bee gathered from thoſe ſtony places, thoſe high wayes, and thoſe pricking thornes, into the which they had caſt the ſound and wholſome ſeede.

7 Neuertheleſſe, as long as it is ſaide, to day,VVe muſt not be diſcouraged to do good. Rom. 8. and during the time of our courſe, wee giue not ouer, nor vtterly diſpayre of the fruits of our labours: but we vrge on, in hope, though not of our owne will, but by the reaſon of him who hath ſubdued vs vnder hope, and be yet the more diligent in our duties, to do that good which may be done in our places to his glorie, who hath prepared vs thereunto. And wee continue yet praying and calling vnto God, that it would pleaſe him yet further to furniſh, to fortifie, to encourage, and to perſwade by his louing Spirit, the builders and repayrers of his owne houſe, to be diligent, able and willing to ſtrengthen that which remaineth, to fortifie the weake handes and feeble feete, to comfort the faint heart & weake wits, which in the bitter taſte of theſe extremities are readie to periſh, ſo farre forth, as hope emboldneth, poſſibilitie perſwadeth, and the word of God warranteth: and this ſhall hold vs excuſed and diſcharged before the Lord, howſoeuer the ſucceſſe of our labours and deſires ſhall appeare to be, the
which we muſt commend to the wiſedome, will, and power of God. And, as this is the beſt way for vs,Eccles. 12. ſo it ſhall be not onely good and profitable, but alſo moſt needfull for all perſons to yeelde themſelues obedient to the wordes of the wiſe, as Salomon admoniſheth: without the which, it is as impoſſible for a man to walke in the way of the Lorde towardes the cheefe good and higheſt happineſſe, as it is for a blind man to walke in a tedious way without a guide.

8. Therefore haue they beene much commended,They haue beene eſteemed for good men, who haue liſtned to the word of them that inſtructed thē in good. as the men of all others, neereſt to wiſedome and a godly life, who haue willingly liſtned to the leſſons of wiſe teachers. The verie Heathen haue thought reuerently of ſuch perſons: and among others of that kind, the Greeke Poet Heſiode thus writeth:
Right good is hee that liſtneth well,
To him who giues him good Counſell.

Seneca.And that reſpecting Seneca, counſailed thus: Moneberis libentur, &c. Thou oughteſt gladly to take admonition, and bee patient when thou art prouoked. If a man chide thee deſeruedly, knowe this, that it maketh for thy good: and though without deſerte, yet thinke this, that hee woulde profitte thee. Feare not bitter wordes, but rather feare obſequies and fayre ſpeeches.Pythagoras. And thus ſayde Pythagoras in his Precepts: Hee that (beeing aſhamed to bee taught) will not ſubmitte himſelfe to diſcipline and nourtour for a
little time, ſhall bee conſtrayned to continue in the obloquie and ſhame of fooliſhneſſe for euer. This is confirmed by the ſentence of Salomon: The Eare that hearkeneth to the correction of life,
Pro. 15.31.32. ſhall lodge among the wiſe: but he that refuſeth inſtruction, deſpiſeth his owne ſoule: but he that obeyeth correction, getteth vnderſtanding.

Dauid, Iehoſophat, Aaron, and other good men, haue well conſidered this, and could be well pleaſed to bee admoniſhed: yea, and that ſliding by an occaſion, they haue patiently borne a gentle correction, repented theyr ſinnes, and amended their liues. And ſurely, herein the right Chriſtian findeth no little comfort and contentation. For when hee ſeeth howe the Lord pacifieth the rage and rigour of the world, with that powerful word which he ſpake to the winde and the ſeas, ſaying: Peace and be ſtill: hee knoweth well how he gently allureth him, as a father doth his childe: and as hee perſwaded Iaphet at the requeſt of Noah, to enter into the Tabernacle of Shem.

In that ſort he entreateth his Children, by his holy Apoſtle Paul: I beſeech you Brethren (ſayth hee) by the mercies of God, that yee giue vppe your bodyes a lining ſacrifice, holy acceptable vnto God. Neither will hee neglect, nor lightly regarde this grace (as they that receiue it in vaine) but hearken diligently, and embrace willingly the wordes of the wiſe, retaine that Grace among them that wayre for redemption in Iſrael, and ſo ſerue God in reuerence and feare, in good contentation. And this alſo are they made the more able and readie to performe by godly and faythfull inuocation of the name
of God in Ieſus Chriſt. For, as the former giueth them light, and the right knowledge of the diuine will: ſo this miniſtreth vnto them ſufficient abililitie to follow and performe the ſame, through the Graces of his ſpirit, the which hee beſtoweth on them that aſke the ſame of him, and the which hath his effectuall operation in the true vſe thereof. For hereof is that liuely and fruitfull faith engendred in the heart of the elected, by the which they be iuſtfied and made fruitfull in all good works.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
The beſt medicines for the cure of mans maladies, muſt bee made of the word of God. An eſpeciall comfortatiue for the magiſtrate.
div.p:
Eccles. 12.
IN euerie Booke of the holy ſcriptures are contained moſt delectable words, vpright writings, euē the words of Trueth, the ſayings of the wiſe being like goades to ſtirre vppe, and like Nayles faſtened by the maiſters of the aſſemblies to confirme, which are giuen by one Paſtour (as ſaith Salomon) wherein is contained and publiſhed that perfect lawe of libertie,The word of God eternall. and whereof there is made a meete medicine for mans maladies. For albeit the eternall word of God may not bee comprehended and included within the leaues, lines, and volumes of Bookes, beeing the ſame which was with God in the beginning, and is euerlaſting, and that naturall and onely begotten
Sonne of God, begotten of the Father before all worldes, whoſe name is VVonderfull, the giuer of counſell, the mightie God, the euerlasting Father, the Prince of Peace: yet hath it pleaſed his goodneſſe, to ſpeake vnto man to his vnderſtanding: and hath commaunded his Prophets and Apoſtles to preach, to write, and to talke accordingly: that is, as Paul ſayde, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . After the manner of men, by reaſon of the infirmitie of man, being moſt vnable to conceiue the things that bee of the ſpirit of God. Therefore, howſoeuer wee imagine the eternall worde of God, and his diuine will, to be ſhut vp in his owne cloſe counſell, Apoc. 5.3, 4, 5 which neither any in heauen, nor in the earth, nor vnder the earth is found worthie to open and declare vnto men, and which we may not preſume to inueſtigate or ſearch without the helpe of the Lion of the tribe of Iuda: Gods written worde. he would that we ſhould hearken vnto his written will, and that word of God which he hath declared and made knowne vnto vs in the holy ſcriptures. Vnto this therfore the ſon of God (whom we muſt heare) ſent the Iewes, and bad thē to ſearch the ſcriptures. The vſe of this written word, he both taught and cōmended vnto vs, when he ſayd three times to the diuell, It is written, It is written, It is written. Thus he asked of the lawiers: How is it written?Mat. 4.
How readeſt thou? And to the two diſciples going towards Emaus, he ſaid: Thus it is written. He commanded his ſeruant Iohn, Apoc. • . to write vnto ye ſeuen churches in Aſia: and Paul commendeth the worde written, whē he ſaith, The Scriptures are writtē for our learning.

2 This is that lawe wherein the bleſſed man delighteth, and meditateth day and night. This is the
foode whereon the godly man feedeth, to nouriſh his ſoule. This is the touchſtone which trieth the ſpirits: this is the Index which ſheweth who are the children of God. This Word giueth comfort, direction, faith, wiſdome, knowledge of the will of God, the feare of God, loue, hope, holy zeale, and all heauenly vertues, when the holy Ghoſt (through the merit of Chriſt) hath his effectuall working in the true vſe thereof.A ſolace for euerie ſore. Of this ſweete hony combe is made a ſalue for all ſores, a medicin for all maladies, a plaiſter of peace againſt al trouble, and comfortatiues to content the children of God at al times, in all places. Therefore I eſteeme this,Ruth. as the beſt ground for Booz to ſow in: as the moſt plentifull field for Ruth to gleane in. This is (indeed) the ſweeteſt water to drinke of, and the wholſomeſt bread for man to feed of. This is that law which the King muſt copie out to lay before him, & that right Scripture which all men muſt ſearch to finde knowledge and life in. Therfore alſo to the ſame would I direct them that want comfort in diſtreſſes, counſell in their buſineſſe, and helpe in their miſeries. Neither doubt I, but that it ſhall bee embraced and well digeſted of them that feare God. But for this our argument and preſent purpoſe,Scripture for contentation of mens mindes. the Pſalmes of Dauid, the Prouerbes of Salomon, and chiefly his Eccleſiastes, or last Solace, which otherwiſe may be called his Common-wealth, are of ſingular choyſe.

3 And this is to be obſerued in theſe bookes, that as Dauid and Salomon haue miniſtred meete matter therein, for the inſtruction, ſolace, and comfort of all Gods children: ſo alſo they being well ſchooled by holy men, enſpired with an excellent ſpirit,
and themſelues both Kings and rulers ouer the church of god, and his people: haue principally before al others, with their doctrine and examples, inſtructed, ſolaced, & comforted Princes,Dauid and Salomon haue com • orted Princes and Magiſtrates. Magiſtrates and all them in high authoritie: and ſo much the ſooner, for that they themſelues felt and wel perceiued, how that the Princes and Magiſtrates are often oppreſſed and troubled, with the manifold treaſons, rebellions, ſeditions, ingratitude, and offences of ſuch as are troublers of the Common-peace, and breakers of tranquilitie, and of ſuch, as lay in waite for the life and liuings euen of them, on whoſe care, wiſedome, and good gouernment, the ſafetie and weale of the people (next vnto God) doth wholie releigh and depende, in euerie age.The Prince it the miniſter of God. According to whoſe good counſaile and direction yet reſerued in the holie Regiſter, the wiſe Prince and Magiſtrate knoweth himſelfe to bee the Miniſter of God, and a principall ſeruaunt of the King of all Kings, and Iudge of all Iudges, whoſe ſentence and power no man is able to reſiſt, and whoſe will muſt be fulfilled.

And that this God is not onelie preſent in the Congregation of Princes (as the chiefe Prince) but alſo beautifieth thoſe Princes with the high title of Gods, and ſonnes of the highest, and to comfort and ſtrengthen them in this place and function, and to take away all feare and fainting from them in authoritie, hee ioyneth his power and bleſsings to the ſame, and aſsiſteth them, and defendeth them, and the right of this gouernment againſt the proud faces, the murmuring mindes, policies, conceits, treaſons, rebellions, conſpiracies, and wilie practiſes
of their enemies bee they neuer ſo manie or mightie: ſo that they ſhall neuer bee confounded, but ſtande ſure, proceede well, get the victorie, and prooue by their owne experience, that it lieth not in the power of man ſo keepe the people in obedience, and to conſerue the Common-wealth: but in the will and power of God, who as he hath ordeined Princes & Magiſtrates, doth alſo giue them wiſdome, power, and obedient ſubiects, and by their miniſterie often ſaueth ſuch from deſtruction, as naturally hate the Magiſtrates, becauſe they deſire to liue without all gouernment, and ſo without order, after their owne corrupt luſts.

How the good Prince behaueth himſelfe in his place.4 But to ratifie this conſolation, and to remooue away all iuſt occaſions of offence, from them that are readie to take offences before offences be offred them. The wiſe Prince taketh on him, & executeth this diuine function, with great reuerence, wiſdome, and in the feare of God. He knoweth that as God is preſent to beautifie, ſtrengthen and defende the right of his authoritie, ſo he doth alſo beholde all that is done, the which he would ſhoulde bee according to the methode and rule of his holie law, and that he will bee an inexorable Iudge, and reuenger of the iniuries & wrongs of them that peruert the iudgement. And he remembreth, that to remoue away that pride which exalteth fleſh and blood from this place, the Lorde hath not onelie ſayde by the Pſalmiſt, Pſal. 82.7. that They bee Gods, whome hee hath to this aduaunced: but alſo ſayeth, that They ſhall die like men, and fall like one of the Princes: that is, if they abuſe the ſacred power: if they rule not theyr people in Equitye
and righteouſneſſe, but oppreſſe them after theyr luſtes,Aug. de abuſ. ſaeculi. Baruc. 3. which is not the leaſt of the abuſes of the worlde, they ſhall periſh, like as did thoſe auncient Tyrants, which in theyr times, rather annoyed, then benefited the Common-wealth. Therefore the wiſe and godly Prince, according to the counſel and examples of thoſe holy men, cōmended in the holy Scriptures, gouerneth and ruleth himſelfe,The praiſe of a Prince. his familie, and the Common-wealth, and hath a chiefe regard to do that which beſt beſeemeth him,In Octauia Tragaedia. which is (as Seneca ſayth) The praiſe of a Prince, notwithſtanding that Nero the Tyrant impugned that ſentence with this: Calcat iacentem vulgus: The Commons will treade on, and oppreſſe the gentle and mercifull Prince.

5 That godly and perfect man Iob ſpeaking in the perſon of a Prince or chiefe Magiſtrate, telleth what was his ſtrength, defence, and comfort in his place, whether men were pleaſed, or not pleaſed: I put vppon mee (ſayeth hee) righteouſneſſe,
Iob. 29.14. which couered mee as a Garment: and Equitie was my Crowne. To this ende was Salomon made King ouer Iſrael, as the Queene of Saba ſayde to him, namelie, To doo equitie and righteouſneſſe: Heere is Equitie, but not without Righteouſneſſe: heere is Righteouſneſſe, but not without Equitie. Equitie and Iuſtice both neceſſarie in a Magiſtrate. And both theſe vertues combined in the ſame perſon, become both him and the place right woorthilie. For as Iuſtice is that habite and affection of the minde, whereby men are apt to do and deſire that which is iuſt, and by the which there is yelded to euery man his right, and therefore woorthilie commended in all men, but chieflie in Princes,
and Magiſtrates, as that whereby the Common-wealth is conſerued & defended: ſo Equitie reſpecting not the letter, but the will and meaning of the law, and intent of the law-makers, doth either aptly apply the ſame to the matters in queſtion, by the wiſdome of the Iudge, or thereby the Iudge applieth himſelfe to the reaſon and qualitie of the cauſe, qualifying the rigour of the law, bowing the law to the cauſe, and not the cauſe to the lawe, knowing that Extreme law is extreme iniurie: And this vertue is as neceſſarie as Iuſtice, and no leſſe commendable in Princes. Salomon himſelfe being the King and chiefe Magiſtrate in the Common-wealth of Iſrael, and thereto beautified with the diuine wiſdome, giueth this good counſaile to all Princes and Magiſtrates. Be thou not iust ouermuch: Eccles. 7.18.19, 23. Luth. ibid. neither ouerwiſe, that thou periſh not. Be thou not wicked ouermuch, neither bee thou fooliſh: leaſt thou die before the time. That is, be thou not too ſeuere an Exactor of the law, leaſt thou become cruell, and ſo hatefull: nor be thou too remiſſe and gentle, leaſt all become nought, and thy ſelfe ouertaken by ſuch as contemne thee, and thine authoritie. For Salomon ſpeaketh of the ciuill iuſtice.

Arcadius negligent. Melanth.6 Archadius the Emperour, being too remiſſe and negligent, puniſhed not thoſe heinous offences that iuſtly required the rodde of iuſtice, to the great iniurie of his ſubiects, to his owne diſhonour, and great daunger.Iulian did not execute iuſtice on them that oppreſſed the chriſtians. Herod. Sylla. So Iulian puniſhed not them that moſt wickedly oppreſſed the Chriſtians, but rather derided the Chriſtians vppon their complaints, caſting their Maiſters commaundement of patience vnder the croſſe in their teeth. But on the other ſide: Herode, Sylla, and Aurelianus, tranſgreſſed iuſtice
through their hard exactions and crueltie: Aurilianus were cruell. they killed as well the peaceable, as the rebellious, and were too ſeuere agaynſt the meaneſt offenders: as of whome Iuuenall might well ſay: Exceſsit medecina modum: The Medicine was too ſtrong, Inuenal. for that diſeaſe. In this reſpect Ariſtotle ſayde:Li. 5. Eth. Iuſtice her ſelfe being weaponed is most cruell.

7 Beyonde manie others, Nero tranſgreſſed,Nero his crueltie. and exceeded in this extremitie, whome gouernment rightly deciphered indeede (for Office tryeth a many). For albeeit,Ariſt. 5. Eth. that during the firſt fiue yeares of his gouernment, hee behaued himſelfe verie prayſe woorthie: and, that Seneca had written and dedicated to his Maieſtie, a Booke intituled, Of Clemencie, or gentleneſſe, therein, exhorting him to that vertue, dehorting him from bloodie crueltie: yet, Nero impudentlie defendeth the ſame agaynſt Seneca, Sen. tragae. in octa act. 1. as hee did likewiſe in the caſe of Octauia the Empreſſe: Ferrum tuetur princepem, ſayth hee, By dint of ſworde must the Prince bee preſerued. In concluſion, hee beeing cruell by nature, and more cruell in his place, killed both the guiltie, and the innocent: the iuſt, and the vniuſt. Hee murthered his moſt truſtie Counſailour Seneca, hee ſlewe his owne Mother, his owne VVife, and cauſed his owne Cittie Rome to bee ſette on fire.

By theſe heinous Tragaedies,Nero left his name reprochfull. and his daily crueltie, he committed the honor of his name to a ſhamefull reproch, as thoſe ancient tyrants had done before him,Tyrannus: ſometime a name of noble Princes. which degenerated from the right noble vertues of Princes. As the tytle 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or Tyrant, in the olde time, was in the good part giuen to
honourable Princes, gouernours, and noble conquerours, in regard of ſtrength, fortitude, and vertue: but at length through the great malice, pride, inſolencie, and crueltie of heathen Potentates, that title became a name of diſgrace:Nero was a proper name. Gell. li. 11. ſo among the Sabines. Nero was a proper name (which noted Vertue, and Fortitude, of that Greeke word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the ſinews, being the coniunction and ſtrength of the members:) and ſuch perſons alſo were of them called Neroes, as excelled others in the moſt egregious fortitude, and noble vertues. Afterward, when this tyrant Nero (who deſcended of the Claudies, which were Sabines) had degenerated from all the heroicall vertues of his aunceſtors, and became ſo bloodie and cruell, he gaue occaſion to the poſteritie, to change that proper name into a name appellatiue, which called them that were cruell, Neroes, and in compariſon, Neroniores, thoſe which were more cruell. Iob. 18.17. Prou. 10.7. Of ſuch ſpeaketh Iob, That their remembrance ſhall periſh from the earth: yea, and The name of them (ſaith Salomon) ſhal ſtink; as of them which haue been the occaſions of the ruine of their owne palace, & people, as the Lord ſaid by Ezechiel touching the Prince of Tyre, Cherub the Prince of Tire in Ezech. 28. who in glorie ſome times ſhined like the bright Cherub, in the houſe of god: but now deformed, and in high contempt.

Moderators of the lawes neceſſarie.8 By this it appeareth, that the Prince is not onelie the Law-giuer, but alſo the Moderator, and qualifier of the ſame law: & that alſo the Magiſtrates in their places, are moderators and qualifiers of the generall law.Luth. in Eccle. And the moderation of the law is no leſſe neceſſarie, then the law it ſelf: cōcerning the which, the time, the place, the perſons, and other circumſtances
of the matters and cauſes duely conſidered, the vertue 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, Equitie, hath a place.Equitie. For Equitie being next neighbors, or one of the daughters of Iuſtice, and placed betweene thoſe two hard extremities, Negligence & Crueltie, withſtanding thoſe extremities, and relieuing the meane, remitteth ſome offences for the cauſe of common concord, and againe puniſheth ſome faults with lenitie and gentleneſſe. And in this ſhall be ſeene that moderate libertie, and that moderate ſubiection,Chytr. Reg. vit. which Plato commended to be ſo excellent good in a common-wealth.

This Princely vertue ſhined in Iulius Caeſar, who when he had a iuſt occaſion offred him to kill Cicero, Iulius Caeſar ſheweth great equitie. M. Marcellus, & ſome others, did neuertheleſſe remit and pardon them. He wel conſidered, that extreme law was wrong, and therfore moderated it through Equitie. And nothing more grieued the heart of that noble Auguſtus, then when by any poynt of ſeueritie, he was too much feared of his Subiects.Auguſtus Caeſar. Therfore to one that offered him a ſupplication with a trembling hand, he anſwered: VVhat? thinkeſt thou that thou offereſt a penny to an Elophant? Hearing alſo of the crueltie of his familiar friend Pollio, he reprooued him for it verie ſharpely: but when hee was certified of the moſt barbarous bloud-thirſtineſſe of Herod in Iury, Mat. 2. which had commanded the yong innocent children to bee murthered, and among them ſpared not his owne ſonne, hee ſaide in high diſpleaſure: Better it is to be Herods hogge, then his ſonne. Hee right well conſidered that ſuch ſeueritie and crueltie to the poore ſubiects, could purchaſe vnto a Prince neither honour, nor riches, nor loue, nor
ſafetie:VVhat is Clemencie. and on the other ſide, Clemencie and Gentlenes, which is defined the temperāce of the mind, which hath power to reuenge: the lenitie of the ſuperiour towardes the inferiour, and the habit whereby hee which is prouoked againſt any man is through goodneſſe reſtrained, is both commodious & commendable, eſpecially for Princes. The conſtraint wherof hath depriued many a potentate of the glorie of his place, and caſt his Crowne downe to the ground, wherof there be extant examples and teſtimonies in hiſtories both humane and diuine.

9 In the due conſideration whereof, although the auncient Romanes had appointed eight ſeuerall puniſhments for malefactours, as namely, Damage, Eight puniſhments. impriſonment, whipping, recompence, ſhame, exile, ſeruitude, death, yet did they very ſeldome, and that neuer vniuſtly,Romani. Tul. Iſidor. li. 2. Etymolog. and without great cauſes, execute them: but ſo were the lighteſt applied, as the feare often ſpread to many, the paine to few, knowing well, that the getting of a kingdome is with ſword, but the continuance thereof is with glorie, mercie, and beneuolence of a Prince to his ſubiects: and the Subiects good will and affection towardes their king, as ſaid Antigonus the Macedonian prince. And this thing was wel weighed of the Emperour Frederik 3. whome Luther therefore remembreth: his common ſaying was:Luth. in Eccl. 5.8.
Qui neſcit diſſimulare, neſcit & regnare, whereto Luther addeth, neſcit & viuere, A man cannot liue which will not winck at ſome faults. Quintilian. ſpoken in the beſt ſence and meaning, as thus: It is impoſſible for a prince to raigne that cannot wink at ſome faults, or forbeare to puniſh them in time and place. In the which ſence, that ſentēce of Quintilian touching a ſchoolemaſter in Grammer, may be taken, that among
the Graces to him belonging, this is one, Eccles. 7.
that hee be ignorant of ſome things: meaning that hee muſt ſeeme not to ſee, nor knowe many faults in his ſchollers. And as thouching thoſe priuate iniuries which touch many men neere, Salomon counſaileth again, ſaying: Giue not thine heart to all the words that men ſpeake, leaſt thou heare thine owne Seruant curſing thee. And this hath beene noted to bee obſerued by Antigonus, to his prayſe.Antigonus. When himſelfe on a time heard certaine lewd perſons to ſpeake vnreuerently of his perſon, hee gently required them to remoue further from him, leaſt happily he ſhould heare them.Octauius Caeſar. And Auguſtus hath beene no leſſe commended, for that he did not onely ſet little by, but alſo pardon the offence of Cynna, the nephew of Pompeie, and alſo Timagines the rayling Hiſtoriographer, and Pollio that lodged the ſaide Timagines in his houſe: and for that hee remitted Aemilius Elianus, which was accuſed to him for an euill talker of his Maieſtie. So alſo King Philip of Macedonia was highly lauded,Philip of Macedonia. for that hee did ſo patiently putte vppe thoſe euill and ſlaunderous wordes of the Peleponeſians touching his owne honour, when ſome of his friendes would that he ſhould bee thereon ſeuerely reuenged on them. Beyonde all theſe, this right vertue (indeede) was diſplayed in Moſes towards the Iſraelites:Moſes. Dauid. Elizabeth Queene of England. in Dauid to Shimei, and is rightly apparant in our moſt mercifull Princeſſe Queene Elizabeth, towards many of her ingratefull ſubiects, and others. But moſt of all, it hath ſhined in the face of our Sauiour Chriſt, which did not onely ſay:Chriſt. VVho ſo ſpeaketh a word againſt the Sonne of man, if ſhall be forgiuen him:
but alſo, Prayed vnto his father, to pardon and forgiue them that nayled him to the Croſſe. And this vertue God himſelfe (which is onely wiſe and knoweth and ſeeth all,God commendeth vnto Princes mercie, gentlenes, by his owne example. whatſoeuer is done and committed againſt him, and from whom the priuie murmuring cannot be hidde) hath by his owne example commended vnto all Kings, Princes, and Magiſtrates in the world, that raigne by his authoritie & grace: for although that he puniſh horrible ſins with horrible plagues, he doth yet not onely ſeeme to winke at, and not to note many ſmall offences of his ſeruants againſt himſelfe, and long ſuffereth men to walke in their owne wayes before he puniſheth them: but alſo expreſſeth great Equitie in the moderation of offences, cheefely there, where by nature the maladies bee not curable. For if the Lorde ſhould deale with men after their deſerts, who were able to abide it? But vnto him belongeth mercie and forgiuenes, when vnto men belongeth ſhame and confuſion: therefore doth hee not enter haſtily into iudgement with them, nor in furie rebuke them, but in gentleneſſe and compaſſion.

Nota.10 All this being ſaide, may not iuſtly embolden any perſon to preſume againſt the Prince and Ordinance,The mercie of the Prince ſhould not encourage men to preſume againſt the Prince and lawes, nor hinder iuſtice. vppon ſuch Equitie and Lenitie of gracious Princes and wiſe Magiſtrates: nor may hinder the noble Prince and Magiſtrate from the execution of iuſtice, as occaſion and reaſons may be miniſtred. For, as hee beareth the Sword not for nought, ſo neither ſhould that man liue without all feare of the ſame, that offendeth: for hee is the miniſter of God, to take vengeance on them that do euill, and to defende and comfort them that do well, and that
it is lawfull for the Prince and Magiſtrate to puniſh (among other offences) eſpecially them that rayle vpon the Gods (that is, the Princes & Iudges) and that male pertly prattle and talke vnreuerently of theyr actions and deedes: a kinde of people woorthie of rebuke and puniſhment. But this hath beene ſaide onely to declare the great patience, lenitie, moderation, graciouſneſſe, mercifulneſſe, equitie, yea, the higheſt magnanimitie of a Prince, when he can bee well pleaſed vppon good occaſions, to neglect and ſet little by the raſh wordes and fooliſh actions of vaine and ingratefull perſons, touching his owne perſon and eſtimation.

11 Finally, although the Counſels of Pompey, The hard haps of ſome princes, ought not to diſcourage others from their duties. Alcibiades, Mithridates, Ageſelaus, haue not beene ſo happie and fortunate as the Counſels of Abraham, Dauid, Moſes, Ioſuah, and ſome other Princes in their times, yet the euents of thoſe things (beyond all expectation) do nothing aſtoniſh, nor diſcourage the wiſe Princes and learned Magiſtrates, which are well ſchooled in the diuine doctrine and feare of God: but they do learne by theſe euents, to knowe their owne infirmitie and the power of God, to bee modeſt, and not to endeuour to compaſſe things after their owne wiſedome and ſtrength, to moue vp none vnneceſſarie matters, to attempt nothing againſt the word and will of God, to remitte no diligence in their dutie, to rule well, to gouerne, to proceede, and ſtand faſt, as Moſes, Ioſuah Nehemiah, The good magiſtrate doth what he can, when he cannot do that he would. Samuel, Salomon, Dauid, and Hezekiah haue done. And moreouer, when they ſee many faults, as well in the ſeate of iudgement, as in other places of their gomernment, and know not how to redreſſe
them, nor how to amend all things that are amiſſe (notwithſtanding all their good lawes, orders, proceedings,Eccles. 3.16. and conſtitutions, a thing which Salomon himſelfe in his owne common-wealth ſaw & complained of) they doo neuertheleſſe exerciſe mercie, Mat. 23.23. iudgement, fidelitie, equitie, & other princely vertues: committing the ſucceſſe of all things to the God of heanen: waiting patiently with prayer for the goodneſſe of the Lord to appeare on them and their people, in the appointed time.

Thus hauing expreſſed the true wiſedom of their places, they ſhine with the glorie of the diuine maieſty by whome they raigne, and do henceforth expect that bountifull reward, which the almightie God promiſed and timely performed vnto his righteous ſeruant Abraham,
Gen. 15.1. according as he ſaid: Feare not Abraham, I am thy ſhield, and thine exceeding great reward. And that beautiful Crowne of eternall glorie, wherwith the ſonne of God ſhall crowne them that haue beene faithfull in his houſe.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Conſolations and inſtructions for the Paſtour.
div.p:
THe wiſe and vigilent Paſtour or Miniſter of the word, being ſent and authorized by the Lord of heauen, and diuinely taught by the wiſedom of his ſonne, ſhould be neither diſpleaſed in his mind, nor diſcouraged in his place, through the tyrannie, the ſophiſtry, the hypocriſie,
the contempt, the vaine cenſures and the ingrateful dealings of worldly men.The miniſter is authorized by God. But knowing the author of his calling to be God, and himſelfe to be the ſeruant of God, he ſhould rather reioyce and be glad, that it hath pleaſed the Lorde in mercie to ſeperate him from the world, to ſerue God in his Church. And truely, if the meane ſubiect haue good cauſe to prayſe the bountie and goodneſſe of his Prince, which ſhall exalt him from the common ſort of the people, and authorize him his honourable Embaſſador or Magiſtrate in the common-wealth, then haue the paſtours and miniſters good cauſe to praiſe the Lord God, who hath in his great loue called them by the motion of his ſpirite within them, and admitted them by an excellent calling alſo, to the preaching of his holy worde, and his diuine place. This conſideration both contenteth Paul, and maketh him glorie in the ſame. Next vnto this, the Miniſter conſidering whoſe ſeruant hee is, may be much bolder (though in a godlier ſort) then thoſe ſeruing men are of the Lords and Maiſters on whome they attende, as beeing through the countenance, authoritie, and power of them much emboldned.Ier. 1.8. Ezech. 2.6. Nowe the faces of Ieremie and Ezechiel being hereby hardened, they feare not the rebukes and frowning faces of men. Paul may bee accuſed and hardly forced by Tartullus, but yet, hee is able to aunſwere for himſelfe, beeing in this place ſuch an one as hee ſhould be. And hee ſaith boldly before king Agrippa: I would to God, that not onely thou, but alſo all they that heare me to day, were not onely ſomewhat, but alſo altogether ſuch as I am, except theſe bandes. In this regarde Michaeas is bolde
to call the people of Iſrael to witneſſe againſt Achab their King.1. King. 22. And Eliſha ſaith without bluſhing vnto Ioram, 1. King. 3.13. in the preſence of Iehoſophat King of Iuda: VVhat haue I to doo with thee? get thee to the Prophets of thy Father, and to the Prophets of thy Mother. And if it were not that I regarde the preſence of Iehoſophat the King of Iuda, I would not looke towards thee, nor yet ſee thee. So was Eliah emboldned before Achab, and Iohn the Baptiſt before Herod, nothing fearing the faces of them that could onely murther the bodie.

2 Thirdly this muſt be remembred, that the Paſtour muſt regarde his place and calling, there into walke worthily. For as he is ſet by his Lorde ouer the houſe, ſo hee muſt be faithfull to diſtribute the portions to them of the houſe in ſeaſon: that is, he muſt (as Paul teacheth) rule well, and labour in the word and doctrine. And this the wiſe man remembreth,Eccles. 12.10
Eccles 12. when he ſaith, that the Preacher was yet more wiſe, and taught the people knowledge: he gaue good heede, ſought out the ground, and ſet forth many Parables: and that he might the better teach the people knowledge, and cauſe them to heare, that he might turne them vnto rightteouſneſſe, Hee was diligent to finde out pleaſant words,
Dan. 11.33. and vpright ſcripture, euen the words of truth: Nullares diſcipulo eſt ita pernicioſa ſicut vita magiſtricontumelioſa. Boet. de diſcipl. ſcolar. Mat. 5.14. and to ſtoppe the mouthes of ignorant perſons (which reſpect more the life then the doctrine of the Paſtour, and be as children which aime rather to the behauiour then to the inſtruction of their parents) it is meete that the light of this perſon doo ſhine before men correſpondent to his teaching (as the right vrim and thumim combined) to the benefit of the Church, and the prayſe of God. God fobidde that he which ſhould be 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
The light of the world, as Chriſt called his Apoſtles, ſhould be Lumen modi, non mundi, The light of the buſhel, and not of the world, as Bernard called ſome of them in his time. Or that they which ſhould be 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . The ſalt of the earth, and inſtructors of others, as well in life as doctrine, ſhould reſemble in knowledge and wiſdome thoſe Italian Prieſts,In dicta Alfonſi. of whom Aeneas Syluius (one of the beſt learned of the Popes) complained, when he ſaid, that the verie maides at theyr diſtaues coulde anſwere, both out of the olde and new Teſtament, and yeeld a reaſon of their faith to their Catechizers: but the Prieſts themſelues were found altogither ignorant in learning and life: or that they ſhould bee both like that prophane and vnlearned Frier, who,A verie learned Frier. after hee had in his old age happilie found a newe Teſtament, and therein read a few words, ſayde to his fellowes, that either thoſe words which he had read therin, was no part of the holie Scriptures, or that he and they were no good Christians. So farre diſcented both his life and Religion from the perfect veritie: ſo blind was hee, though of the fraternitie, in that which hee ſhoulde moſt clearely haue ſeene and declared vnto others! Are theſe perſons able to doo and performe the part of an Inſtructor? Can they deale the true doctrine? Haue they any regarde of edification? No trulie: Neither (indeede) haue they yet taſted the ſweetneſſe of that comfortable Contentation and ſacietie of the Soule, which the holie Ghoſt beſtoweth in the abundance of his graces, to them that rule well, and labour in the worde and doctrine, as faithfull Paſtors.

3 But there be, which to the diſcouragement of
the good labourers thus oppoſe.Hinderances oppoſed to the Paſtor. The day is long: the burthen is heauie: the worke is intollerable: and yet, when the day is ended, and the burthen borne, and the worke performed, where is the reward? who hath his wages? where ſhall the recompence bee expected? but chieflie then, when they ſay: that not onely ſuch as inſtruct many (as Iſaiah, and Michaeah, and Zacharie, and Iohn) do fall by the ſworde, by fire, by captiuitie, and by ſpoyle manie dayes: Dan. 11.33. but alſo ſome of them of vnderſtanding, as Iulian, Nicholas, Iudas, the Biſhops of Rome, and others learned in the Scriptures, do fall, to trie them, and to purge them! Then (I ſay) they reſolue thus with the buier, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, Nought, nought: deare, deare.
Pro. 20.14. Howbeeit, as the faithfull Paſtour dooth acknowledge the grace and mercies of God his Lord and maſter towards him, and is right glad of his calling and place in the Church, with thankfulneſſe: as he ruleth well, and laboureth in the word & doctrine worthily: and as he beleeueth that the Lorde God which hath called him, and ſent him to worke in his vineyard, is both able and willing to help and defend him, as he helped and defended his ſeruants, Samuel, Ieremie, Daniel, and ſuch others: ſo hee doth not reckon that the Lorde hath ſhut him out from the true peace: but he remembreth the wordes of his maiſter,Peace. who ſayde: Peace bee vnto you: my peace I leaue with you: in the worlde ye ſhall haue tribulation: but in me ye ſhall haue peace. The word of Chriſt full of comfort to the Miniſters. Neither dooth hee forget to pray vnto God, that he would vouchſafe to conteine him within the bounds of this peace, that neither by his doctrine, nor by his life, nor by dealing in matters vnneceſſarie, nor by diſputing about
genealogies, and vaine queſtions, nor by the yeelding to the enemie of mans ſoule, hee hinder the happie courſe of the Goſpel of peace, that hee no way diſturbe this peace, which is, and ſhould for euer bee retained among the Miniſters of the Goſpel: as of more account and eſtimation, then all the fauour, friendſhippe, pleaſure, and treaſure of the worlde. And then, after that hee hath long preached peace, and laboured therein,The reſolutiō of the wiſe Miniſter. and yet perceiueth that men prepare themſelues to warres and contentions: and hath beene a workman in the vineyard many dayes, and ſeeth not any fruit of his toile to his deſire: he doth not, for all that, thinke that hee hath ſpoken in the ayre, or that he hath laboured in vaine, and loſt his trauailes: but reſolueth, Eſay. 55.20 that as the raine and ſnow which commeth downe from heauen, returneth not hither againe, but watereth the earth, maketh it fruitfull and greene, that it may giue corne to the ſower, & bread to him that eateth, ſo the word of God which he hath preached vnto the people, ſhall not turne againe voide vnto him, but accompliſh the will of God, and proſper in the rhing whereunto he ſendeth it: and that His labours in the Lord are not in vaine. Moreouer,A reward. he doubteth not, but beleeueth, that his reward is with the Lord, who eſteeming his labours in him profitable, will dulie make paiment thereof in time cōuenient: not according to the quantitie and qualitie of the fruit, but after the meaſure and qualitie of his labors. And in this,The labour of him that waſheth an Ethiopian is not without wages he knoweth himſelfe to be righly likened vnto him that is hired to waſh an Ethiopian or Black-moore, and is promiſed a reward for his dayes labour, howſoeuer the Blac-moore appeare
after his waſhing: and vnto that ſchoolmaſter, who in all equitie is not to be neglected, but to be rewarded for his diligence emploied on his ſcholers, how ſoeuer they profit. Neither doth he thinke, that Ezechiel the Prophet was to looſe all his paynes in his miniſterie, notwithſtanding that the Lorde ſayde of the people to whome hee ſhould preach, They are the children of an hard face, Ezech. 2.4.
and ſtiffe heart: they are a rebellious houſe: briers and thornes are with thee, and thou dooſt dwell among Scorpions. And thou ſhalt ſpeake my wordes vnto them, whether they will heare or not heare: that they may knowe, that there hath beene a Prophet among them. So, albeit that the ingratefull people, which haue no feeling, and as little religion, ſay vnto the Miniſter, wee bee neuer the better for all thy ſtudies, thy paines, thy preaching, thy teaching, thy labouring: and therefore what reaſon haue wee to bee louing, and thankefull vnto thee? yet he perceiueth,Gods iudgements on thē that contemne the word. that their ſuddaine iudgements falling on them in their times, doo teſtifie his labours, which they contemned, and the contempt whereof the Lord nowe reuengeth to his glorie. Againe, hee ſeeth, that there is a rewarde layde vp for him by the Lord in his mercie,A reward for labourers. who forgetteth not his labours, and that hee ſhall receiue this reward in due time to his beſt content. For hee hath heard what hee promiſed. Dan. 11.2. They that bee wiſe ſhall ſhine as the brightneſſe of the Firmament, and they that turne manie to righteouſneſſe, as the ſtarres for euer and euer. Againe, Hier. 45.5. Thy life will I giue thee for a praie in all places whither ſo euer thou goeſt. And (to omit other places) he remembreth the wordes of Paul: 1. Cor. 15.58.
Therefore, my beloued brethren, be ye ſtedfaſt, vnmoueable, alwayes abounding in the worke of the Lord: for aſmuch as wee knowe, that your labour is not in vaine in the Lorde. The labours of all Chriſtians, but chieflie the labours of the faythfull Miniſters, whom the Lorde hath ſet ouer his houſe, to ſuch he ſaith, that cannot lie: Bleſſed is that ſeruant,
Mat. 24.46. and 25.23. his Lorde will make him ruler ouer all his goods. He ſhall be made ruler ouer many things: And in a worde, He ſhall be partaker of the ioy of his Lord. This thing when he enioyeth, he will not ſay, It is deere, deere: but with the Pſalmiſt, hee ſhall ſing, Hinne ma tob! Beholde howe good it is! and with him which hath obtained a great good thing for a little money: It is well woorth my money, Prou. 20.14 I haue therein a great pennie-worth. Then will he commend that which before hee was tempted to contemne, and will not be diſcontented, nor repent him ſelfe of his bargain, though he hath ſolde with that wiſe marchant all that euer he had, to purchaſe the field wich containeth this treaſure: then will hee account indeed (with Paul, Rom. 8.18. that All the afflictions of this time, are not worthie of the glorie that ſhalbe to them reuealed. Chriſt hath made himſelfe an enſample for labourers. To this therfore hath our Lord armed his diſciples: and to ratifie the fame, hee hath worthily made his owne example perpetual for the immitation and conſolation of the painfull labourers. For notwithſtanding he was moſt vnreuerently derided, mocked, oppugned, and perſecuted of the Scribes, Phariſees, high prieſts, and others, in all his doctrines, myracles, and good workes, he did proceed in his moſt godly purpoſes (mawgre all their malignitie) he ſet the Lord euer before his face: the ſame Lord ſtoode at his right hand, hee left not his
ſoule in hell, he ſuffred him not to ſee corruption: he ſhewed him the way of life: he made him full of ioy with his countenance: hee gaue him his hearts deſire: he ſet a crowne of pure gold on his head▪ he exalted him on high, and gaue him a name aboue al names, and made him a King ouer all Kings, for euer and euer. And he hath promiſed, that where he is, there ſhall alſo his miniſter be: and he that miniſtreth vnto him, ſhall be honoured of his father in the kingdome of heauen.

div.head: CHAP. XXIIII.
Comforts to content the houſholder, the Scribe, and other perſons in their ſeuerall places.
div.p:
AS the holy Scriptures haue manie meete meditations for euerie maladie, ſo alſo among others, there be many ſweet comforts therein, to appeaze and content the houſholder, who, as it is before declared, is tormented with no ſmall troubles and afflictions of mind: wherby there is to him commended the right vſe of his calling.The houſholder is to conſider his calling, and vſe it. He is counſelled to marry a wife in the feare of God: to til and manure his ground, ſo ſeeke for wealth & treaſures, by all honeſt and godly meanes, for the maintenance of himſelf, his wife and children, his family and eſtate: to educate and inſtruct his children in the nurture and feare of the Lord: to care for his houſehold, to be mindful of the poore, to do his duty, and not to be daunted with the negligent foole, nor to
giue ouer all, & care for nothing. Thus is he ſchooled to labour, and do his endeuour within the rules of his calling, with quietnes, cōtentation, and chriſtian comfort, hauing in mind that wholſome counſell of King Salomon:
Pro. 27.23. Be diligent to know the ſtate of thy flocke, and take heede to thy hands. Then hauing conſidered of his calling and place,He muſt commit the perfection of his labors to God, to whom he muſt pray to this effect. Luther in Pſal. it ſhalbe the beſt way for him to commit the perfection of his labors and affaires to the Lord, on whom it is euer good to depend, and to whome the good houſholder daylie prayeth to this effect. O Lord God, thou hast ordained me to be an houſholder: the things that appertaine to mine houſe, thou haſt of thy great goodneſſe giuen me: but lo, the burthen and charge thereof, is heauier then that I am able to beare. Therefore I beſeech thee, to ſupplie my place: be thou the good houſholder, and I will with all mine heart ſubmit and yeeld my ſelfe vnto thee. This praier being made in ſimplicitie and truth, the Lord will heare, and thus will he anſwere to the ſame.The Lords anſwere. I will indeed performe this matter: Onelie I will, that thou ſo prepare thy ſelfe, as thou maiſt in patience ouercome and conquer all things. Though matters come not to paſſe after thine owne minde, and when thou wouldeſt that they ſhould be perfited: yet I will not that thou ſhouldeſt deſpaire, nor forſake this kinde of life to the which I haue prepared thee, and called thee to ſerue me in. For ſeeing that thou haſt called vpō me, & haſt acknowledged al theſe things which I haue beſtowed on thee, to bee my gracious gifts, I will gladly preſerue thee and thy familie. Howbeit, if any aduerſe or grieuous things betide thee, I will that thou beare the ſame with patience, in ſuch ſort as thou bee not diſmaied, or doubtfull whether
all other things will not followe, but in the like ſort. Remember my ſeruaunt Iob, who in his afflictions could thus aunſwere: Iob. 2.10. Shall we receiue good things from the Lord, and not receiue euill or aduerſe things alſo? Remember alſo what my ſeruaunt Paul hath written to the Corinthians. There hath no temptation taken you, 1. Cor. 10.13. but ſuch as apperteineth to man, and God is faithfull, which will not ſuffer you to be tempted aboue that yee be able: but will euen giue the iſſue with the temptation, that ye may be able to beare it. To paſſe ouer the Families of Adam, of Noah, of Abraham, of Loth, of Iſaak, of Iacob, of Moſes, of Ioſuah, of Samſon, of Gedeon, of Samuel: What houſholde hath ſeemed more miſerable,The familie of Dauid. then that of Dauid in his dayes? His wiues, his ſonnes, his daughters, his Counſailers, his ſeruants, his kinsfolkes, his ſubiectes, his enemies, both abroade and at home, gaue him oftentimes ſharpe vineger mingled with gall, whereby he mixed his drinke with weeping teares. And ſo after him many hard lots betided his family: yet ſee, how this family continued without ruine or decay, through the only ſtay of my grace, vntill that my ſonne Chriſt was born therof. Wherfore do thou alſo thy dutie in thy place:Ecclus. 7.15. account no labourious work tedious to thee in thy vocation, nor the husbandry that I haue created and cōmit thy ſelfe, and the ſucceſſe of all things vnto me, with faithfull expectation of the performance of all my promiſes; and ſo thou ſhalt not onely haue a peaceable heart and right contented mind in this worlde, but alſo that comfortable and bleſſed life in the world to come, which I haue prepared and promiſed to giue vnto them, that neuer turne their beliefe from me. With theſe moſt ſweet
conſolations, doth the Lord God cheare and ſolace the good Houſholder, whom hee would not haue to be driuen from his place, though neuer ſo yrkſome, Rom. 12.21. nor to be ouercome of euill, but to ſtand faſt, and to ouercome euill with goodneſſe, being through the grace of God made a right valiant ſouldier, to fight vnder the bleſſed banner of his Sonne, againſt the Diuell, the world, and the fleſh.

2 Finally, in all ſorrowfull euents that occurre in this eſtate (among others) that good counſaile of Demipho in Terence is not to be reiected, though a heathen man, yet ſpeaking diuinely, whom therefore Luther writing on the Eccleſiaſtes of Salomon, cap. 10. citeth, ſpeaking much after this ſort: Quamobrem omnes, &c.

q.l: VVherefore, when men their greateſt wealth enioy,Demipho in Phormio.
They cheefely then ſhould ponder well in minde:
How best to beare the burdens of annoy,
The perils, plagues, exiles, to them aſſign'de.
Returning home from farre, how they may findeA good reſolution for the houſholder.
Their ſonnes defaults, their louing wiues enterr'd,
Their tender daughters ſicke, or ſore afer'd.
Theſe be the haps, and hurts, that common be:
Theſe be the things, that eke may come to thee.
VVhat euer falles beſides th'expected lot,
Account it gaine, as ſo much clearely got.

div.p:
3 Moreouer,
A good reſolution for the Scribe or learned writer.
Ier. 45.5.
Baruch the painefull Scribe ought not to be diſcouraged after his laborious watchings and long labours, nor to diſpayre of his good wages and ſufficient recompence: for verily, though his expectation of thoſe worldly promotions which
