he offereth be vaine, becauſe the captiuitie is threatned by the Lord ſhortly to enſue, and a miſerable plague is brought vpon all fleſh, according as himſelfe hath written by the direction of Ieremie the Prophet: yet hath the Lorde prouided for him a farre better thing then worldly promotions: for thus hath the Lorde promiſed him, that Hee will giue him his life for a praie in all places whither ſoeuer hee goeth. And this is no ſmall matter: For as the bodie is more worth then meate, and the life then raiment: ſo a man will not ſticke to giue all that euer hee hath for his life. A treaſure which no worldly man is able to purchaſe with all the plentie of this life. And yet this benefite extendeth it ſelfe further, to the endleſſe comfort of them that take paine by their pens to pleaſure many others, when that of the goodneſſe of God in his ſonne Chriſt, hee ſhall not onely liue among the famous, in this preſent worlde throughout all generations, in the mouthes and memories of men, which reape the fruits of his labours, to the praiſe of God, and their inſtruction: but alſo beyond all time, he ſhall liue, and ſhine with the Lord, among the bleſſed Saints for euermore. And what ſhould a man deſire more? Ii is certaine that the Lorde is euer the ſame: his warrant and worde is of ſo great credite and aſſuraunce, as euer it was ſithence the worlde was created.

An incouragement to yong ſchollers, to write in a booke the words of wiſe men.4 When my ſelfe being a yong ſcholler in the Vniuerſitie, did ordinarily gather and write into a booke, the chief notes of the Sermons and Lectures which I heard preached and read in the Churches and other publike places there, one of my fellowes
(which thought ſomwhat of himſelf) ſaid vnto me, that mine exerciſe was nothing but a drudgery, and he maruailed why I tooke ſuch labour therein? I anſwered him, that thereby I was willing (by the grace of God) to profite not onely my ſelfe, but many others. Neither at this time doo I repent of my paines taken therein, as if I had nought but toyle for my labour (as Baruch did:Iere. 4.5. ) but I am right glad thereof, and do praiſe God for ſuch an opportunitie offered me: not doubting, but, as I doo and ſhall thereby the better diſcharge my dutie in my place and calling, and benefite many others: ſo alſo the Lords promiſe of life in his Sonne Chriſt (on whom by faith I depende) will bee performed and eſtabliſhed indue and conuenient time, to mine endleſſe comfort. Therefore I do gladlie exhort all young men that bee deſirous of knowledge, and ſtudious in the the worde of God, to doo the like, and to make ſome profite and vſe of their long ſtudies and exerciſes, as thoſe gratefull Bees, which flying hither and thither, do collect and gather from manie ſweete flowers, and wholſome hearbs, that little pith or iuice, whereof (their hiues or ſtore-houſes beeing repleniſhed) themſelues are relieued, and manie others comforted. And howſoeuer the wiſedome of the world derideth and diſdaineth the wiſdom of God, which oftentimes appeareth as in fooliſhneſſe before men: yet, let not that maine ſtroke daunt you,Obſonia quiſ
que palato, digna ſuo quaerit: non omnibus vnà voluptas. into whom God hath poured the wiſedome of his ſpirit. And although that one pleaſure contenteth not all, but euerie one hunteth after that which hee beſt fancieth: it is moſt certaine by the firme warrant of Chriſt, that VViſedome
is iuſtified of her owne Children. The wiſe and well affected will eſteeme of your vertues, then what fooles and prophane diriders ſhall do, why ſhould ye regarde? anſwere them after their follie, but not according to their expectation: neither ſing with them in their diſcorded tunes. Let not the ingratefull requitalles of the world trouble you: poſſeſſe your ſoules in patience, and expect the fruits of your trauailes, and comfortable reward from him only, that forgetteth not your loue, your faith, your diligence, your trauaile and paines that ye haue ſuſtained and endured for his cauſe, and the good of your brethren.

A comfort for the poore beleeuers.5 Neither let the poore eſtate of Chriſt and his immitators, cauſe any of vs to diſlike our profeſſion: conſider that God hath choſen the poore of this world, & hath made euen them heires of his kingdome,Art. Solen. whoſe children they are, as Aratus ſaide. The poore receiue the Goſpel without offence, & thoſe poore in ſpirit are bleſſed: for theirs is the kingdom of heauen, as Chriſt himſelfe hath taught vs, who (though he were king of all kings, and rich beyond al the Lords of the earth, without al compariſō) diſdained not at any time to viſit the poore, to accompanie the poore,A comfort for the rich. & to preach the Goſpel vnto them to their great comfort. On the other part, if God giue vs riches, honours, eſtimation in this world, as he gaue vnto Abraham, Dauid, Ioſeph, Daniel, let vs be thankfull to God, and rightly vſe theſe things in the feare of God, as thoſe holy men haue done, and haue taught vs therein, and let vs not abuſe the gifts of God to the ſatiſfying of our fleſhly appetites,Luke. 16. as that Diues did, of whom Chriſt ſpeaketh in the Goſpel:
and as diuers others vſe moſt commonly to do, whē with the ſame, they exalt themſelues in pride, they face their betters, threaten & brow-beat their Chriſtian brethren, wring and vndoo many of their neighbours, and prouide moſt delicious for theyr owne bellies, and gloriouſly for their owne backs, with that, wherewith they ſhould (in all dutie) releeue thoſe poore afflicted, which are conſtrained with penurie to ſtatue, of whom onely this regard they take, Am I the keeper of my brother?Gen. 4. that was Cains anſwere to God, touching his brother Abel. Let vs know, that it hath pleaſed God to make vs his truſtie Stewards,Rich men be Gods ſtewards. and the things that we haue are not our owne, but his things, and therfore it is not lawfull for vs to burie them in the ground with that ſlothfull ſeruant, nor waſte them away with the prodigall ſonne: but to employ them to his glorie, to the bnefit of our brethren, and to the neceſſitie of our ſtates and liues heere. And though it be hard for him that truſteth in riches and worldly promotions, to enter into the kingdom of heauen, yet to them that haue them of the bleſſing of God; as Abraham had, and vſe them rightly, as Abraham did, it ſhall be ſaid, as vnto that good ſeruant in the Goſpel, VVell doone thou good and truſtie ſeruant, thou haſt been faithfull in few things, thou ſhalt therefore be made ruler ouer many things, enter thou into the ioy of the Lord. But whether yee be poore,An inſtructiō. or rich, whether in meane place, or place of extremitie, whether ye doo want or haue inough, let that good counſaile of our Lord Ieſus bee euer remembred and daily obſerued. Take no thought ſaying,
Mat. 6 31. what ſhall wee eate, or what ſhall we drinke? or wherewith ſhall we be clothed? for after al theſe things do the Gentiles ſeeke:
for your heauenly father knoweth, that yee haue neede of all theſe things: but ſeeke ye firſt the kingdome of God, and his righteouſneſſe, and all theſe things ſhall bee miniſtred vnto you. Care not thē for the morrow: for the morrow ſhal care for it ſelfe: the day hath enough with his owne trauell. For our Lord would not, that we ſhould vexe our ſelues out of meaſure in the care of theſe worldlie things: but that labouring truly in our vocations, we ſhould haue an eſpeciall regard of the kingdom of God, & how to walke in a new life in this world: not doubting any thing, but that the Lord which hath created vs, wil ſo prouide euery day for vs, that we ſhall not want things neceſſarie in this worlde, though we augment not the preſent griefe by our exceſsiue carefulneſſe, how to liue in time to come. So that in all worldly things wee ſhould ſtay our ſelues cōtented, only for the things of the kingdom of heauen, & the righteouſneſſe thereof, we ſhould hunger and thirſt, without all ſacietie, as long as we liue: for of this wee can neuer haue inough in this life.The ſacietie of the Saints in heauen. But the ſufficiencie thereof, ſhal be happily enioyed to our endleſſe comfort and contentation, in that heauenly manſion, wherin we ſhal find rowme inough: we ſhall poſſeſſe riches and wealth inough: we ſhall haue honour and glorie inough: and of all good things wee ſhall enioy aboundance without meaſure.

6 In the meane time, let not vs which feare God and belong vnto his kingdome, be diſcouraged, nor diſtracted, when we do not only conſider the generall miſeries of all troubles of all mankind:1. Cor. 15. but alſo when we ponder of thoſe heauie croſſes which we our ſelues are conſtrained to beare, by the which
we were of al men the moſt miſerable, if the dead did not riſe again. With this, let vs heare, & wel obſerue to our cōſolation, that which Ben-Gorian, or the Author of the 2. booke of the Macchabees hath written for the cōfort of all them that read his book:2. Macc. 6.1. I beſeech thoſe that reade this booke (ſaith he) that they bee not diſcouraged for theſe calamities: but that they iudge theſe afflictions not to be for deſtruction, but for a chaſtening of our nation: for it is a token of his great goodneſſe, not to ſuffer ſinners long to continue: but ſtraight wayes to puniſh them. For the Lord doth not long waite for vs, as for other nations, who he puniſheth when they are come to the fulneſſe of their ſinnes: But thus hee dealeth with vs, that our ſinnes ſhould not bee heaped vp to the full, ſo that afterward hee ſhould puniſh vs. And therefore he neuer withdraweth his mercie from vs: and though hee puniſh with aduerſitie, yet doth he neuer forſake his people. But let this be ſpoken now for a warning vnto vs. And that ſaying of the Lord to Paul, in his greateſt diſtreſſe, cannot but rauiſh the ſpirits of them that truſt in God:2. Cor. 12.2.9. Note. My grace (ſayth he) is ſufficient for thee. This word of comfort made him in true patience to poſſeſſe his ſoule, and to haue a contented minde. Vnto theſe, when the vſe of the word of God ioyneth, oh God, what comfort, pleaſure and profit ſhall the beleeuer reape thereof! he ſhall feele how The power of God is made perfite through weakneſſe: and therefore he will reioyce euen in infirmities, that the power of Chriſt may dwel in him: he will patiently beare infirmities, reproches, neceſſities, perſecutions and anguiſhes for Chriſts ſake.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
Euerie man is to take the benefite of time: to keepe within the bounds of his vocation, and to depend on the diuine prouidence: the vnlike endes of pietie and impietie.
div.p:
AS in the word of God there is dulie cōmēded to euery perſon a lawful vocation or calling in this world, wherin he is to ſerue God, benefit his country, & diſcharge himſelf, in the feare of God: ſo is he aduiſed in the ſame, to do the workes of his vocation,The time of working. then whiles health and opportune time ſerueth there vnto. For our life and health is giuen vs of God, of whoſe mercifull hand wee muſt acknowledge the ſame to come by our timely acceptation and right vſing thereof. As he onely foſtereth and ſuſtaineth our life, and our health in this world, ſo hath he appointed it to be but ſhort, and tranſitorie, without any return of it, when it paſſeth away. And when our bodies are diſeaſed and enfeebled, then neither the cogitation is apt to learne anie thing, or to pray, or to ſuſtaine the great cares and painfull labours,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
Ariſtotle. which the vocation requireth: for (as the Philoſopher ſayth) Good health and ſtrength is the verie foundation and ſtay of the life. Therefore wee muſt pray to the Lord, that we may both be taught and learne the true doctrine, and propagate the ſame, and follow the works of our vocation in time conuenient.

2 For, as we be perſwaded, that there is a time
for euerie labour, and euerie worke vnder the Sun (as ſaith Salomon) ſo do we enioy the benefit of our time,The vſe of the benefit of time. when wee embrace and vſe the bleſſings of God, in his feare with thankfulneſſe and contentation. God in this time ſheweth himſelfe in mercie towards vs, hee doth inuite vs to his heauenly banquet, he ſendeth foorth his ſeruants to that ende, and they daily crie vnto vs: Oh come nowe, and make no longer tarrying, for all things are prepared and made readie for you. Beholde (ſayth hee himſelfe) I ſtand at the doore and knocke, if any man open vnto mee, I will come in vnto him. Nowe whiles hee calleth, Apoc. 3.20. Of this Argument I haue written a dialogue, intituled the Teares of Time. lette vs giue care: whiles hee inuiteth, lette vs come: whiles the things be readie, lette vs vſe them, and not contemne the Lordes great bountie and mercie, leaſt peraduenture hee ſay: Yee ſhall not enter inter into my reſt: yee ſhall not taſte of my meate: ye are come too late, the gate is ſhut vppe: I know you not: depart hence: the tide tarrieth for no man: the time is paſt.

There is nothing more precious then Time, Time is precious, yet time is waſted and neglected. and yet (alas) nothing is founde to bee ſo vile in theſe dayes. The day of health paſſeth away, and no man recounteth it: no man conſidereth how his dayes be conſumed, without retire or returne: but as there ſhall not one haire of the head periſh, ſo neither any one moment of time ſhall eſcape. O therfore, before that the houre paſſeth away, which the mercie of thy maker hath giuen thee to repent, to obtaine pardon, to apprehende grace, to atchieue glorie, before the time time bee gone wherein thou mayſt reſemble the diuine pietie, and haſten to the Angelles ſocietie, ſtirre vppe thy negligent
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
will, and bewaile thy committed ſinne.

The Apoſtle admoniſheth (Gal. 6.) VVhiles wee haue time, let vs doo good vnto all men. As if he ſaid: we may be glad, yt we haue this benefit of time, wherein we may through the goodneſſe of God (if wee will) doo thoſe good workes which belongeth to Chriſtians in our ſeuerall vocations: wherefore let vs not looſe this good opportunitie, but diſcharge our duties in the feare of God: and not to lette that paſſe from vs, which being once gon, can neuer bee recouered againe. And that is the meaning of the Prophet alſo where he ſaith:Iſay. 55.
Seeke the Lord whiles he may be found: Cal vpon him, whiles he is neare. It may be, God will not ſo eaſily be foūd at an other time: peraduenture, he will not be ſo readie at an other ſeaſon to offer himſelfe vnto you, as now: therefore account this time as pretious, & neglect it not, wherein the Lord is willing to bee found, if ye ſeeke him: and to be at hand to helpe you, if ye call vpon him. Therfore the wiſe man (which had ſo deepely conſidered of the times and condition of this worlde, counſaileth moſt wiſely:Eccles. 12.
Remember thy maker in the time of thy youth, before the euill daies come. Againe he ſaith: Cap. 7.14. and 9.11. Vſe well the time of proſperitie, and remember the time of aduerſitte: for a man knoweth not his time: But like as the fiſhes bee taken with the Angle, and as the birds are caught with the ſnare, euen ſo are men taken in the perilous time, when it commeth ſo dainely vpon them. Wherefore hee ſaith againe: VVhat ſoeuer thou takeſt in hand to doo, that doo, with all thy power: for in the graue (whereunto thou tendeſt) there is neither work, counſaile, knowledge nor wiſedome.

Thus let him which hath that opportune time ſo
working and doing his dutie, not contemne nor neglect it. He hath time now, to morrow he may not haue it: if hee be vnwilling this day,Qui non est hodie cras minus aptus erit. the next day hee may be further off, as hee ſayth. To morrow more vnfitte, who is unfitte to day. Nowe this is our time, God grant wee neglect it not, but rightly vſe it.

3 Next, wee are to take heede,To continue within the limits of our vocations. that wee follow not thoſe diſcontented and curious perſons, to breake foorth or tranſgreſſe the right bounds of our vocations. Let vs remember what our Lorde ſaide to his Apoſtle Peter, who had forgotten his owne vocation and place, and curiouſly noted his fellow Iohn: If I will, that hee tarrie till I come,
Mat. 21.22. what is that to thee? follow thou me. And that of Paul, where hee ſaith: Lette euerie man abide within the compaſſe of that vocation wherein hee is placed. Men ought to be content with their owne places▪ Thus ought men to be contented with their places and condition of life, (the ſame beeing lawfull) albeit they bee called to labour in the vineyard, but for their ſingle penny a day, or to gleane the eares of Corne after the reapers with poore Ruth: and not to emulate others, or to grutch at them that are in in better ſtate then themſelues are. When Socrates had conſidered the courſe of mans life,Socrates his ſaying touching the choiſe of let • in this life. and had compared the condition of one man with the condition of another, hee ſayde: that if the vniuerſall calamities of all men ſhould bee gathered together into one heape, and then to euerie man it ſhould bee ſeuerally diſtributed like portions out of the ſame heape, it would bee that each man would rather chooſe to beare his owne calamities (meaning ſuch as befall him within his
lawfull vocation and condition) then to take part and part like with others,Note this. out of that commō heape. And ſurely we may well thinke, that euerie man is beſt fitte for that vocation, wherein God placeth him, and that none other can ſo eaſily beare the burdens and greefes of that vocation, as hee that is thereunto ſo appointed by the Lorde, who giueth him abilitie to ſuſtaine the ſame. 1. Cor: 10.13.
Luth. in Eccle. and that the afflictions do ſpring of mans ambition, enuie, ignorance, errours, and infirmities, as things by him deſerued.

4 Neither let vs waxe angrie with our ſelues, or with other mē, if things anſwere not to our trauels and deſires, but conſider that all lieth in the power and pleaſure of God, to whō our eſtates, conditions, and the end of our liues is wel knowne, that he protecteth & guideth vs. Therfore with the poore widow Ruth, let vs rruſt vnder ye ſhadow of his wings, and thus reſolue: Pro. 20.24.19. VVell, our lots are in the hand of God, hee watcheth ouer vs, hee beginneth, he continueth, he endeth ouer worke. VVe are contented with our ſtate and condition, & endeuour to pleaſe God in the ſame. He beſt knoweth what is to be done with vs and with our labours. He is doubtfull of nothing: he worketh all for the beſt to them that feare him, God preſerueth men in dangers. and that do reuerence before him. Beholde! when men in a verie little bottome, ſayle ouer the mightie Ocean, God declareth himſelfe a mightie preſeruer and a moſt ſure guide of life vnto thē, wherein (as ſaith Dauid) they cannot but behold the great workes of God. Now it maketh no great matter though the common mariners know not the way nor the ende of the voyage, if the ſame bee ſufficiently known to the owne or maſter of the ſhip.
In like maner when wee labour and toyle in great extremities and daungers of this life, we euer finde God moſt merciful vnto vs, and a louing Sauiour of our liues: and though we know not what ſhall bee the end of our courſe, being vncertaine of the euent of things, let this yet pleaſe vs, that The Lord our king, our gouernour, our maiſter, our captaine, and right owner, knoweth it well, and directeth vs in the best courſe, whom we ought to hearken vnto, and to follow after the example of Iohn.

5 But ye ſay: Things are confuſed in this world. It is verie certaine,Though all things ſeeme confuſed to vs yet God doth order all. that as in a great aſſembly of many perſons diuerſly diſpoſed (where euerie one of them hath his ſeuerall talke, or ſong, or noyſe) nothing can be perceyued, beſides a moſt confuſed ſound or rumbling: ſo (indeed) is the ſtate of men in this world with themſelues, whom euen their own affaires do aſtoniſh and confound. Neither do they conſider how things proceed, ſucceed, and bee carried in the worlde, no more then the idiot or foole doth conſider of the order and courſe of the Sunne, the Moone, and other celeſtiall motions with the ordinarie diſpoſition of the Elements, and things inferiour with the ſame. Nor ſeeme thoſe men in their buſie ſtruglings and dealings one with another, much vnlike the Ants or Emmets, that wander hither & thither without all order. Howbeit it is moſt true, that the Lord God doth not onely ſee all, Ier. 23.23, 24. and heare all, moſt perfectly: but alſo trieth, diſpoſeth, ruleth, and ordereth all after his wiſdome, will, and power moſt effectually, howſoeuer the groſſneſſe of mans wit cannot conceiue it. There is nothing hidden from the greatneſſe of his power,
Iſay. 40.26.28, 29. ſtrength and
might (ſayeth the Prophet) hee is neither wearie, nor faint, his wiſedome cannot bee comprehended, hee worketh, he ruleth, he moderateth, hee taketh vp, hee casteth downe, he giueth health, he ſendeth ſickneſſe: through him we liue, and mooue. Of this ſpeaketh Sibylla the auntient Propheteſſe.
div.q:
Pre. li 7. ca. 27.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

q.l: Heare me (ye men) and marke well what I ſay:
The King eternall reignes and rules for aye.

div.p: But chiefly the ſweete Pſalmiſt of Iſrael, qualifying thoſe rayling taunts, and godleſſe ieſtures of the prophane heathen, hath moſt finely and diuinely modulated thereof, in theſe ſhort verſes.

q.l: Pſal. 115.2.Lammah iomeru haggoiim?
Aiiehna Elohehem?
Velohenu baſſchamaiim,
Kol aſcher chaphitz Y aſchah.

div.p: Thus engliſhed:

q.l: VVhy ſay the Heathen with geſtures vnſightie?
VVhere now forſooth, is their God almightie?
Our God is in heauen, in his holy hill:
There working all things what ſoeuer he will.

div.p:
And further to declare vnto vs, that all things are done, by the will, power, wiſedome, and prouidence of God, that the Church might haue comfort and patience in all her troubles, and heauie afflictions, vnder the vnhappie raigne of Antichrist, Apoc. 4.2. the Lorde declareth himſelfe to Saint Iohn,
like a moſt mightie and puiſſant King, ſitting on his throane, determining the things that ſhoulde be brought to paſſe.

6 And with this, we are iuſtly moued to conſider, that though the multitude of fooles, and their proſperitie in this world, on the one ſide, and the ſmall number of the godly,God ſeteth the difference betweene the good and euil. Gen. 1.4. Pſal. 58.10. and their aduerſitie on the other ſide (with ſo many ſhewes of confuſion and diſorder in this life) do verie much beguile the opinions of men: yet, that the Lord hath ſet a difference betweene the godly and the vngodly, as hee hath diuided the light from the darkeneſſe. And therefore notwithſtanding, that in this worlde the tares are mixt with the corne, and Nimrod, and Pharao be aduanced in the pride of their hearts: yet the time commeth, when the tares ſhall be weeded out from among the corne, and burnt in the fire, and the corne gathered into the Garner, and barn of ſafetie. This thing the wiſe mā ſetteth forth in theſe words: Sap. 3.1.10. and 5.6.2. The ſoule of the righteous are in the hande of God, and no torments ſhall touch them. But as for the vngodlie, they are puniſhed according to their imaginations. Againe, the righteous do ſtande in great boldneſſe: but the vngodly are vexed with horrible feare. And this the Lord confirmeth in his Sermon of the laſt iudgement. The ſonne of man (ſaith he) ſhall ſeparate them one from another, Mat. 25.
as a ſhepheard diuideth the ſheepe from the goates: and he ſhall place the ſheepe on his right hand, and the goates on the left hand. Vnto this time Salomon looked (no doubt) when hee ſayde:Eccles. 3.16.17.
God ſhall ſeparate the righteous from the wicked, and then ſhall bee the time and iudgement of all counſailes and workes. And this remembred Dauid. Pſal. 58.9, 10.

Obiection. 7 But vntil then, it is ſo that in this world, Diagoras the Atheiſt, and Dionyſe the Tyrant, and the Cyclopicall Epicures, do take their pleaſure to ieaſt at the prouidence of God, contemne the Goſpel, deſpiſe the Lords annointed, diſdaine the Godly, raile on the Miniſters of the word, and nothing feare the threatnings of the holy Prophets, and Apoſtles, and that the rather, becauſe their iudgements are deferred, and their ſelues permitted to wallow in their ſinnes without puniſhment!Reſ. What then? Is there not a God therefore that ſeeth and iudgeth all? And will not he be reuenged on them that ſinne againſt him of malicious wickedneſſe? Yes doubtleſſe. And the time commeth,God hath his particluar iudgements. Pſal. 58.11. Iob. 19.29. when thoſe Atheiſtical and godleſſe miſcreants ſhal know, euen in the world, there is a God that iudgeth in the earth, as Dauid ſaith: and that the ſame God hath not onely a iudgement (as Iob ſaid to Bildad) but alſo particular iudgements, ſometimes ſecrete: ſometimes open, that not at the day of euerie man▪ death onely, wherein there is made a ſeparation betweene the good and the euill: but at ſundrie times within the compaſſe of his life, as the Lord ſeeth it good: Ior. 25 31. for (as Ieremie ſaide) The Lord hath his iudgements to giue vpon all people, and will holde his Court of iuſtice with all fleſh, and will deliuer the vngodly to the ſword. Deut. 32. In the which, as the worke of the Lord is perfite, as Moſes ſayde, and all his wayes are iudgement: ſo alſo hee being Iudge of all the worlde, Gen. 18.28. dealeth according to right, as Abraham diſputeth. For whether his iudgements bee ſecrete or open, generall or particular, he euer executeth them iuſtly, Pſal. 111.8. and performeth them in truth and equitie. And certain it is, that into this iudgemēt is brought
euerie perſon, whether man or woman, young or old, and euerie worke, be it good, or be it euill. In this iudgement the godly ſaints ſtand, Pſal. 1.5.6. and be cleared: they haue great boldneſſe and comfort, they haue quier conſciences, contented hearts, and great gladneſſe. But the vngodly are not able to ſtande: they tremble and fall downe: for why, vnto them the Lord ſpeaketh in his wrath,Though plagues be deferred, yet they are not remoued from the vngodly in the day time. Pſa. 50.21.23 and vexeth them in his heauie diſpleaſure. And though their plagues for a time were not inflicted, but were deferred, when they iuſtly deſerued plagues, by their ſinning a thouſand times againſt God and his ſaints: yet now, their time being come, they be taken ſuddenly in the ſnare as birds, they bee accuſed, condemned, caſt downe headlong, rent in peeces without reſcue, and conſtrained in anguiſh to weepe, waile, howle, wring their handes, and gnaſh with their teeth in torments intollerable. The children of God in the ſenſe of the ſame (for their ſinnes) haue approued theſe iudgements, as it well became them, for iuſt and righteous, and haue condemned themſelues of folly, as iuſtly deſeruing to be iudged:VVhat the godly do in the ſenſe of thoſe iudgements. Dauid. 1. Chro. 21.17. but ſo, as they haue in faith relied on the promiſes of God touching the remiſsion of ſinnes for the ſake of Chriſt vpon their repentance. When Dauid ſawe that the Lordes Angell executed the iudgement of God vpon his people for ſinne, hee confeſſed his owne faults, and acknowledged the vprightneſſe of Gods iudgements: therefore he ſayd, It is I, that haue ſinned and done euill in deede. Let thine hand (O Lorde my God) be on me, and on my fathers houſe: Manaſſes. but not on the people. And Manaſſes King of Iuda made this confeſſion, when he was captiued in Babylon: O Lord, I haue
ſinned, Ioſephs brethren. I haue ſinned, and do know mine iniquitie. Thus the brethren of Ioſeph calling to mind their owne vnnaturall crueltie towards him, ſaid one to another, being in Egypt:
Gen. 42.21.22. VVe haue verily ſinned againſt our brother, in that we ſaw the anguiſh of his Soule, when he beſought vs, and we would not heare him. And therefore is this trouble or iudgement come vppon vs. And Ruben ſaide: See, The Tirants haue beene forced to confeſſe the equitie of Gods iudgements. Adonibezek. Iudg. 1. now is his bloud required. The verie cruell tyrants alſo, which neither feared God, nor cared for man, are at length forced to confeſſe the vprightneſſe of Gods iudgements vpon themſelues: their owne conſciences condemning them. When Adonibezek was taken by the Iſraelites and had his thumbes and great toes cut off, hee ſaide, confeſſing the iuſt iudgement of God: Seuentie Kings hauing the thumbes of their hands and feete cut off, did eate vnder my table; as I haue done, ſo God hath rewarded mee. So Pharao the Egyptian tyrant,Pharao. when hee heard the mighty thunders as the voice of God in his land, he was afraide, confeſſed his ſinne, and granted the iuſtice of God: The Lord is righteous (ſaith he) but I and my people are wicked. Mauritius. And thus Mauritius the Emperour after his great Pride, diſdaine, crueltie againſt the Chriſtians, and other hainous ſinnes, being taken by wicked Phocas, and ſeeing his wife, his two ſonnes, and his three Daughters now murthered before his face, and himſelfe awayting the like lot, hee confeſſed his ſinnes vnto the Lord, and acknowledgeth the iuſtice of God, in theſe words (of the Pſalmiſt) Iuſtus es,
Pſal. 119.137. Domine, & rectum Iuditiumtuum. O Lord, thou art righteous, and iuſt is thy iudgement.

8 Therefore, although the men of this world in
their groſſe blindneſſe beyonde the darkeneſſe of Egypt, perceiue not iudgement:Prou. 28.5. and the ignorant and fooliſh conſider not whether there bee any contribution of pietie and impietie in this life, (wherein the Lord God ſuffereth his owne Children to bee euill entreated by tyrants,In this life there is a contribution of pietie and impietie. and to wander out of the way in the wilderneſſe) vntill they feele the verie iudgements of God vpō themſelues: yet (truely) all they that feare the Lord and ſeeke him, do vnderſtand all things:Prou. 28.5. they do wel perceiue and ſee how that Impietie is plagued either generally or particularly, ſecretly or openly, and ſometimes both waies, euē here in this life. And that pietie and godlines is wel rewarded in this life either generally or particularly, openly or ſecretly, as ſaith the wiſe man. Eccles. 8.13.14. I knowe that it ſhall be well with them that feare the Lord and do reuerence before him: but it ſhall not be well vnto the wicked: neither ſhall hee prolong his dayes: but he ſhall be like a ſhadow becauſe he feareth not the Lorde. Note this. And they do ſee and vnderſtand that the Lord will not ſo deferre to puniſh the vngodly when they doo ſinne againſt him, nor ſo referre things to the cenſure of his laſt generall iudgement, as that his particular and ſecret iudgements ſhall haue no force in this worlde: but that according to that ſaying of the wiſe: Pro. 11.31. The Righteous ſhall be recompenced on the Earth, how much more ſhall the wicked and the ſinner! Therefore, lette vs not ſay with thoſe mockers that walke after their owne luſts, and put farre the day of the Lord,2. Pet. 3.4.9. VVhere is the promiſe of his comming? For the Lord is not ſlacke concerning his promiſe, as ſome men count ſlackneſſe, but is patient toward vs, and would haue no man to periſh, but
would haue all men (of what nation or ſexe ſo euer they be) to come to repentance, to be ſaued. Neither let vs be bold vpon this,Not to preſume on Gods long ſufferāce therefore becauſe God ſuffereth a ſinner to do euill a thouſand times, hee liketh well of his dealing, and will alſo permit vs to ſinne without controlment: but let vs knowe, by the examples and teſtimonies of the holie Scriptures, and the daylie experiment of the power and wiſdome of God among men (which we may well obſerue) that God is able and will indeed) ſmite the vngodly in this world, and afterward hee will caſt them downe into hel.El. Schaddai. For he is that El. Schaddai, the moſt rich and ſufficient God: which contenteth his Saints with all good things, and giueth vnto the vngodly the iuſt rewarde of their ſinnes. Hee is that Pantocrator, the Omnipotent and Almightie God, whoſe power is according to his will, for the aduauncement of his children, and the abaſing of them that contemne him. Hee is Iehouah Elohim, El Kanna, as himſelfe ſayth: The Lord God, a iealous God, that viſiteth the ſinnes of the parents vpon their children, which walke in their vngodly wayes, vnto the third and fourth generation, and ſheweth mercie vnto thouſands in them that feare him, euen here in this life. Therefore hee hath iuſtly condemned and confounded from among the children of men, firſt ſecretly and particularly: then openly and generally, that enuious Cain, that ſhamleſſe Cham, that proude Nimrod, that bloudy Herod, that traiterous Iudas, that tyrannous Nero, that diuelliſh Iuliā, that hypocritical Annanias, that witch Simon, & in a word, that deſtroying Apolion, with all his peſtlent Polypragmones, to whom he giueth this heartie comfort: Now weepe and howle
for the miſerie which is come vpon you. Iam. 5. And on the other ſide, the ſame God through his great mercie in Chriſt the promiſed ſeed, doth pardon, preſerue, and glorifie his faithfull and righteous ſeruants, Abraham, Enoch, Iſaac, Iacob, Moſes, Ioſuah, and all other which haue apprehended the promiſe and beleeued in his ſonne. Theſe hath he made as his Garden, well locked and cloſe ſealed from all the annoyes of wilde beaſts, whoſe fruits are as a Paradice of Pomgranates, with all ſweete fruits and commodities. Theſe hath hee louingly inuited to his heauenly banquet, theſe he entertaineth at his bleſſed table, and there he doth moſt friendly and comfortably cheare them with theſe ſweete words: O yee friends, eate, drinke, and be merie, O ye beloued.
Cant. 4.12.13.

9. Now let it not ſeeme loathſome to the reader, that the tragicall Poet be heared, touching the contribution of pietie & impiety, vertue and vice, both in this life and afterward. And of the firſt thus writeth Seneca:

q.l: Nunquam Scygias fertur ad vmbras,Seneca. in traged. Hero cul. Act. 5.
Inclyta virtus, viuite fortes,
Nec Lethaeos ſaeua per amnes
Vos fata trahent: ſed cum ſummas
Exigit horas, conſumpta dies,
Iter ad Superos gloria pandet.

div.p: That is,

q.l: Reioyce all ye, that vertuous be,
for vertues neuer die:
Nor cruell death, that ſtops mens breath
ſhall blot you out: for why?
VVhen that laſt day ſhall take away
your life from mortall paine:
Then ſhall yee flie to loftie ſkie,
with glorious Saints to raigne.

div.p: Seneca. traiged. Octau. Act. 3. de. Nerone.In another place hee ſetteth forth the reward of Impietie, where hee bringeth in Agrippina, ſpeaking to Octauia the Empreſſe, touching the Emperour Nero, who had now compaſſed to depoſe and murther the ſaide Octauia his wife (quamuis nullo crimine) albeit hee found her guiltleſſe (as ſhe alſo ſaid) in theſe words.

q.l: The infernall furie in reuenge,
doth haſten to prouide:
For wicked Tyrant, worthy death,
ſharpe ſtripes, and flights: beſide,
Paines paſsing thirſt of Tantalus as the Poets feigne, that for offending the gods, he ſtandeth in water to the verie mouth, and yet cannot drinke. Tantalus,
and Siſyphus turneth a ſtone towards the top of the hill, which euer ſlideth backe againe. Siſyphus hard toyle:
The Darts that pearec'd lewd Titius is ſhot and pearced with an arrow for his filthie luſt. Tityus,
and Ixion, is tormented on a wheele in hel, for vnreuerent boaſting. Tibul. li. 10. Ixions wheele, to nouile.
Though hee his Pallace garniſht gay,
with Marble faire, and gold:
And armed ſouldiers guard his gate,
his glorious ſeate to hold, &c.
A time ſhall come, when he muſt yeeld
his life to ſhamefull fall:
His necke to foes, forſaken quite,
and wretched wanting all.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
VVee ought to confeſſe and ſubmit our ſelues to the power, mercie, and will of God: to eſchew contention, to retaine contentation, and to pray for ſtrength and opportunitie, to perfoome our duties.
div.p:
THat wee may therefore walke ſafely through the troubleſome Sea of this mortal life, it is right neceſſarie,The beſt way to walke in, without danger. that we acknowledge not only that god is, but alſo that God is moſt ſtrong, ſufficiēt, omnipotent, and euerlaſting, to whom onely, and that iuſtly, is aſcribed all power, all riches, all wiſedome, all ſtrength, all honour, all glorie, all praiſe. Next, it is neceſſarie that we beleeue and confeſſe, that the ſame God for the ſake of his ſonne, is good to Iſrael: that is, to vs his faithfull and elect children: in the ſenſe whereof, we are right worthily occaſioned to loue him with Abraham, Dauid, Iohn, Marie, and other his Saints, with all our heart, with all our ſoule, with all our mind, with all our ſtrength, & to ſing in good harmonie with thoſe heauenly ſouldiours 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Glorie be to God on high. Thirdly,Luke 2.14. it is neceſſarie that wee humbly ſubmit and yeeld our ſelues wholy to the power, will, and mercie of this our God, to permitte and ſuffer him moſt gladly to guide vs, to gouerne vs, and all our affaires, to deale for vs, to vſe vs and our miniſterie and labours in all things, and in all ſort, as it ſhall beſt pleaſe his heauenly grace at all times and ſeaſons: knowing right well, that hee will in mercie ſo prouide in
the diſpoſition of his graces towardes vs, that all things ſhall work tog • ther for our good, if we loue him, feare him, and depend on his mercy. And ſurely howſoeuer the maligne world ſhall iudge or imagine of the waies or workes of God we that are thus taught of God,The beſt wiſedome. do know moſt aſſuredly, that this is the beſt wiſdome in the world, to ſhrowde our ſelues vnder the wings of his prouidence and protection, againſt the fraile & chaungeable things of this vaine life, therein to reſt contented with that lot, which it ſhall pleaſe God to appoint for vs in the ſame: and to expect through faithfull hope, a a bleſſed ende of our loue and labour, euen in the middeſt of the horrible confuſions of this world, in the which no man liuing wanteth his croſſe: and through the which, the godlie take vp their croſſe and follow Chriſt, with patient minds, towards the goale of eternall life.

2 They that haue ſo learned this wiſdome that they vſe to make proofe thereof, liue not in loath of their owne ſtates and conditions of life, nor do they intrude on the vocations of others: they doo not affect the Seas, whoſe calling is, to liue on the land: but be well pleaſed with that lot and life, which the Lord hath called them vnto in his feare.The gratefull men of the golden age. 4. Eſd. 9.19▪ They in good ſort reſemble thoſe auntient gratefull men of the golden world, who being ſchooled by Iuſtice, and not acquainted with pernicious brawles, contentions, ſeditions, and thoſe common maladies of the copper age (as the Poets call it) did (vnder the rule of Iuſtice) liue contented with that which they had. Of them thus writeth Aratus:
Men ſimplie liu'd content, remou'd
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
&c. Aret ſolen. 63
from hurtes of raging Seas:
They brought not ſpoiles from far in ſhips,
but beſt themſelues did pleaſe.
VVith Oxen toyle, to till the ſoyle,
for worthie Iuſtice then,
Did miniſter aboundantlie,
to theſe right gratefull men.

And trulie, if we Engliſh men were ſo well learned in this wiſedome, as we ought to be, we would not groane for innouations,Indeed, the faults which be, are of the negligence and corruption of them that ſhould execute the Lawes, and not in the lawes which are prouided in our land. & the alteration of the religion, ſtate, gouernment, and lawes conſtituted, prouided and eſtabliſhed within this Realme. The which we cannot but acknowledge for good, godly and profitable in all equal cenſure & reaſon, howſoeuer it be, that fraile men through their imperfections and infirmities doo faile and offend in the due execution and right performance of the ſame. Neither is it meete, that the negligence, defects and offences of thoſe men ſhuld occaſiō the things which of themſelues are ſo good, honeſt, and profitable, to be condemned and contemned for naught and vngodlie: as neither the tranſgreſſions, negligences, ſinnes, defects and offences of men, againſt the diuine lawes of the Lord, ſhould cauſe them to be cō demned and reiected: for though there was neuer any man which yet fulfilled that lawe (Chriſt onely exceped) and the executioners thereof haue failed beyond all meaſure in that which of them was required, yet may we not ſay that the lawe of God is therfore imperfect, or vniuſt, ſeeing that the default
is not found in the lawe: but in them onely, that ſhould either obſerue the ſame, or puniſh the tranſgreſſours thereof after their deſerts.Solomon could not amend al faults in the commō wealth, a cauſe of his complaint Eccleſ. 3.16. and 4.1. And indeede heereof Salomon complained, but healpe it he could not, albeit he was the chief Magiſtrate ouer the cō mon-wealth of Iſrael: namely, that Impietie could not be fully corrected, nor all things which were a miſſe could be reformed and amēded by the Iudges. The Lawes were godlie, and officers were appointed to execute thē accordingly: howbeit, ſinne increaſed daylie, neither was there founde a ſufficient remedie againſt the ſame. Therefore, that onelie which might be done, he did: yt which was incurable, he was forced to leaue, & cōmit vnto the lord, to be corrected and amēded after his diuine wil, & not as a man would.

Good counſaile to be followed: Be content with the ſtate and ſeeke not an alteration.3 Wel then, let vs learne wiſedome of King Salomon in this point, let vs not deſire thraldome in the leath of our libertie, nor pull that miſerie on our heads againe through our owne murmure and diſcontentation, out of the which it hath pleaſed God (not of our deſerts, but of his mercie in Chriſt) to deliuer vs: but rather, let vs vſe our libertie in contentation, and obſerue thoſe good things, as the bleſſing of God with thankes-giuing, leaſt that through our diſcontentation and vnthankfulneſſe we be depriued of them, and brought into the bondage of Egipt again, where vnder the heauie hands of cruell taſke-maiſters, wee ſhall be conſtrained to ſighe and groane without any comfort or eaſe: that thereby, we may at length learn to know & diſcerne the right difference between the ſeruice of the Lord who in mercie ſaueth vs, & the thraldome of worldlie Tyrants, which ſeeke to captiue and deſtroy vs,
without all mercie or compaſsion. And this beeing ſpoken, I would gladly intreate the right Chriſtians, and true Subiects to the Lords Annointed (without all diſdaine) not onely to record, or at the leaſt, once againe to remember what things they haue eyther read or heard in this diſcource, and ſuch like bookes of inſtruction, admonitiō and cōfort: but alſo wold euery day before they ſleepe or take reſt, call their owne waies into remembrance, and duly examine their owne actions, their owne words,VVhat men ſhould euery day thinke on and performe their owne thoughts. In the which, if they haue doone well, and as it beſt became them, they may both reioyce, and continue therein with thankfulneſſe to ye Lord, that hath giuen them the abilitie and opportunitie ſuch things to effect: but if they haue faulted, tranſgreſſed, or neglected dutie therein, to the diſhonor of God, to the hurt of their neighbors, to their own diſcredit and ſhame, they may then be ſorie, repent, and endeuour without delay, to correct, amend and recompence that, wherein they haue faulted & offended. To this purpoſe,Pith. claud. Mino. in Alcuat. Emb. 17. I gladly remember (as we ſhould not refuſe that which is good) and that golden counſaile and wholſome inſtruction of Pithagoras to his ſcholers, conteyned in theſe verſes.

q.l: See, that thine heauie eyes, to ſleepe,
at night be not afourded:
Vntill the deedes of all that day,
three times, thou haſt recorded.Three very profitable queſtions for euery man to aſke of himſelfe.
VVhat haue I done, not as I ſhould?
Or what, which ſhould not bee?
Or, what neglected I, to day,
which well pertain'd to mee?

div.p: 4 But now, becauſe that (whiles we bee in this world) through our owne praue affections, and wicked imaginations, which wee haue brought with vs from the wombe of her that conceiued vs in ſinne (whereon the enemie of our Soules prayeth greedilie, and ſeeketh to drowne vs in deſtruction) we cannot doo that which is good, and that which the Lord requireth of vs: but that all our ſufficiency commeth to vs from the Lord God, who onely maketh Saincts of them which were conceiued in ſin and borne in vncleanneſſe▪ and maketh true Chriſtians of them which were ſometimes as ſheepe going aſtray, by the vertue of his ſpirit, regenerating them in the bloude of his Sonne our Sauiour, in whoſe name onely hee willeth vs to call and come vnto him in all our afflictions: it is both good and neceſſarie that we inuocate his holy name, Inuocation and prayer neceſſarie for all men. and pray vnto him (through our Mediatour Chriſt) that hee will vouchſafe to graunt and giue vnto vs, all thoſe healps (in the performance of our duties) which by nature we cannot haue. This is an exerciſe which the Lord himſelfe commanded, which Chriſt & his Apoſtles and Martyrs haue vſed and commended vnto vs, and which hath many firme promiſes of conſolation and ioyfull effectes in the word of God.

This is that, which is a ſacrifice to God, and to him a pleaſure. A plague to the diuell, and to him a paine. An healpe to man, and to him a comfort. This is that, which is a preſeruatiue againſt all tēptations: a comfortatiue to confirme our heartes: an inkindling of our zeale to godlineſſe: a rauiſhing of our minds with the loue of celeſtiall things. This
is a defence for vs againſt them that ſeeke to ſeduce vs: a ſtay for our faith: a way to come by that which we want: a keye to open the locke that ſhutteth vp euery good bleſſing: this is the vp ſhotte of that complete Armour of proofe, wherewith the Apoſtle would, that the right Chriſtian ſouldiour (and ſo the prophet proteſtant) ſhould be furniſhed. Epheſ. 6.18. Therefore, al ye that be fathers, traine vp your children in this holie exerciſe: ye that bee maiſters, doo the like vnto your ſeruants. All ye that be Chriſtians (of what eſtate, condition or degree ſoeuer ye bee) be ye occupied in this ſeruice.

5. There ſhould no place keepe you from this ſeruice of God: there ſhould be no ſocieties,The place of prayer. Pſal. 50.15. Baruc. 6.5. nor companies, that ſhould hinder you (for not onelie in word, but alſo in a godlie wel-wiſhing prayeth the godlie, and their ſighes, groanes and thoughts are heard vnto the Lord well inough) whether we be in the temple with Hanna, or in the houſe with Cornelius, or on the toppe of the houſe with Peter, or in the denne with Daniell, or in the dungeon with Ieremie, or in the ſea with Ionas, or in the place of execution with Stephan, or in the garden with Chriſt, or in the way with Abrahams ſeruant, either priuately alone, or publiquelie with others, lette vs not omitte this holy worke: for this is good and acceptable to the Lord: ſo it be done in faith. And as we muſt bee thus exerciſed euery where, ſo alſo at all time and times, both night and day, with that bleſſed man, Pſal. 1.2. not onely in aduerſitie, when we haue ſorrow, neede ſickneſſe, affliction, trouble and miſerie:The time, 1 Tim. 28. but alſo in proſperitie, whē we be in health, wealth, ſafetie, peace, hearts-eaſe and felicitie. Not onely in
age when we ſhalbe creeping towardes the graue,In age. and poaſting to our long-home, and ſo moued to record our wretched peregrinatiō through this vale of miſerie in wofulneſſe: but alſo in youth and luſtie age,In youth. when we haue yet the flowers of our life greene and cheerefull in our hands, and are crowned with roſe-buddes and freſh garlandes on our heads, whatſoeuer our eſtate and condition bee in this world. This is the meaning of Salomon where he ſaith:Eccles. 12.1. Epheſ 6.
Remember thy maker in the daies of thy youth: and th' entent of Paule, when he biddeth vs to pray alwaies.

VVhat we ſhould aſke.6 When it ſhall pleaſe God to exerciſe vs with trouble and affliction, let vs pray vnto him, that in patience we may be able to wade through the tediouſneſſe therof, without fainting. Againe, in proſperitie and peace, let vs pray, that we grow not ſecure, and forget our maker, and that we looſe not all that, by flattering proſperitie, which hard aduerſitie is not able to take frō vs, for ye aduerſarie of our ſoules, dealeth ſubtilly and ſuggeſteth mightilie: he dooth moue them to murmure,The ſubtiltie of Satan. whom the lord afflicteth: and he tempteth them with preſumptiō, whom the Lord enricheth with benifits. Thus did he aſſault Noah with drunkenneſſe,Noah. whome the great deluge could not drowne,Loth. and inflamed Loth, with the luſt of inceſt, whom the ſier of Sodome could not burne. And in this time, the number of them is not ſmall. that though when they ſuſteine trouble by ſea or by land, promiſe many things to bee performed vppon their deliuerie, do notwithſtanding that, when they arriue into the hauen of reſt & tranquility, forget al, and make ſhipwracke of greater treaſures then the
wealth of this world. Moreouer, whē we be yong, let vs pray, that our youth deceiue vs not: & when we bee olde, that our elder yeares make vs not to murmour againſt God, and ſo bee vnreadie to doo our dutie: for as Sathan is ſubtill, ſo letteth hee not to ſearch the inclination and diſpoſition of euerie man. If men be inclined to pleaſures, with pleaſures will he adulate them: if men be likely to be daunted with aduerſitie,How Sathan dealeth. then in aduerſitie will hee prooue them. If men be diſpoſed to preſumption, he will tempt them to preſume. If they be weake and fearefull, with feare and deſperation he will endeuour to deſtroy them. If they be niclined to couetouſneſſe, then with couetous deſires will he tempt them: if to malice, then with malice: if to wrath, then with wrath: if to pride, then with pride, and ſo forth, vnto all the which motions the fleſh is ſubiect, & the enemy is ſtrōg to allure the minds of mē: inſomuch, that without faithfull praier, the good motions of the ſpirit wil be ſuppreſſed in them. Therefore let vs pray in the ſpirit, and pray with vnderſtanding at all times, in all places, and ſo ſhall we expell him that is ready to harbor in our hearts to hurt our ſoules.

7 Leete vs pray vnto God for the ſafetie,For whome we muſt pray. health and proſperitie of our moſt gracious and ſoueraigne Princeſſe, and for the wealth of all them that bee put in authoritie vnder her as the Apoſtle exhorteth) that wee may leade a quiet and a peaceable life in all godlineſſe and honeſtie: for that is good and exceptable in the ſight of God our Sauiour. Let vs alſo pray for the peace & godly proceedings of the Paſtours, and all the true profeſſours of Gods holy word: that vtteraunce may bee
giuen vnto them, that they may open their mouthes freelie to vtter the ſecrets of the Goſpel, that therin they may ſpeake freelie as they ought to ſpeake. Let vs pray & make interceſſion and giue thanks for all ſaincts, and for all men. Let vs pray for our ſelues, that wee may not be lead into temptation, but may be deliuered from that euill (I meane the diuell) that our faith fayle vs not:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : That is, from the diuell. Mat. 6.13. and 13.19. but that it may bee increaſed, confirmed, fructified and fortified: that we beleeuing in Chriſt, may not be ouercome, but get the victorie, and be accounted worthie to eſcape al thoſe things that ſhall come, and may ſtand in great conſtancie before the ſonne of man.

Then moſt aſſuredly the Lord our God (for the loue and merite of his Sonne) who hath both commaunded vs, and taught vs to pray, and promiſed to graunt the requeſts of his Saints (being vnto him as moſt ſweete Odours powred out of golden vialles) will graunt vs for,Apoc. 5.8. and towardes the performaunce of that which he requireth, his holy Spirit, the Spirite of wiſdome and vnderſtanding: the Spirit of Counſaile and ſtrength: the Spirit of knowledge, and of the feare of God: to our exceeding great Conſolation and Contentation in this World: and after this painefull Peregrination, when the happie day of Refreſhing commeth, at the ioyfull reſurrection of the Righteous, we ſhall bee contented with that eternall Societie and Sacietie of the Sonne of God our Sauiour, and higheſt Contentation.

The Epiphonêma and vſe of this Preparatiue.8 Lo! Theſe bee the ſoueraigne Simples wherof being thus collected and compounded, I haue confected this Preparatiue to Contentation. I doubt not, but that (by the good grace of God, the vertue
thereof being well applied,This Preparatiue is to be applied. will ſomewhat allaie and abate the inſolencie and courage of thoſe diſcontented perſons, who (in their madde moods and ſtrange conceits and opinions) do yet ſtay without the doore of the houſe,1 To the diſcontented perſon Luk. 15.25. with that angry Elder Brother of whome Chriſt hath ſpoken in the Goſpell, and haue not bene willing, nor would be perſwaded to enter into the houſe of ioy and contentation, with the yonger Brother: but rather prepare themſelues in high diſpleaſure to fight againſt the Lord, againſt the Lords annointed, and againſt all charitable Chriſtians, as profeſſed enemies to all peace and Contentation.

Secondly, I truſt in the Lord God,2 To the true chriſtian proteſtant that the right Chriſtian Proteſtant, which contemneth the lewde world, and is ſtraunge in the Lord, and in the power of his might, will imbrace and apply this Preparatiue, whereby the ſooner he may be comforted, ſtrengthened, inſtructed and encouraged to ſtand faſt, to proceed well and proſper in his holy faith and profeſsion againſt the diuel, and againſt the bitter taunts and wicked practiſes of Sathans ieaſting fooles: I meane the vngodly deryders of religion, and contemners of holy diſcipline.

Thirdly, I perſwade,3 To the true ſubiect. that all the true hearted ſubiects will be the readier by the operation of this confection, to imbrace brotherly fellowſhip, to feare God and honour the Prince. Finally,4 To euerie Chriſtian. that euery true Chriſtian (in his ſeuerall vocation and place) will hereby alſo the ſooner be moued to walk on wiſely, honeſtly, and worthily in the way of the Lord, towards that chiefe Good, and higheſt happineſſe, where the Lord Ieſus liueth and raigneth for euer with God the Father,
and God the Holy Ghoſt, in perfect Contentation.
To the which three perſons and one moſt mightie God Iehouah, be worthily aſcribed, all bleſsing, all glorie, all wiſedome, all thanks, all honor, all power, and all Contentation for euermore. Amen.

q.p: God perſwade, or allure Iapheth, that he may dwell in the Tentes of Shem: and let Canaan be his ſeruant.

div.head: A Chriſtian Confeſsion and Prayer, for Contentation.
div.p: O Lord God of hoaſts, Creator, protector and preſeruer of mankinde, which loueſt Righteouſneſſe, and hateſt iniquitie: we doo heere acknowledge and confeſſe before thee, and before the face of al thine holy Angels, that (notwithſtanding thy manifold bounties, benefites and bleſsings powred foorth on vs) we haue greeuouſly ſinned againſt heauen and before thy Maieſtie: wherin we haue both declared our horrible ingratitude towards thee, and right worthily deſerued to be ſhut out from thy preſence, and to receiue and feele all thoſe troubles, vexations, plagues, and miſeries, wherewith for ſinne thou art wont in thy iuſtice to paine, vexe, and torment the children of men: and that were it not of thine owne good loue and endleſſe mercies (in the merite of thy Sonne Ieſus our Sauiour) in could not the, but that (according to our deſerts (we ſhuld ſuddeinly periſh, & be caſt away for euer. For (alas) vnto vs, and vnto euery one of vs belongeth nothing elſe, but wrath, ſhame, and deſtruction.

Howbeit, ſeeing that it belongeth not only to thy Iuſtice to puniſh ſinners: but alſo to thy mercie, to pardon them that repent and turne vnto thee: and that thou art the ſame God which taketh no pleſure in the death of a ſinner, but rather wouldeſt that he
ſhould conuert and liue, and to that ende haſt both called, excited and prouoked vs, to beleeue in thee, to come vnto thee, to pray vnto thee, to repent, and to hope for pardon in thee. We be heartely ſorie (O Lord) for all our miſdeeds, and in all humilitie doo caſt our ſelues downe vnder thy footeſtoole, yet ſo, as in the name of thine holy Sonne Ieſus (in whom we beleeue, and on whom we depend) we hope to finde grace. Let it be thy good pleaſure therefore (moſt gratious God) to accept vs cloathed in the white garment of his innocencie and righteouſnes, for we haue no cloathes of our owne to couer our naked bodies and ſinfull Soules, and to ſhrowde vs from the ſtormes of thy fearce wrath, againſt the which, all the wiſedome, righteouſneſſe, holineſſe, power and pollicie of man, ſhall be but as thoſe fig leaues wherewith Adam couered himſelfe when he had ſinned. We beſeech thee to behold vs in thy Sonne our Sauior, to conſider our miſeries, to think vpon vs for the beſt, to conuert vs, that we may be conuerted: to forgiue vs all our ſinnes, the cauſes of all our miſeries, and to receiue vs gratiouſly. Then (as we be moſt bounden) we wil offer vp vnto thee the Calues of our lippes we will take the Cup of Saluation, and cal vpō thy name: we wil yeeld thee the ſacrifice of Righteouſneſſe, and put our truſt in thy mercy: we will glorifie thee in thy Sonne. O moſt mercifull God, take away from amongeſt vs, all thoſe vnhappie opinions, Sectes, Seditions, Sciſmes, vaine queſtions, idle diſputations, genealogies and ſtrifes about words: and all wicked Contentions and thriftleſſe Diſcontentations, which ſpringing vp of mans pride, ambition & malice, ſo much
diſquiet the tranquilitie of the Church, and diſturbe the peace of thy people: and in ſteed thereof, confirme in our hearts the truth of thy Sonne, Chriſtian Faith, Humilitie, Charitie, and the peerleſſe Peace of his Goſpel: that therof we may take delight: that therein we may meditate continually: that thereby we may edifie & prouoke one another in thy feare, with good Contentation. O Lord, ſaue and deliuer vs from that wofull and deadfull Woe, vnto the which the inhabitors of the Earth and of the Sea, are (by a iuſt decree) ſubdued, through their wilful vngodlines and preſumptuous ſinnes, prouoked by the horrible rage of that diuell, which is come downe vnto them with ſo much the greater furie, by how much the nearer he draweth in his diſsipation and end. Graunt alſo (O good Father) that though this laſt attempt of the enemie be fearcer then the former, by the which, he now aſſayeth to touch thine Annointed, to harme thy Prophets, to quench out the light of Iſrael, and to deface the glory of thy Sonne Ieſus: yet, that the fall and deſtruction of this deadly enemie, and of all his miſchieuous miſcreants, may ſoone and ſodeinly ouertake both him & them to their endleſſe woe and diſcontentation. But that (on the other ſide) thy Grace and Mercy may ſhine towards thy faithfull hand-mayden Elizabeth, our moſt excellent Princeſſe, and to all vs her Graces obedient ſubiects, and thy deare children, that thereby both her Princely Maieſtie, which feareth thee, and alſo we which honor thee, and which to her Highneſſe be obedient, may ſo poſſeſſe our ſoules in the middeſt of the troubles of this wretched life, and ſo wholie dedicated to ſerue
thee, in trembling and feare, that we may reſt vnder the ſhadow of thy wings, to the praiſe of thy moſt holy Name, to the ſweet comfort of our ſoules, and to our higheſt Contentation, in Ieſu Chriſt thy Sonne our Sauior, Amen.

div.head: A Chriſtian Memorandum for all perſons, that they order and content themſelues, in their ſenerall vocations and places.

lg.l: YE Noble Princes which do raigne
as goddes, by Gods good grace:
Be wiſe: with Right and Equitie,
Ye Pastors, watch, feed wel your flocks,
and faint not for the paine:
In holy life, and doctrine true,
Ye Lawiers, that mens rights defend,
deale truth in lites of lawe:
Regard mans life, before your gainer,
That ſalues ye frame right to the ſores,
Ye valiant Captaines with your bands,
Diſtribute them the law full pay,
Ye common Souldiers, ſee to this,
Ye Swaines, your wayns with Oxe direct
Ye Saylers, rightly raunge the Seas,
and nought but truth dye tell.
That to your Crafts and manuall Arts.
Ye Subiects all, obey your Prince,
Ye Neighbours eke, be brethren like,
Ye Husbands loue your wiues, and them
Ye VViues be ſubiect, and obey
Ye Fathers, nourtour well your ſonnes,
and that ſhall be your gaine.
Ye Maiſters, to your ſeruants yeeld
Ye Seruants, ſerue your maiſters with
Proteſt the Truth, and ſtriue t'attaine
Ye Christians all, learne ye of Chriſt
to ſerue the Lord: and frame
For God his Creatures at the firſt
For man, the not t'abuſe, but t'vſe
And with the ſame, to euery one,
A due vocation in this world,
he would, that men ſhould liue,
In ſumme, feare God, obſerue his lawes,
For lo, this is that totall ſumme,
Which done, thou ſhall account in fine,
When thou ſhalt find Eternall Ioies,
O Father grant this of thy grace,
All our defects: O holy Spirit
Keepe well thy Church ſo deerely bought,
Preſerue the Realme, and graunt (good Lord)
thy peace that we may haue, Amen.
